Slide 4: History of Present Illness ----------- The pain is described as ""tearing"" and radiates to the back. He also reports feeling lightheaded and short of breath. No associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. No prior episodes of similar symptoms.  Slide 5: Past Medical History ----------- Notable History: - Chronic Hypertension for the past 15 years  managed by medication. - Smoking history of 20 pack-years. He quit smoking 10 years ago. - No history of hypercholesterolemia  diabetes mellitus  or previous cardiovascular disease.  Literature suggests that hypertension and smoking are major risk factors for aortic dissection.  Slide 6: Physical Examination  ----------- On Physical examination  J.S. appears distressed from pain. Vital signs reveal hypertension. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm without murmurs. There are no significant findings on pulmonary  abdomen and extremity examination.   Slide 7: Differential Diagnosis ----------- At this time  the differential diagnosis includes acute coronary syndrome  pulmonary embolism  and aortic dissection.  Slide 8: Radiological Findings  ----------- Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) of the chest was ordered and revealed an aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the descending aorta.   Slide 9: Final Diagnosis  ----------- Aortic Dissection  Slide 10: Management and Outcome ----------- The patient was immediately started on intravenous medication for blood pressure control and referred to cardiothoracic surgery for further evaluation.   Slide 11: Discussion ----------- Despite being a relatively rare condition  aortic dissection is often deadly  especially without prompt diagnosis and treatment. It should always be considered as a diagnostic possibility in patients with chest pain  particularly those with a history of systemic hypertension.

Title: Case Presentation: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Hypertensive Male  Patient Identification: Mr. A  a 57-year-old African American male.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with sudden onset severe tearing or ripping chest pain that radiates to the back.  History of Present Illness: The patient started experiencing pain early this morning  which heightened over the past few hours. The pain  originally localized to the chest  is now radiating to his back. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the chest. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and nausea. The patient reports no alleviating or aggravating factors to the pain. He hasn't experienced similar symptoms in the past.  Past Medical History: Mr. A has a ten-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and he is a former smoker. No history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  or any respiratory diseases. No familial incidence of aortic diseases or aneurysms.  Social History: Mr. A is an electrician by trade. He stopped smoking two years ago but admits occasional alcohol use. He is married with three children  and lives with his wife and the youngest child.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient exhibited signs of distress and was diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg in the right arm and 160/90 mmHg in the left. The heart sounds were heard clearly with no murmur  but there was an apparent difference between the pulses in both arms.   Impression: Given the patient's history  the physical examination  and the extreme  sudden  tearing chest pain that radiates to the back  I suspect an acute aortic dissection. This is further affirmed by the patient's long-standing uncontrolled hypertension  which is known to predispose to the condition. I recommend immediate hospitalization and diagnostic imaging of the aorta with either a CT scan or MRI  followed by appropriate surgical or endovascular interventions as indicated.  Patient Education: Mr. A needs to be aware of the seriousness of his condition and the risks involved. He should also be educated about the importance of routine follow-ups and blood pressure management.   Disclaimer: The above case presentation is standard and does not apply to all individuals  as aortic dissection can present differently in each patient. The information here represents the demographic most likely to present with aortic dissection  according to existing literature and research.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 Years Old Sex: Male Race: African-American   Mr. John is an African-American male  aged 65 years  presently experiencing sudden severe chest pain  described as tearing  ripping  or shearing. The pain started in the anterior part of the chest and is now radiating to the back. In addition to this  he is experiencing shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Mr. John has a history of hypertension for the last 15 years  which has been managed with medication. Unfortunately  he has poor adherence to his blood pressure controlling treatment regimen. Mr. John was previously a smoker but quit 5 years back. He is also a known case of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  diagnosed 10 years ago and managed with medication and lifestyle modification. Family history reveals that his father died of an aortic aneurysm at an age similar to Mr. John's current age.  Epidemiological studies show that aortic dissection is more common in males  particularly amongst those of African American descent. The peak incidence is in the 7th decade of life. Hypertension and smoking are major risk factors for the development of aortic dissection. Also  a family history of aortic aneurysm puts him in a high-risk group for aortic dissection. To confirm the diagnosis  relevant radiographic studies including a CT angiogram of the Thorax will be conducted.  This prompt discussion is one of relevance given that Mr. John's current presentation and past medical history suggest a possible aortic dissection  a condition which warrants immediate medical attention to avoid severe complications or even fatality.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 60-year-old Caucasian Male  Introduction: The patient in focus is Mr. John Albury  a 60-year-old Caucasian male of American nationality. He presently lives alone in Manhattan  New York  being a retired accountant. He was brought in to the Emergency Department complaining of severe sharp chest pain spreading to his back. The highlight of his case is a past medical history significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 30-year history of smoking  which are risk factors for cardiovascular pathology.  Detailed Patient History: Mr. Albury had been under regular medications for hypertension (metoprolol) and hypercholesterolemia (atorvastatin). Despite numerous recommendations from his primary care physician  he continued to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily. He has no history of diabetes  kidney disease  or any known drug allergies.  Present Complaint: The onset of the current severe chest pain occurred while he was sitting on his recliner watching television. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation  starting from his chest and radiating to his back. His discomfort was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin that he had previously been prescribed for his atypical chest pain.  Observation: On initial assessment  Mr. Albury looked apprehensive and pale. His blood pressure was elevated. A noticeable difference between the blood pressures in his right and left arms was observed  indicating possible aortic dissection. His pulse was noticeably irregular  and he showed signs of initial shock.  Conclusion: Given his demographics  including his age  gender  and Caucasian ethnicity  as well as his history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking  Mr. Albury aligns with a typical high-risk profile for aortic dissection. Literature states that aortic dissection is most common in males and usually occurs in the sixth and seventh decades of life  with a higher prevalence in Caucasians. Hypertension and smoking significantly enhance the risk of developing this condition.  Moving forward  immediate diagnostic imaging  such as a CT angiogram  is recommended to confirm the diagnosis. Prompt medical or surgical intervention should be initiated upon confirmation.

Title: A Case of Aortic Dissection in Elderly Male Patient  Patient Overview:   The patient is a 70-year-old African-American male presenting with severe chest discomfort. He is tall and has a thin built. He does not smoke and maintains a low-sodium  low-fat diet. He has a regular exercise routine but has complaints of sudden episodic pain in the chest area  which he described as ""tearing"" or ""ripping""  radiating to his back.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a chronic history of hypertension which was diagnosed 20 years back. His blood pressure is not well controlled  which is one of the leading risk factors for aortic dissection. He has been on anti-hypertensive drugs  which is primarily a combination of ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers.   In addition to this  he has a familial history of connective tissue disorder  Marfan's Syndrome. Six-years ago  the patient was diagnosed with a mild form of Marfan Syndrome  characterized by a high-arched palate  tall stature  and an enlarged aortic root.  The patient has no history of any coronary artery disease  diabetes  or any other significant illnesses. He's had no surgeries or hospitalizations in the past. In his family history  it appears that his father died of aortic aneurysm at the age of 74.  Based on patient's age  ethnicity  and previous cardiovascular history  the suspicion of an aortic dissection is high. Literature suggests that males  especially African-Americans  of ages 60 to 80 are at an increased risk. Chronic hypertension  a high prevalence in African-American populations  is a significant risk factor  along with underlying genetic conditions like Marfan's Syndrome. Further confirmatory diagnostics like a CT scan will be carried out.

Title: Presentation of Aortic Dissection   Patient Identification: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male named Mr. Washington. He resides in Detroit  Michigan and lives an active lifestyle through jogging and swimming. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with both his father and grandfather suffering from the same.  Past Medical History: Mr. Washington was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  which has been somewhat controlled with lifestyle changes and medication. He has also had occasional high cholesterol levels and undergoes yearly tests for the same. Apart from these ailments  Mr. Washington has never had any significant surgeries or severe illnesses and has been generally considered a physically fit and healthy man.  Presenting Issue: Mr. Washington presented himself to the emergency department today with acute chest pain  describing the pain as ""tearing"" and as the most severe he has ever experienced. The pain appeared to radiate to his back between the shoulder blades and was accompanied by bouts of breathlessness. He noted that his pain started suddenly without any warning while he was out jogging.  Given his demographic profile and his description of his symptoms  a quick examination and a CT Scan was ordered. The radiology report confirmed the worst fears: a type A aortic dissection.  Studies show that African American men are one of the groups with the highest rates of hypertension  which is a risk factor for aortic dissection. Men are more likely than women to experience aortic dissection  and it most commonly occurs in people over 60 years old. This demographic information aligns with Mr. Washington's case.  It's also significant to note that this patient's lifestyle and habitual physical activities may have contributed to the condition  even if indirectly. Blunt chest trauma can result from vigorous and repetitive exercises  and can potentially initiate an aortic dissection  especially in those with a genetic predisposition.  Summary: Mr. Washington's case demonstrates that despite leading an active and seemingly healthier lifestyle  the risk of a severe cardiovascular event can remain high due to chronic conditions like hypertension and the presence of a family history of heart problems. Thus  underlining the importance of routine clinical assessments and vigilant monitoring of common cardiovascular risk factors in high-risk groups.

Patient Presentation  I am presenting a 67-year-old African-American male patient  identified as Mr. B. Mr. B is a retired truck driver  originally from Georgia. He came to our Emergency Department presenting with a sudden  severe pain in the middle and upper parts of his chest  radiating to his back. He described the pain as ""tearing"" in nature. He mentioned that the pain was not related to his activities or meals.   Mr. B has a significant past medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels  both of which have been relatively well managed for the past 15 years with antihypertensive medication (Losartan Potassium) and a statin (Atorvastatin)  respectively. Additionally  he also has a history of tobacco use  with a 30 pack/year history but quit smoking 10 years ago. There is no known history of diabetes  or any familial cardiac issues.   In terms of lifestyle  Mr. B confesses to have a sedentary lifestyle  with poor dietary habits inclusive of high sodium and high cholesterol food items. His Body Mass Index (BMI) of 29.1 suggests obesity. He denies any intake of illicit drugs or excessive alcohol. Mr. B has no known drug allergies.  Considering the present symptoms and past medical history  the possibility of aortic dissection was considered  taking into account his age  race  male gender  and chronic hypertension  which are recognized high-risk factors for aortic dissection according to literature. A further diagnostic process with a CT scan was initiated to confirm the diagnosis.  In conclusion  Mr. B is a representative case for aortic dissection considering his demographic details and relevant risk factors. The patient's history and initial presentation are consistent with typical presentations for aortic dissection. Therefore this case exemplifies the importance of immediate recognition and treatment for such a life-threatening condition.

“Good afternoon  I will be presenting Mr. Jose Santoro  a 63-year-old Hispanic male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension  current smoker  and a past medical history of coronary artery disease with stent placement two years ago. He is obese with a BMI of 31 and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to desk-bound work.  Mr. Santoro arrived at the emergency department earlier today with severe  sudden onset of chest pain which he described as 'tearing' and 'ripping.' The pain is in the anterior region of the chest and radiates to his back. Accompanying symptoms include diaphoresis and difficulty breathing  but no associated nausea  vomiting  or dizziness was reported.   He recalls feeling unwell for the past few weeks  with occasional bouts of dizziness and fainting episodes  but he attributed these to work-related stress and did not seek medical attention.  On examination  we found his blood pressure reading to be significantly higher on his right arm compared to his left. His pulses were also diminished in his lower limbs suggesting vascular insufficiency. This wide pulse pressure differential is suggestive of a possible aortic pathology such as aortic dissection which is further supported by his presenting symptoms.   Given Mr. Santoro's high-risk profile- uncontrolled hypertension  smoking  coronary artery disease  and obesity- he has multiple risk factors that predispose him to aortic dissection. Among these  hypertension is especially significant as it accounts for approximately 75% of cases  while smoking  which is also quite prevalent in his population demographic  has been associated with not only dissection but also other atherosclerotic diseases.”  Therefore  immediate diagnostic imaging such as CT angiography or transesophageal echocardiogram is warranted to confirm diagnosis and guide treatment plans.

Title: Presentation of Aortic Dissection   Demographics:  Patient is a 65-year-old African American male residing in a suburban neighborhood.   According to the literature  aortic dissection is more common among males and the risk increases with age (Crawford  2019). African American population is reported to have a higher incidence of aortic dissection (Howard et al.  2013).   Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain is described as tearing or ripping in nature.  Past Medical History: Notably  our patient has a history of hypertension  which is the most common risk factor for aortic dissection (Crawford  2019). He is also diagnosed with Buerger's disease - a rare disease of arteries and veins in the arms and legs  which might have contributed to the overall vascular health decline. The patient has been a smoker for the past 40 years. No history of surgery or trauma.  Clinical Overview: On examination  there was a difference in blood pressure between the right and left arms. Heart sounds were normal and there was no murmur. Distal pulses were decreased. These findings raised the suspicion of aortic dissection.   Considering the demographics  risk factors  clinical history and presentation  the patient was diagnosed with an aortic dissection and further confirmed through imaging modalities.  References: Crawford  T. C. (2019). Aortic dissection. Cleveland Clinic: Cardiovascular Diagnosis & Therapy  1-15.  Howard  V. J.  Kleindorfer  D. O.  Judd  S. E.  McClure  L. A.  Safford  M. M.  Rhodes  J. D.  ... & Howard  G. (2013). Disparities in stroke incidence contributing to disparities in stroke mortality. Annals of neurology  73(4)  619-627.

Title: A Case Presentation on Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 66 years Sex: Male Race: White Occupation: Retired construction worker   Presenting Problem:  Mr. Johnson presents to the emergency room with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back  particularly between his shoulder blades. He states the pain started when he was at rest and describes it as a tearing sensation. His vitals at arrival indicate a high blood pressure of 164/95mmHg with a pulse of 110 beats per minute. He appears to be in considerable distress.  Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of uncontrolled hypertension. He was diagnosed 15 years ago and has been inconsistent with his antihypertensive medication due to financial constraints. Seven years ago  he was a heavy smoker  consuming about a pack a day but he quit smoking when he was diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is also positive for hyperlipidemia. There is no family history of heart disease or aortic dissection.  Overview:  Aortic dissection is a potentially fatal condition predominantly affecting males more frequently than females  with the highest incidence occurring in 65-75 years old individuals. Mr. Johnson's age  gender  and history of long-term uncontrolled hypertension and smoking are potential contributing factors to his current clinical presentation. The severe chest pain he is experiencing  often described as tearing or ripping  is commonly associated with aortic dissection. His high blood pressure is also indicative of the potential for an aortic event  possibly due to increased stress on the vessel walls.  Initial Assessment:  Given Mr. Johnson’s presentation  a high clinical suspicion for aortic dissection is warranted. Immediate diagnostic investigations like transesophageal echocardiogram  CT angiography or MRI angiography will be ordered to confirm the diagnosis. A multidisciplinary team approach involving cardiology  radiology  and cardiothoracic surgery should be mobilized due to the potential complexity and acuity of his care needs.

Slide 1: Introduction  We present the case of a 67-year-old Caucasian male suffering from an aortic dissection. This demographic is consistent with the literature indicating that aortic dissection is more common in men  of older age  and often in the white population.  Slide 2: Demographics & Personal History  Our patient is a recently retired accountant  a father of three adult children  practicing regular exercise and has a history of smoking  but quit 20 years ago. With regard to lifestyle  he follows a diet high in sodium and fat.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  In line with relevant literature  our patient has a notable past medical history which includes a long-term history of hypertension  a major risk factor for aortic dissection. He also has a history of high cholesterol  which he has been managing with prescribed statins for over a decade. He has no history of diabetes nor any genetic diseases.  Slide 4: Recent Health Concerns  Over the last few months  our patient reported of experiencing intermittent chest pain  initially thought to be due to heartburn or indigestion. This has progressively worsened over time and  more recently  the patient experienced an abrupt onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back.   Slide 5: Presentation & Symptoms  The patient presented to us today with symptoms of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  pulse discrepancy and symptoms suggestive of cardiovascular collapse (fainting).   Slide 6: Summary  We have thus outlined the profile of a typical patient presenting with an aortic dissection  while highlighting the importance of considering this condition in patients with similar demographic and medical history. Accurate diagnostic tests and immediate medical intervention shall be pursued to improve patient's outcomes.

Presentation Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in an Older Adult Population  I. Introduction   Good morning/afternoon/evening. Today  I am presenting a case of acute Aortic Dissection (AD). This condition  though rare  holds significant clinical importance due to its high mortality rate when left untreated. We'll look at the conventional presentation  diagnostics  and management strategies.  II. Case Presentation  Our patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in a suburban area in the Mid-Western region of the United States. This demographic is chosen based on research  indicating that most AD patients are men in their 60s to 70s. Additionally  aortic dissections are more prevalent in Caucasians than in other racial and ethnic groups.  III. Past Medical History  The patient has a significant medical history of hypertension for the past 20 years. There is a documented history of tobacco use  with the patient self-reporting 35 pack-years of smoking. He has experienced prior cardiovascular events including a myocardial infarction approximately three years ago  and also reports a family history of cardiovascular disease. His medications include amlodipine  metoprolol  and aspirin. He hasn’t previously had any surgical interventions.  IV. Presenting Complaints  The patient presented to the emergency department with an abrupt onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back  predominantly between the shoulder blades. Additionally  he mentions experiencing shortness of breath.   V. Physical Examination  On examination  the patient appeared acutely distressed with visible diaphoresis. Notably  there was a difference in blood pressure readings between both arms. Heart sounds were normal with no murmurs  and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   VI. Diagnosis   Considering the clinical history and presentation  the preliminary diagnosis is Acute Aortic Dissection. Further imminent examination and imaging studies  such as a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the thorax and echocardiography  were done to confirm the diagnosis.    VII. Conclusion   This case presentation underscores the need for a prompt diagnosis of aortic dissection  considering the severity of the underlying pathology. Early recognition is key to managing patients and as clinicians  we must maintain a high index of suspicion  especially when treating older adults presenting with sudden severe chest or back pain.  Thank you for your attention. Any questions are welcome.

Title: Presentation of a Case of Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:  Mr. Joseph Brown  a 65-year-old African-American male  retired plumber who lives with his wife in an urban neighborhood  presents to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Brown reports severe and sudden chest pain which he describes as ""a tearing sensation"" that started about 2 hours ago while watching T.V. at home.  Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of hypertension being managed with antihypertensive drugs for the past 10 years. He also had a smoking history of about 20 pack years and quit smoking 5 years ago. He has no known allergies.  Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure shows a significant difference between the right and left upper extremities. His heart rate is elevated with a slightly reduced pulse pressure and the breath sounds reduced on the left side. His BMI is 29  indicating he is overweight.  Pathophysiology:  In Mr. Brown's case  uncontrolled hypertension seems to be the primary predisposing factor for the development of aortic dissection. The constant stress on the arterial walls from high blood pressure weakens it over time. Age-related changes and the possible contribution of smoking may have exacerbated the arterial wall stress.  Demographics and Aortic Dissection Relations: Aortic dissection is more common in males and incidence rises significantly after the age of 60. Hypertension is present in the majority (approximately 72%) of patients with aortic dissection. African Americans have been found to have a higher risk of aortic dissections compared to other racial groups. Smoking  which is a risk factor  was also present in this patient's history.   To summarize  our patient fits the commonly seen demographic and clinical profile for aortic dissection  which includes being an older male  being of African-American descent  a history of hypertension  and a history of smoking.

Title: Presentation of Acortic Dissection in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Introduction: Mr. John Williams is a 70-year-old African American male  presenting with a sudden onset of severe chest pain.  Past Medical History: Mr. Williams has a complicated medical history. He was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago and has been managing it with medication since then. Mr. Williams was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 10 years ago. Despite these  he has not been fully compliant with his medications leading to suboptimal control of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  He has a known history of smoking for the past 50 years  consuming about a pack of cigarettes each day  however  he quit smoking 2 years ago. He has no known history of diabetes  stroke  or any other cardiovascular disease. There's no family history of any genetic connective tissue diseases.  Presentation: Mr. Williams came to the ER in the early hours of this morning  describing a sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and states it began at rest. He rates his pain as a 10 out of 10. His onset of pain was sudden. He had been fine when he went to bed  only to be awakened at around 1am by the intense pain. However  he does not report any associated symptoms like fainting  palpitations  shortness of breath  or sweating.   Current Condition: Currently  he is experiencing continuous pain  despite taking his usual analgesics. Blood pressure readings reveal high systemic hypertension. His pulse is regular but slightly elevated due to pain and anxiety. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities in heart sounds.   Conclusion: Keeping in view his age  his pathological history particularly of hypertension and smoking  together with the severe onset 'tearing' chest pain  the possible diagnosis of aortic dissection is suggested. Further diagnostic tests  including a chest X-ray  EKG  and CT angiography will be pursued to confirm this.  The above presentation reflects the fact that aortic dissections are more common in males  people aged 60-80  those with a history of hypertension  and among African American ethnicity  as supported by the literature.

Title: A Case Presentation of Aortic Dissection: A 65-Year-Old Male Patient  Introduction: We're discussing the case of a 65-year-old African American male  who primarily speaks English and is a retired construction worker. His initial presentation to the emergency department was prompted by sudden onset  severe chest pain that radiated to his back. He reports a history of poorly controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-year history of smoking  which he quit five years ago. The patient of late has limited access to healthcare due to financial instability. There is no family history of cardiovascular disease.   Demographics: Our patient belongs to the demographic group commonly associated with aortic dissection. The incidence rates are higher in males and the individuals over 60. Furthermore  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking  all prevalent in his history  are well-established risk factors for the development of aortic dissection. Also  racial disparities exist in hypertension-related complications  with African Americans being disproportionately affected.  Past Medical History: When questioned further  he described his chest pain as 'tearing' and 'agonizing.' The patient's blood pressure readings have been consistently above the range of 140/90 mm Hg on several past primary care visits. His hyperlipidemia has not been effectively managed due to discontinuation of statin therapy against medical advice. Although he quit smoking about five years ago  he has a 20-pack-year history of smoking.  Evaluation: Physical examination revealed an elevated blood pressure of 160/95 mm Hg in the right arm and 145/90 mm Hg in the left. His cardiovascular examination was significant for a discrepancy in pulse delay between the upper and lower extremities  which is a commonly observed physical sign in patients with aortic dissection. Laboratory tests showed elevated D-dimers  and Chest CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis of Type A aortic dissection.  Conclusion: Our patient represents a demographic with multiple stepped-up risks for aortic dissection – namely age  gender  race  and longstanding poorly controlled risk factors for cardiovascular disease. His presenting symptoms and signs  coupled with confirmatory radiologic evidence  led to the diagnosis of aortic dissection. Prompt surgical intervention is planned for this patient  emphasizing the pressing need for aggressive risk management strategies in such high-risk  representative groups.

Patient Presentation:  Title: A 66-year-old African American male with a history of untreated hypertension presenting with acute aortic dissection.  Introduction:  Mr. Johnson  a 66-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe chest pain  radiating to the back  which commenced less than an hour ago. He is a lifetime resident of the Baltimore area and is retired from a career as a construction worker. He has a history of chronic untreated hypertension and smoking for 40 years  although he quit five years ago.   Clinical History:  Mr. Johnson's personal medical history is unique in terms of having untreated hypertension for over a decade  with periodic readings often in the 160/90 range. Despite his awareness of this condition  he has declined treatment multiple times due to a general distrust of the healthcare system. Additionally  he has an unverified history of Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm in his maternal lineage  with no known Marfan Syndrome cases. He has not undergone any previous surgeries and has no known allergies. His social history is otherwise unremarkable  apart from a significant 40-year smoking history.  Clinical Presentation:  Today  Mr. Johnson exhibits signs of acute distress  describing his current pain as severe and sharp  a ""ripping"" sensation  conspicuously different from any pain he's experienced before  even comparing it to the pain caused by kidney stones. Moreover  he is also experiencing moderate dyspnea and minor dizziness but denies any associated nausea  vomiting  diaphoresis  or loss of consciousness.  In terms of demographic data regarding aortic dissection in literature  it's noteworthy that this condition is more prevalent in males (especially between ages 60 and 70) and is substantially common in people with a history of hypertension. African American ethnicity  while not typically considered a major risk factor for aortic dissection  has been associated with a higher prevalence of hypertension  which indirectly increases the risk of an aortic dissection. Other habits like smoking  presenting in Mr. Johnson's case  also increase the risk of developing aortic dissection.  Conclusion:  In summary  Mr. Johnson  a 66-year-old African American male known for untreated severe hypertension and extended smoking history  currently presents with symptoms and risk factors highly suggestive of an acute aortic dissection. A prompt diagnostic evaluation and management plan are critical at this stage.

Title: Presentation of Aortic Dissection in a 68-year-old Male with a History of Hypertension  Patient Profile: Mr. John Palmer is a retired  68-year-old Caucasian man currently residing in the suburbs of North Carolina  USA. He has a prolific history of uncontrolled hypertension  dating back at least 20 years. He also has a history of tobacco use  having smoked a pack a day for approximately 25 years  but quit about 8 years ago.   Clinical Presentation: Mr. Palmer reports experiencing a sudden onset of severe and sharp tearing pain in his chest radiating to his back  which occurred while he was gardening. The severity of the pain led him to stop his activity and immediately seek help.   Past Medical History: Mr. Palmer was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 48. Despite prescribed antihypertensive medications  he has been inconsistent in their usage and his blood pressure has remained poorly controlled. In addition  he has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) likely related to his history of smoking. Despite quitting smoking over a decade ago  Mr. Palmer has noticed a gradual deterioration of his respiratory function  which has been managed with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators. Apart from these  he has no known allergies.   Family History: His father had a history of ischemic heart disease and died at the age of 55 due to a myocardial infarction. His mother died at age 80 due to complication of stroke. He has two siblings who are alive and well  both diagnosed with hypertension.   Social History: Mr. Palmer has been retired for eight years from his job as a construction foreman. He lives with his wife and their dog. He denies the use of alcohol or illicit drug. He is socially active in his neighborhood organizing various community events. He enjoys gardening and reading in his free time.   The aforementioned picture paints the clinical portrait of a typical patient at risk for aortic dissection  which is most common in men ages 60 to 70  in addition to pre-existing hypertension  a significant risk factor. Aortic dissection remains highly associated with a history of smoking  despite cessation. It reflects the global and regional demographic characteristics for such presentations.

Title: Presentation of Aortic Dissection in a 60-year-old African American Male  Patient Profile: Mr. Brown is a 60-year-old African American male  coming in with complaints of sudden  severe chest pain.  Presenting Complaint: He describes his pain as ""tearing"" and radiating to his back  starting approximately 2 hours ago. He has never experienced such a feeling before  rating the pain a 10 on a scale from 1 to 10.   Past Medical History: Mr. Brown was diagnosed with hypertension ten years ago and has struggled to manage it consistently due to financial and environmental constraints. Low adherence to prescribed medication is a recurring issue.   Risk Factors:  His medical history shows essential hypertension  untreated high cholesterol  and a 20-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes per day  which he quit five years ago. His family history suggests a propensity for cardiovascular diseases: his father died of stroke at 68  and his older brother underwent coronary artery bypass grafting surgery nine years ago. Unfortunately  he has been largely sedentary throughout his life  which along with his unhealthy diet  makes him slightly obese (BMI 30.5 kg/m2).  Demographic Representations: The demographic details presented here regarding aortic dissection are accurate with respect to existing medical literature. Aortic dissections are more common in men  with an average age at presentation of 63 years  slightly older than Mr. Brown is. African Americans  in particular  have a higher risk of aortic dissection partly due to higher rates of poorly controlled hypertension.   Also  poor control of hypertension is common in this demographic group. Prevalence of smoking  which is a risk factor for aortic dissection  is close to 20% among African American men. Thus  Mr Brown's history of smoking further increases his risk alongside his hypertension and cholesterol issues.  Conclusion: The patient's symptoms  demographic factors  lifestyle choices  and nascent medical history collectively suggest a high possibility of aortic dissection. Therefore  immediate diagnostic evaluation and potential intervention are highly recommended.

Title: A Case Study Presentation on Aortic Dissection  Presenting Patient: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male standing 5'9 tall  weighing 95 kg  presenting with a chief complaint of sudden severe chest pain radiating to his back which began whilst he was asleep in the early hours of the morning. The patient further describes the pain as “tearing” in nature. No prior incidence of such occurrence has been reported by the patient. He's a retired mechanical engineer  moderate smoker (20 cigarettes a day for the past 35 years)  and a social drinker. He lives with his wife in the suburbs and is fairly active community member.  Demographic Information: As per the demographic data  aortic dissection is more common in males and the patient's age sits within the typical age range of 60-70 years old for aortic dissection. Furthermore  being Caucasian he represents the highest incidences of aortic dissection as per several studies and literature.   Past Medical History: On further inquiry  the patient divulges a known diagnosis of hypertension for the past 15 years  managed with regular antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide). Additionally  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes for the last 5 years  which is well-controlled on Metformin. The patient has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father dying from a stroke at age 68. The patient is also moderately obese  with a body mass index of 30.8  and has a past history of high cholesterol  managed with statins (Atorvastatin).   In conclusion  the patient's medical history of long-standing hypertension  being a smoker  as well as his family history of cardiovascular diseases  might have increased his risk factors for aortic dissection. His presentation is consistent with the symptoms commonly reported in literature for this condition. As next steps  additional diagnostic tests  such as a computed tomography (CT) scan or a transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)  will need to be done to confirm the diagnosis.

Title: A Case Presentation on Aortic Dissection  Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Thompson  a 62-year-old African American male from Boston  Massachusetts  arrived in the emergency room reporting a sudden onset of severe chest pain. The pain began while he was at rest  and he described it as 'tearing' and 'ripping' in nature  radiating towards his back. Mr. Thompson also reported associated symptoms of fainting and shortness of breath. He further mentioned that the pain is unlike any he has experienced before  stating its intensity was 'off the charts.'   Medical and Social History:   Mr. Thompson has a known medical history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 15 years. He was prescribed medication for hypertension management but had been non-compliant with his medication regimen. Mr. Thompson is a smoker with a 30-pack-year history and admits to habitual heavy alcohol use. He has no family history of cardiovascular diseases. He works as a construction laborer. He has no known drug allergies.   Racial/Ethnic Considerations:   The incidence of aortic dissection is higher in males and African American individuals. African Americans have higher rates of hypertension  a significant risk factor for aortic dissection  which might contribute to the demographic representation.  Conclusion:   In summary  Mr. Thompson's demographic characteristics  medical history  and his presenting symptoms align with the clinical picture of an aortic dissection. Immediate diagnostic and therapeutic measures should be implemented according to established guidelines to manage the potentially fatal condition.  References:  * Braverman  A. C. (2010). Acute aortic dissection: clinician update. Circulation  122(2)  184-188.    **Please note: This is a fictional case based on the epidemiology of aortic dissection. Individual patient experiences can vary.

Title: Presentation of an Aortic Dissection Patient  Patient Profile: Patient is Mr. John Rivera  a 65-year-old African American male. He currently resides in Chicago  Illinois. Mr. Rivera is retired  formerly serving in the U.S. Army  and is currently living with his wife. His familial history reveals that both his father and older brother had experienced heart disease.   Past Medical History: Mr. Rivera has a complex medical history. He was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago  which remains only slightly controlled despite antihypertensive therapy. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  but has a total pack history of 30 years. He has been diagnosed with high cholesterol and is being managed on statins. There is no report of diabetes  renal disease  or respiratory disease. He underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery ten years ago due to significant coronary artery disease.  Presenting Issue: Mr. Rivera arrived at the emergency room and reported severe chest and back pain  especially between the shoulder blades  which he described as ""ripping"" in nature. The pain was sudden in onset and has persisted for a couple of hours. He also noted some associated shortness of breath  but there is no report of other symptoms like fainting  dizziness  or weakness.  On examination: Mr. Rivera appeared distressed due to pain. His blood pressure shows significant differences between the two upper limbs  suggesting a vascular abnormality. Auscultation of the chest shows a murmur suggestive of aortic insufficiency. His pulses were asymmetric.  Aortic dissection was suspected due to the unique features of the presenting symptoms and past medical history. This suspicion was later confirmed through a CT angiogram. The patient was admitted to the ICU for urgent surgical intervention.  This case highlights the significant risk and prevalence of aortic dissection among elderly  hypertensive males  especially those with a history of smoking and coronary artery disease  as supported by literature.

Patient Presentation:  John Doe is a 62-year-old Caucasian male presenting with severe pain in his chest and back.   Medical History:  Mr. Doe is a former smoker with a 10-pack year record  quitting about 15 years ago. He has a known medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol  both of which have been partially controlled with medication. There is no diabetes  COPD  or other cardiovascular or lung diseases present.   There is also a family history of potential note  as his father suffered from an aortic aneurysm.   Presentation & Symptoms:  Mr. Doe described the pain as ""ripping"" or ""tearing""  a characteristic description often linked to aortic dissection. It started in his chest and has been rapidly progressing towards the back. He reports no radiation to the neck or arms but states that the pain seems to move in sync with his heartbeat. Symptoms intensified within a few hours following initial onset  prompting his visit to the ER.   Along with his pain  Mr. Doe also reported feeling faint and experiencing shortness of breath. Interestingly  he states that his blood pressure has been abnormally high lately  despite adherence to his antihypertensive regimen.   Mr. Doe's age  gender  history of hypertension  smoking  and family history of aortic disease  along with his presenting symptoms  align with the demographic most commonly associated with aortic dissection  which are Caucasian males in their 60s. A high index of suspicion is critical because quick diagnosis and treatment are paramount in managing this life-threatening condition. We ordered immediate diagnostic tests  including a CT scan and D-Dimer  to confirm the diagnosis and plan subsequent management.   In the future  Mr. Doe could potentially benefit from smoking cessation programs and lifestyle changes to decrease hypertension and improve his overall cardiovascular health. He should also familiarize himself with the symptoms of aortic dissection  given his increased risk  and seek immediate medical attention should these symptoms present.

Patient Presentation:  We will discuss Mr. J  a 65-year- old African American male presenting with symptoms consistent with an aortic dissection. Mr. J hails from Chicago  Illinois and is married with three adult children. He is a retired mechanical engineer and his wife is a school teacher.   Mr. J has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which he was diagnosed with when he was 36 years old  working in a high-stress job with long working hours. He has been on antihypertensive therapy since his diagnoses and his blood pressure has usually been under good control. Additionally  he was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia ten years ago and is on statin therapy. He does not have diabetes or any kidney disease. He has no known drug allergies  and he has never been a smoker. He does not have any family history of aortic dissection or connective tissue diseases. His father had a heart attack and his mother had a stroke.  Today  he was brought into the emergency department by his wife  complaining of sudden severe chest pain. The pain began while he was eating dinner  described as tearing and radiating to his back. He also reported feeling clammy and sweaty  experiencing shortness of breath  and feeling generally unwell.  Aortic dissection disproportionately affects males  and African-Americans are at slightly higher risk than other racial or ethnic groups. Additionally  hypertension  which affects African-Americans at higher rates than other racial/ethnic groups  is a leading risk factor for aortic dissection. Age  one of the strongest risk factors for aortic dissection  with most cases occurring in individuals between 50-80 years old. Hence  a 65-year-old hypertensive African-American male is representative of a population at risk for this condition.   A prompt diagnosis and management plan for Mr. J's aortic dissection will be instituted  keeping in mind his age  race  and medical history to provide an optimal patient-driven approach.

Title: A Case Presentation on Aortic Dissection  Patient Overview:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male presenting in the ER with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back. The pain is described as 'tearing' in nature. The patient reports that symptoms initiated while he was at home  and progressively became intense over a span of several hours.   Medical History:  The patient has a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last ten years and a smoking habit of 20 years. He has also been on medication for high cholesterol for the past five years. His father and uncle both died of heart diseases in their late 60s. The patient does not have a history of any surgeries  and denies any allergies to food or medication. He lives with his wife in the city  is retired  and has a social history of moderate alcohol drinking.  Literature Basis:  According to existing literature  the occurrence of aortic dissection is more commonly observed in men  and with the patient's age  being over 60  he falls in the high-risk group. Additionally  hypertension is a significant risk factor  prevalent in 75% of cases. His history of smoking and high cholesterol also facilitates atherosclerosis  thus increasing the risk of aortic dissection. Furthermore  the African American population is shown to have higher rates of hypertension compared with other racial and ethnic groups  emphasizing his risk.  Image and Diagnosis:  Imaging  CT angiography  in particular  confirms a diagnosis of an aortic dissection  showing a tear in the intima of the aorta and a dissection flap.  In conclusion:  This patient's demographic and medical history put him at high risk for the development of aortic dissection. Next steps would include immediate surgical consultation and initiation of blood pressure control therapy. Education regarding the importance of strict blood pressure and cholesterol control  cessation of smoking  and limiting alcohol intake would be crucial in management and prevention of future cardiovascular incidents.

Patient Presentation: A 62-year-old African American male patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of intense  tearing  interscapular pain radiating to the back along with shortness of breath. He describes the pain as extremely sharp and severe and informs that it began abruptly a few hours ago. He also complains of diaphoresis and mild dizziness. There is no loss of consciousness  no nausea  vomiting  or abdominal pain but he has increasingly become anxious due to the intense pain.  His past medical history is significant for long-term hypertension  for which he was prescribed antihypertensive medication that he admits to not taking regularly. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He has no known drug allergies. There is no family history of any significant cardiovascular disease. He has been living a sedentary lifestyle with a high-fat diet.   Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 200/120 mm Hg in his right arm and 160/90 mm Hg in his left arm  pulse rate 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and the patient appears uncomfortable due to pain. Cardiovascular examination shows normal heart sounds without any murmurs  jugular venous distention  or peripheral edema. Pulmonary  abdominal  and neurological examinations are unremarkable.  Given the patient's history  physical examination findings  and demographic details  aortic dissection is suspected  and immediate diagnostic and management steps are undertaken.

Patient Presentation:  A 61-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  sharp chest pain radiating to his back. The pain began roughly 2 hours ago while he was working in his backyard and has progressively worsened since.  His past medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension  a 20-year smoking history  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. He also reports a high cholesterol level but non-compliant with diet changes and statin medication. His BMI is 29. No history of surgery is reported.   Despite taking his antihypertensive medications  his blood pressure at presentation is 175/95 mmHg. He does not have diabetes  but his eating habits were poor which contribute to his obesity.  In the ED  his physical examination exhibits slight diaphoresis and pallor. Auscultation reveals a faint diastolic murmur. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  An EKG shows non-specific ST segment changes but no signs of myocardial infarction. Urgent computed tomography angiography reveals a dissection involving the ascending and descending thoracic aorta. The patient is rushed to the operating room for emergent cardiovascular surgery.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and cigarette smoking. He has been complaining of sudden and severe chest pain radiating towards the back. He describes the pain as ripping or tearing sensation which had a sudden onset while he was doing house chores. He is also feeling weak and dizzy. He has a history of uncompliant hypertension treatment over the past ten years  and a 20-pack year history of smoking. His family history is significant for early cardiac deaths in his father and grandfather. No history of high cholesterol levels or diabetes. He admitted to not adhering to a healthy diet and his engagement in physical activities is minimal. The patient does not have any prior surgeries. Furthermore  he denies any symptoms of fever  cough  shortness of breath  or recent illnesses.    Upon physical examination  he seems uncomfortable with evident anxiety. His vital signs were recorded as blood pressure of 170/105mmHg in left arm and 155/100mmHg in right arm  a heart rate of 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  and a body temperature of 98.6 degrees F. His cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic insufficiency.    Based on his age  race  history of uncontrolled hypertension  and current symptoms  a diagnosis of aortic dissection was considered. This was confirmed by Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA).

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jack Donovan is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency room with sudden and severe pain in the chest radiating to the back. He reports the pain began while he was shoveling snow in his driveway. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation. The pain is 10 out of 10 in intensity. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  which he reports has been poorly controlled. He has a history of tobacco use  smoking a pack a day for about 35 years. He is on antihypertensive medication  but he admits to having forgotten to take it sometimes over the past few weeks. He denies any known personal or family history of connective tissue diseases or aneurysms. The patient looks uncomfortable with a look of anxiety in his expression.  Physical exam: Blood pressure is 170/95 mmHg on the right arm and 155/90 mmHg on the left arm  heart rate is 110 bpm  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute and temperature is 98.6°F. Cardiac exam is significant for a diastolic murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space which may indicate aortic regurgitation.  Based on his presenting symptoms  physical exam findings  demographic details  and significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use  the impression is raising high suspicion for an aortic dissection.  Considering recent population studies  aortic dissection is most common in males aged 60-70 years old  which is consistent with our patient. Lastly  Mr. Donovan's risk factors like uncontrolled hypertension  and long-term tobacco use make him a high-risk candidate for aortic dissection. The next step would be immediate medical stabilization  including pain control and blood pressure management  and confirmatory tests for aortic dissection such as CT scan.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 66-year-old African American male with a known history of uncontrolled hypertension  smoking  and an episode of uncomplicated myocardial infarction 6 years ago. He presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his back. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and it started about 2 hours ago. He also reports mild dyspnea  but denies any nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. He is slightly diaphoretic and looks anxious.  Vitals on arrival show a blood pressure of 200/110 mmHg  heart rate of 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. On physical examination  he is found to have a blood pressure discrepency  with a higher reading in his right arm compared to his left.   He is up to date on his vaccinations  and his last wellness exam was over a year ago. Daily medications include aspirin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril. Despite medication compliance  his blood pressure remains poorly controlled. He has been a smoker for 40 years.   Given his presenting symptoms and history  there is a high clinical suspicion of aortic dissection. Urgent imaging and cardiovascular surgical consultation will be needed.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Robert Torres  a 67-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain that began approximately two hours ago. The pain is described as ""tearing"" and radiates to his back. He notes the pain started while he was at rest  and has progressively gotten worse. He rates it as 10 out of 10 on the pain scale.   Mr. Torres has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which he was diagnosed with 10 years ago. He is currently on Lisinopril 20 mg once daily and Metoprolol 50 mg twice daily but admits he has poor compliance due to his busy  usually stressful schedule. He also has a 30-pack year smoking history  but he quit five years ago. His family history is noteworthy for his father  who suffered a myocardial infraction at the age of 70.  On physical examination  Mr. Torres appears anxious. His blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg in the right arm and 160/80 mmHg in the left arm. Heart sounds are normal  without murmur. Neurological exam reveals no neurological deficits.   Given his history and presentation  an urgent CT angiogram is ordered to confirm the suspicion of aortic dissection. Although generally seen in older men  this case aligns with the literature showing that African American males have higher rates of aortic dissection  especially in the context of a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old African-American male presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden and severe sharp pain in his chest and back that started an hour ago while he was mowing the lawn. The pain is an 8 on the 10-point scale and appears to be radiating down towards the abdomen. Patient looks visibly distressed because of the pain and appears pale and sweaty.  Patient has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension for almost 15 years which he says is usually around 170/100 mmHg  despite being on regular antihypertensives. He also has a history of 45 pack-years smoking but quit 5 years ago. He has no other known coronary artery disease  diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  or any family history of aortic disease. He says he did not experience similar symptoms before. He is allergic to penicillin and takes prescribed medication (amlodipine and metoprolol) irregularly.  On examination  the patient's blood pressure is recorded as 180/110 mmHg and pulse of 110 bpm. His left arm blood pressure is significantly higher than the right arm  and a diastolic decrescendo murmur is audible on auscultation. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable  and the patient is afebrile. Neurological examination demonstrates no deficits.  This presentation is suggestive of aortic dissection  and immediate further investigations  including a CT angiogram  have been advised. The patient has been informed of the potential critical nature of his condition  and the necessity for prompt intervention to manage his case has been stressed.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American man with a past medical history of smoking  chronic high blood pressure  and high cholesterol presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden-onset chest and back pain. The pain is reported as “tearing” or “ripping” and started suddenly about two hours prior to his arrival.  The patient reports the pain as 10/10  and says it radiates from his chest through to his back. He also notes a feeling of ""fullness"" in his chest. He has no history of similar pain. He denies any recent trauma  nausea  vomiting  shortness of breath  cough  dizziness  or fainting spells.  On physical examination  he appears distressed due to the pain. He is hypertensive with a blood pressure reading of 170/110 mmHg. His pulse is irregular with a rate of about 110 beats per minute. He has no visible edema  cyanosis  or jugular venous distension. Auscultation of the heart reveals a diastolic murmur. There is a discrepancy in blood pressure between his right and left arms.  The patient's past medical history reveals that he has been diagnosed with hypertension for 20 years but has been inconsistent with his antihypertensive medication use. He also has dyslipidemia  for which he takes statins  and has been smoking a pack of tobacco cigarettes daily for around 40 years.  Given the patient's clinical picture and history  a diagnosis of aortic dissection is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old African American male presented with sudden  severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back  which began approximately two hours before he arrived in the emergency department. His vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg and a heart rate of 90 bpm. The patient reported an associated feeling of ""impending doom""  difficulty in breathing  and dizziness.   Demographics:  The patient is a retired truck driver  a non-smoker  living with his wife in an urban setting  who consumes alcohol moderately  specifically beer  during social events. He is not a known drug abuser.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for at least fifteen years  for which he has been on Lisinopril and Amlodipine. His compliance with medication is poor due to his belief in alternative medicine. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidaemia three years ago for which he takes Simvastatin irregularly. He reported a few episodes of transient chest pain in the past which he self-attributed to 'stress'. His father had suffered from a heart attack in his sixties.  This clinical presentation suggests an aortic dissection  which is particularly prevalent in hypertensive  African American males over 60 years old. His blood pressure and heart rate are dangerously high  and the patient's symptoms (chest pain  feeling of impending doom  difficulty breathing and dizziness) are typically associated with aortic dissections. His previous history of cardiac diseases also suggests an increased risk of aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James Craig  a 65-year-old African-American male  presents to the Emergency Department reporting a sudden onset of severe chest pain described as tearing that started approximately four hours ago. The pain is radiating to his back  between his shoulder blades.  His past medical history reveals he has hypertension which he admits to not managing well due to lack of adherence to his antihypertensive treatment prescribed by his primary care physician. He also has a smoking history of 20-pack years. He denies use of any recreational drugs. His family history includes a father who had an aortic aneurysm at an elderly age.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is noted to be significantly higher in the right arm compared to the left  and on auscultation  a diastolic murmur is detected. A chest x-ray reveals a mediastinal widening and his ECG is normal. He appears anxious and is in acute distress due to the severe pain.  In view of suspected aortic dissection  emergency computed tomography (CT) of the aorta is being arranged. The patient is placed on IV nitroprusside to decrease blood pressure and pain control is achieved with morphine.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a sudden  severe chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation. He also experiences nausea  sweating  and shortness of breath.  The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 8 years and a 35-year history of tobacco use. The patient also had a diagnosis of Marfan syndrome in his early adult years  a condition that affects the body's connective tissue. His family history reveals a father who had an aortic dissection at the age of 72. The patient has not been compliant with his antihypertensive medications.  On examination  his blood pressure is significantly higher in the right arm compared to the left. A diastolic murmur is also audible in the second right intercostal space. An EKG shows no changes suggestive of a myocardial infarction. His body mass index is 30 kg/m2  indicative of obesity.  The presentation points towards a likely diagnosis of an aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. R is a 67-year-old African American male who arrived in the emergency department appearing pale and sweating. He complains of sudden severe pain in the chest and back that started an hour ago  describing it as 'tearing' or 'ripping'. The pain has not been relieved nor aggravated by movement or changes in body position. It was accompanied by shortness of breath and fainting. He denies having similar pains in the past and does not recall any injury that could relate to his current symptomatology.   Mr. R is a retired mechanic  a current smoker with a 40-pack year history. He drinks alcohol occasionally. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been managed with lisinopril for the last 15 years.   Mr. R's father died of a myocardial infarction in his early 60s and his mother had a stroke at the age of 78  subsequently his family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. Despite this  Mr. R has never been worked up for heart disease other than having had his blood pressure managed. He has been largely non-compliant with his hypertension therapy for the past few months due to financial issues.  On examination  his blood pressure is elevated  with a difference between the right and left arms. His pulse rate is 110 beats per minute but irregular. Mental status exam reveals mild confusion. Cardiac examination reveals a diastolic murmur. Lung examinations are clear. His lower extremities are cold to touch with diminished peripheral pulses.   Despite initial treatment  his pain and discomfort only slightly decrease. His EKG shows non-specific changes but no findings suggestive of acute myocardial infarction. The suspicion of aortic dissection is high due to his history  presentation  and initial clinical findings. CT angiogram is planned to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith is a 62-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with sudden and severe chest pain that radiates to his back  associated with shortness of breath. The pain is tearing in nature and started suddenly about two hours ago during physical exertion. He describes his pain as the worst he has ever experienced.   He has a significant medical history of uncontrolled hypertension for 15 years  for which he has not been regular with his medications. He also has a known history of smoking for the past 40 years and occasionally drinks alcohol. There is no known family history of heart disease.   On examination  his blood pressure is found to be significantly high at 180/95 mmHg  with a difference of 20 mmHg between the left and right arms. His pulse is 110 beats per minute. There is a diastolic murmur heard at the left sternal border. Neurological examination is unremarkable and no limb weakness or sensory loss is detected.   The diagnostic picture thus points towards the possibility of an aortic dissection. It is necessary to proceed with immediate imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis and further plan the management. His elevated blood pressure  history of hypertension  and smoking habit are significant risk factors for aortic dissection.  This presentation is crucial due to the high mortality rate associated with untreated aortic dissection. Early identification and management may aid in better patient outcomes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Smith is a 63-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer by profession. He presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe chest pain that started an hour ago while he was having his lunch. He described the pain as a sharp and tearing sensation through the midline of his chest  radiating to his back. He has a 20 year history of hypertension and was diagnosed with high cholesterol two years ago  both conditions are loosely controlled on medications.  He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking cigarettes.   The knock-on effects of his hypertension include left ventricular hypertrophy  which was identified during an echocardiography report 5 years ago. He has been taking Lisinopril and Atorvastatin as prescribed by his primary care physician  but has been inconsistent with taking his medications due to side-effects. Mr. Smith denies any history of trauma  aortic interventions  connective tissue disorders  or familial thoracic aortic diseases. He denies illicit drug use.  The only significant family history he reported was that his father passed away in his 60s due to a myocardial infarction. He did not report related symptoms like shortness of breath  dizziness  or palpitations but looked anxious and worried due to the severity of the chest pain. His social history is notable for alcohol use; he reports having a few beers on weekends. His daughter accompanied him to the hospital and reported that he had been complaining of general malaise for the past few days.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Sanchez is a 62-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the emergency department with a complaint of a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain started about an hour before his arrival and has not subsided. He describes it as a ripping sensation. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  smoking for 40 years  and also has a familial history of aortic dissection in his father.   On examination  his blood pressure is found to be markedly different in both arms  180/100 in the right and 160/95 in the left. A murmur of aortic regurgitation is heard. He appears anxious and diaphoretic.   The high-risk features of his condition include his age  male sex  history of hypertension  and his family history of aortic dissection. The sudden onset of severe pain  the radiating nature of it  and the differences in blood pressure between his arms are suggestive of an aortic dissection. The history of smoking also increases his risk of aortic and other vascular diseases.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe chest pain that he describes as “tearing” in nature. The pain dichotomously radiates to his back. The patient also reports feeling short of breath  along with mild dizziness.   Past medical history reveals that he has lived with hypertension for 30 years and has a history of smoking. He is restricted from physical activity due to his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for which he is on an inhaler. Additionally  he informs the attending physician of his habit of alcohol consumption and that he smokes a pack of cigarettes a day.  Medical history also includes aortic valve stenosis  for which he underwent aortic valve replacement ten years prior to this episode. The patient reports that he has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication  losartan  for the past month due to financial difficulties.   Of note  his father suffered a stroke at the age of 60. There are no other known hereditary diseases in the family. Although Mr. Smith leads a rather sedentary lifestyle  his diet largely consists of high-sodium processed foods. He resides with his wife in a suburban home and is retired.   The physical exam reveals a blood pressure of 190/110 mmHg in his left arm  while the right arm reading is 160/90 mmHg. Mr. Smith also has a pulse of 110 beats per minute and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Pulses in the lower extremities are diminished bilaterally. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.   Given Mr. Smith’s history and the nature of his present symptoms  the healthcare team has immediate concerns for aortic dissection. Further diagnostic testing is pursued to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 67-year-old Hispanic male  a retired firefighter  presented to the ER with sudden onset  acute severe chest pain radiating to his back. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and stated it began while he was working in his yard.   Past Medical History:  He has a known medical history of chronic uncontrolled hypertension  smoking for 25 years (though he quit over a decade ago)  and a previous myocardial infarction 5 years ago.  Family History: There is no significant pertinent family history.  Current Medications:  He is currently on antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril 20mg) and low-dose Aspirin.  Relevant Findings:  Upon examination  his blood pressure was significantly high at 180/110 mmHg. There was a noted pulse discrepancy between the upper limbs.   This combination of clinical presentation  severe hypertension  and vascular discrepancies  coupled with his past medical history  raised a strong suspicion for an aortic dissection. An immediate CT angiography was ordered for confirmation.

Patient Presentation Example:  A 65-year-old African-American man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  sharp  tearing pain in the chest radiating to the back  dyspnea  and anxiety. The pain is described as worst pain ever experienced by the patient. He also reports feeling ""a ripping sensation"" in the center of his chest. The pain started while he was trying to lift a heavy box at his home. It prompted him to sit down due to the severity  and did not subside with rest.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been poorly controlled for the past 10 years due to inconsistent follow up and medication non-adherence. He also has a history of End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. The patient has been non-compliant with his diet and medication regimen  often skipping his blood pressure medication. His family history is also remarkable for hypertension in his parents and an older brother.   He is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. His regular medications include Lisinopril and Amlodipine for blood pressure control  and he is on a renal diet.   On physical examination  the patient is anxious and in visible distress. His blood pressure reading is markedly different between his right arm (166/98 mmHg) and left arm (140/88 mmHg). His heart rate is 110 beats per minute. Pulses in his bilateral lower extremities are difficult to palpate. On auscultation  a diastolic murmur is noted.  Considering the patient's symptoms  differential blood pressure  and past medical history  the working diagnosis is aortic dissection. An emergent CT angiography of the thorax confirms the diagnosis  showing a type A aortic dissection. The patient is immediately referred to the Cardiothoracic surgery for surgical intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. R  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department with severe  tearing pain in his chest radiating to his back. He describes the pain as ""worst he has ever experienced"" and that it started abruptly about an hour before his arrival. He has also been experiencing episodes of dizziness and shortness of breath. On further questioning  he admits to antihypertensive medication non-compliance.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension over 15 years  smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for 35 years and a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA). His father passed away at 70 due to heart disease. On examination  his blood pressure is found disproportionately high in the right arm compared to the left. Heart sounds are normal with no audible murmur and there is no peripheral edema. His EKG shows no signs of myocardial infarction. The findings so far raise clinical suspicion of aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back. He describes the pain as sharp and ""tearing""  and ratings it a 10/10. He also reports feeling short of breath  slight confusion  and lightheadedness. He has a known history of untreated hypertension and has been a smoker for over 40 years.   His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg and a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute. He has a significant discrepancy in blood pressure between both arms. A soft early diastolic murmur is noted on cardiac examination. Neurologic examination demonstrates a unilateral lower extremity weakness. He has an anisocoric pupil and mild ptosis on the left  suggestive of Horner’s syndrome.   Patient's family history reveals his father died of a stroke and his mother suffered from heart disease. On social history  he admits to less than ideal eating habits  low moderate exercise  and daily alcohol use.   The clinical profile  high blood pressure  and examination findings suggest an aortic dissection  which is a critical  life-threatening condition. His male gender  age  African-American ethnicity  family history of cardiovascular disease  smoking  uncontrolled hypertension  and sedentary lifestyle might be contributing factors to his current condition. His symptoms  such as severe and sudden chest and back pain  shortness of breath  confusion  and neurologic signs  are significant features in the clinical presentation and should promote urgent diagnostic imaging and management.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back. Pain is described as 10/10 in intensity  starting approximately two hours ago while he was at rest. He also reports dizziness and shortness of breath but denies any other symptoms including loss of consciousness  palpitations  nausea  or vomiting. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension which has been poorly controlled. The patient has a 50 pack-year smoking history; he also used to consume alcohol but has been abstinent for 20 years. He has never been diagnosed with any heart disease before this instance. His father passed away from a heart attack at 70 years of age  and his older brother has a history of peripheral arterial disease. His physical examination shows high blood pressure (170/90 mmHg) and a diastolic murmur at the right second intercostal space. His labs show an elevated d-dimer level.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 67-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department with severe  sudden onset chest pain. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and radiating to his back  which started about an hour ago while he was at home. He rates the pain at 10/10  unaffected by movement or breathing.
