Mr. Johnson  a retired construction worker  has a past medical history significant for Stage 2 hypertension  which has been controlled by losartan for the last 10 years. He also has a 40-pack year history of smoking  but quit smoking around 5 years ago. He denies any family history of cardiac conditions. His BMI is 29  reflecting overweight status.  Concerning the symptoms  he also complained about mild shortness of breath. His ability to talk in full sentences and no signs of respiratory distress suggest absence of any acute respiratory problem.   On general examination  he is afebrile and looks uncomfortable. His BP is 170/100 mm of Hg in the right arm and 155/90 mm of Hg in the left arm. His pulse rate is 78 bpm  regular  and equal in all peripheries. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.  An initial EKG does not show any ST segment changes and troponin levels are normal.   This patient's age  race  history of uncontrolled hypertension  and previous smoking habit place him at a higher risk of an aortic dissection. The presentation of severe chest pain with a tearing nature and variation of BP between the arms increase suspicion for this diagnosis. An urgent imaging study is vital for the confirmation  usually a CT Angiography.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas Harrison is a 62-year-old African-American male who presents to the emergency department with an onset of sudden severe  tearing pain in the chest radiating through to his back  along with shortness of breath  excessive sweating  and a sense of impending doom. The pain is described as pressure-like  unrelieved by nitroglycerin and is accompanied by faintness.  His relevant past medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension for 15 years  3 years of poorly controlled diabetes and a smoking history of 30 pack-years. No history of loss of consciousness  trauma  or prior cardiovascular interventions. No family history of aortic dissection or other connective tissue disorders.  On physical examination  blood pressure is found markedly different in each arm (170/100 in the right  126/86 in the left). A diastolic murmur noted on examination prompting the medical team to order further imaging to investigate the possibility of aortic dissection. His ECG showed no ischemic changes.  Clinically  Mr. Harrison's age  race  uncontrolled hypertension  smoking history  and the sudden onset of severe tearing chest pain  difference in blood pressure between arms etc suggest a high suspicion for aortic dissection. An urgent CT scan was ordered for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 69-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 20 pack-year tobacco use. He presents to the emergency department complaining of acute onset severe  tearing  and radiating chest pain from his anterior to his posterior chest  which started while he was having his breakfast.  He further describes the pain as the most severe he has ever felt  with an intensity of 10/10 that it made him break out in cold sweat and feel nauseous though no vomiting. The pain seemed to migrate downwards in its course. He denies any recent trauma  recent surgeries  fever  cough  or respiratory distress and has no history of similar pain except for intermittent episodes of intense headache.  On admission  his blood pressure was noted to be 180/100 mm Hg and pulse rate 105 beats/min. The blood pressure in the right arm was about 20 points higher than in the left arm. His BMI was calculated to be 29 indicating obesity.   His medications include amlodipine  atorvastatin  and low-dose aspirin for secondary prevention  with poor medication adherence reported. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease in his father  who passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He lives with his wife  is retired  and has been a regular smoker for the past 40 years.  Given his acute  severe  tearing chest pain in the context of uncontrolled hypertension and a significant tobacco history  there is a high clinical suspicion for aortic dissection. Immediate investigations including EKG  chest X-ray  and CT angiogram are being arranged.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension and heavy smoking  currently complaining of a sudden  severe ""tearing"" chest pain that started a few hours ago. He states that the pain began in the chest and has since migrated to his back. He describes the pain as the worst he has ever experienced  rating it as a 10/10 on the severity scale and differing from his previous episodes of angina.   He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications due to financial constraints and lack of insurance. Other than hypertension  the patient also has a history of high cholesterol levels and smoking about a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He denies any family history of aortic aneurysms  Marfan's syndrome  or other connective tissue disorders. He denies any known drug allergies.   On examination  he is diaphoretic and appears acutely ill. His blood pressure is found to be significantly different in both arms  and there is evidence of decreased peripheral pulses. No audible murmur is detected during his cardiac auscultation.   He is immediately sent for further cardiovascular imaging. The presentation and symptoms suggest strongly towards aortic dissection  and early diagnosis and intervention are critical.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old African-American male  presenting to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The pain started approximately 2 hours ago and has persisted  becoming progressively worse. He describes it as a sharp  tearing sensation. He also reports feeling slightly short of breath  but denies cough  fever  or any other symptoms.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 20 years. It was diagnosed when he was 47 years old and although he was prescribed medication  he has been noncompliant with his treatment and does not routinely monitor his blood pressure. He also has a history of cigarette smoking (half a pack per day for 30 years but quit 5 years ago). His father died of a stroke at the age of 67  and he has an elder brother who died of aortic dissection at age 65. He does not have diabetes  any history of heart issues  or other chronic illnesses.   His current medications include Amlodipine 5mg once daily  which he is inconsistent in taking. However  he reports no known drug allergies.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  his blood pressure is significantly different between his arms (160/90 mmHg on the right and 130/80 mmHg on the left). He appears to be in moderate distress due to pain. Cardiovascular exam is notable for a diastolic murmur heard best at the right sternal border. His lungs are clear to auscultation.   Emergency Department Course:  Mr. Johnson is taken immediately for a CT scan  which reveals a Stanford Type A aortic dissection  necessitating immediate surgery.  Based on reported risk factors for aortic dissection among older males such as hypertension  family history  and smoking  Mr. Johnson's case is representative. Furthermore  it highlights the importance of blood pressure control and medication adherence in such patients to avoid emergencies like the one encountered here.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old male  Mr. Jackson  from African-American descent presents to the emergency department experiencing severe chest pain. He describes the sensation as a sudden tearing or ripping pain in the middle of his chest  radiating to his back. He also reports shortness of breath and a sense of impending doom. Patient also mentions a sudden onset of faintness and perspiration.   Demographic Details:  Mr. Jackson is a retired financial advisor  a smoker for the last 35 years with a pack a day. The patient continues to drink alcohol socially and admits to mild recreational drug misuse in his youth. His diet lacks fresh fruits and vegetables. He lives alone in the city but has two adult children in close communication.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Jackson has a documented history of hypertension which was uncontrolled for many years  but he has been compliant with his medication for the past three years. He also has hyperlipidemia and a previous diagnosis of Bicuspid Aortic Valve for which he underwent aortic valve replacement surgery ten years prior. His father passed away at the age of 57 due to a myocardial infarction. His mother is alive and well at the age of 86.   Based on the information given this patient falls under a high-risk group for aortic dissection due to his age  gender  race (with African-Americans having a higher incidence rate)  his history of hypertension and bicuspid aortic valve  unhealthy lifestyle  and family history of heart disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 65-year-old African-American male who presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The patient also reported feeling short of breath  profuse sweating and nausea. His vital signs revealed elevated blood pressure.   Relevant Medical History:  Mr. J has a documented history of high blood pressure  for which he is currently taking Lisinopril but has been poorly compliant with his medication. He also has a 20 pack-year history of smoking and past medical history of bicuspid aortic valve. He has familial history of heart diseases - his father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at age 64.   Demographic Details:  He is a retired school teacher living with his wife in Philadelphia  Pennsylvania. His ethnicity is consistent with a higher prevalence of hypertension  a critical risk factor for aortic dissection. His age and male sex also align with the typical demographic that presents with aortic dissection  which is most common in men  60 to 70 years old. His smoking and non-compliance with his anti-hypertensive medication have significantly contributed to his risk of developing aortic dissection. His history of bicuspid aortic valve  a congenital malformation associated with aortic dissection  is also a contributing factor.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with sudden  severe chest pain. He describes it as a tearing sensation that radiates to his back. The pain started about one hour ago which caused him to break out in a cold sweat and was associated with a feeling of impending doom.  He has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension  which he is on medications for but admits to not taking them regularly. The patient reports being a current smoker with a 20-pack-year smoking history and occasional alcohol user. His father expired due to myocardial infarction at an age of 58.  On physical examination  the patient is pale  diaphoretic  and appears restless. His BP is 180/110 mmHg in the right arm and 165/95 mmHg in the left. His pulse rate is 95 BPM  and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals a slightly decreased pulse and delayed capillary refill time in the right upper limb.  Considering his symptoms  past medical history and physical examination findings  aortic dissection is suspected  with his uncontrolled hypertension presenting a significant risk factor. An immediate CT aortogram is advised to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old African-American male who arrived in the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain that started about two hours ago while lifting boxes at his job in the postal service. He described the pain as a tearing sensation radiating to his back  between the shoulder blades. He also reported some difficulty in breathing and lightheadedness but denied any nausea  fever  cough  or palpitations.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a 15-year history of uncontrolled hypertension  for which he is taking hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril  but admits noncompliance with his medication regimen due to side effects. Additionally  he has a 10-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily  and a family history of premature cardiovascular disease. There is no known history of Marfan syndrome or connective tissue disorders in his family. There is no previous significant history of surgeries  no known drug allergies and he denies any recreational drug use.   Demographics:  According to literature  the incidence of aortic dissection is more common in males over the age of 60  with hypertension as a major risk factor. Current smoking trends also suggest a higher prevalence among African American males. This case scenario reflects these demographics taking into account the overrepresented age  sex  race  and relevant risk factors associated with aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Quinn  a 69-year-old African American male  presents himself in the emergency department with severe and sudden onset chest pain that he describes as ""tearing"" which started around two hours ago. Mr. Quinn is a retired truck driver who is currently living in San Diego  California.  Mr. Quinn reports feeling unwell and has been experiencing profuse sweating. He mentions the pain started in his chest and has now migrated to his back. Although he did not lose consciousness  he reported feeling faint initially. He doesn't report any associated symptoms such as shortness of breath  cough  or palpitations.  James has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years and moderately controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for about 7 years. He has a 20-pack year history of smoking but he said he stopped smoking when he was diagnosed with diabetes. He has a family history of hypertension and heart disease; his father died of a heart attack at 72 and his older brother underwent bypass surgery 5 years back. He has been noncompliant with his hypertensive medications for about a fortnight due to financial constraints.  Mr. Quinn appears visibly distressed and is profusely sweating. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 188/112 in the right arm and 160/98 in the left arm. His heart rate is rapid at 110 bpm. Cardiac auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation. The neurologic examination is unremarkable.  Given Mr. Quinn's clinical presentation  history of hypertension and sudden onset chest pain  there is a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection. An immediate chest CT angiogram is justified to confirm the diagnosis. He is promptly started on aggressive antihypertensive therapy.

Patient Presentation:  I am seeing Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African American male patient who presented to the ER with sudden  severe chest pain that started an hour ago. According to him  he started feeling an intense and sharp pain in his chest  that then migrated to his back  almost like a tearing or ripping sensation. Mr. Johnson reports that the pain was more severe than any pain he has ever experienced.  Mr. Johnson has a past medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol for which he has been on medication for the past 10 years. He also has a 35 pack-year history of smoking although he quit 5 years ago. He reports occasional alcohol use but denies any illicit drug use. There is no known family history of heart disease or any connective tissue disorders.  On initial assessment his blood pressure was 162/98 mmHg in the right arm and 154/92 mmHg in the left arm. His heart rate was 96 bpm  respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minutes and his O2 saturation is 95% on room air. His body mass index is 29 indicating he is overweight.  Given his risk factors of being hypertensive  his age  male gender  and his african american ethnicity  along with his symptom of a sudden severe chest pain that migrated to his back; I was highly suspicious of an aortic dissection. He was immediately stabilized and relevant imaging studies were ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 70-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with severe  sharp chest pain that started suddenly about 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to his back. According to him  the pain is different from anything he has experienced before  rated 10/10  and is not position-dependent or related to exercise. Apart from pain  he also reports having shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and feeling lightheaded.   Mr. Johnson has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 20 years and a smoking history of 40 pack-years. He quit smoking 5 years ago. He had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago and underwent angioplasty. He also has a familial history of heart disease as his father had a heart attack at age 65.   He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication due to the side effects of the medication and financial problems. His regular medications include aspirin  clopidogrel  and atorvastatin.  On physical examination  he appears diaphoretic and in considerable distress from pain. His blood pressure is 200/120 mmHg  pulse 112 bpm  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 90% on room air  and temperature 37.6°C (99.7°F). A grade 3/6 diastolic murmur is heard over the left second intercostal space. An examination of peripheral pulses indicates that the pulse in the right arm is diminished compared to the left arm. Neurologically  he is oriented to time  place  and person  but appears anxious.  Given his age  history  and clinical presentation  an aortic dissection is highly suspected. Immediate medical attention and relevant investigations are warranted.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. George R. is a 69-year-old African-American male presenting with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to the back between the shoulder blades  mimicking the signs and symptoms of acute myocardial infarction that began at rest. The nature of pain is sharp  tearing and excruciating. He also reports difficulty breathing with light-headedness and sweating.  Past Medical History:  He is a known hypertensive for 20 years almost on regular medication but has been poorly compliant over the past few months. His hypertension was poorly controlled  with recent BP measurements in the outpatient clinic often being above 160/100 mmHg. Furthermore  he has a history of smoking  consuming at least a pack of cigarettes daily for about 30 years.  Family History:  Mr. George has a family history of a first-degree relative (his mother) who suffered an aortic dissection at age 75.   Lifestyle and Social History:  He denies alcohol or drug use. He is a retired engineer who lives alone and has neglected his general health after his wife passed away five years ago.  Review of Systems:  No nausea  vomiting  pallor  or loss of consciousness. The pain is not related to body position or exertion and it is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient appeared uncomfortable  sweaty  and anxious. The blood pressure was found to be significantly different between the right and left arms  indicative of possible aortic dissection. The heart rate was slightly tachycardic but he was afebrile and his respiratory rate was at the upper limit of normal.  Given the severity of the pain  family history  and physical examination findings  the patient was immediately referred for cardiovascular imaging.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Brown is a 63-year-old African-American male who presents to the Emergency Department with acute onset severe chest pain that he describes as ""tearing"" and radiates to his back. He states it started suddenly about two hours ago  without any triggering factors. It's unlike any pain he's experienced before.  He has a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  existing for several years  and a prior history of smoking of about a one pack a day for 40 years  which he quit ten years ago. Incidentally  he also has familial hypercholesterolemia which is currently being managed with statins. He does not have regular checkups with his primary care physician but tries to manage his conditions as optimally as possible.  In terms of current symptoms  along with the pain  he also reports shortness of breath  feeling light-headed and experiencing palpitations. He denies experiencing any nausea  vomiting  sweating  or loss of consciousness.  He has no known allergies and is currently on Amlodipine and Atorvastatin for his blood pressure and high cholesterol respectively. There is a family history of early-onset heart disease  specifically  his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 52.

Patient Presentation:  Program: Cardiology Patient: Mr. Liston  a 62-year-old African American male Chief Complaint: Severe  sudden onset chest pain  History of Presenting Illness:  Mr. Liston states that he was having a normal day when he suddenly experienced an excruciating tearing pain in his chest that radiated through to his back  between his shoulder blades. The pain began while he was resting at home and has progressively worsened over the past hour. He describes the pain as a constant  severe  sharp  and worst he has ever felt. He denies any alleviating or exacerbating factors and states he also feels dizzy  short of breath  and nauseous. He denies history of trauma  surgery  or recent heavy lifting.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Liston has a significant history of hypertension  for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide  but admits he hasn't been compliant in taking his medications regularly  nor in monitoring his blood pressure. He also has a 20-year history of smoking  with 1 pack per day. No known allergies.  Family History:  His father died from a heart attack at the age of 67  and his mother died from stroke at the age of 64.  Social History:  Mr. Liston is a retired construction worker. He has been married for 35 years and lives with his wife. He continues to smoke but denies alcohol or illicit drug use.  Review of Systems:  No recent weight change  fevers  cough  abdominal pain  urinary symptoms  or other systemic symptoms. He reported dizziness which became worse upon changing positions. The dizziness is occasionally accompanied by diaphoresis.  Validation:  The reported details are consistent with the epidemiology of aortic dissection  which commonly occurs in hypertensive  male patients in their 60s-70s. The sudden severe chest pain  described as tearing or ripping  radiating to the back  associated with dizziness  sweating  and difficulty breathing  are common symptoms of aortic dissection. The diagnosis of aortic dissection should be considered in this patient  and he should urgently receive appropriate diagnostic studies  like a CT angiogram of the chest.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old African American male presenting in the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  sharp chest pain that started about 2 hours ago. The pain  according to him  is ""tearing"" in nature  located in the anterior chest and radiates to his back between the shoulder blades. Concurrently  he has also experienced shortness of breath  sweating  and light-headedness  hence his visit.  He has a 20-year past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension despite being on antihypertensive medications. He also reports a history of tobacco use  with a 40-pack year smoking history. Though not presently smoking  he only quit 2 years ago. Allegedly  there is no significant family history concerning cardiovascular diseases according to his knowledge.   Essential details such as his background  his known hypertension  and history of tobacco smoking are all noted as they tally with the risk factors often associated with development of aortic dissection as per literature. His demographic group (being male and African American) also makes incidence of the condition more probable when compared to women and other race groups.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of a sudden onset of severe chest pain  which he describes as a 'tearing' sensation that radiates to his back. He has never experienced this type of pain before. The patient also reports shortness of breath  nausea  and light-headedness. He rates his pain as a 10 on a scale from 0 to 10.  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which he's been taking Atenolol for the past 10 years. He also has a 20-year history of heavy smoking. There's no known history of heart disease in his family. He is a retired construction worker  currently living alone.  Physical examination reveals diaphoresis  an irregular pulse and a blood pressure of 170/105 mmHg. Breath sounds are semi-clear with coarse crackles over the left lung base. He is visibly anxious  and the pain appears unrelieved despite the administration of morphine in the ambulance en route to the hospital.  The patient's combination of severe  sudden onset chest pain  hypertension  his age  race  and smoking history- all these factors direct the differential diagnosis towards aortic dissection. Immediate diagnostic testing  including a CT scan of the chest  is warranted for further confirmation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African-American male presenting to the emergency department with severe  sharp chest and back pain that started suddenly about an hour ago. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and rates it a 10 out of 10 in terms of intensity. It started in his chest and has since radiated to his back.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which he is on amlodipine  but admits to non-compliance with his medication regimen.   He is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year history and quit 10 years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol  primarily during social outings. Mr. Johnson also has a family history of heart disease  with his father having had a heart attack in his 60s.  He denies any associated shortness of breath  cough  or abdominal pain. No loss of consciousness  dizziness  or weakness. He denies recent trauma or injury.   This presentation  in combination with his medical history  would warrant immediate investigation for possible aortic dissection which is a potentially life-threatening condition. His race  age  hypertension  and a history of smoking puts him at a higher risk for aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. A is a 60-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe  sharp chest pain radiating to the back. The discomfort started while he was having dinner about 2 hours prior to his arrival at the hospital.  He reports a history of hypertension  which has been poorly controlled over the past few years. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago  which has been managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. More recently  he had been diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia and prescribed statin therapy  but due to financial constraints  he was unable to afford the medication and subsequently stopped taking it.  He has a 30-pack-year smoking history  and drinks alcohol socially. His father had a stroke at the age of 70 and his mother passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 78.  Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg  Heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute and a temperature of 98.6°F. On auscultation of the chest  a diastolic murmur is heard along with decreased breath sounds in the left lung field.  Given the acute onset of symptoms  his longstanding uncontrolled hypertension  and relevant family history of cardiovascular events  a suspected diagnosis of aortic dissection is made. He is immediately referred for a CT scan of the chest to confirm.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Hispanic male presented to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of sudden  severe upper back pain which he described as tearing. The pain reportedly started while the patient was at rest. He also acknowledged a history of hypertension which has been partially managed but often runs high due to noncompliance with medication. His other past medical history included a smoking habit of 30 pack years and hyperlipidemia.   He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or lower extremity weakness. However  he also reported that he has been feeling light-headed since the onset of back pain. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease with his father passing due to a heart attack in his early 70s.  Upon physical examination  there was a noted difference in blood pressure between the right and left upper extremities. An immediate CT scan of the chest was ordered  which demonstrated a type B aortic dissection.  His vital signs upon arrival are as follows:  Blood pressure: 170/95 mmHg right arm  150/90 mmHg left arm Pulse: 92 beats per minute Respiration: 20 breaths per minute Temperature: 98.6°F (37°C) O2 Saturation: 96% on RA BMI: 29.6 (overweight)  Rest of the examination was unremarkable.   Note: This is an example of a concise patient presentation and does not necessarily represent all possible presentations of aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  A 66 years old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe chest pain. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" in nature  which started while he was cleaning his garage. The patient states that the pain radiated to his back and since then  continuing for several hours. He is experiencing shortness of breath but denies any nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. He has no known history of trauma or injury. The patient is diaphoretic and appears uncomfortable. He denies any similar previous episodes. He is a former smoker with 30-year pack history  quit 5 years back.   His past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension  despite being on antihypertensive therapy with a thiazide diuretic  and beta-blocker. He was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years back. He also has a known history of hyperlipidemia presently under control with statins. He reports occasional alcohol intake but denies any recreational drug use. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  his father died at the age of 60 due to myocardial infarction.  His blood pressure in right arm measured 182/98 mm Hg and 158/90 mm Hg in left arm. A grade 3/6 systolic murmur was appreciated on the left sternal border. Other physical examination findings include weak femoral pulses bilaterally. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.   This presentation is suggestive of aortic dissection and further diagnostic imaging and management would be required for confirmation and subsequent decision making.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Liu is a 65-year-old Asian male with a past medical history of long-standing uncontrolled hypertension and a 30-year history of smoking. He does not have any significant familial heart disease history.   He presents to the emergency room with severe  sudden-onset chest pain radiating to his back. He describes the pain as a ""tearing"" sensation. It started while he was lifting a heavy object at home. He does not mention any other concurrent symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  shortness of breath  or palpitations. On further examination  he exhibits unequal arm blood pressures and has a slightly decreased heart rate.  On review of his previous medical records  it's evident that his hypertension has been resistant to therapy despite being on multiple medications. His only other co-morbidity is chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) which he manages with occasional inhaler use. He has no known drug allergies. On average  he consumes two alcoholic drinks a week. He lives alone after his wife's death two years ago and has two children who live out of state.  The primary concern given Mr. Liu's presentation and history is aortic dissection  likely triggered by his chronic uncontrolled hypertension and exacerbated by his smoking history.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain characterized as ""tearing"" or ""ripping"" in nature. The pain started while the patient was at rest and has progressively worsened over the past 2 hours. It radiates to his back  particularly between the shoulder blades.  Past medical history reveals long-standing hypertension for which he has been non-compliant in taking prescribed medication. The patient also has a 20-year history of tobacco use. He is a retired construction worker. His family history is significant for an older brother who died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 59.  On examination  he appears to be in significant pain and distress  with slightly elevated blood pressure readings and an irregular pulse. The patient is breathing with some difficulty and appears sweaty and pale.   A quick bedside transthoracic echocardiogram shows signs of aortic dissection. Immediate intervention is planned.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Brown  a 60-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency room with a chief complaint of sudden severe chest pain pervading to his back. The pain  which he describes as ""tearing"" in nature  began approximately 2 hours ago and has been steadily worsening.   Mr. Brown has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which he has been non-compliant with his prescribed medication due to cost. He also has a 40-year history of smoking one pack a day but quit smoking two years ago. He has no history of surgeries or other significant illnesses.   On admission  his vital signs are: blood pressure 180/120 mmHg  pulse 95 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 97% on room air  and body temperature 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit. Physical exam reveals a man in acute distress  anxious  and profusely sweating. He has an audible systolic murmur noted on cardiac auscultation. His pulses are equal in all four extremities.  Given his presentation and history  suspicion is high for aortic dissection. An immediate CT angiography is planned to confirm the diagnosis. Mr. Brown's hypertension increases his risk factor for acute aortic dissection. His non-compliance with antihypertensive therapy may have contributed to this potential acute event. The pain description given by him is fairly characteristic of aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Davis  a 56-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department  complaining of a sudden onset  severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back for the past 4 hours. He states the pain was severe and worst when it began. In addition  he reports feeling lightheaded  shortness of breath and faint. He has no prior history of similar pain. He is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He also consumes alcohol occasionally  but denies any recreational drug use. His medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been poorly managed  and hyperlipidemia. He  however  has no history of Marfan syndrome or any familial history of cardiovascular diseases. He has not undergone any prior surgeries.   On examination  he appears profoundly diaphoretic. Initial vital signs reveal blood pressure to be 160/85 mmHg on the right arm and 145/80 mmHg on the left arm  pulse rate is 110 bpm  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  temperature is 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air.   Given these signs and his significant past medical history  aortic dissection is strongly suspected. He was immediately transferred to a resuscitation bay for further investigations and management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African-American male presenting with sudden onset of severe  tearing pain in his chest radiating to his back approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as sharp  and worse than anything he has ever experienced. His attendant also reports that the patient has been sweating and looks pale.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years  poor medication adherence and control. He smokes approximately 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol socially. There is no known history of heart diseases in the family.  Recent History:  Mr. Johnson reports no recent physical exertion  trauma  or stressful event. He went to bed feeling well  only to be awakened by the pain. He took one of his ""blood pressure pills"" at home when he felt unwell but did not notice any improvement  which prompted him to seek medical care.  Initial Physical Examination:  On physical examination  Mr. Johnson's blood pressure is found to be 190/100 mmHg. His pulse rate is 100 beats per minute with pulses palpable bilaterally in upper and lower limbs. Heart sounds are regular  without murmur. His pain does not alleviate when he leans forward. The remainder of his examination is unremarkable  and he is oriented towards time  place  and person.  Conclusions:  Considering the history and physical examination findings  the preliminary diagnosis is a suspected aortic dissection. Mr. Johnson's age  race  male sex  and history of hypertension are all significant risk factors for aortic dissection  as is his long history of smoking. The severe  tearing pain  with sudden onset and radiation to the back  is classic for aortic dissection.  Immediate Plan:  Stat EKG  chest X-ray  and if possible  CT scan of thorax are required. Pain control and antihypertensive therapy are the initial steps in management. The assessment of the severity of dissection and need for surgical intervention will depend on further diagnostic tests. His family needs to be notified and informed of seriousness of the condition.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Charles  a 70-year-old African-American retired truck driver  presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden  severe chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes the pain as ""ripping"" and ""tearing"" in nature. Neither rest nor sublingual nitroglycerin has relieved the pain. He also complains of shortness of breath  stating he feels as though he cannot catch his breath. He denies any history of trauma or cough prior to the onset of pain.  His past medical history includes hypertension  for which he is taking hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine. He is also a smoker with a pack per day habit for 30 years. He consumes alcohol in moderation. Mr. Charles has a surgical history of a bilateral hip replacement due to osteoarthritis. He mentions that his mother also had hypertension and died of a stroke  but he's unclear about the details.   Upon examination  his blood pressure is noted to be significantly higher in one arm than in the other. There are signs of early shock such as sweating  rapid heart rate  and light-headedness. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur and blood investigations show elevated levels of D-dimer.  A chest radiograph reveals mediastinal widening and a CT angiogram subsequently confirms the diagnosis of aortic dissection. The patient is immediately prepared for a potential surgery in light of the severity of the condition  his significant risk factors and presenting symptoms.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Davis is a 67-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with abrupt onset of severe chest pain. The pain started approximately an hour ago and has been increasing in intensity. Mr. Davis describes the pain as ""tearing"" and ""radiating"" towards his back.  His medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been poorly controlled over the past few years. He is a former smoker  with a history of smoking for 35 years  but quit 10 years ago. He admits to having a few occasional drinks. His family history is notable for cardiovascular disease - his older brother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and his mother had a stroke when she was 75.  On examination  there is a differential blood pressure between his arms  with the left arm reading significantly higher than the right. He presents mild sweating  pale complexion  and noticeable discomfort. His heart sounds are normal  but a 'blowing' diastolic murmur can be heard.  Mr. Davis's demographic and health profile make him a typical patient for an aortic dissection. Male sex  advanced age  and African American ethnicity are factors associated with a higher risk of aortic dissection. His long history of poorly controlled hypertension  prior smoking  and family history of cardiovascular disease further contribute to his risk profile.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Nelson  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes it as the worst pain he's ever felt  which started while he was lifting heavy items in his garage. He also reports shortness of breath and light-headedness.   His past medical history is significant for long-standing uncontrolled hypertension despite taking antihypertensive medication. He also has a 20-year history of tobacco use  and a family history of aortic diseases - a brother who had an aortic aneurysm and a father who died from complications of aortic dissection.   His vital signs upon admission include blood pressure of 165/100 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation level of 93% on room air. Examination reveals an anxious and distressed patient with diaphoresis. Furthermore  there is a discrepancy in the patient's blood pressure readings in both arms. Thus  aortic dissection is greatly suspected due to his history  present symptoms  hypertension  and varying blood pressure. Immediate diagnostic workup  including computed tomography angiography (CTA)  is initiated to confirm the diagnosis and guide appropriate management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Garcia  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe  tear-like chest pain radiating to his back.  The patient history obtained reveals that he was in his usual state of health until 1 hour prior when he suddenly felt a tearing sensation in his chest. He describes the pain as ""the worst pain I have ever experienced "" rating it a 10 on a scale of 1 to 10. The pain was followed by profuse sweating and a feeling of impending doom. He denies any associated symptoms such as palpitations  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness.  His past medical history is significant for untreated hypertension  a 20 pack-year history of smoking  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. He denies any previous diagnoses of connective tissue disorders or any history of recent trauma. He has no known drug allergies. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide which he reports sometimes missing when he feels “okay”.  On examination  he appears pale and diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg in his right arm and 160/100 mmHg in his left arm. His heart rhythm is irregularly irregular. There is a difference in the strength of his femoral and radial pulses.  The above presentation information has led to a suspicion of an aortic dissection and necessitates further diagnostic workup for confirmation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Charles is a 68-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of sharp  severe chest pain that started several hours ago. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" radiating from his chest to his upper back. He also reports shortness of breath  profuse sweating  dizziness  and weakness in his right leg.   His past medical history includes hypertension for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide  type 2 diabetes controlled on metformin  and hyperlipidemia managed on statins. He quit smoking a decade ago but consumed alcohol moderately.   Charles is a retired school principal  lives with his wife  and says he has been compliant with his medications and regular check-ups. His father had a history of cardiovascular disease and passed away due to a heart attack.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Maria Gonzalez is a 67-year-old Latina female who arrived at the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset chest pain that radiates to her back. She describes it as tearing or ripping. She rates it as a 9 out of 10 for pain intensity. Accompanying the chest pain are symptoms of lightheadedness  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating.  She is a retired school teacher and does not smoke or consume alcohol. Her BMI is in the range of obesity. She resides with her husband and has three grown-up children. She reports her compliance with social distancing and hygiene protocols given the COVID-19 situation. She has a medical history of hypertension for the past 15 years  controlled with antihypertensive medication - Losartan. She was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 5 years ago  managed by Statins.  Her family history is significant. Her father died of stroke and her mother was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and passed away due to heart failure.  Considering her severe chest pain with risk factors like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  older age  and her family history of cardiovascular diseases  an aortic dissection is suspected. The patient requires immediate imaging studies  such as a CT angiogram  to confirm the diagnosis.  Note: Aortic dissection is more common in males and in older patients (60-80 years). Aortic dissection is most commonly associated with hypertension - more than 75% of patients have a history of hypertension. The presentation may be influenced by race/ethnicity and cultural health beliefs  perceptions  and behaviors.

Patient Presentation:   A 68-year-old Hispanic male  Mr. Dominguez  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden and severe ""tearing"" pain in his chest which radiates through to his back. He describes it as ""the worst pain he has ever felt."" The pain was not associated with exertion  shortness of breath  or sweating. However  he mentions feeling dizzy and nauseated.   His past medical history is significant for poorly controlled hypertension for 10 years  a 40-pack year smoking history  and mild hyperlipidemia. His hypertension was being treated with amlodipine but he had been sporadically compliant with the medication. He has no personal or family history of connective tissue or chronic inflammatory diseases.   He lives alone and is retired. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. His current vitals show he has high blood pressure (180/100 mmHg) with differential pulse rate and blood pressure between his right and left arm. Physical examination reveals a diaphoretic patient in distress  but no cyanosis or pallor. Auscultation reveals a normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs.   Considering the acute onset of his symptoms along with his past medical history and clinical findings  a suspected diagnosis of aortic dissection is made and immediate management is initiated.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jacobs is a 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  moderate aortic stenosis  and smoking. He was brought into the emergency department by his wife with chief complaints of sudden  severe chest pain that started an hour ago at home. According to Mr. Jacob  the pain is sharp  radiating to the back  and worsens with movement.   Furthermore  he describes his pain as ""tearing"" in character  differing it from any chest pain he has had before. His wife adds that he became acutely short of breath and turned pale soon after the onset of the chest pain. He denies experiencing any nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis but admits to feeling lightheaded. He could not recall any precipitating factors or any personal or family history of such pain.   Over the past few months  despite prescribed and regular medication  his blood pressure has been poorly controlled. He has a 30-year history of tobacco and alcohol use but denies any current illicit substance use. He has not undergone any surgical procedures in the past. There is no relevant occupational or environmental exposure history.  On examination  his vitals on arrival are BP: 170/120 mmHg  Pulse: 110 bpm  RR: 22 breaths/min  Temp: 36.9 C  SpO2: 94% in the room air.   The assessment reveals an anxious looking patient with pallor  diaphoresis and slight difficulty in breathing. Cardiovascular examination is significant for a systolic murmur. Neurologically  he is oriented to time  place and person without any focal neurological deficits.  This presentation is suspicious for an aortic dissection  given Mr. Jacob's demographic factors (older age  male  African American race)  personal medical history (hypertension  aortic stenosis)  risk factors (smoking)  and clinical symptoms (sudden severe chest and back pain  shortness of breath).

Chief Complaint:  Sudden severe chest pain  History of Present Illness: A 59-year-old African American male presents with the sudden onset of severe  “tearing” chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain started about 30 minutes ago  is constant and rates 10/10. He also reports shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom. He denies any trauma  cough  fever  or recent illness. He felt well prior to the onset of the pain.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of stage 2 hypertension for 15 years and a 40-pack-year smoking history  recently quit about 6 months ago. He also has a known history of high cholesterol but has been non-compliant with his medications—Lisinopril and atorvastatin. He does not have a history of diabetes.   Family History: His father had a history of heart disease and died from a heart attack at the age of 60. His mother is alive and well with a history of hypertension.   Social History: He is married  retired. He reports drinking alcohol moderately but quit smoking 6 months ago.  Review of Systems: Positive for general malaise and mild fatigue over the past few weeks  has lost some weight recently due to a diet change to a healthier lifestyle intended to manage his high cholesterol and blood pressure. Negative for recent injuries or trauma  cough  fever  gastrointestinal symptoms  extremity pain/numbness  or neurological changes.  Physical Exam: He appears acutely distressed. Vital signs are temperature 37°C  pulse 110 beats per minute  respiration rate 18 breaths per minute  blood pressure 170/110 mm Hg in the right arm  and 150/90 mm Hg in the left arm. There is a grade III/VI systolic murmur heard loudest at the right second intercostal space. The rest of his physical exam is otherwise unremarkable  with normal heart and lung sounds  and no obvious signs of trauma or injury.  Based on the patient's presenting symptoms  aortic dissection is suspected and the necessary diagnostic tests (e.g.  CT angiogram) would be ordered urgently.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Davis is a 62-year-old African-American male presenting to the emergency department with sudden  severe chest pain described as ""ripping"" in nature. The pain was sudden onset while lifting heavy objects at work and has been progressively worsening over the hour. He mentions that the pain seems to be radiating to his back between his shoulder blades. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  dizziness  and profuse sweating.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Davis has a chronic history of uncontrolled hypertension that he attributes to inconsistent medication usage. He also has a history of cigarette smoking  approximately 10-15 cigarettes per day  for the last 30 years. He was diagnosed with early-stage chronic kidney disease two years ago  but has had no other severe cardiovascular-related issues. There is no family history of Marfan Syndrome or connective tissue disorders.   Demographic Details:  According to his demographics  Mr. Davis is an active worker who is still involved in heavy lifting at his construction job. He is married with three grown children. Though he acknowledges his unhealthy habits and chronic disease history  he expresses lax concern due to his necessity to continue work and provide for his family.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain of sudden onset. The pain is described as ""ripping"" or ""tearing "" radiating to his back.   The pain started roughly two hours ago and has been relentless since. He also reports lightheadedness  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating.   Past Medical History:  Patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  which has been poorly controlled. He also has a history of high cholesterol and 40 pack years smoking history. He had a history of IV drug use in his early adulthood but has been sober for more than 30 years now.  There is no known family history of any cardiovascular diseases. Other significant history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with oral medications  and mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).   Social History:  Mr. Doe is a retired factory worker and currently lives with his wife in their own house. He states that he quit smoking 8 years ago  but he continues to consume moderate quantities of alcohol (1-2 glasses of whiskey most nights). His diet is high in processed and fast foods. He has a sedentary lifestyle and rarely exercises.  Patient’s hypertension and smoking history in addition to his age and ethnicity potentially predispose him to a higher risk of developing an aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  A 63-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset central chest pain that radiates through to the back. The patient describes the pain as ""tearing"" and rates it as 10/10 in severity. He indicates that the pain started about two hours ago and has been constant since. Associated symptoms include profuse sweating and nausea.  The patient has a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  smoking for 30 years  and an earlier diagnosis of Marfan syndrome. He is currently on medication for his hypertension  but admits to missing several doses over the past week. His father had a history of aortic aneurysm and his younger brother had an aortic dissection in his late fifties.  He denies any history of trauma. There is no change in vision  speech  or strength in any of his four extremities. Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 175/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.  The patient appears anxious and in severe distress  and there are signs of early shock with cold  clammy skin. A systolic murmur is audible on auscultation. Neurological examination does not show any signs of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a height of 5'10"" and weight of 220 pounds  presenting with sudden onset of severe chest and upper back pain radiating to the neck. The pain is described as “ripping” or “tearing” and began approximately 1 hour prior to presentation during a vigorous attempt to lift a heavy object at work. The patient states that the pain is unlike anything he's previously experienced and rates it 10 out of 10 in severity.   He has a past medical history significant for poorly controlled hypertension  a 40-pack year smoking history  and a familial history of aortic disease. On physical examination  the patient exhibits elevated blood pressures  specifically 185/115 mm Hg. The patient also displays differential blood pressures between his arms  with the left arm reading notably lower than the right. There are no known drug allergies. He takes Lisinopril for his hypertension but is often non-compliant.   In light of this presentation  the primary suspicion is an acute aortic dissection. Given the patient's history of hypertension and the occurrence of the pain during a period of straining  the pieces fit together for this diagnosis. An urgent CT angiogram is recommended to confirm the suspicion and assess the extent of the dissection.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old African American male presented to the Emergency Department with acute onset severe chest pain  described as ""tearing"" in nature that started about 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to his back.  Relevant demographic information:  The patient is a retired blue-collar worker  weighing approximately 210 lbs  with a height of 5'9""  making him +50 lbs overweight for his height. He is a current smoker with 20 pack-years of smoking history. He has a lifetime of high occupational stress. He resides in an urban setting and is a widower  living alone.  Relevant past medical history:  His medical history is significant for grade-2 hypertension which has been poorly controlled. He reports non-compliance with his medication as he ""feels fine"" without them. He also has a 20-year history of Type II diabetes mellitus  although it has been managed through diet and exercise  with HbA1c usually ranging between 7.5 – 8.0%. His cholesterol levels have been borderline high on his recent general check-up. Additionally  he has been taking over-the-counter NSAIDs most days for chronic knee pain. His family history is significant: his father died of a heart attack at age 65 and his brother had a stroke at age 60.   His surgical history includes an appendectomy at age 20. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use  and lives a fairly sedentary lifestyle. He has no known drug allergies.   He has been taking Amlodipine 5mg  Metformin 1000mg  and Lisinopril 10mg  daily for his underlying conditions but admits to periodic noncompliance  particularly with his anti-hypertensive medication.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Davis  a 68-year-old African American man presents to the Emergency Department with severe chest pain. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and radiating to his back  starting abruptly about two hours ago. He rates the pain as a 10 on a scale from 0 to 10.  Demographics:   Mr. Davis is a retired construction worker and a widower  living with his daughter. He has a 30-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and was a smoker for 40 years (2 packs/day). His father died at 71 with a similar chest pain  later diagnosed as aortic dissection at autopsy.   Past Medical History:   The patient's past medical history includes Hypertension  Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease from prolonged smoking  Hyperlipidemia and Peripheral Arterial Disease. He had a myocardial infarction in his late 50s  but has been non-compliant with his heart medications  including his antihypertensives. His last recorded BP at a check-up a month ago was 180/100 mmHg.   Physical Examination:   Upon examination  his blood pressure is significantly different in both arms. Other pertinent findings include a diastolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space  suggesting aortic regurgitation. Neurological examination shows mild lower limb weakness and decreased reflexes. The patient is anxious and diaphoretic.   This information above is based on general demographic trends and individual variations are  of course  important. Aortic dissection tends to occur more frequently in males and African Americans and is often associated with hypertension and smoking. There may be a genetic component given his family history.   These symptoms paired with Mr. Davis' past medical history are highly suggestive of an aortic dissection and should be treated as a medical emergency.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to his back for the past two hours. The pain is described as ""tearing"" in nature. Patient feels light-headed and reports of mild shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 10 years and smokes about a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. Patient was also recently diagnosed with moderate atherosclerosis but is not on any regular medication due to non-compliance. He states that he occasionally takes over-the-counter pain relievers for frequent headaches  which could be indicative of his high blood pressure.  Social History:  The patient lives alone. He was a construction worker but has been retired for the past four years. He has a history of heavy alcohol use but quit two years ago.  Family History:  His father had a stroke at the age of 65 and died of a myocardial infarction at 70.   Review of Systems:  On further review systems  the patient reported he is experiencing some difficulty in breathing and has had a few episodes of cough. Patient also noted that he has been having intermittent bouts of nausea since the start of his chest pain.   Physical Examination:  Upon examination  his blood pressure was found to be significantly different between two arms (160/90 mmHg in right arm; 110/80 mmHg in left arm). He appeared pale and anxious. Cardiac auscultation revealed a weak pulse  and a diastolic murmur heard best over the right second intercostal space. Lung fields were clear bilaterally. His pulses were reduced  more noticeably in the lower extremities compared to the upper. His neurologic examination was normal.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Mohammed is a 63-year-old African American male who has presented to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain that started an hour ago. He describes the pain as sharp  radiating from his chest to his back. It’s unlike any pain he has had before. Additionally  he mentions experiencing shortness of breath. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for ten years and cigarette smoking of 15 pack-years. He is not on any regular medications. He denies any previous cardiac history or surgeries. His father had an aortic dissection at the age of 70. He currently works as a taxi driver and lives with his wife. He denies alcohol use but admits that despite being advised to quit smoking multiple times by his primary care physician  he has not been successful.  On examination  his blood pressure is found to be significantly different in two arms  he has a regular pulse and normal heart sounds  but there is decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. His ECG shows no ischemic changes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. White is a 64-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency room with sudden onset  severe chest pain that started about one hour ago. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and radiating to the back. The patient also reports shortness of breath  nausea  and weakness.  He has a significant past medical history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  high cholesterol  and being a former smoker  having quit ten years ago after a mild heart attack. He reports adherence to medications  including metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.  On examination  the patient appears acutely distressed with evident perspiration. Vital signs show blood pressure of 170/105 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 28  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. There is a notable discrepancy in blood pressure between both arms.  Further examination reveals diminished pulses in the legs and a systolic murmur can be heard on auscultation of the heart. Chest X-ray  Electrocardiogram  and CT Angiography are planned for further evaluation suspecting an aortic dissection. The patient is managed with aggressive blood pressure control while awaiting definitive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: A 67-year-old African American male patient presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The pain came on abruptly about two hours ago and has gradually increased since it began. The patient described it as the ""worst pain of his life.""   Past medical history is significant for hypertension which has been poorly controlled despite treatment. The patient mentions he has been non-compliant with his anti-hypertensive medication due to financial constraints. He also has a history of 40 pack years of smoking  though he quit 10 years ago. He denies any use of cocaine or other illicit substances.   His vitals on presentation showed a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg  heart rate was 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation was 92% on room air and he was afebrile. Physical exam revealed a diaphoretic patient in distress  with diminished pulses in the left upper extremity compared to the right. There were no obvious external signs of trauma.   The high suspicion for aortic dissection prompted an immediate computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest  which confirmed the diagnosis of acute type A aortic dissection. The patient was emergently transferred to the CV surgical team for management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Roberts  a 70-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain that started approximately two hours ago. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" in nature  and mentions it radiates to his back. The patient also complains of shortness of breath  but denies any associated symptoms such as cough  nausea  vomiting  or palpitations.  He has a past medical history significant for uncontrolled high blood pressure  for which he has been non-compliant with his prescribed medications  specifically  Lisinopril  which he hasn't been taking regularly due to financial constraints. He also has a history of cigarette smoking for the past 50 years and occasional alcohol. There is no known personal or family history of heart disease  thoracic injuries  or connective tissue disorders.  On examination  he appears in distress due to severe pain  is sweaty  and has an increased respiratory rate. During the physical examination  blood pressure measurements display significant discrepancy between his two upper extremities.  Given his presenting symptoms  demographic characteristics  history of long-standing hypertension  and difference in blood pressure between extremities  a working diagnosis of aortic dissection is made and he is rapidly evaluated for appropriate management. His uncontrolled hypertension and his smoking habit are possible contributory factors for his current condition. The patient is therefore advised for immediate cardiovascular imaging for the confirmation of this diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 62-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset  severe pain in his chest radiating to his back. He describes the pain as 'tearing' and progressively worsening for the last 2 hours.  He states the pain started while he was doing yard work. He admits experiencing shortness of breath but denies nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and dyslipidemia. Mr. Doe has been quite non-compliant with his medication regimen. He has a 40-pack-year history of smoking and admits to consume moderate amounts of alcohol on weekends. His family history reveals that his father died from an 'aortic aneurysm.'   On a physical exam  he appears anxious and diaphoretic. His blood pressure is 175/110 mmHg  pulse rate 100 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 22 per minute. There's a difference in blood pressure readings between both arms. And a systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space. The rest of the examination findings including neurologic exam were unremarkable.   His ECG revealed left ventricular hypertrophy but no evidence of acute ischemic changes. The chest X-ray was concerning for mediastinal widening.  This presentation is highly suspicious for thoracic aortic dissection  and the patient is immediately scheduled for a CT aortogram to confirm the diagnosis  and the cardiology team is consulted for further management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old African American male presents to the emergency room with severe  sudden chest pain. He describes the pain as very sharp and ""tearing "" and says it started about 2 hours ago. He rates the pain as a 10 out of 10. He also reports feeling short of breath.   On examination  he's found to be hypertensive  with a blood pressure of 190/100. His pulse rate is 110 beats per minute. There is also a discrepancy in blood pressure readings between his left and right arms. His breathing rate is 22 breaths per minute.   His past medical history reveals long-standing uncontrolled hypertension  for which he denies taking his prescribed medication regularly. He also has a history of tobacco use  with approximately 40 pack-years.  Initial EKG findings reveal no signs of myocardial infarction  and due to his symptoms and risk factors  a CT angiogram is ordered that confirms the diagnosis of aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 62-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that began approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" in nature and radiating to his back  concentrated more on the upper back. He rates the pain as 10/10. He also reports feeling a general weakness along with a mild headache. His medical history is significant for hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and a long history of tobacco use (smoked 1 pack per day for last 40 years). He has been on Lisinopril and Atorvastatin for the past 10 years for his hypertension and cholesterol  respectively. His family history reveals his father had an aortic aneurysm and died at the age of 72 from an unknown cause.  Upon examination  his blood pressure is significantly higher in the right arm (200/110mmHg)  compared to the left arm (150/90mmHg). Pulse exam reveals slightly delayed pulses in the lower extremities compared to the upper. Auscultation of the heart reveals a faint early diastolic murmur. Neurological examination reveals mild disorientation and confusion.  Given his symptoms  clinical examination  high-risk factors  including male sex  advanced age  hypertension  smoking history  high cholesterol  and a family history of aortic disease (father's aortic aneurysm)  there is a high index of suspicion of aortic dissection.

A 67-year-old African-American male  retired labor worker  visits the emergency department with extreme chest pain that he describes as tearing which started suddenly while he was having dinner. The pain seems to radiate to the back. He also complains of shortness of breath and weakness in his legs. His wife  who accompanied him  mentioned that he turned pale and was sweating profusely. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past ten years and a long-standing smoking habit of 40 years with an average of one pack a day. He also has mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm 3 years ago. His father died at 60 due to an cardiovascular accident. He admits to not taking his prescribed antihypertensive medications consistently and doesn't follow a specific diet or exercise routine.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Williams is a 70-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  sharp  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The pain began approximately 3 hours ago. He states the pain is unlike anything he has experienced before.   He has a known medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide and has had a hard time keeping it under control. He is also a former smoker with a history of 20 pack-years. He has no known history of coronary artery disease or high cholesterol. There is no family history of aortic dissection or connective tissue disorders.   Patient's vitals reveal a blood pressure of 175/100 mmHg and HR of 100 bpm. Physical examination reveals asymmetrical blood pressure in both arms  diaphoresis  and diminished pulse in the left arm.   This demographic and clinical presentation is consistent with a high risk for aortic dissection  which is more common in males  in the older population and particularly among African American patients. Uncontrolled hypertension and smoking are significant risk factors for aortic dissection as well.

A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department reporting sudden-onset  severe chest pain that started 1 hour prior. The pain was tearing in nature and radiated through to his back  prompting him to seek medical attention. His wife also mentioned that he seemed confused and had difficulties speaking during the car ride to the hospital. He denied any associated symptoms like palpitations  shortness of breath  or sweating.   The patient has a known history of poorly controlled systemic hypertension for the past 20 years and a 40 pack-year smoking history. His father had suffered from an aortic dissection at an older age. He does not have a history of drug use. His medication regimen included Lisinopril and Amlodipine for hypertension  but his adherence to therapy was self-reported as inconsistent. He is retired and lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. He does not consume alcohol and has stopped smoking 5 years ago.  Upon presentation  his vitals are: Blood Pressure right arm - 210/117 mmHg  left arm - 160/97 mmHg; Heart Rate - 91 beats per minute; Respiratory Rate - 17 breaths per minute; Temperature - 98.6°F; Oxygen Saturation - 98% on room air. The physical examination reveals a slight decrease in strength in the patient's right arm and leg with somewhat slurred speech pointing towards a possible neurologic deficit.  Given his history and presentation  an immediate workup for suspected aortic dissection is initiated  including CT angiography  EKG  and cardiac enzymes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old African American male  who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as tearing or ripping and started approximately an hour ago. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  type II diabetes  and smokes one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His family history revealed that his father had died of aortic dissection at the age of 60. On presentation  his blood pressure is 200/110 mmHg and his heart rate is 110 beats per minute. His weight is 220 pounds with a height of 5'8"". His BMI is classified as obese and he admits lack of regular exercise and high calorie diet intake.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James is a 68-year-old African American male presenting with a sudden severe pain in the center of his chest  which radiated through to his back between his shoulder blades  with an onset around two hours ago. Patient describes the pain as a tearing or ripping sensation. His medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension and a smoking habit of 30 years. There is no history of trauma. On physical examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic  with blood pressure measurements significantly different in the two arms and a weak pulse in the right arm. Lung auscultation reveals faint diastolic murmur  but no visible chest deformities or contusions. No neurological deficits noted at the time of examination. He denies any recent cough  fever  headache  or visual changes. Family history includes a brother who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is retired from his job as a construction worker and lives with his wife.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anthony Anderson is a 65-year-old African American male who presents to the Emergency Department (ED) reporting severe  ripping chest pain that started suddenly about 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to his back and is described as the ""worst pain of his life."" He reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. He denies any history of trauma or injury.  Mr. Anderson has a medical history significant for unchecked hypertension  a 45-pack a year history of smoking  and a previous myocardial infarction approximately two years ago for which he underwent stenting. His medications include Aspirin  Lisinopril  and Amlodipine; however  he is not consistent in taking his medications due to financial restrictions.   On physical examination  he seems extremely anxious and diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 185/110 mm Hg in his right arm and 160/95 mm Hg in his left. Heart rate is 110 beats per minute and respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute. Auscultation reveals a harsh systolic murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space. Neurologic examination shows unequal pupil size  likely indicating compromised blood flow to the brain.  This clinical presentation of sudden onset of severe chest pain  history of hypertension  and the age  gender  and ethnicity of the patient raise strong suspicion for aortic dissection. Due to the high mortality rate associated with this condition  rapid diagnosis and treatment are crucial. He is planned for immediate management and diagnostic imaging to confirm the suspicion of aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male  presents in the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset chest pain radiating to his back. He describes it as a tearing or ripping sensation. He also complains of shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Johnson has a documented history of hypertension which has been poorly controlled over the years. He also had a history of smoking tobacco for around 20 years but quit smoking 10 years ago. Furthermore  he underwent an open cholecystectomy 8 years ago.  Family History:  His father passed away at the age of 70 due to a stroke and his mother has well-controlled hypertension. His eldest brother died at age 67 from a heart attack.   Social History:  He is a retired construction worker  living with his wife and dog. He denies alcohol use  but admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years  though he claims he quit 10 years ago.   Discussion:  The patient’s presentation fits with a potential diagnosis of aortic dissection  which typically presents as abrupt severe chest or back pain  often described as tearing  ripping  or shearing in nature. This condition is most common in men in their 60s and 70s  and African Americans are disproportionately affected. The patient's history of long-standing hypertension and smoking both represent significant risk factors for aortic dissection. Given the seriousness of this condition  immediate attention and intervention are crucial.

A 65-year-old African-American man presents to the emergency department complaining of acute onset  severe chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain started suddenly about two hours ago  and is described as “tearing” or “ripping.” He rates the pain as being 10 out of 10 in severity. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which has been poorly controlled. He is a former smoker and quit 5 years. He denies having any past episodes of such severe pain. On physical examination  he is found to have a significantly elevated blood pressure and a rapid pulse.
