Title: A Case Study of Aortic Dissection  1. Introduction We present the case of a 65-year-old black male known with hypertension  who reported to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain described as ""tearing"" in nature.  2. Demographics Aortic dissections are more common in men  the ratio is approximately 2-3:1. According to literature  black men are at a higher risk compared to their white counterparts. Majority of the patients are between 60-80 years old with a median age of 63. Our patient falls in this age group thus representative of the demographic distribution in the literature.  3. Past Medical History The patient has a 10-years long history of hypertension and reveals non-compliance with antihypertensive medication due to side-effect concerns. Hypertension is one of the leading risk factors for aortic dissection  observed in about 75% of cases.  4. Presenting Complaint The patient reported severe chest pain with a sudden onset  which he described as sharp  tearing  and radiating to the back. Such pain is typical in over 90% of patients with aortic disfunctions.  5. Further Evaluations On examination  a difference in blood pressure between both arms was noted  a classic sign pointing towards an aortic dissection. The ECG showed no signs of acute myocardial infarction.  6. Investigations CTA confirmed the diagnosis of a Stanford type A aortic dissection  extending from the ascending aorta to the superior mesenteric artery.  7. Management The patient was started on intravenous beta-blockers to control blood pressure and heart rate  and he underwent emergent surgical repair to replace the dissected part of the aorta with a synthetic graft.  8. Conclusion While being a relatively rare pathology  aortic dissection carries high morbidity and mortality rates if not promptly diagnosed and treated. Patient's demographic data  history of hypertension  and classic clinical presentation  are all key components to suspicion and diagnostic confirmation.  9. Discussion Understanding the typical demographic and clinical presentation of such cases primes us well for quicker identification and management  thereby increasing survival rates and reducing complications.    Note: All Confidentiality and HIPAA Guidelines were maintained during the creation of this hypothetical case.

Title: A Case Study: Aortic Dissection in a 65-year-old Male with Hypertension  Slide 1: Introduction This presentation discusses the case of a 65-year-old faced with aortic dissection  a critical circulatory system disorder  and the potential impact of his past medical history on his current health condition.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Patient: 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  non-smoker  with moderate alcohol consumption. Location: Living in the urban Midwest  USA  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Our patient has a history of untreated hypertension for the past ten years. He also had mild high cholesterol levels but no history of diabetes  autoimmune diseases  connective tissue disorders  heart disease  or previous surgeries.  Slide 4: Aortic Dissection - High Risk Groups Aortic dissection  more common in men than women  typically affects those between 60 and 80 years old. It’s often linked with hypertension  which our patient had. Smoking and consumption of alcohol can also increase the risk of this condition.  Slide 5: Current Presentation The patient presented with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the back  initially thought to be a heart attack. Upon examination  a marked difference in blood pressure between the right and left arm was detected  raising suspicion of aortic dissection.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests  A CT scan further confirmed the diagnosis  revealing a Stanford Type A aortic dissection  which involves the ascending aorta and is considered a surgical emergency.  Slide 7: Importance of Hypertension in Aortic Dissection Chronic hypertension can cause prolonged mechanical stress on the aortic wall  leading to intimal tearing and the formation of an aortic dissection. In our patient's case  uncontrolled hypertension was the leading risk factor.  Slide 8: Conclusion Early diagnosis and immediate management are crucial in patients with aortic dissection due to the high risk of rupture and potential life-threatening complications. This case highlights the importance of regular monitoring and control of hypertension  a major risk factor for developing aortic dissection.  Slide 9: Lessons Learned Preventive approach towards hypertension and regular checkups for individuals of high-risk groups can immensely alleviate the risk of such dangerous conditions. As medical professionals  it is our responsibility to raise awareness  promote preventive measures  and ensure early detection and treatment.

Title: A Clinical Presentation on Aortic Discretion: A Case Study   Slide 1: Introduction  Topic: Aortic Dissection   Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Here  we present a case of a 65-year-old Caucasian male  John Doe  presenting with aortic dissection. This demographic (older Caucasian males) represents a significant proportion of aortic dissection cases. However  aortic dissection affects both sexes  all races  and all age groups.  Slide 3: Patient’s Previous Medical History  John Doe was diagnosed with uncontrolled hypertension ten years ago. His reluctance towards consistent medication usage and poor lifestyle behaviors contribute to his hypertension. He also has a history of tobacco use  which has compounded his risk of developing aortic dissection. Both hypertension and smoking are well documented as being significant risk factors for aortic dissection.  Slide 4: Symptoms and Presentation  John presents with sudden severe chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain is described as tearing in nature. John also exhibits symptoms of nausea  vomiting  and profuse sweating.   Slide 5: Physical Exam and Diagnosis Upon examination  John had differing blood pressure readings in his arms. A subsequent CT angiography confirmed the suspicion of aortic dissection  defining it as type B as it originated distal to the left subclavian artery.  Slide 6: Overview of Aortic Dissection  Aortic Dissection is a serious condition characterized by a tear in the aorta's inner layer. This leads to the formation of two pathways for blood flow  thus weakening the aorta's structure and increasing the risk of rupture.  Slide 7: Treatment and Prevention Treatment options are rooted in mitigating high blood pressure  the primary risk factor. Beta-blockers are preferred  although other antihypertensives may be used. John should also cease smoking. In severe cases like John’s where the risk of rupture is high  surgical intervention may be necessary.  Slide 8: Conclusion Effective management of John’s aortic dissection primarily focuses on controlling his hypertension and encouraging lifestyle modifications to reduce future risk. This case illustrates the importance of educating patients on the adverse risks of uncontrolled hypertension and the profound effect lifestyle changes can have in mitigating those risks.  Slide 9: References A prospective review of relevant literature on aortic dissection  demographics  and risk factors.

Title: A Case of Aortic Dissection in an Adult Male  Slide 1: Introduction Aortic dissection is a potentially lethal illness and quickly manifests as a medical emergency. The following real-world case presentation reportedly involved a 55-year-old African-American male with risk factors that align with the demographic most commonly afflicted with this condition in the literature.  Slide 2: Patient Background & Past Medical History The patient is a 55-year-old African-American male  with a history of hypertension and high cholesterol. He's also a long-time smoker  with a 30-pack year smoking history. These conditions  notably hypertension and smoking  make this demographic specifically vulnerable to aortic dissection.  Slide 3: Presenting Complaints & Symptoms The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain that began unexpectedly. It radiates to his back and is described as ""tearing"" or ""ripping."" The pain has persisted for 3 hours since onset. The patient also reported nausea  light-headedness  and shortness of breath.  Slide 4: Physical Examination & Investigations  On physical examination  the patient was uncomfortable  with sweat beads on his forehead. His blood pressure was 180/120 mmHg with a split difference between the left and right arm. He had a weakened pulse in the lower extremities in comparison to the upper. This heightened the suspicion of aortic dissection. Upon conducting a CT scan  it revealed a Type B aortic dissection.  Slide 5: Course of Treatment The patient was initially managed for pain and hypertension. He was started on IV beta-blockers to control blood pressure and heart rate. As it was a type B (it did not involve the ascending aorta)  a conservative treatment approach was favored initially. Ongoing monitoring and repeated imaging have been advised to detect early signs of potential complications.  Slide 6: Conclusions & Learning Points This case underscores the importance of noting risk factors in relation to demographic data. It emphasizes the need for prompt recognition and immediate diagnostic testing for swift management of aortic dissection. Early detection dramatically improves outcomes  underlining the need for high clinical suspicion in similar patients.   Merely relying on population and demographic data can lead to delayed diagnosis and poorer outcomes in high-risk individuals  as aortic dissection is a medical emergency. Therefore  it is crucial to heighten the awareness of its risk factors and typical presentations among healthcare professionals.

Title: A Case on Aortic Dissection  Slide 1: Introduction - Description: A rare yet fatal medical condition  Aortic Dissection is a serious risk to cardiovascular health predominantly affecting males over the age of 60.   Slide 2: Demographics - Description: Aortic Dissection mostly onset in the sixth to seventh decade of life with a distinct male predominance - roughly 65% of patients. Hypertension is the most common risk factor accounted for nearly 75% of cases.  Slide 3: Patient Profile - Description: Mr. X  a 70-year-old male  with a past medical history of untreated hypertension and smoking  presented with severe chest and back pain  described as ""tearing"".   Slide 4: Past Medical History - Description: The patient has been living with uncontrolled hypertension for over a decade and had had a smoking habit of 20 years until his cessation five years ago. There is no known history of heart disease in the family.  Slide 5: Symptoms and Signs - Description: Apart from severe pain  the patient showed symptoms of clammy skin  nausea  shortness of breath  and altered pulse rate. Potential differential includes Acute Myocardial Infarction  which was ruled out through ECG and cardiac serum markers.  Slide 6: Diagnosis - Description: Based on the intense pain along with pulse deficit  suspected aortic dissection was confirmed via a CT scan showing an intimal flap dividing the aortic lumen  a definitive sign of aortic dissection.  Slide 7: Conclusion - Description: Prompt assessment of this high-risk patient led to immediate diagnosis. This case emphasizes the criticality of recognizing atypical presentations of common diseases in geriatric populations  especially those with a history of hypertension and habit of smoking.    References:  - Clinical manifestations and diagnosis of acute aortic dissection. (2020). In UpToDate. Waltham  MA: UptoDate Inc. - Erbel  R.  Aboyans  V.  Boileau  C.  et al. (2014).ESC Guidelines on the diagnosis and treatment of aortic diseases. European Heart Journal  35(41)  2873–2926.

Title: Aortic Dissection: A Case Review  Slide 1: Introduction An overview of Aortic Dissection  a serious cardiovascular condition where the inner layer of the aorta tears  allowing blood to surge into the walls of the aorta. Happens mostly in men  aged 60-70 years.   Slide 2: Patient Profile Patient X is a 65-year-old African-American male who presents with severe  sudden chest pain radiating to the back  a common symptom of aortic dissection. He is a retired construction worker with a 40-year smoking history.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Patient X has a documented history of untreated hypertension  a significant risk factor for aortic dissection. He also has mild hyperlipidemia and a paternal family history of aortic dissection. Still  he has never been screened for the condition.  Slide 4: Current Health Status Patient's blood pressure is highly asymmetrical: 170/100 mmHg on the right  and 130/80 mmHg on the left  indicating potential aortic dissection. He exhibits signs of mild distress and anxiety  typical in sudden painful conditions like this.  Slide 5: Investigations Computed tomography (CT) with contrast and a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) will be arranged immediately to establish diagnosis. Additional lab investigations including complete blood count  coagulation profile  kidney function tests etc. will be done simultaneously.  Slide 6: Potential Diagnosis The presenting symptoms  coupled with the patient's medical history  predominantly suggest aortic dissection. If confirmed  classification into Stanford Type A or B will dictate the treatment plan.  Slide 7: Intervention & Treatment If a diagnosis of aortic dissection is confirmed  management will first stabilize the patient hemodynamically  followed by urgent surgical intervention (for Stanford A) or medical therapy with possible endovascular intervention (Stanford B).  Slide 8: Long Term Management  A tailored protocol including strict blood pressure control  regular aorta imaging and lifestyle modifications  like smoking cessation  will be planned.  Slide 9: Conclusion  It is pivotal to promptly diagnose and treat aortic dissections  given their grave prognosis. It also highlights the essentialness of regular screenings in high-risk individuals.  Slide 10: References Bibliography showcasing the references for the information provided throughout the presentation.

Title: Understanding Aortic Dissection: A Case Review  Slide 1: Introduction - Aortic dissection is a serious condition that occurs when the inner layer of the aorta tears. Blood surges through the tear  causing the inner and middle layers of the aorta to separate (dissect). - It can lead to fatal complications including stroke and heart failure.    Slide 2: Demographics and Epidemiology - Aortic dissection affects approximately 5 to 30 individuals per 1 million every year. - The condition commonly affects men aged 60 to 70  however it can occur at any age. - A higher prevalence is observed in African American populations compared to Whites.    Slide 3: Patient Case Overview - Subject: Male  African American  Age: 65. - Occupation: Retired engineer.    Slide 4: Medical History - History of high blood pressure (hypertension) poorly controlled over the course of 15 years. - Previous history of smoking (20 cigarettes/day for 30 years). - No known allergies. - Family history of aortic aneurysm.    Slide 5: Presenting Symptoms - The patient arrived at the Emergency Department reporting sudden severe chest pain described as ""tearing"" in nature  radiating to the back. - Associated with shortness of breath and profuse sweating.    Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests and Findings - ECG showed non-specific findings. - Chest radiograph indicated a widened mediastinum. - Computed tomography (CT) angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection  Stanford Type A.    Slide 7: Treatment and Prognosis - On presentation  the patient was immediately stabilized  and cardiothoracic surgery was notified. - The patient underwent an emergency ascending aortic repair with replacement of aortic valve. - Postoperative course was uneventful  and the patient was discharged with proper medication including beta blockers and antihypertensive drugs  and instructions to control blood pressure tightly. - Regular follow-up appointments were scheduled with Cardiology.     Slide 8: Conclusion - This case reinforces that improper management of hypertension can lead to serious health problems such as aortic dissection. - Healthcare professionals must ensure proper blood pressure and regular follow-ups for high-risk patients to avoid life-threatening complications.  Slide 9: Questions and Answers - Open for discussion and questions.  Slide 10: References - Cite sources reviewed to prepare this case presentation.

Title: A Case Presentation on Aortic Dissection   Slide 1: Introduction Today  we will be discussing a case which centers upon aortic dissection  a life-threatening condition characterized by a tear in the aorta's inner layer. A CT angiography was ordered and confirmed the diagnosis.  Slide 6: Diagnosis The patient was diagnosed with Type A aortic dissection that is proximal and involves the ascending aorta. He was transferred to the ICU for close monitoring post-surgery. He then participated in a cardiac rehabilitation program to aid in his recovery. Slide 9: Conclusion It is imperative to take into account the demographic and risk factors associated with aortic dissection along with presenting symptoms to ensure speedy diagnosis and effective management. Preventative measures and lifestyle changes play a significant role in managing conditions such as aortic dissection  where risk factors such as hypertension  smoking  and family history are prevalent.

Title: Aortic Dissection: A Case Study   Slide 1: Demographics & Identity  Patient Profile: 60-year-old African-American male. Research reveals that aortic dissection is most common in males aged 60 to 70. African Americans have the highest incidence of aortic dissection.  Slide 2: Past Medical History  Our patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension - a prominent risk factor of aortic dissection. He was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago. He also has a history of smoking  another contributing factor. He does not have any family history of connective tissue disorders.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms Four days ago  the patient started experiencing severe chest pain radiating to his back. He describes this as tearing or ripping. He also reported feeling weak on his left side and fainting two times.   Slide 4: Physical Examination On examination  his blood pressure was significantly different between the two arms  and a diastolic murmur was heard suggesting aortic regurgitation. Neurological examination revealed mild left-sided weakness.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Assessment Results from a CT angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection  Stanford Type A. There was an intimal flap in the ascending aorta extending into the aortic arch.  Slide 6: Treatment & Management An emergency surgical intervention was performed to repair the dissection to avoid fatal complications. After hospital discharge  a strict blood pressure control regimen is recommended to minimize the risk of recurrence along with cessation of smoking.  Slide 7: Discussion This case highlights the importance of maintaining the control of hypertension  one of the significant risk factors of aortic dissection. Though African Americans have a higher chance of occurring this condition  yet early detection  control of risk factors  and immediate surgical intervention can prevent fatal outcomes.   Slide 8: Conclusion  While aortic dissection is rare  it is a potentially life-threatening condition. High suspicion index  early diagnosis  and prompt surgical management - as was done in this case - are key to patient survival.

Title: Aortic Dissection: A Case Presentation  Slide 1: Introduction We present the case of a 65-year-old Caucasian male patient  historically underrepresented in the literature  with aorta dissection. This case is of particular interest due to the patient's initially ambiguous presentation and swift progression.  Slide 2: Demographics  Our patient is reflective of typical demographics associated with aortic dissection  with a median age of 63 and male predominance (65%).  Slide 3: Patient Profile  The patient is a smoker with a 45 pack-year history. He continues to consume a moderate amount of alcohol. His family history is significant  with a mother and brother dying of heart attacks in their 60s.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  Our patient has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He also experienced an uncomplicated myocardial infarction 15 years ago  which was medically managed. His medications include a statin  beta-blocker  and ACE inhibitor.   Slide 5: Presenting Symptoms  The patient presented complaints of sudden  intense chest pain  describing it as a tearing sensation. The pain radiated to the back. He also described shortness of breath and a feeling of impending doom.  Slide 6: Physical Examination  The observation underlined acute distress. Blood pressure varied between arms  and a murmur was noted in the aortic area. Pulse was irregular  and respiratory distress was noted.   Slide 7: Diagnostic Evaluation  Notable findings included D-dimer elevation and chest X-ray demarcating a widened mediastinum. A CT angiogram conclusively identified an aortic dissection  categorized as Stanford Type A.  Slide 8: Summary This case illustrates the importance of considering an aortic dissection in a differential diagnosis when an elderly  hypertensive male presents with acute  severe chest pain. Its onset and rapid escalation highlight the importance of swift diagnosis and treatment in these cases.

Title: Aortic Dissection: A Clinical Case Study.  Slide 1: Introduction • This presentation involves a case study of aortic dissection  a serious cardiovascular disease. Our focus is to understand the diagnosis  treatment and management aspects.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics • Patient X is a 65-year-old African American Man. Statistically  males are at higher risk  and the disease commonly affects people aged over 60. African Americans are found to have a greater likelihood of suffering from this disease.  Slide 3: Medical History • Patient X has a history of hypertension for the last 20 years  managed with thiazide diuretics and ACE inhibitors. • He also has a history of smoking  another contributing factor for aortic dissection. • Other aspects of his medical history include a diagnosis of diabetes type 2  and mild obesity.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms • Patient X presented with sudden severe chest pain radiating to the back  shortness of breath  sweating  and light-headedness.   Slide 5: Diagnosis  • Taking into account the patient’s hypertension history and symptoms  aortic dissection was suspected. • A CT scan confirmed the diagnosis showing an intimal flap and false lumen consistent with Stanford Type B aortic dissection.  Slide 6: Treatment & Management • Patient X was admitted to the intensive care unit and started on intravenous beta-blockers to manage his blood pressure and heart rate. • Endovascular stent-graft placement was performed considering the patient's type B aortic dissection.   Slide 7: Follow-up  • Regular monitoring of blood pressure  cholesterol  blood sugars  and body weight was emphasized to patient X. • Advice was given to avoid strenuous activities and smoking. • Emphasis was placed on medication compliance and regular follow-up appointments.   Slide 8: Education & Awareness • It is vital to educate patients on risk factor management and how to recognize symptoms of aortic dissection for early detection and management.   Slide 9: Conclusion • This case study highlighted hypertension control  risk stratification  and timely intervention as integral to the management of aortic dissection.    This concludes our case study presentation on an aortic disclassification patient  showcasing the process from presentation to follow-up for a comprehensive learning experience.  Note: Based on their unique professional fulfillment  some clinicians may propose diversified management plans matching this patient's needs and clinical history.

Title: Aortic Dissection: A case presentation   Slide 1: Introduction  Aortic dissection (AD) is a severe and often deadly illness  prevalent predominantly among aging male adults. It is associated with hypertension and connective tissue disorders  illustrating the need for patient vigilance and swift medical response when symptoms develop.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Patient Profile: A retired Black American male  aged 64  living in the urban USA. Represents a demographic group with a higher prevalence of hypertension  a significant risk factor for AD.  Slide 3: Patient's Lifestyle and Socioeconomic Conditions  The patient is a former heavy smoker who has quit for ten years and indulges light alcohol. He held a high-stress job before retirement  with a history of inadequate sleep patterns. His socioeconomic conditions fall within the low to middle-income bracket  restricting his access to quality healthcare facilities.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  Has a chronic history of uncontrolled hypertension for 15 years  although on medication. Family medical history involves a brother who had AD.  Slide 5: Clinical Presentation  Presented with sudden  severe pain in the chest and back  described as ""tearing"" traveling down to the abdomen. Additionally  there was shortness of breath and fainting spells.   Slide 6: Investigation  Upon initial physical examination  blood pressure was notably different between extremities  and a murmur was audible over the aorta upon auscultation. Further diagnostic imaging (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis.  Slide 7: Management and Conclusion  Immediate management initiated with current protocols of beta-blockers for blood pressure management and surgery. Follow-up care involves strict blood pressure control and lifestyle modifications.   End Slide: This case aims to raise awareness of hypertension control  especially in demographics with higher prevalence  and the life-threatening complications it can lead to  like aortic dissection.

Slide 1: Title: Case Study: Aortic Dissection in a 68 year-old Male Patient    Slide 2:  Title: Patient Demographics - Gender: Male  - Age: 68 years old - Ethnicity: African American - Occupation: Retired  previously worked as a truck driver - Location: New York  USA    Slide 3: Title: Patient History  - Hypertension  - No known allergies - No history of familial genetic disorders  - Non-smoker  - Occasional alcohol consumer.  Slide 4:  Title: Past Medical History  - Patient has been managing hypertension for the past 15 years with regular medication. - Other health issues include early-stage chronic kidney disease  and obesity.    Slide 5:  Title: Presenting Complaint  - The patient presented with severe  acute chest pain radiating to his back.  - The pain was described as ""tearing"" and began abruptly.   Slide 6: Title: Physical Examination & Investigative Findings  - Blood pressure: High and unequal in both arms - Heart rate: Tachycardia  - ECG: Normal sinus rhythm  no signs of myocardial infarction - CT Scan: Revealed an ascending aortic dissection extending from the aortic root to the right common iliac artery.    Slide 7:  Title: Diagnosis  - Acute aortic dissection (Type A)    Slide 8: Title: Treatment Plan  - Emergency surgical repair for Type A Aortic Dissection - Following surgery  blood pressure control is crucial to prevent recurrence. This would include beta-blockers and other antihypertensive agents.    Slide 9:  Title: Prognosis  - Early surgical intervention improves patient survival rate. - Secondary complications can be avoided with good post-op care and lifestyle adjustments. - Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor blood pressure and overall cardiovascular health.   Slide 10:  Title: Conclusion - The patient is a typical reflective of the higher risk group for aortic dissection: the elderly  male  African-American citizens with a history of hypertension. - Prompt diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention can prove to be life-saving. - This case emphasizes the importance of considering aortic dissection in differential diagnosis in patients presenting with severe chest pain.

Slide 1: Introduction  Aortic dissection is a serious and life-threatening medical condition that occurs when the inner layer of the aorta tears. Due to the significant mortality associated with this condition  an understanding and prompt diagnosis is vital for timely treatment.  Slide 2: Demographics  Aortic dissection typically affects men aged between 60 and 70  however it can occur at any age. Statistically  the condition is more prevalent among males  accounting for 65% of cases. Persons of African descent are approximately 2 to 3 times more likely to experience aortic dissection compared to caucasians.  Slide 3: Case Presentation  Our patient  Mr. R  is a 67-year-old African American male smoker with a known history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol. He presents to the ER with sudden severe chest pain  radiating to his back described as 'tearing' in nature.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  Mr. R has been suffering from hypertension for the past 15 years and has been irregular with his medication. He also has hyperlipidemia and has been a smoker for around 40 years. He previously underwent a coronary angioplasty. There is no family history of aortic disease.  Slide 5: Clinical Assessment  Physical examination revealed an anxious patient with elevated blood pressure mainly in the right arm. Cardiovascular exam demonstrated irregular heart sounds  discrepancy in peripheral pulses and a murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation.   Slide 6: Investigations  The EKG does not show any evidence of myocardial infarction and lab tests are within normal limits except for a mild elevation in D-dimer. The defining diagnostic test is the CT angiography of the chest  which demonstrates dissection of the ascending aorta.  Slide 7: Management  Mr. R was immediately started on intravenous antihypertensive medication to control his blood pressure and heart rate. An emergency cardiothoracic surgical consult was sought for a possible surgical repair of the dissection.  Slide 8: Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of understanding the demographics and risk factors associated with aortic dissection. The need for prompt diagnosis and appropriate management can be life-saving in such situations. Encouraging healthy lifestyle choices may significantly decrease the risk for developing this condition.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking presents to the ER complaining of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain started abruptly about an hour ago and is described as a tearing sensation. The patient is excessively sweating and appears to be in distress. His blood pressure is elevated with different readings in both arms. He denies any symptoms of nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness but reports a momentary blurring of vision.

A 62-year-old African American male with a past medical history of chronic uncontrolled hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and heavy tobacco use presents with severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was abrupt onset and is associated with diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. On examination  he has a blood pressure differential between the right and left arms and a diastolic murmur is appreciated along the left sternal border. History indicates poor adherence to antihypertensive medications. He is 30 pounds overweight  works in a high-stress job and reports a 20 pack-year smoking history. The combination of his age  race  and particularly his history of hypertension and smoking significantly increases his risk for an aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain described as tearing and radiating to the back. Pain was constant  lasted for more than one hour  and was associated with shortness of breath. He also reported feeling lightheaded. The patient denied any nausea  vomiting  or sweating. His blood pressure was found to be uneven between the two arms with lowered pulses in the right arm and an elevated heart rate. His history and symptoms raise the possibility of aortic dissection. The gender  age  and race of the patient are consistent with literature showing higher incidence rates of aortic dissection in older males and increased prevalence among the African-American population  while his history of hypertension and smoking significantly adds to the risk.

A 65-year-old African American male with a known history of hypertension and tobacco use presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset chest pain that began approximately two hours ago. The pain is described as sharp and tearing  and it radiates to the shoulder blades. The patient is visibly distressed  sweating profusely  and also reports feeling dizzy. His vitals on presentation show a hypertensive blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg. Examination reveals discrepancy in pulse strength between his right and left arm. The combination of acute severe pain intensity  hypertensive crisis  and his existing risk factors suggest a potential aortic dissection.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room with sudden severe chest pain  described as tearing and radiating to his back. The pain started suddenly an hour ago while he was at rest. Past medical history includes moderate hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 15-pack-year smoking history  which he quit 10 years ago. His father died of an aortic aneurysm at age 75. Vitals on presentation show a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg and a heart rate of 96 bpm. Physical exam is notable for diaphoresis and mild inter-arm blood pressure difference (15 mmHg). His cardiopulmonary exam is otherwise normal  with no signs of congestive heart failure. He denies any symptoms of abdominal pain or lower extremity weakness. An EKG shows no changes. His pain is not relieved by nitroglycerin. Given the abrupt onset and description of his pain  including the family history of aortic disease  a bedside transthoracic echocardiogram is performed suspecting an aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of long-standing uncontrolled hypertension and heavy tobacco usage presents with sudden and severe chest pain described as ""tearing"" and radiating to the back. He also reports shortness of breath and faintness. His blood pressure readings are disparate between the two arms. He has no known allergies  but there is a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His medications include Lisinopril  which he admits to not taking regularly. On examination  the patient exhibits diaphoresis  pallor  as well as tachycardia and hypotension. He has had no surgeries in the past. His blood work shows an elevated d-dimer level.

A 60-year-old African American male with a known history of poorly controlled hypertension and smoking presented in the emergency department with sudden and severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back. He described the pain as the worst he has ever felt. His blood pressure was found to be markedly different in both arms. Additionally  he was noted to have a faint pulse on palpation of his right femoral artery. Other features on examination included diaphoresis and signs of distress. His EKG shows nonspecific abnormalities. This overall presentation is highly suggestive of an aortic dissection.

A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and a smoking habit of 20 years presents with sudden  severe central chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes the pain as a ""tearing"" sensation and it is accompanied by alterations in his pulse  shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a faint feeling. His blood pressure reading is asymmetrical. The intensity of the pain has remained constant since the onset about 3 hours ago. He denies any episodes of recent trauma  surgery or ingestion of illicit substances. He has no family history of any aortic or connective tissue disorders. His presentation suggests the possibility of an aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African American man presents with sudden  severe chest pain described as ""tearing"" and ""ripping""  which commenced approximately two hours ago. The pain reportedly started in the chest and is radiating towards the back. He also mentions experiencing shortness of breath  near syncope  and mild confusion. He has a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  tobacco smoking  and atherosclerosis. On examination  he displays signs of hypertension with a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg and pulse of 110 beats per minute. His cardiovascular exam reveals a diastolic murmur. Neurological examination indicates mild loss of muscular strength in his left arm  indicating possible involvement of arterial branches supplying the arm. There are no previous records of any genetic conditions like Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. He does not have any history of traumatic injuries or prior aortic instrumentation. His immediate family history is not significant for any cardiovascular events or genetic disorders.

A 65-year-old  African American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use disorder presents with sudden  severe chest pain which radiates to the back. The patient describes the pain as ""tearing "" which has been persistent for 3 hours. He is reported to have a history of non-compliance with his hypertensive medications and frequently smokes a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. On examination  blood pressure readings are significantly different between each arm. He shows no signs of peripheral cyanosis  pallor  or diaphoresis. He has no history of cardiac disease or surgeries. No familial history of connective tissue disorders. The sudden onset of severe chest-to-back pain in a hypertensive smoker is suspicious for aortic dissection  necessitating immediate investigation and potential intervention.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia and smoking  presents to the ER with acute severe chest pain radiating to his back. The onset of pain was sudden and has been persistently worsening over the past few hours. The patient also reports feelings of faintness  and shortness of breath. His medical history includes a 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension  a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  a 20-year history of hyperlipidemia  and a history of chronic heavy smoking. His prescriptions include amlodipine  metformin and atorvastatin. The patient is also a retired mechanic  living with his spouse and has a family history of cardiovascular disease – his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. Physical examination reveals significant hypertension with a blood pressure reading of 190/110 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 110 beats/min. His mental status is slightly altered due to pain and anxiety. The physical exam also reveals weak femoral pulses and an early diastolic murmur on cardiovascular examination. The patient's EKG is unremarkable.

A 60-year-old African-American male former smoker with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  Marfan syndrome  and familial history of aortic diseases presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  sharp chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" in nature. Since the onset of the pain  he has experienced episodes of dizziness  shortness of breath  and excessive perspiration. On examination  the patient has unequal blood pressure readings in both arms and an early diastolic murmur on auscultation  suggestive of aortic regurgitation. His EKG shows no evidence of myocardial infarction.   According to available evidence  this patient's risk factors  such as advanced age  male gender  African-American race  history of smoking  uncontrolled hypertension  and genetic predisposition (Marfan syndrome  family history)  align with common risk factors associated with aortic dissection. His presenting symptoms are highly suggestive of the condition.

A 67-year-old African-American male with a documented history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain started while he was at rest and has steadily worsened over the past several hours. The patient also reports feeling weak and lightheaded but denies any other symptoms such as shortness of breath  nausea  or diaphoresis. Examination reveals a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg in the right arm and 145/90 mmHg in the left arm. Heart rate is regular but elevated at 100 bpm. Cardiovascular exam documents an early diastolic murmur but is otherwise unremarkable. Neurological evaluation reveals a stable and alert patient without focal deficits. Given the patient's age  race  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and the acute onset of severe  tearing chest plus back pain  he is suspected to have an aortic dissection warranting urgent imaging and vascular surgical consultation.

A 65-year-old African American male with a known history of chronic uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain that radiates to his back. He also reports feeling lightheaded and short of breath. An initial physical examination reveals asymmetrical blood pressure readings in his arms  a high-pitched diastolic murmur best heard over the right second intercostal space  and weak or absent pulses in his lower extremities. His medical history is significant for a diagnosis of Marfan syndrome during his adolescence. He experiences no relief with nitroglycerin administration. The patient's ongoing tobacco use  hypertension  along with his Marfan syndrome  predispose him to cardiovascular issues  and his symptoms are suggestive of aortic dissection.

A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history of untreated hypertension and smoking  presents to the emergency department complaining of abrupt and severe chest pain that radiates to the back. He describes the pain as ""ripping"" in nature  beginning in the anterior chest and moving posteriorly. On presentation  he is diaphoretic and pale  with a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg on the right arm and 145/85 mmHg on the left arm. Further examinations reveal decreased pulses in the lower extremities. EKG shows no sign of myocardial infarction. A murmur of aortic regurgitation is audible on cardiac auscultation. There was no history of trauma or drug abuse. There is no family history of connective tissue disorders. His recent medical history shows non-compliance to anti-hypertensive medications.

A 63-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled high blood pressure and evidence of atherosclerosis presents with severe  sharp chest pain radiating to the back. The pain started suddenly and is described as ""tearing."" The patient also reports feeling dizzy and shortness of breath. On examination  his blood pressure is markedly different in his arms  with the left arm measuring much higher. He also has a weak pulse in the right leg. He has a smoking history of 30 years and a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His most recent blood pressure reading from last month showed a significantly high 180/110 mmHg. He is not on any medication. The patient is in obvious distress and exhibits signs of anxiety. The suspected diagnosis is aortic dissection.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  heavy smoking  and a recent traumatic injury from a fall presents to the emergency department with sudden chest pain described as sharp and ""tearing "" which radiates to his back. He also reports symptoms of faintness  diaphoresis  and shortness of breath. His current blood pressure measurements show a discrepancy between arms. The patient has no known allergies to medications. Family history involved a cousin who died abruptly due to aortic disease. His prescribed medications include a beta-blocker and diuretics for hypertension  which he takes irregularly. The symptoms and personal history signal a concern for potential aortic dissection.

A 69-year-old African American male with a long-standing history of poorly controlled hypertension and a smoking habit of 40 pack-years presents with a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain that radiates to his back. He informs that the pain started a few hours ago  was maximal at onset  and has remained constant since. He also reports associated shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and lightheadedness. On examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic  with a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg in his right arm and 150/100 mmHg in his left arm. There's a new 3/6 diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border  and his pulses are asymmetric  weaker in the left upper extremity compared to the right. EKG shows no signs of myocardial ischemia. Suspicion is high for aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old African-American male patient with a history of untreated hypertension and smoking presents with sudden severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain is described as tearing or ripping and is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a sense of impending doom. His blood pressure is significantly higher on the right arm compared to the left. Physical examination discovers an early pulse in the right carotid artery and a murmur consistent with aortic insufficiency. He has no history of cardiac surgery or injury. His family history includes a brother who had an aortic dissection at age 70. The combination of his demographics  medical history  family history  and clinical presentation raise a strong suspicion for aortic dissection.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with an acute onset of severe  sharp  tearing chest and back pain that he rates as a 10 out of 10. The pain started approximately three hours ago and appears to be radiating to his abdomen. He is diaphoretic and appears acutely distress. His blood pressure is higher on his right arm than his left. Other pertinent positives include shortness of breath and dizziness. His past medical history is significant for high cholesterol and a 15-pack year smoking history. Family history is relevant for hypertension and ischemic heart disease. Review of systems is negative for fever  cough  or recent weight loss/significant weight changes. Physical exam reveals hypertension and a difference in blood pressure between arms. His presentation suggests aortic dissection.

A 62-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension and heavy smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain  described as ""tearing""  radiating to his back. Pain is associated with diaphoresis  nausea  and vomiting. He has a mild confusion and displays signs of a faint pulse in the right leg. His vital signs reveal BP of 180/110 mmHg  tachycardia  and respiratory distress. Prior medical history also reveals suboptimal compliance with antihypertension medication. Family history is significant for connective tissue disorder - Marfan syndrome  however  the patient does not have a confirmed diagnosis of it himself. His clinical signs and symptoms are highly suggestive of acute aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking presents with a sudden onset of severe  ""tearing"" chest pain radiating to the back. He also reports accompanying symptoms like dizziness  profuse sweating  and some difficulty in breathing. He has no known history of any heart surgeries or connective tissue disorder. His blood pressure is significantly different in both arms; it is much higher than his usual records. He appears to be in distress with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and his blood pressure is elevated at 185/100 mmHg. He was diagnosed with hypertension more than 10 years ago but has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication. His pulse is regular but rapid and on physical examination  there is an early-diastolic murmur heard best at the upper right sternal border. There were no clear signs of a Marfanoid habitus. His urinalysis also reported hematuria. EKG reveals no abnormalities. He denies any family history of aortic dissection or connective tissue disease.

A 65-year-old African American male  with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe chest and back pain that occurred while lifting heavy items. The pain began in the anterior chest but has since radiated toward his back. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and rates it a 10/10 in severity. He denies any associated shortness of breath  nausea  or recent illnesses in the past few months. He notes that he has not been taking his antihypertensive medication regularly over the past several months due to financial issues. The patient's blood pressure is found to be significantly higher on the right arm compared to the left arm.

The patient is a 60-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension and smoking. He presents to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain radiating to the back  described as tearing or ripping in nature. He also reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  shortness of breath  dizziness  and transient loss of consciousness. His blood pressure is significantly different in both arms. Considering his age  gender  race  and risk factors - hypertension and smoking  there is a high suspicion for aortic dissection. Further diagnostics are needed to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the condition.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sharp chest pain that started abruptly about an hour ago. The pain radiates to his back  is tearing in nature  and is associated with shortness of breath. He also reports a history of untreated hypertension for many years and past medical history reveals previous myocardial infarction. He appears to be in visible distress  clammy  and his blood pressure is significantly different between his two arms. No history of Marfan syndrome or any connective tissue disorders. Review of Systems is positive for fatigue and decreased appetite. The patient is a retired engineer  denies tobacco and illegal drug use but admits to moderate alcohol use. Family history is significant for early-onset coronary artery disease. His physical examination is remarkable for diaphoresis  elevated blood pressure  and faint peripheral pulses. The clinical picture is highly suggestive of an aortic dissection.

A 66-year-old African-American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and prior tobacco use presents complaining of sudden  severe chest pain  radiating through to his back. The pain began while he was doing yard work  and is described as tearing or ripping. He has also been experiencing lightheadedness and shortness of breath. He reports taking medication for high blood pressure  but admits he does not always take it as prescribed. His blood pressure is significantly higher in his right arm than his left. His heart rate is slightly tachycardic and a diastolic murmur can be heard on auscultation. His physical exam also reveals diminished pulses in his left lower extremity. Given the above  he is suspected to have an aortic dissection.

A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain. The pain is described as sharp  constant  and radiates to his back  mainly the interscapular area. The pain intensity escalated over the last hour and is rated an 8 on a scale of 10. In addition  he reported feeling light-headiness  shortness of breath with diaphoresis  but no report of fever or cough. On physical examination  he appears diaphoretic and distressed. There is a notable blood pressure difference between the right and left arm. Pulses in the lower extremities are diminished but are present. There are normal heart sounds without murmur  rub  or gallop  and the lungs are clear. A neurological exam finds no abnormalities.

A 63-year-old African-American male with a history of chronic  uncontrolled hypertension presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back. The patient also reports symptoms of dyspnea and sensation of impending doom. He denies any recent trauma  fever  or recent invasive procedures. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure discrepancy between upper extremities  a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation  and decreased pulses in the left lower extremity. The patient has a 40 pack-year smoking history but denies having Marfan Syndrome or a family history of aortic disease. This clinical vignette represents a scenario suggestive of an acute aortic dissection.

A 69-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension and 35-pack years of smoking  presents to the emergency department with escalating severe chest pain he describes as 'tearing' in nature radiating to the back. He denies having any related symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  diaphoresis  or dizziness. However  he reports experiencing a sudden onset of the pain about an hour ago. His blood pressure reading shows an interarm difference  with the right arm showing a higher reading than the left. He has no known allergies  and he only takes medication to manage his blood pressure without being adherent to it regularly. He’s retired  lives alone  and his support system includes his two children who live nearby. He has no history of illegal drug use. His father died from a stroke  and his mother had a history of high blood pressure. This patient's presentation suggests the possibility of aortic dissection  which is consistent with his demographic profile and risk factors.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and high lipid levels presents with a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain that radiates to his back. The patient also reports feelings of faintness  excessive sweating  and mild confusion. Vital signs indicate abnormally high blood pressure. This constellation suggests the possible diagnosis of an acute aortic dissection.

A 64-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and peripheral arterial disease presents with sudden severe tearing chest pain that radiates to the back. He also reports associated symptoms of sweating  faintness  shortness of breath  and nausea. The patient indicates that he has a 45-pack-year smoking history. On presentation  he is found to have a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg  pulse rate of 115 bpm  right arm blood pressure noticeably lower than the left  and a new diastolic murmur on cardiac auscultation.

A 65-year-old African American male with a known history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking presents with a sudden onset of severe  sharp interscapular pain radiating to the chest. He describes it as a ""tearing"" pain and rates it 10/10 in intensity. Over the past hour  he developed increasing dyspnea and lightheadedness. He denies trauma  fever  or other associated symptoms. Physical examination is notable for slight differences in blood pressure between the right and left upper extremities  although these differences may be minimal. Family history is notable for a father who suffered from a similar event. The patient's distress and significant history point towards the possible diagnosis of aortic dissection. Risk factors include his advanced age  race  male gender  history of hypertension  and tobacco use.

A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension presents with a sudden and severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain is described as “tearing” or “ripping” in nature and has been increasing progressively over the last few hours. On examination  he is found to be hypertensive and diaphoretic. Other cardiovascular findings include asymmetry between the peripheral pulses and a blood pressure difference greater than 20 mm Hg between the arms. No significant family history of cardiac diseases. He is a smoker with a 40 pack year history but denies any alcohol or drug use.

A 65-year-old African American male with a history of poorly managed hypertension presents with sudden onset of severe  tearing pain in his chest and back. The pain is described as radiating to his upper abdominal and leg region. He has a history of smoking  with a 40 pack year history and previous myocardial infarction. On presentation  the patient appears anxious and reports a sense of impending doom. His blood pressure is significantly different in his two arms  and pulses are asymmetrical. Auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur. Additional findings include mild dyspnea  diaphoresis  pallor  and an altered mental state with signs of confusion and restlessness.

A 66-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with a sudden  severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back. The patient also reports a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years. Other comorbid conditions include diabetes mellitus and a 40-pack year smoking history. The pain is associated with shortness of breath and nausea. On physical examination  the patient appears uncomfortable with a blood pressure of 180/100mmHg and a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  with unequal pulse and blood pressures in the upper extremities. The patient lacks a history of similar symptoms. The diagnosis of aortic dissection is suspected based on the patient's presenting symptoms and his relevant medical history.

A 67-year-old African American male  with a significant past medical history of poorly controlled hypertension  smoking  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe centralized chest pain radiating to his back. The pain is described as 'tearing' in quality and is rated as 10/10 intensity. The patient also reports feeling diaphoretic  nauseated  and having difficulty catching his breath. On physical examination  there is a notable variation in blood pressure reading between the right and left arm. No history of coronary artery disease or collagen vascular disease. There is no family history of aortic disease.

A 60-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension presents with sudden severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was abrupt  with a tearing or ripping sensation. He also reports shortness of breath  dizziness  and a slight fever. He is a smoker with a 20-pack-year history and has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication. Physical examination indicates a pulse deficit with a blood pressure discrepancy between the upper extremities. He also shows signs of distress with profuse sweating and pale skin. EKG shows non-specific changes. Given the presentation and clinical context  the patient is suspected to have aortic dissection  which is a medical emergency that requires immediate attention.

A 65-year-old African American man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department with acute  severe  tearing chest pain that radiated to the back. The pain started suddenly about 3 hours ago  and has not relieved even after rest. He states that the pain is unlike anything he has experienced before. He appears sweaty and pale  and is described by his daughter as being very anxious. He is experiencing shortness of breath and was reportedly feeling lightheaded prior to arrival. His blood pressure is significantly different between his arms  and a murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation can be heard upon auscultation. ECG does not show signs of myocardial infarction. His medical history includes a 30-pack year smoking history and familial history of connective tissue disease  however  he himself has never been diagnosed. He denies use of illicit drugs.

A 65-year-old African-American male with a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension presents with sudden onset of tearing chest pain radiating to the back. He reports the pain as severe and unrelenting  rated 8/10. He also reports feeling short of breath and slight dizziness. He denies any recent trauma  falls  or heavy lifting. The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  for which he was intermittently compliant with his medication regime of Amlodipine 5mg daily. He also has a 15-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes a day  but quit 5 years ago. The patient has no known allergies. On examination  his blood pressure is significantly different between right and left arms  and a murmur is heard on cardiac auscultation.

A 62-year-old African-American male with a medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension and a smoking habit presents to the emergency room with sudden spell of severe 'tearing' chest pain radiating to the back. The pain was also described as very severe and different from anything experienced before. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  sudden onset of sweatiness  and faintness. Symptoms began an hour before presenting without any apparent triggers. On examination  the patient is visibly anxious  and there is a slight difference in blood pressure readings between the two arms. There is no history of trauma or similar episode in the past. Family history reveals premature cardiovascular diseases.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of chronic hypertension and tobacco use presents to the emergency room with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and different from anything he's ever experienced before. Additional symptoms include unexpected shortness of breath  dizziness  and fainting. His blood pressure on presentation is elevated and asymmetric between both arms.

A 70-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension presents to the ER with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his back. His pain is described as tearing in nature and has a severity of 10/10. His accompanying clinical features include dyspnea  diaphoresis  and pallor. He mentions a history of smoking but quit 10 years back. There is no significant family history or personal history of connective tissue disorders. Blood pressure is notably higher on the right arm than the left  and his pulse appears to be weak. On initial examination  a diastolic murmur is appreciated. These features raise clinical suspicion for aortic dissection.

A 69-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension  smoking  and a familial history of aortic disease  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to the back. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and it began an hour ago while lifting a heavy box. On exam  he is diaphoretic  in visible distress  and has differing blood pressure measurements in each arm. An EKG reveals no myocardial infarction but a subsequent CT scan of the chest reveals aortic dissection. The patient reports no previous incidents of chest pain  indicating that this event might be the result of chronic untreated hypertension.

A 71-year-old African American male  ex-smoker with a known history of hypertension and untreated hyperlipidemia  presents with sudden onset severe chest and back pain  described as tearing in nature. He additionally reports feelings of anxiety and dizziness. On examination  blood pressure is observed to be significantly different between the left and right arms. The patient has a faint  early diastolic heart murmur heard best at the second right intercostal space  suggesting possible aortic regurgitation. He is tachycardic  but otherwise stable. EKG shows no signs of myocardial infarction. His neurological examination  including cranial nerves  motor  sensory  and reflexes are normal. Of concern is a suspected aortic dissection.

A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history of stage 2 hypertension  smoking and hyperlipidemia presents with severe and sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back. The patient describes the pain as a tearing sensation. On arrival  the patient was observed to exhibit shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and pallor. Blood pressure values displayed significant differences between the left and right arm. He also reports a history of intermittent claudication. He has been a smoker for over 40 years and does not have regular follow-ups for his hypertension. His immediate family history reveals his father having suffered an aortic aneurysm. His hyperlipidemia has been poorly managed due to noncompliance with statin therapy.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of systemic hypertension  Marfan Syndrome  and a history of smoking. He presents with an abrupt  severe  ripping chest pain radiating to the back  dyspnea  and a difference in blood pressure between the right and left arms. He also exhibits symptoms of syncope  which suggests possible involvement of the carotid arteries. The patient's systemic hypertension represents a risk for aortic dissection. The Marfan Syndrome diagnosis further supports suspicion of aortic dissection  given that it is a connective tissue disorder associated with the disease. The patient's history of smoking adds to the cardiovascular risk profile. These symptoms and history warrant immediate diagnostic imaging to confirm an aortic dissection.

A 69-year-old African American male presents with severe  tearing chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  high cholesterol  and tobacco use. The pain started suddenly  radiates to his back  and is associated with profuse sweating. He has an asymmetrical blood pressure reading showing higher value in right arm  as well as a pulse discrepancy. He has a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation on auscultation. His chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum. His electrocardiogram is normal. His D-dimer levels are elevated.

A 67-year-old African American male  with a past medical history significant for long-standing uncontrolled hypertension  occasional heavy alcohol intake  and a 30-year history of cigarette smoking  presents with a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back since the past 6 hours. The pain has progressively worsened and is associated with shortness of breath  excessive sweating  and fainting spells. On examination  his blood pressure measures 200/110 mmHg in the left arm and 180/100 mmHg in the right arm. He has a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border  his pulses are asymmetric in both upper limbs  and he appears acutely ill. There are no signs of peripheral cyanosis or edema. There is mild abdominal distension with tenderness. His neurological examination demonstrates reduced strength on the left side compared to the right. He has no significant family history of vascular diseases. His medications include amlodipine which he admits he often forgets to take. He denies illicit drug use. The clinical picture suggests a suspected aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  Marfan syndrome  and a 30-pack year smoking history  presents to the emergency department with intense  sharp chest pain and back pain of sudden onset. The pain  described as ""tearing "" began while the patient was lifting heavy boxes earlier in the day  and has progressively worsened. Other associated symptoms include lightheadedness  shortness of breath and sweating. He denies having any similar episodes in the past. The patient also appears anxious and reports a deep sense of impending doom. On exam  patient is pale with a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg on right arm and 160/90 on the left arm. Heart rhythm is regular but fast with a rate of 110 bpm  and auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur.

A 69-year-old African American male  past smoker with a history of high blood pressure (poorly controlled)  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of cardiovascular disease  presents with sudden onset severe tearing or ripping chest and back pain that radiated to his abdomen and down his legs. The pain began while he was at rest. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath and dizzy spells moments after the pain started. On examination  there are discrepancies in pulses and blood pressure measurements between the right and left arms. Initial ECG shows no evidence of acute myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old African-American male  retired construction worker  with histories of hypertension and regular tobacco use presents to the emergency department with intense  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. He describes it as the ""worst pain of his life"". On examination  he has blood pressure differential between the two arms and a faint diastolic murmur over the aortic area on auscultation. His medical history is notable for non-compliance to antihypertensive medication. His family history reveals his father had an aortic aneurysm.

A 65-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  smoking  and Marfan syndrome presents to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe chest pain. The pain is described as tearing and radiates to his back. Associated symptoms include syncope  shortness of breath  and weakness in the lower extremities. He appears pale  diaphoretic  and is in obvious distress. His pulse is weak and blood pressure readings differ in his right and left arm. On examination  a murmur consistent with aortic regurgitation is heard. His blood pressure is poorly controlled  despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. No previous history of cardiac disease or prior surgeries.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents with sudden  severe chest pain which he describes as sharp and tearing  radiating to his back. The patient's medical history is significant for untreated hypertension  a smoking habit of 30 years  and familial hypercholesterolemia. He also reports experiencing intermittent short breath and dizziness for the past couple of hours. On physical examination  there is a difference in blood pressure between the upper extremities. His heart sounds are normal  but there is a faint diastolic murmur heard best at the right sternal border. No history of connective tissue disorders  trauma  or recent procedures that could have triggered the aortic dissection. Initial laboratory investigations including full blood count and cardiac biomarkers are within normal limits. An urgent CT angiogram is arranged for definitive diagnosis  given high suspicion for aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old African American male with a history of untreated hypertension and sporadic tobacco use presents with abrupt  severe tearing chest pain radiating to his back along with instances of light-headedness. He has a past medical history significant for stage 2 hypertension which is currently managed with lifestyle modification  with poor adherence to prescribed medications. The intensity of the pain has not decreased since its onset  indicating no relief. He further expresses symptom features suggestive of impaired blood supply such as pallor  cold and clammy skin. In addition  he is also experiencing anxiety and restlessness possibly due to extreme pain and discomfort. His blood pressure is significantly higher than previous readings and there's a discrepancy between the left and right arm blood pressure. He denies any previous similar episodes  family history of aortic disease  or use of cocaine or other stimulants. His EKG shows no signs of ischemia or infarction. These symptoms signify a possible aortic dissection requiring immediate evaluation and management.

A 65-year-old African American male  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use  presents with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back. He describes the pain as tearing or ripping. His blood pressure is markedly different between his right and left arm. His heart rate is 110 bpm  respirations 20 per minute  oxygen saturation 94% on room air  and blood pressure 190/100 mmHg on his right arm and 160/80 mmHg on his left. He shows signs of slight confusion. There is a family history of heart diseases. His smoking and hypertension could have predisposed him to atherosclerosis  potentially contributing to the development of his presenting aortic dissection. His symptoms suggest a type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta  which is a surgical emergency.

A 67-year-old African American male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and smoking presents to the ED with sudden  sharp  and tearing chest pain radiating to his back. He describes feeling lightheaded and has shortness of breath. On examination  he has a blood pressure discrepancy between his right and left arm and a diastolic murmur is heard  suggestive of aortic regurgitation. The patient is diaphoretic with pallor. Taking into account his older age  race  gender  and history of uncontrolled hypertension—all risk factors for aortic dissection—this patient's symptoms appear to be consistent with an acute aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use presents with abrupt onset of severe  sharp interscapular back pain likened to being ""ripped apart."" The pain started around 1 hour ago and has been continuous since. He also experiences shortness of breath and feels dizzy. Physical examination reveals a difference in blood pressure recordings between both arms and a diastolic murmur in the precordial area. The patient denies any history of trauma prior to the onset of symptoms.

A 65-year-old African-American male with a history of poorly-controlled hypertension and smoking presents to the ER with severe sudden-onset chest pain described as “tearing” radiating through to his back. He has additional symptoms of shortness of breath and mild confusion  and shows slight difference in blood pressures between his right and left arms. His past medical history reports recurrent episodes of blood pressure above 140/90 mmHg  indicating chronic hypertensive condition. He also reported that he has been a smoker for over four decades. His family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  smoker for 40 years  and familial history of aortic disorders  presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain that started two hours ago. The pain is described as sharp  tearing  and radiating to the back. He also reports weakness in his legs  accompanied by lightheadedness. Vital signs reveal blood pressure discrepancy between arms  with the left arm having a lower reading than the right. Exam also reveals diminished pulses in the bilateral lower extremities. There are no signs of marfanoid habitus.

A 65-year-old African-American male with a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 40 pack-year smoking habit presents to the Emergency Department with acute onset  severe and sharp chest pain radiating towards his back. The pain began suddenly about an hour prior to his arrival. He also reports shortness of breath and lightheadedness. He looks pale and mildly diaphoretic. His blood pressure is notably different in each arm  with the right arm recording a higher blood pressure than the left. His pulse is rapid. He's of average build. He admits non-compliance with his antihypertensive medications. The degree  location and sudden onset of his pain along with his hypertensive history and findings on physical examination raises a high suspicion for aortic dissection.

Subject: 65-Year-Old Male Patient with Aortic Dissection  A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history for severe hypertension  smoking  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with intense  tearing chest pain that radiated to his back. The onset of pain was spontaneous  peaking in minutes and is persisting. He mentions it as the worst pain of his life. The patient felt lightheaded and experienced profuse sweating. He also has a history of non-compliance with his hypertensive medications. VS shows elevated BP asymmetrically (Right arm BP: 180/95 mm Hg; Left arm BP: 165/90 mm Hg). The clinical picture is highly suggestive of aortic dissection. The patient is at risk given his age  gender  medical history  and symptomatology. On further examination  a diastolic murmur indicative of aortic insufficiency is noted  increasing the need for immediate intervention and management.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male  with a medical history of long-term uncontrolled hypertension and smoking  presents to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset sharp  tearing chest pain that radiates to his back. On examination  the patient displays signs of severe anxiety and distress perhaps indicative of aortic dissection. There exist disparities in blood pressure between his left and right arm. Heart sound assessment reveals faint diastolic murmur pointing towards aortic regurgitation. Furthermore  a transient ischemic stroke is suspected due to momentary weakness in the patient's lower extremities. Given a family history of Marfan syndrome  aortic dissection can be considered a potential etiology for the aforementioned presentation. Further diagnostic measures are required to confirm the diagnosis and determine type and extent of aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  smoking  and high cholesterol presents with severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back. He also reports experiencing an abrupt onset of the pain that has persisted for a couple of hours. He looks pale and diaphoretic  and his vital signs reveal high blood pressure. He has a history of non-compliance to his antihypertensive medications. The patient denies any history of trauma or injury preceding the pain. His family history indicates his father suffered from an aortic dissection at the age of 70. The combination of persistent chest pain  history of hypertension  and family history of aortic dissection raises concern for a similar condition in this patient.

A 65-year-old African American male  with a known medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30 pack-year smoking history  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back. He reports the pain began while he was lifting heavy furniture at his home. He also admits to having felt dizzy and short of breath since the pain started.
