The patient appears in acute distress  with a slightly elevated blood pressure reading of 160/95 mmHg on the right arm  with a significantly lower reading of 130/80 on the left arm. He appears cool and pale  with a weak pulse in his lower extremities. EKG shows no signs of myocardial ischemia or infarction  but the chest radiograph reveals a widened mediastinum. Suspicion is high for thoracic aortic dissection.

A 63-year-old African American male with a medical history of hypertension known for the last 10 years and smoking pack for two decades  presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of extreme sharp  tearing pain in the upper back which radiates to the front chest. The pain was initiated an hour ago while the patient was at rest. The patient also reports feeling lightheaded and suffering episodes of syncope. On examination  patient was found to have unequal blood pressure in arms and a diastolic murmur could be heard upon auscultation. Symptoms indicate acute aortic dissection.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a history of untreated hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes it as a sharp and tearing sensation. His blood pressure is significantly different in both arms  and he has a diminished femoral pulse. His family history is significant for cardiac disease. He reports additional symptoms including dizziness  sweating  and nausea. His EKG is non-specific. The combination of history  symptoms  and physical exam findings raises the possibility of aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:  A 70-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and a 50-pack year smoking history presents with severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back. He also describes associated shortness of breath and dizziness. The patient notes that the pain was sudden in onset and has progressively worsened over the past 2 hours. He also mentions experiencing cold  numb legs. On physical examination  he is found to have an elevated blood pressure (170/110 mm Hg) and a discrepancy in pulses between the upper and lower extremities. His cardiovascular exam reveals an early diastolic murmur best heard at the right sternal border.  Aortic dissection is highly suspected given the patient's advanced age  male gender  African American ethnicity  and history of prolonged hypertension and extensive smoking. The presentation of severe chest pain of sudden onset that is tearing or ripping in character  radiating to the back  along with physical findings of a diastolic murmur and discrepancy in pulses is consistent with this diagnosis. His symptom of cold  numb legs potentially indicates compromised blood flow to the lower extremities  suggesting a type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta. This condition constitutes a medical emergency  and a surgical consult is warranted for potential repair.

A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  smoking and familial history of Marfan syndrome  presented to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden  severe sharp chest pain radiating to his back. The pain began at rest and is not relieved by nitroglycerin. On further examination  he was found to have a blood pressure difference between the left and right arms. Auscultation of the heart revealed a diastolic murmur due to aortic regurgitation. An emergency CT scan showed an intimal flap in the aorta  confirming the diagnosis of aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe chest and upper back pain that is described as sharp and tearing. His pain started suddenly while he was at rest and has been constant since onset. It radiates to his neck and down to his abdomen. The patient reports associated shortness of breath  sweating and faintness. His blood pressure on presentation is significantly higher on the right arm compared to the left. The patient has a history of increasing dosage antihypertensive medications over the past year due to poorly controlled blood pressures. He has no known family history of connective tissue disorder.

A 65-year-old African American male presents with acute  severe  interscapular back pain that began suddenly about three hours ago. The pain is sharp and tearing  radiating to his chest. The patient describes it as the worst pain he has ever experienced. He has a past medical history of hypertension and smoking. On examination  the blood pressure in his left arm is significantly higher than in his right arm. He appears sweaty and in severe distress.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension and tobacco use presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden  severe chest pain of 4-hours duration described as ""tearing"" and radiating to the back. The patient also reports experiencing shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. On examination  his blood pressure is significantly different between his two arms  and a diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation. The patient's pain is not relieved by nitroglycerin. His history of hypertension and tobacco use  the abrupt onset and specific nature of the symptoms  combined with the physical findings significantly raise the suspicion for aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain is described as tearing and is associated with shortness of breath  fainting  and profuse sweating. The patient's blood pressure on presentation is markedly high  with a pulse paradoxus and a noticeable difference in pulse and blood pressure readings between the right and left upper extremities. Patient records indicate ineffective hypertension management  and a 30 pack-year smoking history. This presentation suggests an acute descending type B aortic dissection.

A 60-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension  moderate tobacco use  and Marfan syndrome presents with sudden onset severe chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" or ""ripping"" in nature. He is also experiencing episodes of syncope  shortness of breath  and weak pulses in his right arm. His blood pressure is significantly higher in the left arm than the right. The combination of his risk factors (hypertension  smoking  Marfan syndrome)  symptoms (severe chest/back pain  syncope  shortness of breath  and pulse deficit)  and physical exam findings suggest a possible aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old African American man presents with severe  abrupt-onset chest pain that radiates to his back. He has a documented medical history of hypertension  which has been poorly controlled. The patient is a longtime smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He reports that the chest pain started suddenly and is unlike anything he has ever experienced. On examination  he appears distressed and anxious with a noted difference in blood pressure between his arms. His heart rate is elevated  and his skin is cold and clammy. No history of familial connective tissue disorder is present. The patient’s symptoms  ethnicity  age  and relevant medical history makes this a classic clinical scenario for aortic dissection.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male patient with a known history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking presents with a sudden episode of severe chest pain radiating to the back. The patient describes this acute chest pain as a sharp  tearing sensation. He also reports shortness of breath and profuse sweating. His family history reveals a sibling who suffered a similar heart complication. Upon physical examination  an early diastolic murmur suspicion of aortic regurgitation is observed  and difference in blood pressure between two upper limbs is reported. The patient's pulses are also thought to be unequal. His vitals are unstable  with an elevated blood pressure of 175/105 mmHg  a heart rate of 98 bpm  a respiratory rate of 18 rpm  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. The patient has no history of any surgeries but reports a recent occurrence of heightened stress.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with an acute onset of severe chest pain  described as a tearing sensation that radiates to his back. The patient has a relevant medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 30-year history of smoking. He appears in significant distress  sweating profusely and has a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diminished peripheral pulse inequality and an early diastolic murmur is heard on cardiac auscultation. He reports no prior similar episodes and no family history of aortic dissection. His EKG shows no signs of myocardial infarction. The constellation of acute severe pain  a significant history of hypertension  and smoking along with physical exam findings suggests the possibility of an aortic dissection. Rapid diagnosis and treatment are critical in this situation due to potential fatal outcomes associated with aortic rupture.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of untreated hypertension and smoking presents with sudden  severe chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain is described as ""tearing"" in nature. The patient looks pale and is sweating profusely. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg in the right arm but only 150/85 mmHg in the left arm. Physical exam also reveals a diminished left radial pulse. Patient is in obvious distress and reports a history of similar  though less severe  chest pain episodes over the past month which he dismissed as heartburn. He has no known history of connective tissue disorders. He has two first-degree relatives who had myocardial infarctions before the age of 60. His social history includes a 30-pack year smoking history but no alcohol or illicit drug use.

A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-year history of smoking presents with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back. He rates the pain as 10/10 and describes it as 'tearing'. On presentation  the patient is sweaty and pale  has an elevated blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg  a pulse rate of 105 bpm and shows signs of peripheral cyanosis. Upon auscultation  a difference in blood pressures and heart sounds between his right and left arms is noted. An EKG shows nonspecific ST and T wave changes but no signs of myocardial infarction. His medical history and symptoms raise high suspicion for an aortic dissection.

A 63-year-old African American male with a significant history of uncontrolled hypertension  tobacco use  and family history of cardiovascular disease presents to the emergency department with an acute onset of severe  sharp  and tearing chest pain radiating to his back. He complains of dizziness and has some difficulty breathing. He also reports feeling a weak pulse in his left arm. Physical examination reveals markedly different blood pressure readings in his arms  a diastolic murmur  and mild diaphoresis.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a notable medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  and smoking presents with sudden  severe tearing chest pain which radiates through to his back. The patient also complains of shortness of breath and feeling light-headed. He has a known family history of cardiovascular disease. He has not been compliant with his antihypertensive medications. On examination  the patient appears anxious  with diaphoresis. His blood pressure is significantly higher in the right arm compared to the left  and he has a pulse deficit. Auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation. No previous history of hyperlipidemia  diabetes mellitus or any autoimmune diseases. The patient's symptoms suggest an acute aortic dissection.

A 63-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension  a pack-a-day smoking habit of 40 years  and a family history of heart diseases presents with severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain is sudden  sharp  and described as ""tearing."" He also appears extremely anxious  hypertensive with a blood pressure of 200/110 mmHg  and there's a discrepancy in pulses: palpable in the right arm  but weaker in the left. He also mentions experiencing transient episodes of blurred vision. An EKG shows nondiagnostic changes and the patient's chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum. He is also experiencing mild shortness of breath and slight dizziness  which he initially attributed to anxiety. His BMI is in the obese range.

A 60-year-old African-American male with a history of smoking  poorly controlled hypertension and high cholesterol  presents with sudden  severe chest pain that radiates to the back  breathlessness and profuse sweating. The patient reports that the chest pain is tearing in nature and of an intensity he has never experienced before. He also reports minor syncopal episodes. The patient also discloses a family history of connective tissue disorders.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a significant past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and history of smoking presents with sudden onset severe tearing chest and back pain. The pain radiates to his back  and he describes it as the most severe he has ever experienced. He also reports experiencing light-headedness and intermittent shortness of breath. On examination  he shows signs of shock with a blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg in the right arm and 160/90 mmHg in the left arm  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His physical exam reveals a discrepancy in blood pressures between both arms  decreased breath sounds in the left lung  and a diastolic murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space. No neurological abnormalities are present. These findings raise concerns about aortic dissection.

A 70-year-old Caucasian man with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with sudden severe interscapular pain  described as ""ripping"" in nature  along with dyspnea  and sweatiness. He has no familial history of connective tissue disorders  or aneurysms. On physical examination  his blood pressure is 180/90 mmHg in the right arm and 150/80 mmHg in the left arm  and he has a diastolic murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space. Gratifying no history of trauma  piercing  or surgery  these symptoms and examination findings suggest the possibility of an aortic dissection. His risk factors such as advanced age  male gender  hypertension  smoking  and atherosclerotic disease further increase the index of suspicion.

A 65-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking presents with acute onset  severe  sharp  and radiating chest pain that began an hour ago. The pain is described as tearing in nature  with a severity of around 8 out of 10  and the patient reports that the pain began while at rest  soon radiating to his back. The patient also claims to feel short of breath  and reveals episodes of faintness. He denies any related symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. He has no known history of coronary artery disease. The patient appears in severe distress with pale skin  diaphoretic  and blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg with a heart rate of 100 bpm. On exam  a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation can be heard. The lower extremity pulses are asymmetrical with diminished left dorsalis pedis compared to the right.

A 65-year-old African American male with a known history of poorly controlled hypertension for 20 years and 30-pack year smoking history  presents to the emergency department with a sudden intense  tearing pain in the mid-back region that radiates to the front of the chest and dyspnea. He is visibly in distress  sweating profusely and having an elevated heart rate and blood pressure. On examination  he has a difference in blood pressure between his right and left arm and a murmur on auscultation at the base of the heart. He denies any recent trauma or heavy lifting prior to the onset of symptoms. He also reports that his father passed away suddenly in his 60s with similar symptoms.

A 63-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain described as 'tearing'. Pain started about 2 hours ago  radiates to his back and progressively worsens  reaching its peak intensity within a few minutes. Additionally  the patient noted an associated shortness of breath and feeling of faintness. There was no relief with rest or nitroglycerin  which he took at home. Vital signs are notable for blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg and pulse of 100 bpm. On physical examination  a discrepancy in pulse and blood pressure between arms is noted along with a diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. Blood tests reveal a slightly elevated D-dimer level. His EKG shows no signs of ischemia or infarction. In light of his risk factors  symptoms  and physical findings  an acute aortic dissection is suspected. He will need a definitive diagnosis with a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) and emergent treatment to prevent life-threatening complications like aortic rupture.

A 68-year-old hypertensive African-American male with a recent history of cocaine use presents to the ER with a sudden and severe chest pain that radiated to his back  described as ""tearing or ripping"". His vitals show uncontrolled hypertensive crisis with BP 210/110 mm Hg. He also reports transient episodes of fainting. His past medical history suggests he has been poorly compliant with his antihypertensive medication regimens. Lab work is notable for elevated D-dimer levels. Chest x-ray shows wider mediastinum  raising suspicion of aortic dissection.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a heavy 40-pack-year smoking habit presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back  stating that it is ""tearing"" or ""ripping"" in nature. He showed signs of dizziness  shortness of breath  and excessive sweating. He reports the pain began 2 hours ago while at rest and has progressively worsened since onset. On exam  there's noted variation in blood pressures between left and right arm and diminished pedal pulses.

A 67-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use presents with sudden onset of severe interscapular back pain and dyspnea. The pain is described as tearing and is rated as a 10 on a scale from 1-10. The patient also reports feeling faint and experiencing dizziness. He denies any chest pain  nausea  vomiting or other gastrointestinal symptoms. He has no history of surgical procedures. On examination  the patient is diaphoretic with a blood pressure discrepancy between his right and left arm  with the left arm blood pressure being significantly lower. He also has a faint early diastolic murmur heard best at the right sternal border. His electrocardiogram shows non-specific ST shortening. A high clinical suspicion for aortic dissection is made.

A 60-year-old African American male with a past history of uncontrolled hypertension  current smoker  presents with a sudden  severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back. He also reports experiencing general malaise  fainting  and shortness of breath. On examination  he has different blood pressure readings in each arm and there are signs of pulse deficit and decreased urine output. His family history reveals a father who died prematurely due to cardiac diseases. He doesn't participate in any regular physical activity and follows a high cholesterol diet. He was non-compliant with his antihypertensive treatment. His history  demographics  and presenting complaints are highly suggestive of an aortic dissection.

A 66-year-old African American male patient with a known history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking comes to the emergency room alleging sharp  tearing chest and back pain lasting for 2 hours. He also reports that this acute thoracic pain seems to radiate downwards towards his abdomen. In addition to chest and back pain  the patient also exhibits symptoms of diaphoresis  and an episode of syncope. On physical examination there is a significant discrepancy in blood pressure readings between each arm (>20mmHg). His medical history includes hyperlipidemia. No history of Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndromes or congenital heart problems are reported. He has undergone no previous cardiovascular surgeries. The patient is not on any anticoagulant medication. His family history is negative for aortic aneurysm or aortic dissection. Despite his significant discomfort and distress  there are no objective signs of heart failure  such as pulmonary rales or peripheral edema.

A 67-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension  tobacco use  and Marfan syndrome presents with acute onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back. The pain started abruptly and has been constant for the past two hours. He also reports nausea  profuse sweating  and shortness of breath. On examination  his blood pressure is significantly different between the right and left arms. His heart sounds are normal  but a diastolic murmur can be heard upon auscultation. The remainder of his physical examination  including respiratory and neurologic examinations  is unremarkable.

Patient Representation:  A 63-year-old African American male current smoker with a longstanding history of uncontrolled hypertension and high cholesterol presents in the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset  severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. He also reports shortness of breath  sweating and nausea. He hasn't taken his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications regularly due to financial difficulties. He denies any recent trauma to the chest or related history of connective tissue disorders. On examination  his blood pressure is notably different between his two arms. His medical history is significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 40-pack per year smoking history. The patient's symptoms  along with his demographic representation and medical history  are best consistent with aortic dissection. Immediate intervention is required to confirm the diagnosis and manage the condition to prevent life-threatening complications.

Patient is a 66-year-old African-American male  with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use. He presents with sudden  severe and tearing chest pain that radiates to the back. The patient also reports abrupt onset of shortness of breath and a sense of impending doom. On physical examination  there is a discrepancy in blood pressure between both arms and a new diastolic murmur is heard upon auscultation of the chest. The patient is sweaty and appears distressed. His body mass index is 28  indicating overweight.

A 63-year-old African American male with a history of high blood pressure and tobacco use presents to the emergency department with sudden  severe chest pain described as a sharp tearing sensation radiating to his back  between the shoulder blades. The patient has been suffering from uncontrolled hypertension for the last ten years and has been a 30-pack-year smoker. He is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 30.2 kilograms/meter squared. The patient has been reporting increasing dizziness and confusion since the onset of the pain. This presentation of severe pain  along with his history of hypertension and high-risk behaviour of smoking  raises a high suspicion of aortic dissection.

A 70-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension and tobacco use presents to the ER with sudden onset of severe pain in his chest and back. The pain started suddenly  is described as tearing  and radiates to his back. He also complains of shortness of breath  and his blood pressure is asymmetric between arms. No previous history of surgery or other systemic disease.

A 65-year-old African American male  previously diagnosed with chronic hypertension poorly managed due to medication non-compliance  presents with sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back. He also reports a history of smoking. He was also noted to have a mild dyspnea and diaphoresis. No history of trauma is reported. On physical examination  his blood pressure is discovered to be markedly high and there is a difference in pulse and blood pressure readings between his right and left arms. No past surgical history is reported. His only known allergic reaction is to penicillin. Family history revealed father had passed away due to aortic dissection.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired  presents with acute onset of severe posterior chest pain radiating to the back. The pain is described as tearing  with an intensity of 8 out of 10. The patient has a 20-year history of uncontrolled hypertension  and a smoking history of 25 pack-years. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. He denies shortness of breath  but reports feeling faint and slightly confused. He also has a mild fever and his blood pressure is significantly higher in one arm than the other. These symptoms occurred at rest and have persisted for 3 hours. He has no known drug allergies and is currently on Lisinopril for his hypertension. His father died of a stroke at 68 years old and his older brother died of myocardial infarction at 60 years old. Review of systems is negative for lower extremity weakness or paresthesia  bladder or bowel incontinence  cough  loss of consciousness  or focal neurological deficits. Physical examination reveals a diaphoretic patient in distress with a cardiac murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space. Hazard ratio  given his risk factors and symptoms  is highly suggestive of aortic dissection.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use presents with sudden  severe chest pain that is described as tearing and radiating to the back. In the past  he was compliant with medication; however  for the last two months  he has not been able to access his medications due to a loss of insurance. The patient states that the pain started abruptly and has intensified over the past two hours. He also reports feeling dizziness  excessive sweating  and shortness of breath. On examination  he has a blood pressure of 187/110 mmHg  pulse rate of 105 beats per minute  and asymmetric blood pressure readings between both arms. The patient denies any history of trauma and has no family history of heart diseases.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Name: Male Patient X - Age: 70 years old - Race: Caucasian (White) - Occupation: Retired Engineer - Marital Status: Widowed  Medical History: - Known Hypertensive for 30 years - Diagnosed with Marfan Syndrome  a genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue  - Long history of tobacco use; quit smoking 10 years ago - Past medical history significant for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) - Treated for Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm 5 Years Ago - Father died of Stroke at the age of 60 - Mother had Aortic Aneurysm - Regular use of antihypertensive medications and low dose aspirin  Chief Complaint: - Sudden extreme chest pain radiating to the back  described as ""tearing"" or ""ripping"" - Shortness of breath - Weakness and dizziness  On Examination: - Blood pressure: High  different readings in each arm - Pulse: Rapid - Skin: Cool  sweaty - Abdominal examination: Mild tenderness over the abdominal aorta - Neurological Examination: Mild paralysis on one side of the body  Notes: - Aortic dissection incidence is highest among men aged 60 to 70  - It is more common in people with certain genetic disorders such as Marfan syndrome - Hypertension and atherosclerosis contribute as risk factors - Smoking increases the risk of aortic dissection - Family history plays an important role  - There is an association between coronary artery disease and aneurysm of the thoracic aorta; both can be caused by atherosclerosis - Asymmetry in blood pressure can be a key sign of aortic dissection - The described chest pain is typical of aortic dissection and immediate medical attention is required. - The presence of neurological symptoms may suggest the involvement of arteries supplying the brain or spinal cord.

Problem Representation:  Patient Characteristics: - Age 60s to 70s - Gender: Majority Male - Ethnicity: African-American - Occupation: Retired - Socio-Economic status: Middle-class - Sedentary Lifestyle  Medical and Family History: - Hypertension: Existing condition  well-controlled with medication but with occasional high readings noted. - Atherosclerosis: Mild to moderate degree of plaque buildup in arteries. - Family history: Father died from aortic dissection at age 70. - Smoking history: Significant  smoked half a pack daily for 40 years  quit 10 years ago. - Alcohol history: Regular alcohol use  1-2 standard drinks daily. - No previous surgeries - No known allergies  Presenting Symptoms: - Severe chest pain  described as tearing or ripping  starting in the chest and radiating towards the back. - Possible loss of consciousness. - Shortness of breath and difficulty in speaking due to pain. - Varying degrees of pain and symptoms based on the type and severity of the dissection.  Physical Examination: - Elevated blood pressure  particularly in upper extremities. - Positive for pulsus paradoxus. - Possible presence of a diastolic murmur  indicative of aortic regurgitation. - Findings can vary based on the type and location of the dissection.  Possible Imaging and Lab Tests: - CT scan with contrast: To visualize the dissection and determine its extent. - Transesophageal echocardiography: To confirm the diagnosis and assess for complications. - D-dimer test: May be elevated  normal results can help to exclude dissection. - Complete Blood Count (CBC)  Electrolytes  Troponin  BUN/creatinine: To assess for other complications or concurrent problems.  This patient fits the typical demographic and medical history of a patient presenting with aortic dissection as supported by current literature. Aortic dissection is more common in males  particularly of African-American descent  and in those aged 60-70. Hypertension  atherosclerosis  smoking  and alcohol use have all been identified as risk factors. The presentation  notably the severe tearing pain radiating to the back  is highly suggestive of the condition. Confirmatory imaging and further management would be based on the patient's overall medical condition and stability.

Problem Representation:   Subject:  Mr. Johnson is a 60-year-old African American male with a past medical history of long-standing uncontrolled hypertension and high cholesterol. His family history is significant with a dad who died of a heart attack at 65 and a brother diagnosed with abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of sharp  severe chest pain radiating to the back between the shoulder blades. The pain started an hour ago while he was resting at home and was unlike any he had ever experienced.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a fifteen-year history of hypertension which was poorly controlled despite being on medication. He also has a high cholesterol level for which he takes a statin. However  he admits not always taking it regularly due to occasional side effects. He is also a former smoker who quit 5 years ago after a 30-year history of smoking.  Family and Social History:  His father died at the age of 65 due to a myocardial infarction and his elder brother  age 64  recently underwent a surgical procedure for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He consumes alcohol occasionally and admits to a 5-year history of recreational cocaine use in his younger years but denies any recent drug use.  Current Medications:  Atenolol 50mg qDay  Lipitor 40mg qDay  This clinical scenario is representative of a high-risk demographic group (older  hypertensive male  African American  smoker  high cholesterol  family history of aortic disease) for aortic dissection. Regarding the racial bias  even though ethnicity is not identified as an independent risk factor  some studies have shown African American ethnicity had higher rates of aortic dissection  potentially due to higher prevalence of hypertension in this population. His history of poorly controlled hypertension and high cholesterol  family history  and his previous smoking and cocaine use  are all important contributing factors that increase this patient's risk of developing aortic dissection.  References:  1. Howard  D. P. J.  Banerjee  A.  Fairhead  J. F.  Perkins  J.  Silver  L. E.  & Rothwell  P. M. (2013). Population-based study of incidence and outcome of acute aortic dissection and premorbid risk factor control: 10-year results from the Oxford Vascular Study. Circulation  127(20)  2031–2037. 2. Clouse  W. D.  Hallett  J. W.  Schaff  H. V.  Gayari  M. M.  Ilstrup  D. M.  & Melton III  L. J. (2004). Acute aortic dissection: population-based incidence compared with degenerative aortic aneurysm rupture. Mayo Clinic Proceedings  Elsevier.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department. He is an ex-smoker with a 35-pack-year history  quit smoking 10 years ago. He takes medication for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed well for the past 15 years. He also has a history of elevated cholesterol levels requiring statin therapy. The patient is retired and lives alone.  Clinical Presentation: The patient presents with sudden severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain is described as tearing and came on suddenly. It began while he was cleaning his home. He describes feeling nauseous and anxious.  Family History: There is a relevant family history of cardiovascular diseases  including his father who had a myocardial infarction at age 60  and his maternal grandfather who died from a stroke.   Social History: He denies alcohol or illicit drug use. He is relatively active  often going for walks and doing exercises at home.  Evaluation: Upon examination  blood pressure is found to be markedly different between his right and left arms. There are no significant murmurs and lung sounds are clear.  a) Problem: Suspected aortic dissection b) Context: A high-risk male patient with an appropriate clinical history and relevant symptoms c) Indicators: History of smoking  hypertension  type II diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia; sudden severe chest pain radiating to the back  noticeable difference in blood pressure between two arms. d) Actions: The patient is immediately referred for a CT angiography of his chest and further cardiovascular evaluation to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the aortic dissection. e) Follow-up/Outcome: Pending results of the imaging  the patient will likely be admitted to the hospital for monitoring and treatment  which may include surgery if the dissection involves the ascending aorta or if his condition worsens. f) Notes: An aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnosis and management. Patient profiles like this one  with multiple risk factors  necessitate a high index of suspicion when they present with the appropriate symptoms.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: The patient we are considering is a 67-year-old African American male  as the incidence of aortic dissection is reportedly higher in males with an average age of onset around 60-70 years. It is also observed to be a bit more prevalent among Black or African American people compared to other races.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented in the emergency department (ED) exhibiting severe sharp  tearing chest pain that radiates to the back. The pain was acute in onset. He also reports symptoms of light-headedness and shortness of breath.   Past Medical History: This patient has a history of untreated high blood pressure (hypertension)  a significant risk factor for aortic dissection. He also had a prior history of smoking  which has been linked to cardiovascular diseases. There's a family history of connective tissue disorders  particularly Marfan syndrome in this case  which increases the risk for aortic diseases. Finally  the patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) about 7 years ago  another factor that could contribute to the current condition.  Current Medications: The patient is currently not under any antihypertensive medication  resulting in his hypertension being uncontrolled. There are no other medications recorded  and it's noted that the patient has been non-compliant with prescriptions in the past.  Physical Examination: On physical exam  the patient appeared in severe distress. Blood pressure readings in both arms showed significant difference  a possible indicator of aortic dissection. Heart rate was slightly accelerated  and there were audible diastolic murmurs noted over the aortic area.  Based on the age  gender  race  severe tearing chest pain  and blood pressure differential  the patient's symptoms point towards a possible aortic dissection  that needs to be confirmed with appropriate imaging techniques  including echocardiography or computed tomography angiogram (CTA).

Problem representation:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male with a previous medical history of uncontrolled high blood pressure  renal dysfunction and peripheral artery disease  presents with severe chest pain that radiates to the back  along with nausea  heavy sweating  shortness of breath and syncope. He has a significantly high body mass index of 35 and used to smoke 1 pack of cigarettes per day until five years ago. His current medications include aspirin  atorvastatin and nifedipine.  In terms of family history  his father had a history of coronary artery disease and his mother had a stroke at the age of 70. Mr. Johnson himself has a history of heavy alcohol use  but he quit fifteen years ago. He has been working as a mechanic  known for its high-stress environment  and does not engage in regular physical exercise. He has missed several primary care appointments in the past and does not adhere to a healthy diet.  He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication  which has led to poorly controlled blood pressure over several years. He is also notorious for avoiding healthcare visits due to the fear of diagnoses and interventions. His CBC  lipid panel  and kidney function tests have been abnormal in the past. He had a bout of acute kidney injury three years ago which has led to chronic kidney disease. His previous EKG reports have shown left ventricular hypertrophy.  Based on the literature  Mr. Johnson falls into the highest risk demographic for aortic dissection given his age  race  male gender  hypertension  smoking and alcohol history  obesity  and peripheral artery disease. His presentation is also consistent with classic symptoms of aortic dissection  which include severe chest pain  radiated pain and symptoms related to organ ischemia. Non-compliant behavior with his antihypertensive drugs may have also contributed to his condition.   In conclusion  Mr. Johnson is a high-risk patient for aortic dissection and requires urgent diagnostic and potentially surgical intervention.

Problem Representation:   Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to the back. The patient is a heavy smoker having 50 pack-year tobacco smoking history. The patient also reports previous history of hypertension for which he has been on medication.   Past Medical History: The patient's medical history involves high blood pressure which he has been dealing with for the past 15 years. He has been prescribed medication but the control has been inconsistent. Records show the patient has been incompliant with his hypertensive medication. He also has a history of smoking excessively for decades. No other significant issues like heart disease  diabetes or other chronic illnesses are found in the patient’s past medical records.   Family History:  The patient's father and uncle had a history of heart disease and hypertension.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with sudden  severe chest pain that has started a few hours prior to consultation. The pain tends to fluctuate  but it does not subside completely. The nature of the pain is tearing  sharp  ripping  and it radiates to his back and neck. The patient reports feeling faint and dizzy.   Physical Examination: Physical examination reveals Pulse deficit and blood pressure difference between the left and right arm which rises a suspicion of aortic dissection. The pulse  blood pressure  and other preliminary physical examination results are significantly abnormal.  Considering the manifestation of symptoms  the medical history of the patient  the presentation of severe tearing chest and back pain  pulse differential  and hypertension  suspicion for aortic dissection gets higher and demands immediate attention and further investigation.  Relevant Demographic Data: From the literature  we found that aortic dissection is more common in men than women  with about 65% of cases being male. It most often occurs in people aged 65 and older and is more common in Caucasian men. Risk factors associated with aortic dissection include hypertension  smoking  and a history of heart disease. With these considerations  our patient representation aligns with accurate demographic​ representation.

Patient Representation:  Profile:  The patient is a 69-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension presenting with sudden and severe chest pain.  Demographics: The patient lives in an urban environment and has a history of smoking for 40 years  recently quit last year. He is retired and lives with his wife  who is his caregiver. He has a record of occasional alcohol consumption. The patient is obese with a BMI of 30.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presents with sudden  severe chest pain  which he describes as ""tearing"". The pain seemed to radiate towards the back. Additionally  the patient seems a bit anxious and is sweating profusely.   Past Medical History:  Significant for hypertension  which has been somewhat poorly controlled. He has had episodic increases in systolic blood pressure  noted to be as high as 180 mm Hg. The patient also has a history of high cholesterol  for which he takes medications.   Family History: His father died at the age of 76 from myocardial infarction. His mother died at the age of 82 from a stroke. The patient has one younger brother who is living with type 2 diabetes.  Relevant Test Results: His chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. His aortic diameter measured via Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is >5cm  indicative of aneurysmal dilation. Recent blood pressure readings show systolic pressure consistently above 140 mm Hg  despite medical management.  In conclusion  this is a high-risk patient due to age  ethnicity  uncontrolled hypertension  history of tobacco use  and family history of cardiovascular diseases. Reports of acute onset  severe chest pain combined with radiographic findings suggests possible aortic dissection. Further diagnostic testing is necessary to confirm.   (Note: The demographics here are broadly representative and based on general literature suggesting that older  hypertensive males  especially of African American ethnicity  and smokers are at higher risk for aortic dissection. But the probability of these conditions may vary with individual risk factors and geographic location.)

Problem Representation:  Patient: A 65-year-old African American male  History: The patient has a previous medical history of high blood pressure which has been poorly controlled for the past 10 years. He was diagnosed with hypertension in his mid-50s and was prescribed antihypertensive medication  which he admits to not taking consistently. He also has a 20-pack year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. The patient doesn't have any history of cardiac surgery. His father died from a stroke at the age of 70  and he has a younger brother with coronary artery disease.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain  described as sharp and tearing  radiating to the back. The pain started about an hour ago and has been progressive.   Vital Signs: Blood pressure is found to be significantly different between both arms  with the right arm being 145/95 mmHg and the left arm being 120/80mmHg. Pulse rate is elevated at 110 beats per minute. Oxygen saturation is 95% in room air.   Physical Examination: The patient is anxious and diaphoretic. There is decreased breath sound in left lower lung fields and a grade II/VI diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border.  The aforementioned patient representation is typical for aortic dissection  reflecting demographic information from literature that suggests higher prevalence among males and African Americans. It includes relevant risk factors like hypertension  smoking  and family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient's presentation  physical exam findings  and vitals are suggestive of aortic dissection  a life-threatening condition  warranting immediate diagnostic investigation and management.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - A 70-year-old African-American male.  Demographic and Lifestyle Characteristics: - The patient is a retired truck driver  living with his wife. - He is overweight with a BMI of 30.  - His lifestyle includes a diet high in fats and salts  sedentary with minimal physical activity.  - He has been a lifelong smoker with around 40 pack years of smoking history. - He admits to chronic alcohol consumption.  Relevant Past Medical History: - The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years. - About 5 years back  he suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA) but recovered with no residual damage. - He also had a Marfan syndrome evaluation that came back inconclusive  which requires further follow-up. - He has often complained of chest pain over the last year which was attributed to costochondritis. - Five months ago  he was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and is not well controlled.  Current Problems: - The patient presents with a sudden and severe tearing chest pain  radiating to the back between the shoulder blades. - His blood pressure on presentation is elevated at 200/120 mmHg. - He appears pale  sweaty  and in intense pain. - Pulsus paradoxus is noted on physical examination and heart murmur is detected.  Possible Disease Associations: The given symptoms  clinical presentation  and medical history suggest a possible diagnosis of aortic dissection. His uncontrolled hypertension  smoking history  and diabetic condition contribute significantly towards this suspicion as they are known risk factors. His age  gender  and ethnicity also line up with the demographic factors typically associated with increased risk of aortic dissection.  Next Steps: Further diagnostic tests such as a CT scan or angiography will be required to confirm the suspected diagnosis of aortic dissection. Immediate medical attention to control the elevated blood pressure and manage the pain is necessary. A thorough cardiovascular examination and consultation with a cardiologist is needed for this patient.  Based on literary studies  aortic dissection is more prevalent in males  often above 60 years old. Hypertension is the most common risk factor. Other risk factors include tobacco use  high-intensity weightlifting  pregnancy and conditions such as Marfan syndrome  bicuspid aortic valve or a history of heart surgery. Ethnicity is also considered as a predisposing factor  with African-Americans having a higher prevalence. It is thus critical to take these into consideration when assessing a patient for a potential aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:   Subject: Mr. Doe  a 62-year-old African American male  presented with sharp  severe chest pain radiating to the back  accompanied by shortness of breath and faintness. His medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension for the last 15 years  smoking approximately one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years  and a family history of vascular diseases. He does not regularly take his antihypertensive medications.  On physical examination  he presented with varied blood pressure readings on both arms  a rapid heartbeat  and slight paralysis of the lower extremities. He appears anxious and diaphoretic. There is no history of trauma or injury. He works as an administrative officer  is married with two children  and lives in an urban area.  Background: Studies have shown that the peak age for aortic dissection is the sixth and seventh decades of life  with a mean age of 63 years. Men account for approximately two-thirds of cases and are twice as likely to suffer from it than women. African Americans have a higher predisposition towards this condition  and hypertension is considered a key risk factor  present in more than 75% of cases. Other risk factors include smoking  hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol)  atherosclerosis  and family history of vascular diseases.  Risk stratification: Given the patient's presentation and past medical history  Mr. Doe has several risk factors making him at a high risk for aortic dissection: age  male gender  African American ethnicity  hypertension  smoking history  and family history of vascular diseases. Immediate diagnostic procedures and appropriate medical intervention are required.  Plan: Immediate CT angiography is necessary to confirm aortic dissection diagnosis. Given the acute presentation  hypertension  and high suspicion of aortic dissection  the patient should be admitted to the hospital intensive care unit for close monitoring and quick intervention if the condition deteriorates. Antihypertensive therapy should be initiated immediately  aiming to control blood pressure. If the diagnosis is confirmed  surgical consultation will be necessary.    Follow up and recommendation: he should quit smoking and he should be followed up closely by a cardiologist  a vascular surgeon  and primary care physician who can address his hypertension control and overall cardiovascular risk.   Note: This problem representation is a general indication. Each patient should be individually evaluated and managed based on their conditions and characteristics.

Problem Representation:  I. Demographics:  The patient is a 61-year-old African-American male who currently works as a truck driver. His body mass index (BMI) is 28  indicating that he is overweight. He is a current smoker  consuming 1 pack of cigarettes per day over the last 25 years. He is not a heavy alcohol drinker and does not take any drugs. He lives alone and has no significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. His dietary habits involve fast food and high-sodium snacks due to his demanding work schedule.  II. Clinical Presentation and History:  The patient presents with sudden severe chest pain that is described as tearing in nature and radiates to his back. He has associated symptoms of profuse sweating  faintness  and shortness of breath. There is no history of fever  cough  hemoptysis  or other respiratory symptoms. He denies any symptoms of right upper quadrant pain  jaundice  or gastrointestinal symptoms.  III. Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension  which was diagnosed three years ago. He has been irregular with his blood pressure medications and tends to forget to take them due to his irregular work schedule. He shows no history of diabetes mellitus or hyperlipidemia. Records indicate that he has not been screened for aneurysms or other related diseases due to his lack of consistent healthcare follow-up.  In terms of surgeries  he had a right inguinal hernia repair approximately 5 years ago but no other major surgeries or hospitalizations. He has no known drug allergies but is known to skip his daily antihypertensive medication (Metoprolol) due to occasional side effects involving mild dizziness.  His latest blood pressure measurement indicates high blood pressure (165/95 mmHg). His last Lipid profile check was 18 months ago  and it showed normal values. For routine diabetes screening  the patient declined further examination. His resting electrocardiogram  done a year ago  was normal.  IV. Social History  The patient lives alone and works as a long-haul truck driver. He currently smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and has an irregular dietary and sleep schedule due to his work. He does not exercise regularly. The patient acknowledges poor control over his blood pressure  due to often forgetting to take his medicine because of his busy and unpredictable work schedule.   This patient  being African American and male  falls into a demographic that carries a higher risk of aortic dissection. His age  hypertension  and smoking habits further compound his risk. His symptoms of severe and sudden chest pain that radiates to his back carry high suspicion for aortic dissection  particularly given his personal and demographic predispositions.

Patient Profile:  Demographics: - Gender: Male - Age: 65 years - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired schoolteacher - Socioeconomic status: Lower-middle-class - Residence: Urban  Past Medical History: - Hypertension: Diagnosed 10 years ago  on medication (ACE inhibitors)  sometimes noncompliant with medication. - Smoking: Smoked 1 pack a day for 30 years  quit 5 years ago. - Elevated cholesterol: Managed with diet and statin medication. - No history of diabetes. Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired schoolteacher from an urban setting presents with sudden severe chest pain described as tearing or ripping  radiating to the back. The patient has a significant history of hypertension diagnosed a decade ago and has been prescribed ACE inhibitors  although compliance to medication is intermittent. The patient has no past medical history of diabetes.  There is a higher incidence of aortic dissection in males  particularly of Caucasian ethnicity. Elevated cholesterol levels could have aided in plaque formation  further stressing the aortic wall. It's also important to note the patient's age; aortic dissection is more common in those over 60.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 69-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of systemic hypertension  a 40-year history of smoking and a confirmed diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presents to the Emergency Department with severe  sudden onset chest pain that he describes as 'tearing' in nature. The pain is located in his anterior chest and radiates to his back. The patient additionally expresses feelings of anxiety and reports symptoms like inclining dyspnea and palpitations.  Onset: The pain began around 2 hours ago while he was at rest  watching television. His symptoms have continued to intensify since onset.  Associated factors: His blood pressure reading revealed an abnormally high measurement. Additionally  the patient has diaphoresis and appears to be in distress.   Past Medical History: Diagnosis 1 - Systemic hypertension Diagnosis 2 - Marfan syndrome  The patient has been on anti-hypertensive medication for the past ten years  however  he admits to not managing his blood pressure adequately and states that his medication adherence has been poor. His history of smoking has made him more susceptible to developing a variety of cardiovascular health conditions.  Relevant Family History: The patient's family has a documented history of aortic disease  with his father dying suddenly at the age of 57 from an aortic dissection.  Physical Examination Findings: On examination  he has asymmetrical blood pressure readings in his arms with diminished peripheral pulses. Additionally  cardiac examination reveals a diastolic murmur  consistent with aortic insufficiency.   Clinical Reasoning: The patient's age  gender  aforementioned symptomatology  and the mentioned risk factors (hypertension  smoking  history of Marfan syndrome  and family history of aortic disease) incline suspicion towards an aortic dissection. The 'tearing' chest pain radiating to the back  his high blood pressure readings  and the presence of a diastolic murmur further support this hypothesis. Thus  the patient should be efficiently assessed using appropriate diagnostic tools like Computed Tomography (CT) scan for definite diagnosis and further management.

Problem Representation:  Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old African American male. He is a retired mechanic and a current smoker with a pack-per-day habit for the past 40 years. He drinks alcohol occasionally and reports a diet high in red meat but low in fruits and vegetables.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient was brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain began about an hour prior to admission while the patient was in his garage working on a car.   Past Medical History:  He has a confirmed history of hypertension  which has been poorly controlled for the past 15 years. In addition  the patient was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 5 years ago but has been non-compliant with his lipid-lowering medication. He also has peripheral artery disease diagnosed three years ago  for which he refuses to change his lifestyle.    Family History: The patient's father died of a myocardial infarction in his 70s  and his mother passed away from a stroke in her late 60s. His older brother had an aortic dissection at the age of 62.   Physical Examination: On examination  he appears to be in severe distress with diaphoresis. Blood pressure measurements show a significant difference between his right and left arms. Auscultation reveals a murmur consistent with aortic insufficiency.   This representation is in line with findings in medical literature  which state that older-aged  male  African American individuals with a history of smoking and uncontrolled hypertension are at a significantly higher risk for aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 69-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. X  presents to the emergency department with severe and sudden onset chest pain that has been ongoing for the past two hours. He described the pain as a sharp  ""tearing"" sensation radiating to his back. On a scale from 1-10  he rates the intensity of the pain as 9. He appears pale  anxious  and diaphoretic. He is a long-term smoker with a 50-pack-year history.   Background: Mr. X has a known history of hypertension  which his primary care physician has struggled to control despite medication compliance and lifestyle modifications. He also has a relevant family history of aortic dissection  with his father having suffered from the disease at a similar age. Furthermore  he has a history of high cholesterol and minor coronary artery disease  for which he takes aspirin and statins.  Personal habits: He is a retired school teacher with a sedentary lifestyle. His diet is high in fat and cholesterol  and he consumes moderate alcohol. He does not engage in regular physical activity owing to his demanding job and has been under considerable stress recently.  In this case  the problem space is the aortic dissection  and the demographic representation focuses on the increased risk associated with male sex  older age  and white race. The relevant past medical history (e.g.  familial predisposition  hypertension  high cholesterol  coronary artery disease  smoking) helps to illuminate potential contributing risk factors that must be considered.   Relevant literature: Literature suggests that the majority of patients with aortic dissection are male (75%)  and the mean age at presentation is 63 years (Clouse et al.  2004). However  the incidence significantly increases after age 60. White individuals  particularly men  are of higher risk (Howard et al.  2013). Smoking and hypertension are considered among the top risk factors  contributing to more than 70% of all cases. Family history cannot be ignored as it is prevalent in about a fifth of cases (Nienaber & Clough  2015). Furthermore  pre-existing cardiovascular diseases also increase the risk of aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:   Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African-American male who presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sudden onset  severe chest pain that has been radiating to his back. He describes the pain as tearing and says it is unlike anything he has experienced before. He also reports feeling lightheaded and has vomited once at home.  Relevant Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a known history of high blood pressure (hypertension) for the past 10 years  which is poorly controlled with medication. He also has a history of moderate tobacco use  smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. There is also a known history of cardiovascular disease  with a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He denies illicit drug use but reports having chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to his long history of smoking. He has no known drug allergies. His father died of a stroke in his early 70s  and his mother had breast cancer.  Demographic Information: Mr. Johnson is retired from his job as a truck driver. He lives with his wife and they have two grown children who live out of state. He completed high school but did not attend college. He has been on Medicare since he retired. He claims to have average diet habits  yet confesses he rarely exercises.   Literature Perspective: Literature indicates that demographic characteristics such as being of African-American ethnicity  being a male  and being over the age of 60 pose an increased risk for aortic dissection (AD). Additionally  AD is typically associated with a history of hypertension  tobacco use  and pre-existing cardiovascular conditions. These risk factors  coupled with his presenting symptoms  make aortic dissection a primary diagnostic concern for Mr. Johnson.

Demographic Characterization:  Patient's Identity: 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Relevant Past Medical History:  1. The patient has a well-documented history of hypertension. 2. He also has a history of tobacco use (30 pack-years history  quit 10 years ago). 3. Diagnosed with Marfan's syndrome at an early age. 4. The pain radiates towards the back and seems to move downwards. He is visibly in distress and appears pale and sweaty. Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: The patient is a 70-year-old African American male. The patient lives in an urban setting with his wife and is a retired school teacher. He is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. He claims to drink alcohol sparingly  primarily on social occasions.   Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension for about 25 years managed with amlodipine. He was previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus approximately 15 years ago managed with metformin. The patient also has a history of hypercholesterolemia managed with simvastatin. There are no known allergies to medications.   Representation of the Primary Problem: The patient reports chest pain that began suddenly about 12 hours ago. It was described as a sharp  severe pain that radiated to his back. It was accompanied by profuse sweating  nausea  and vomiting. He also experienced shortness of breath. There is no prior history of similar pain.   Evidence Of Need: The sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back  in combination with his past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  points towards a possible aortic dissection. Aortic dissections predominantly occur in older males  fortifying the patient falls into the risk category. Hypertension is also a major risk factor for aortic dissection  which is prevalent in this patient's chart. Immediate investigation and management may be necessary to prevent serious complications such as rupture of the aorta which could lead to a life-threatening situation.  Rationale Statement: Given the patient's demographics  past medical history  and presentation  it is crucial to evaluate him for aortic dissection. African American males over the age of 65 have a higher prevalence of hypertension and are at an increased risk of aortic dissection. His history of hypertension  as well as his age  race  and gender  put him in high risk category  justifying further diagnostic studies  such as CT angiography of the aorta. Concurrently  this case must be managed as a medical emergency  to reduce the risk of morbidity and mortality.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male  retired from his job. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years and has a moderate drinking habit. He leads a sedentary lifestyle  with minimal physical activity. His diet is not balanced and tends to be high in fats and cholesterol.  Chief Complaint: He presents to the ER with a severe tearing or ripping pain in the chest which started about 2 hours ago. The pain seems to radiate to his back.  Past Medical History: He has a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years  for which he has been non-compliant with his medications. He was diagnosed with moderately enlarged aorta (4.5 cm) two years ago during a routine check-up. He also has a history of high cholesterol levels. His family history includes one brother with an aortic aneurysm and one sister deceased from aortic dissection.  Demographic Characterization: According to published literature  a typical patient with aortic dissection is adult  often male  mostly between the ages of 60-70. Problem Representation:  Patient Information:  67-year-old African American male from an urban area  Chief Complaint:  Intense and sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back  Past Medical History:  The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension. The patient's demographic information and past medical history  especially of hypertension and smoking  are consistent with risk factors for aortic dissection.

His sedentary lifestyle could also have contributed to his overall cardiovascular risk profile. In conclusion  the patient is a typical representation of a patient presenting with an aortic dissection  given his demographic profile  past medical history  and presenting symptoms.

History of tobacco use: Mr. Smith was a heavy smoker for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. 4. Prior cardiac surgery: The patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 5 years ago.  Family History: A history of aortic dissection in a first-degree relative.  This paradigmatic case is based on the epidemiological data present in the literature that suggest aortic dissections are more common in men than in women  with a peak incidence in the 6th and 7th decade of life. It often presents as a consequence of uncontrolled hypertension over a long duration and is frequently associated with smoking  hyperlipidemia  prior cardiac surgery  and is more common in caucasians. Furthermore  a familiar trend pointing to a genetic predisposition has been identified.  Risk Factors: The risk factors include hypertension  raised cholesterol levels  smoking  prior heart surgery  and family history.  Objective findings on physical examination:  1. Pulse deficit 2. Aortic regurgitation 3. Hypertension in the right arm compared to the left 4. Neurological signs related to ischemia in the territories supplied by the carotid or vertebral arteries.  The investigation included an immediate CT Scan which confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection. Urgent management has been planned with the cardiothoracic team.  The patient has been counselled about the condition  the urgent need for surgical intervention  and the risks associated with it.

Patient Representation:  Mr. Green is a 62-year-old African-American male who works as an electrician. He presents with severe chest pain that's been worsening since yesterday. The pain starts from the center of his chest and radiates to his back  described as tearing or ripping. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  anxiety  nausea  fainting and sudden difficulty in speaking or understanding speech.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Green was diagnosed with hypertension eight years ago  which remains poorly controlled. He has also been a smoker for the past 40 years with an average of 20 cigarettes per day. He has a history of high cholesterol levels  known for 10 years  for which he takes atorvastatin. He reports no history of diabetes or kidney disease. Mr. Green infrequently drinks alcohol and denies any recreational drug use. There is a family history of hypertension and heart disease.  Explanation:  Aortic dissection is more common in males  occurring in two thirds of patients  and the peak prevalence is in the 6th and 7th decades of life. African-American males are at a higher risk factor due to the disproportionate prevalence of hypertension in this demographic group. Smoking and dyslipidemia are also predisposing factors. Hypertension is the most common risk factor  found in more than 70% of patients. Patients often have a history of cardiovascular disease  atherosclerosis  or prior cardiac surgery. Family history of aortic disease may be present in around one fifth of patients. Finally  chest pain  often described as severe  tearing or ripping  and sometimes radiating to the back  is typically the presenting symptom. Other symptoms may include those related to malperfusion syndromes  such as syncope or stroke symptoms.

Problem Representation:   Demographic Information:  A 65-year-old male who is mainly of Caucasian descent. He's a former smoker and alcoholic  with a sedentary lifestyle and a diet that tends to be high in fat and cholesterol.  Clinical Presentation:  The patient presents with sudden and severe chest pain that radiates to the back  similar to the pain in a heart attack. He also reports shortness of breath  anxiety  weakness  and fainting spells. The patient categorizes his pain as sharp and tearing. This report represents a typical patient who might present with aortic dissection. However  it's important to note that the presentation can vary significantly. Complete patient history  thorough physical examination  and necessary diagnostic procedures must be carried out to confirm the diagnosis and form an effective treatment plan.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 60-year-old African American male  current smoker who has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.   Demographic: As per literature  an aortic dissection tends to occur more frequently in males than in females. It is also more common among people aged 50 and above. African-Americans have a higher risk compared to other races. As a 60-year-old African American male  the patient falls within the highest risk category.  Risk Factors: 1. Hypertension: Patient has long-standing uncontrolled hypertension. Hypertension is the most common risk factor for aortic dissection. 2. Smoking: The patient is a current smoker. Smoking causes damage to the blood vessels  increasing the risk of aortic dissection. 3. Hypercholesterolemia: Patient has a history of hypercholesterolemia. High cholesterol can lead to atherosclerosis  which can weaken the aorta and increase the risk of dissection.  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension: Long-standing uncontrolled hypertension predisposes to aortic dissection. 2. Hypercholesterolemia: Chronic high cholesterol levels put the patient at a higher risk of developing atherosclerotic changes  which increases the risk of dissection. 3. Severe chest pain that radiates to the back (tearing or ripping)  2. Shortness of breath 3. Loss of consciousness   Based on these findings  a strong clinical suspicion for potential Aortic Dissection is present. Further investigation with imaging studies such as a CT scan or MRI should be immediately pursued.

Problem Representation:  1. Patient. Demographic Information:  John  a 60-year-old Caucasian male presents himself as a patient. He is a former smoker and currently works as a manager in a high-stress job. He is about 5'10"" and weighs 180 lbs indicating a normal body mass index.  2. Presenting Complaint:  John presents with a sudden severe chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes the pain as tearing or ripping. He has a history of hypertension which is not very well controlled. The pain intensified over a period of hours.  3. Past Medical History:  John was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 45. He has a history of heavy smoking for 20 years but quit 10 years back. He also has hyperlipidemia  and a family history of aortic disease.  4. Review of Systems:  John’s hypertension and cholesterol have been managed with medication  but he has expressed difficulty maintaining a strict regimen due to the nature of his job. He endorses feeling the chest pain around the time of waking up.  5. Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  his blood pressure was found to be markedly high with differences in upper and lower extremity readings. He is mildly dyspneic but pulses are palpable and symmetrical. Heart sounds appear normal with no murmur.   Relevant Data  Literature-Based:  According to the literature  up to three-quarters of all patients presenting with aortic dissection are male  and most are aged over 60 (Khan et al.  2002). Having an existing condition of hypertension  smoking history  and a family history of the disease increases the risk of developing aortic dissection (Nienaber & Clough  2015). A high-stress job may also contribute to poorly controlled blood pressure  thereby contributing to the risk of aortic dissection. In terms of presenting symptoms  abrupt  severe chest or back pain is the classic symptom most often resulting from the initial aortic tear (Nienaber & Clough  2015). If the area of dissection restricts blood flow  peripheral pulses may differ. Hence  different readings from upper and lower extremities could hint an ongoing aortic dissection. Some may also present with a normal heart exam. This demographic characterization and medical history align closely with the presentation and risk factors found in the existing literature.   References:  - Khan IA  Nair CK. Clinical  diagnostic  and management perspectives of aortic dissection. Chest. 2002;122(1):311-328.  - Nienaber CA  Clough RE. Management of acute aortic dissection. Lancet. 2015;385(9970):800-811.

Patient Profile:  John Brown is a 67-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department with sudden-onset and severe chest pain described as ""tearing"". The pain started about an hour ago when he was out for a morning walk. The pain radiates to his back and Mr. Brown has complained that it is worsening over time  a characteristic which tends to differ from his occasional angina pain.  Demographic Characterization:  John is a retired engineer  a non-smoker  and does not drink alcohol. He lives with his wife in their home. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases - his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Past Medical History:  He has a past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  for which he has been having regular follow-ups  though his compliance with the antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications is questionable. He also has a history of stable angina and was prescribed nitroglycerin as and when required. John had a renal stone surgery 20 years ago but has had no recurrence of stones. He does not have any known allergies.  Upon examination  his pulse was irregular and blood pressure readings were vastly different in the right and left arms. His medical provider noted an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border.  According to the literature  factors such as prolonged hypertension  older age  male sex  and African American ethnicity are known risk factors for aortic dissection. Non-compliance with antihypertensive medication could have led to persistent high blood pressure leading to mechanical stress on the aortic wall. Moreover  his symptoms of severe chest and back pain along with the blood pressure discrepancy in the arms align with typical presentations of aortic dissection  warranting immediate investigation and intervention.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 67-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain is described as tearing or ripping  with a 10/10 severity. The patient reports history of hypertension.   Demographics: Age: Studies suggest that the incidence of aortic dissection is higher among older individuals  with the majority of cases occurring in individuals between the ages of 60 and 80. The mean age at presentation is about 63 years. Gender: Aortic dissection is more common in males  with a male to female ratio of about 2:1. Race/Ethnicity: Aortic dissection rates are reportedly higher in Caucasians compared to other races.  Past Medical History: Hypertension: Hypertension is the most common predisposing factor  present in approximately 75% of cases of aortic dissection. Cardiac surgery or catheterization: Procedures that involve the aorta can lead to aortic dissection. Atherosclerosis: Atherosclerosis can lead to weakening of the aortic wall  predisposing to aortic dissection. Connective tissue disorders: Disorders such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can increase the risk of aortic dissection. Family history: There is an increased risk of aortic dissection in individuals with a family history of the condition. Cocaine use: Cocaine use can lead to an acute rise in blood pressure  increasing the risk of aortic dissection.  Presenting Symptoms: Chest pain: Severe chest pain is the most common symptom of aortic dissection. It often has a sudden onset and may be described as sharp  tearing  or ripping. Pain radiation: The pain may radiate to the neck  jaw  back  or arms. Syncope: Fainting may occur due to decreased blood flow to the brain. Shortness of breath: This may occur due to involvement of the aortic valve or pulmonary artery  resulting in heart failure. Pulse discrepancy: A difference in pulse between the right and left arms may be noted. Neurologic symptoms: If the dissection involves the carotid arteries  patients may present with stroke-like symptoms.   The problem representation will allow for appropriate diagnostic and management strategies to be implemented  including immediate imaging studies for confirmation of diagnosis and possibly urgent surgical intervention.

The pain started when the patient was at rest at home yesterday evening and has radiated to his back. - Associated symptoms: Difficulty breathing  profuse upper body sweating  nausea  rapid heart rate (tachycardia) and fluctuating blood pressures.
