This representation reflects the demographics of a typical aortic dissection patient according to the literature. Significant gender-related differences in the infrarenal aortic diameter of patients undergoing screening for abdominal aortic aneurysms. J Vasc Surg. 2002;35(5):947-952.

He is known to have high cholesterol levels as well. - Family History: No known family history of heart diseases or conditions  including aortic dissection. His father died of lung cancer  and his mother had diabetes and hypertension. - Social History: The patient was a heavy smoker and drinker until he underwent bypass surgery  after which he quit both.  Physical Examination:  - General Appearance: The patient appears to be in discomfort and distress with excessive perspiration. - Vitals: Blood pressure is significantly different between the two arms  the pulse is rapid and feeble.  - Cardiovascular system: Heart sounds are faint with a diastolic murmur noted. - Respiratory System: Shortness of breath with rapid shallow breathing with otherwise clear lungs.    Diagnostic Evaluation:  - Blood tests: Elevated D-dimer and slightly increased white blood cell count.  - Imaging: CT angiography indicates the presence of an aortic dissection in the ascending aorta. - EKG changes suggestive of left ventricle strain pattern.   Note: The demographic profile is based on the literature that suggests that aortic dissection is more common in males  particularly in their 60s and 70s  and occurs more frequently in individuals of African American and Asian ethnicity. Furthermore  conditions such as hypertension  atherosclerosis  and smoking also increase the risk of having an aortic dissection. The presentation  clinical findings  and diagnostic evaluation mentioned above are typical of a patient presenting with an aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 66-year-old African American male  with a reported body mass index (BMI) of 29.5  indicating obesity. He has a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia and has been a smoker for almost 30 years. There is a family history of both heart disease and high blood pressure.   Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presented with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that had radiated to the back  specifically between the shoulder blades. The pain was described as sharp and tearing  starting from the upper front of the chest and moving toward the back. His vitals showed high blood pressure (165/100 mmHg) and a rapid heart rate. The patient also experienced symptoms such as shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea.  Past Medical History:  Longstanding poorly controlled hypertension was evident in his medical record for the last 15 years  and he was irregular on his antihypertensive medication. His dyslipidemia was diagnosed around 10 years ago and he was on statins. He was also a heavy smoker  with around 20 cigarettes/day  and had been smoking for the last 30 years.   Further Examination/Test Result:  A chest X-ray was carried out  which suggested widening of the mediastinum. The suspicion of an aortic dissection was confirmed by a subsequent computed tomography angiography (CTA)  which showed a dissection starting from the ascending aorta and extending into the descending part.  Note: This is a prototypical scenario and may not represent all cases of aortic dissection.   Sources:  1. Tsai TT  Nienaber CA  Eagle KA. Acute aortic syndromes. Circulation. 2005;112(24):3802-3813. 2. Howard DPJ  Banerjee A  Fairhead JF  et al. Population-Based Study of Incidence and Outcome of Acute Aortic Dissection and Premorbid Risk Factor Control: 10-Year Results From the Oxford Vascular Study. Circulation. 2013;127(20):2031-2037.

Patient Information:  John D.  a 60-year-old African-American male  presents himself in the emergency room of a local hospital. His weight is 210 lbs and his height is 6 feet  giving him a BMI of 28.4. He is a high-ranking officer in the military forces and leads a high-stress lifestyle. He reports being a smoker for around 35 years with a pack per day consumption. He also admits to a moderate consumption of alcohol.  Chief Complaint:  John complains of a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. He describes it as tearing or ripping. He reports the pain began at rest  and that it is unlike any pain he's previously experienced.   Past Medical History:  Upon review of his past medical history  John has a diagnosis of hypertension  which has been inconsistently controlled over the last ten years. He has been taking anti-hypertensive medication irregularly. He has no history of diabetes  but his cholesterol levels have been on the higher side in his last few regular check-ups. He is not currently on any lipid-lowering medications. There is no history of heart surgeries  but his father died of a heart attack at the age of 65. No history of Marfan syndrome or other connective tissue disorders could be traced in the family history.  On examination:  He appears to be in severe pain and distress with a blood pressure of 155/105 mmHg in his right arm and slightly lower 140/100 mmHg blood pressure in the left arm. His heart rate is 130 beats per minute. His respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  and his oxygen saturation rate is 95% in room air. The cardiovascular system examination revealed a normally located apex beat without any other abnormal findings on auscultation.   Summary:  Based on the chief complaint  medical history  and physical examination  the most likely diagnosis for John is acute aortic dissection  consistent with the demographic pattern of this disease  which typically occurs more commonly in males around the age of 60  particularly in individuals with a history of hypertension and smoking. His ethnic background of being African-American also puts him at a higher risk. A chest x-ray along with further diagnostic procedures including a CT scan or an MRI of the chest might be needed to confirm the diagnosis. The high-stress lifestyle  inconsistent blood pressure control  and familial history of cardiovascular disease add to the complexity of the case. A cardiologist should be on board for further management and risk stratification. The patient should also be counselled on smoking cessation and better control of his hypertension and cholesterol levels.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Ray  age 65  Caucasian male  Demographics:  Mr. Ray is a retired school teacher living in a suburban area with his wife. They are financially stable and he has access to good healthcare. He is a smoker and has a 30 pack-year history. He has a sedentary lifestyle with sporadic exercise. He also had a hypercholesterolemia diagnosis 4 years ago for which he takes statin medications. He was hospitalized once for a non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) 2 years ago. There is a past record of him not being very compliant with his medication.  Clinical Presentation:  Mr. Ray presents with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain is described as tearing in nature and is associated with shortness of breath and sweating. His vitals show high blood pressure and his physical examination is suggestive of heart murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation. He shows signs of neurological deficits suggesting compromised blood supply to some part of his brain. His ECG shows nonspecific ST-T wave changes.  Problem Representation:  The patient is an elderly Caucasian male  with a history of poorly controlled risk factors such as hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  smoking and family history of cardiovascular disease. He presents with severe chest pain of sudden onset radiating to his back  associated symptoms suggestive of compromised heart function and neurological deficits. This scenario is highly suggestive of a diagnosis of aortic dissection  a potentially life-threatening condition requiring urgent evaluation and treatment. His past medical history and the demographic details put him into a high risk category for aortic dissection. His clinical presentation and physical examination further support this potential diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 67-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension and tobacco use. Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. He has a Body mass index of 26 and resides in an urban area.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient presents with a severe  sudden-onset chest pain  which he describes as sharp and ripping  radiating to his back. He also reports feeling faint and shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a ten-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and has been a smoker for 30 years averaging a pack every day. Previous assessments showed an enlarged proximal ascending aorta. He has also been treated on several occasions for chest infections due to his continued smoking. He has no known drug allergies.  Social History:  The patient is a retired construction worker  lives alone  and is partially dependent on social services for support. He is a non-drinker but has been a heavy smoker for over three decades.  Family History:  There is a family history of ischemic heart disease. His father died of a myocardial infarction in his 70s and his mother of a stroke in her late 60s. His elder brother is receiving treatment for hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Working Diagnosis:   Based on the patient's history  presenting symptoms  and risk factors  a working diagnosis of aortic dissection is made. Immediate further investigations  such as CT angiography of the thoracic and abdominal aorta  are required to confirm the diagnosis and identify the Stanford classification of the dissection.  Note:  Aortic dissection incidences are more frequent amongst males  aged 60-70  and in those with a history of hypertension. A meta-analysis revealed that African-Americans have a greater risk for aortic dissection compared to Caucasians. Heavy smokers and genetic predisposition also elevate the risk.  Plan: 1. Immediate hemodynamic stabilization 2. Immediate diagnostic confirmation 3. Prepare for possible surgical intervention 4. Address modifiable risk factors  i.e.  patient education to quit smoking and control hypertension.   References: 1. Clouse WD  Hallett JW Jr  Schaff HV  Gayari MM  Ilstrup DM  Melton LJ 3rd. Improved prognosis of thoracic aortic aneurysms: a population-based study. JAMA 1998; 280:1926. 2. Olsson C  Thelin S  Stahle E  Ekbom A  Granath F. Thoracic aortic aneurysm and dissection: increasing prevalence and improved outcomes reported in a nationwide population-based study of more than 14 000 cases from 1987 to 2002. Circulation 2006; 114:2611. 3. Howard DP  Banerjee A  Fairhead JF  et al. Population-based study of incidence and outcome of acute aortic dissection and premorbid risk factor control: 10-year results from the Oxford Vascular Study. Circulation 2013; 127:2031.

Based on this patient's profile - particularly his age  gender  longstanding  poorly controlled hypertension  a history of atherosclerosis  and his habit of smoking - he is at a significantly increased risk for acute aortic dissection. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: John Doe  a 70-year-old non-Hispanic Caucasian male  presents symptoms including sudden severe chest pain  racing heart  loss of consciousness  and leg pain.   Family History: The patient reports a family history of several cases of cardiovascular diseases particularly hypertension.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of high blood pressure (hypertension) and arterial disease. The patient also reported being a regular smoker for over 40 years (2 packs/day)  has high cholesterol level  and is slightly overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28. No history related to connective tissue disorders like Marfan Syndrome or inflammatory conditions was reported.  Epidemiological Background: His profile aligns with the typical demographic representation of aortic dissection patients. Aortic dissection predominantly affects males approximately in the age range of 60-70  and non-Hispanic whites are represented at a higher frequency when compared to other races. Risk factors prevalent in the patient's medical history - such as long-term hypertension  atherosclerosis  and tobacco use - are among the leading causes of aortic dissection as confirmed by current literature.   Main Problem: Given the patient's demographic  medical history  and symptomatic presentation  it is highly suggestive of aortic dissection  therefore immediate medical attention and further diagnostic tests are warranted.   Supportive Findings: His family history of hypertension  personal history of high blood pressure  being a regular smoker for a significant period of time  history of arterial disease  and current presentation of severe chest pain  loss of consciousness  fast heart rate  and leg pain strongly support the suspected diagnosis of aortic dissection.   Hypotheses to Pursue: The primary hypothesis is aortic dissection  particularly Type A dissection due to reported chest pain. Alternative diagnoses could potentially be myocardial infarction  pericarditis  or pulmonary embolism.   Plan: Immediate diagnostic tests such as a chest X-ray  an ECG  an MRI  or a transesophageal echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of aortic dissection. If confirmed  it requires immediate medical or surgical intervention.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: 1. Demographic Information: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male. 2. Socio-economic status: The patient has a middle-class socio-economic status and is retired from his job. 3. Health History: The patient has a history of smoking and is a habitual drinker. He has been on hypertensive medication for over 15 years. Also  the patient has a family history of cardiac disorders. 4. Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Problem Situation: 1. Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with severe chest pain  which he describes as 'tearing' and radiating to the back. The pain is sudden and came on without warning. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  fainting  and rapid pulse. 2. Time: The patient was rushed into the hospital's emergency room. 3. Duration: The patient states the pain started just a couple of hours ago and has been persistent.  Medical Examination Results: 1. Vital Signs: High blood pressure of 176/120 mmHg. Heart rate is pounding and slightly irregular at 110 beats per minute. Oxygen saturation is lower than usual at 89% on room air. 2. Physical Findings: Upon examination  differential blood pressure in the arms is observed. The murmur of aortic insufficiency can be heard on auscultation. 3. Lab Tests: D-dimer levels are elevated. 4. Diagnostic Imaging: Chest X-Ray showed the mediastinal widening. Follow-up computed tomography angiogram (CTA) shows aortic dissection.  `Relevant Background Information: Aortic dissection is a relatively rare but fatal disease that mainly affects elderly males. The incidence rate is slightly higher in the African American population. Studies show the majority of AD patients are hypertensives. Other risk factors include smoking  dyslipidemia  pre-existing aortic aneurysm  and bicuspid aortic valve disease. The classic symptom of an aortic dissection is severe 'tearing' chest pain  which can radiate to the back. Certain physical examination findings and diagnostic tools are used to confirm the diagnosis. Immediate treatment is often required to prevent severe complications such as aortic rupture.

Patient Profile: Patient J.D. is a 65-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to his back.  Past Medical History: Patient has a significant past medical history of poorly controlled hypertension over the past 20 years. He also has a history of smoking for 30 years but quit 2 years ago. He has a familial history of cardiovascular diseases with his father dying of a heart attack at the age of 50.   Presenting Symptoms: Patient reports a sudden onset of severe chest pain with a tearing or ripping sensation which started an hour ago while he was taking a walk around the neighborhood. The pain then spread to his upper back. The patient appears pale and anxious  and his heart rate and blood pressure are elevated.  Demographic Representation: Based on literature  the majority of patients with aortic dissection are males above the age of 60. Smoking and hypertension are major risk factors for aortic dissections. Furthermore  black individuals have been found to have a higher risk of aortic dissections compared to other racial backgrounds.   Relevant Information: Aortic dissection is an emergency condition where the large blood vessel branching off the heart (aorta) tears. Hypertension and hardening of the arteries (atherosclerosis) can increase a person's risk of aortic dissection. Other risk factors can be a history of bicuspid aortic valve  aorta inflammation due to conditions such as vasculitis  and a family history of aortic dissection. The clinical presentation of an acute aortic dissection can mimic other cardiovascular emergencies  resulting in delayed diagnosis and increased morbidity and mortality.   Conclusion: Thus considering the high-risk patient's history and presenting symptoms  a prompt evaluation of the aorta via imaging is indicated to confirm the diagnosis of aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 66-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department. He is an ex-smoker with a past medical history of hypertension and atherosclerosis. He is currently on antihypertensive medication. His BMi is 27. He has a family history of aortic disease.  Presenting Problem: The patient complains of sudden and severe chest pain radiating to the back  suggestive of aortic dissection.  Past Medical history: 1. Hypertension: He was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and has been taking antihypertensives regularly. However  his blood pressure has been poorly controlled.  2. Atherosclerosis: He was diagnosed three years ago when he presented with claudication. He was managed conservatively.  3. Smoking: He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years  but quit five years ago.  4. Family History: His father died from an aneurysm at age 67.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient had a blood pressure of 175/115 mmHg  a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  and was in visible distress. Heart sounds were faint. There was discrepancy in blood pressure measurements between his right and left arms.  Diagnostic Assessment: Based on his symptoms and findings  he was suspected to have an aortic dissection. An immediate CT angiography was ordered  which confirmed the diagnosis of an ascending aortic dissection (Stanford type A).  Plan: Given the patient’s presentation and confirmation of aortic dissection  he was referred for immediate surgical intervention - repair or replacement of the dissected aorta.  This problem representation showcases features that are typical of an aortic dissection  including the risk factors (hypertension  atherosclerosis)  presenting symptoms (chest pain)  important diagnostic indicators (discrepancy in blood pressure between arms)  and the indicated treatment (surgical intervention).

Additionally  he has COPD likely secondary to his history of heavy smoking  and a prior incidence of frozen shoulder.  Mr. Doe reports sudden onset chest pain  radiating to the back and is also experiencing shortness of breath. He has been taking medication for his hypertension (beta-blockers) and high cholesterol (statins) but admits his compliance is sporadic which may have exacerbated his current condition.  Given his family history of aortic aneurysm (father)  there is a heightened concern regarding his presenting symptoms. His lifestyle habits  including lack of physical activity  a diet rich in high cholesterol foods  alcohol abuse  and a history of heavy smoking  have likely contributed to his medical conditions.  His recent echocardiogram and chest X-rays have indicated the presence of aortic dissection  which explains his symptomatic complaints and is consistent with his personal and family medical history. Patient Representations:  1. ""Mr. Smith is a 63-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  tobacco use  and high cholesterol. His symptoms include sharp and tearing chest pain that began very suddenly and has been consistent for 2 hours. He also complains of pain in his back. He has no known allergies or other medical conditions. Smith’s father died due to cardiovascular disease at the age of 70  which also relates to some genetic predisposition.""  2. ""Ms. Johnson is a 50-year-old Caucasian female who presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain  radiating to her back and varying in intensity. She has a known history of Marfan Syndrome  a condition associated with an increased risk of aortic dissection. She doesn't smoke and tries to minimize alcohol intake. Her father underwent surgery for an aortic aneurysm in his 60s.""  Based on existing literature  demographic and health characteristics associated with higher risk of aortic dissection include:  - Age: Majority of aortic dissections occur in individuals aged 50-70 years. - Sex: Men have twice the likelihood as women to suffer from an aortic dissection  although women have higher mortality rates. - Race: Aortic dissection is more common in African Americans than in Caucasians. - Hypertension: Chronic hypertension contributes to approximately 75% of all aortic dissections. - Smoking: Tobacco use can damage and weaken the aortic wall  increasing the risk of aortic dissection. - Hereditary Disorders: Conditions such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can cause weakness in the aortic wall  predisposing patients to aortic dissection. Patient's with a family history of aortic disease can also be at a higher risk. - Previous Heart Surgery: Aortic dissection can occur as a complication of heart surgery.   Understanding these factors helps to formulate an appropriate and realistic problem representation. It's crucial to always personalize care and treatment based on individual patient demographics  lifestyles  and comorbidities.

Chronic kidney disease - Likely secondary to hypertension and diabetes.  According to numerous studies  the average age of patients presenting with aortic dissection tends to be in their 60s or 70s  with a belated presentation in women. Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a longstanding history of hypertension and smoking. He has a body mass index of 28 suggesting overweight status. His other past medical history includes hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic renal disease. There is also a recorded familial history of cardiovascular diseases.  Chief Complaint: The patient mainly complained of sudden onset of tearing or ripping chest pain that radiated to his back.  Presenting Symptoms: Apart from the chest pain  other reported symptoms included dizziness  fainting  sweating  nausea  shortness of breath  and weakness or paralysis on one side of the body. Upon physical examination  there was a noted discrepancy in blood pressure between the right and left arms  and a faint pulse.  Relevant History: The patient’s history of hypertension is significant and has been poorly controlled  with the patient admitting non-adherence to antihypertensive medications. His smoking history spans over 40 years with a 20 pack-year history.   Patient's medication history includes metformin for type 2 diabetes  statins for hyperlipidemia  and several antihypertensive medications. He also takes aspirin daily due to his risk for cardiovascular diseases. There is no known drug allergy.  Literature Review: The patient's demographic and medical history align with typical risk factors for aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is more common in males over the age of 60 (Tsai TT  et.al.  2005)  especially those with hypertension (Hiratzka LF  et.al.  2010). In addition  cigarette smoking is also associated with an increased risk for aortic dissection by causing degenerative changes to the aortic wall (Goldfinger JZ  et.al.  2014). Furthermore  the presence of atherosclerosis represented in this patient via hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes  significantly contributes to the risk of aortic dissection (Prakash S  et.al.  2010). Problem Representation:  Demographics:  - Age: The typical patient with aortic dissection is often between 60 and 80 years old  with a mean age of 63 years. - Gender: Aortic dissection is more common in men compared to women. The male to female ratio is approximately 2:1 to 3:1. - Race: The incidence of aortic dissection is higher in African Americans compared to Caucasians.  Relevant Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Hypertension is the most common risk factor present in up to 70% of all cases of aortic dissections. This makes it important for any hypertensive patient to have this condition well-controlled to minimize potential risks.  2. Genetic connective tissue disorders: Patients with genetic conditions such as Marfan Syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome are highly susceptible to aortic dissection due to their weakened connective tissues.  3. Bicuspid aortic valve: This congenital heart defect contributes to an increased risk of aortic dissection.  4. History of heart surgery or catheter procedures: Previous heart procedures like valve replacement surgery  cardiac catheterization  or aortic aneurysm repair can increase the susceptibility to aortic dissection.  5. Cocaine usage: Substance abuse  particularly cocaine  can result in temporary hypertension which may cause aortic dissection.   6. Atherosclerosis: Hardening of the arteries due to a buildup of plaque makes the aorta more susceptible to tears.  7. Family history: There is a higher risk of developing an aortic dissection if a first-degree relative has had the condition.   8. Previous history of aortic dissection: Patients who have had an aortic dissection before have a higher chance of having another.  This is a basic problem representation. Depending on the patient's specific case  other demographic factors like body mass index (BMI)  lipid profile  smoking status  etc. may also be relevant.

Patient underwent a coronary bypass surgery seven years ago. History of vascular surgeries could potentially predispose the patient to develop aortic dissections.  3. Patient's father died due to rupture of aortic aneurysm  suggesting a possible genetic predisposition.  4. Patient is a reformed smoker and quit smoking after his bypass surgery. Smoking is typically considered to be a risk factor for aortic dissection.  5. This diverse yet connected set of risk variables makes him a typical candidate for an aortic dissection suspicion. The severe chest or upper back pain  described as a tearing or ripping sensation  coupled with his demographic and personal medical and family history  point to a sufficient cause to consider aortic dissection in the diagnosis.

Patient Representation:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 67-year-old Hispanic male  presents with an acute severe onset of tearing chest pain radiating to the back. He mentions having experienced shortness of breath  fainting spells  and sudden difficulty speaking. The patient's symptoms  family history and lifestyle conditions including smoking and uncontrolled hypertension heighten the suspicion of aortic dissection. His heart-related history and features of the presentation also raise considerations for acute coronary syndrome.   Note: The above problem representation is based on the fact that aortic dissection is more common among males and older adults  with an average age of onset in the early 60s. Hypertension is present in a majority of cases  with smoking and a history of aortic disease also common risk factors. Hispanic ethnicity is not specifically associated with increased risk  but has been included here for representative purposes. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired from an executive position which was highly stressful. He is presenting with an acute onset of severe chest pain  described as tearing or ripping and radiating to the back. He has been a smoker for over 40 years  consuming approximately one pack per day  and has a regular moderate intake of alcohol. His weight is in the obese range (BMI: 32.5) height: 5'10"" and his physical activity is minimal.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history which includes essential hypertension  managed with daily medication (Amlodipine 5mg  Metoprolol 50mg) for over 20 years. The patient also has a history of atherosclerotic peripheral vascular disease. Additionally  he was diagnosed with high cholesterol levels 15 years ago and is on a statin. He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery 5 years ago due to a history of coronary artery disease.  Family History: There is a known family history of cardiovascular disease  with both his father and brother dying from myocardial infarctions in their 60s. There is no known family history of connective tissue disorders or genetic conditions related to the cardiovascular system.  Clinical Examination: On arrival  the patient is in moderate distress  sweating profusely. Pulse rate: 110/min  BP: 160/110 mmHg in the right arm and 145/90 mmHg in the left arm. Examination reveals diminished pulse in the left femoral artery compared to the right. Chest auscultation reveals no lung abnormalities but a loud diastolic murmur heard on the left sternal border. The patient presents with unequal pupils  left pupil dilated more than right indicating probable neurological involvement.  In this scenario  we have described a typical elderly male patient with several risk factors for aortic dissection  such as advanced age  chronic hypertension  atherosclerotic disease  smoking and obesity. He presents with classic symptoms of aortic dissection  including severe chest pain radiating to the back and unequal blood pressures in the arms. The clinical examination findings also point towards a probable diagnosis of aortic dissection with cardio-vascular and neurological involvement. His medical history of long-term hypertension and cardiac diseases — both significant risk factors — coupled with immediate family history of cardiovascular disease  aligns accurately with the demographic representation found in the literature for aortic dissection.

Problem Representation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old  African American male with a BMI of 28 has been admitted to the emergency department presenting with an intense  sharp pain in his chest and back. The pain began suddenly and is radiating down to his abdomen. There are symptoms of shortness of breath  fainting  and weakness on one side of the body but no history of trauma.   Past medical history reveals that Mr. Doe is suffering from chronic hypertension for the last ten years and has been regularly taking antihypertensive medication. Along with that  there is a record of less controlled diabetes mellitus for the past seven years. He also has a positive history of smoking 1 pack/day for the last 25 years. There had been an episode five years ago of transient ischemic attack (TIA) but since then no neurological deficits were reported.  Personal history suggests that he is retired and lives with his wife. Consumes alcohol socially but there's no known history of substance abuse. His father died of myocardial infarction and his mother passed away due to stroke  indicating a strong family history of cardiovascular disease.  On examination  there is a recorded blood pressure discrepancy  with the left arm showing increased blood pressure compared to the right. His pulse rate is high and has irregular rhythm. Breath sounds are observed to be normal. Neurological evaluation reveals decreased strength in his right arm and leg.  In summary  a hypertensive  obese  African American male smoker with diabetes mellitus and a family history of cardiovascular disease presents with severe chest and back pain  shortness of breath  fainting  and an episode of weakness on one side of the body suggestive of a possible aortic dissection. Further validation through imaging modalities like Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE)  Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE)  CT scan  or MRI of the aorta is warranted.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 60-year-old African American male patient presented with a sudden onset of severe chest pain  which he described as “tearing” and “ripping.” The pain was predominantly located in the anterior part of the chest  radiating to the back. Also  African Americans are comparatively more likely to develop aortic dissections as compared to Caucasians.  Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of uncontrolled high blood pressure for about 15 years which is a significant risk factor  despite being prescribed antihypertensive medications. He is also a regular smoker since his teenage years and was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) 5 years ago. He underwent Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) for his CAD. No evidence or history of genetic connective tissue disorder is recorded. Family history revealed his father had a sudden death in his late fifties due to some heart-related issues.   Clinical Presentation: On physical examination  a diastolic murmur was heard best at the left sternal border and the patient had a different blood pressure reading in each arm. Electrocardiography (ECG) did not show any sign of myocardial infarction. A bedside transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed an enlarged aortic root and ascending aorta.   These historical information  demographic characteristics  and current clinical presentation support the suspicion of aortic dissection. The immediate next step would be a definitive radiological investigation for the confirmation of diagnosis. Further information  such as the extent of the dissection  would dictate the course of therapy — whether the patient would need urgent surgery or could be managed initially with aggressive medical management to control blood pressure.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 67-year-old Caucasian female with a History of Hypertension.  Introduction: Aortic dissection (AD) is a life-threatening condition understandably more prevalent in men than women. According to literature  patients who are Caucasian and over 60 years are more susceptible. This report highlights the case of a 67-year-old Caucasian female with a previous medical history of chronic hypertension  presenting with a type A aortic dissection.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female  who lives independently and is a lifelong non-smoker. She has a documented medical history of chronic and poorly controlled hypertension for the past 15 years  which she attributes to noncompliance with her antihypertensive medications (Calcium channel blockers). She does not have a history of diabetes  stroke  or kidney disease. She has no known drug allergies.  She presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with an abrupt onset of severe chest pain described as sharp and tearing  radiating to her back. The pain was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. She reported associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis and nausea.   Physical examination showed an anxious patient with a blood pressure of 200/110 mmHg and pulse rate of 105 beats per minute  regular. The cardiopulmonary examination was significant for decreased breath sounds on the left side. Heart sounds were regular  no murmur was noted. Her neurologic exam was unremarkable.  Investigations: Diagnostic workup involved a chest X-ray which revealed a widened mediastinum. An electrocardiogram showed no signs of an acute coronary syndrome. Lab investigations  including cardiac enzymes  were within normal limits. Owing to the suspicion of an aortic dissection  a CT angiography was performed which confirmed a type A aortic dissection.  Management and Follow-Up: The diagnosis was regarded as a surgical emergency. Cardiothoracic surgery was consulted immediately and she was taken to the operating room for emergent repair of the dissection  which was successful. Following the surgery  she was transferred to the ICU for postoperative care. She was started on beta-blockers to control her blood pressure. Her post-operative period was uneventful.  In the 6-month follow-up  she reported to be well with adequate blood pressure control. She was counseled on the importance of strict compliance to antihypertensive medications and was started on a low-sodium diet. Scheduled follow-up appointments were planned to monitor her blood pressure and overall health.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection in patients with poorly controlled hypertension presenting with severe chest pain. Additionally  it emphasizes the critical role of patient education and compliance in the management of chronic illnesses like hypertension which  when poorly controlled  can lead to catastrophic outcomes.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged African American Female with Uncontrolled Hypertension: A Case Report  Abstract: This case report discusses a rare occurrence of acute aortic dissection in a 54-year-old African American female with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension. This demographic not only provides a unique viewpoint due to its infrequency in current literature  but also emphasizes the importance of managing chronic health conditions to prevent emergencies like aortic dissection.  Case Presentation: A 54-year-old African American female presented to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to her back. The patient described the pain as a ""tearing"" sensation. Her past medical history was significant for uncontrolled hypertension and obesity with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 35. She was a non-smoker  consumed alcohol occasionally  and had no known drug allergies.  Prior to the hospital visit  the patient had multiple encounters related to her hypertension  and medication nonadherence was a repeated concern. Although she was prescribed a combination of Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide for high blood pressure control  the patient admitted that she did not take her medications regularly due to side effects and financial constraints.  Upon arrival  her blood pressure was significantly high (210/115 mm Hg). The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed no signs of ischemia. An urgent computed tomography angiography (CTA) was performed due to the suspicion of aortic dissection  which confirmed a Stanford type B aortic dissection.  Management and Outcome: The patient was immediately started on labetalol to lower her blood pressure and was taken to the operating room for endovascular repair. She tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the Cardiovascular Intensive Care Unit post-operation. The patient was discharged home after 12 days  with improved hypertension control  and has remained asymptomatic on follow-up visits. She was also referred to a socially responsible medication program  to assist with the financial aspect of her treatment regimen.  Discussion: This case underscores the importance of patient adherence to chronic disease management and the severe consequences that can ensue when such diseases remain uncontrolled. Uncontrolled hypertension remains a significant risk factor for aortic dissection  making routine monitoring and treatment essential. Additionally  comprehensive patient care should consider the socioeconomic factors that may impact a patient's ability to adhere to a prescribed treatment plan.  Conclusion: While acute aortic dissection is rare  its potential to be lethal demands an expedient diagnosis. Thorough medical history  particularly concerning prolonged uncontrolled hypertension  is crucial for early detection and treatment. Attainment of blood pressure control and commitment to medication adherence also play substantial roles in preventing such medical emergencies.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection in a 63-Year-Old Female  Identification and Demographics  The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden-onset severe chest pain. She is a retired school teacher  living in a suburban neighborhood with her husband. The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is no known family history of heart diseases or genetic conditions.  Presenting Complaint  At the ED  she reported experiencing sudden-onset  severe chest pain radiating to her back  which she described as ""tearing"" in nature. She had also briefly lost consciousness prior to arrival at the hospital.   Medical History  Apart from hypertension and diabetes  the patient has been generally healthy  with regular checkups. Diabetes and hypertension were diagnosed ten years prior  and the patient manages these with diet  oral medications  and regular exercise. She is a non-smoker and drinks socially.   Physical Examination and Investigations  Physical examination revealed the patient to be nervous with cold  sweaty skin. Blood pressure measurements showed a significant difference between the patient’s right arm (200/95 mm Hg) and left arm (160/90 mm Hg). On auscultation  a diastolic murmur was appreciated. Electrocardiogram (ECG) did not indicate any acute ischemic changes.  Chest X-ray displayed a widened mediastinum. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was subsequently performed revealing a type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the right common carotid artery and all the way down to the renal arteries.  Diagnosis and Treatment  The patient was diagnosed with a Type A aortic dissection. The severity of her condition and the involvement of ascendant aortic section necessitated immediate surgical intervention – an emergency surgical aortic repair was pursued. Her post-operative phase was stable  and the patient was discharged after a week with prescriptions for blood pressure and blood sugar control.  Follow-up  The patient has been advised to continue her blood pressure and blood sugar medications strictly  refrain from strenuous activities and heavy lifting. Regular follow-ups at the outpatient department have been scheduled for surveillance  managing the risk of future aortic complications  and ensuring optimal management of her hypertension and diabetes.  Discussion   The case demonstrates the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients presenting with severe chest pain even in the absence of typical risk factors such as male sex and smoking. Furthermore  it underscores the urgency of diagnosis and need for immediate surgical intervention to reduce the high rate of mortality associated with ascending aortic dissection.   Early recognition  high clinical suspicion  and prompt treatment can result in significantly improved outcomes in patients with aortic dissection.

Case Report: Emergent Diagnosis of Aortic Dissection in a 68-Year-Old Caucasian Male  Patient Information:   Mr. X is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  residing in Salt Lake City  Utah  with no familial support. He is a retired civil engineer and lives alone.   Chief Complaint:  The patient arrived at the emergency department (ED) complaining of sudden  severe chest pain that had started a few hours earlier  which he described as 'tearing' and radiating to his back.  History of Present Illness:   The patient's symptoms started abruptly while he was at home watching television. The pain was unrelieved by rest or usual medications and was accompanied by profuse sweating  extreme anxiety  and a feeling of impending doom.  Past Medical History:  The patient had a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He is an ex-smoker (20 cigarettes/day for 30 years  quit 10 years ago) but does not consume alcohol. There is also a significant family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of myocardial infarction at age 64. He had no known drug allergies.   Physical Examination:  On arrival to ED  his blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg on right arm  145/90 mmHg on left arm. Heart rate was 110/min  respiratory rate 24/min  temperature 98.2F  and oxygen saturation was 96%. The examination revealed diaphoresis  pallor  and distress due to pain. Cardiac examination showed tachycardia without murmur. Chest and lung examination did not reveal any abnormality.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Electrocardiography (EKG) showed nonspecific ST changes  and initial troponin was not elevated. However  due to the nature of the chest pain  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest was obtained which revealed a type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta through the aortic arch and descending aorta into the iliac branches. Hemoglobin levels  kidney and liver function tests were all within normal limits.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous labetalol to maintain his heart rate around 60 bpm  and his systolic blood pressure between 100-120 mmHg. He was subsequently transferred to the cardiothoracic surgery department for an emergency surgical repair.  Outcome and Follow up:  A Bentall procedure was successfully performed to repair the aortic root  ascending aorta  and the aortic valve with a composite graft. Postoperative recovery was uneventful  and the patient was discharged home on postoperative day 10 with prescriptions for antihypertensive therapy  and a comprehensive appointment for follow-up and interventions targeting lifestyle and secondary prevention.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection  although relatively rare  is a life-threatening condition often presenting with severe  abrupt onset chest pain. This case underscores the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection in older patients with a history of hypertension and other risk factors  who present with excruciating chest pain.    This case also highlights the importance of early and aggressive blood pressure and heart rate control in patients with aortic dissection and emphasizes that definitive treatment  through open surgical or endovascular techniques  can be lifesaving.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a History of Hypertension: A Case Report  Introduction: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition  that predominantly affects older adults  characterized by a tear in the inner layer of the aorta which allows blood to surge into the aorta outer layers. This case involves a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with severe telltale chest pain culminating in a diagnosis of aortic dissection.  Case Report: Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male from Midwest America with a previous medical history of long-standing uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history. The patient is retired and lives with his wife  and he has three adult children. He had quit smoking ten years ago and took Lisinopril and Atorvastatin to manage his conditions  albeit inconsistent with his medication compliance.  Clinical Findings: The ambulance crew found the patient in severe distress outside his residence. He complained of an abrupt and severe tearing pain in his chest that radiated to his back. Initial vital signs showed a blood pressure of 200/110 mmHg  a pulse rate of 120 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Physical examination revealed a diaphoretic and grimacing man with asymmetrical upper extremity pulses.   Diagnostic Assessment: A 12-lead ECG performed en route revealed no evidence of myocardial ischemia. However  the combination of the patient's severe chest pain and hypertensive urgency raised concerns for aortic dissection. On arrival to the hospital  a CT angiogram of the chest was performed  which confirmed a Stanford type A aortic dissection originating from the ascending aorta and extending into the descending aorta  raising the case to critical and necessitating immediate surgery.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was admitted to the cardiovascular intensive care unit (CVICU) and emergently taken to the operating theatre for surgical management involving an ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement while maintaining continuous medical treatment for his high blood pressure.  Outcome and Follow-up: The patient's postoperative course was complicated by prolonged ventilation due to respiratory failure and transient acute kidney injury. After a 14-day hospitalization period including inpatient physical and occupational therapy  the patient was discharged to a sub-acute rehabilitation facility. During his 3 months follow-up appointment  the patient was found to be generally well and adherent to his medication regimen with controlled blood pressure.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition  diagnosis  and treatment of aortic dissection  based on characteristic symptoms and risk factors. Moreover  it underlines the critical role that adherence to chronic condition medication regimens  like antihypertensives  can play in preventing severe complications.

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year-Old Female with Hypertension: A Case Report   Introduction: Aortic dissection  characterized by a tear in the aorta's inner layer  is a relatively infrequent but potentially fatal disease  significantly connected with hypertension. We present a case of a type A acute aortic dissection in a 65-year-old Caucasian female patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension.  Case Presentation: The patient  a retired 65-year-old Caucasian woman  presented to the emergency department with acute severe chest pain. The pain onset was sudden and described as ""tearing"" in nature  radiating to the back. She denied any association with effort or emotional stress. She had smoked approximately 20 cigarettes/day for 40 years and ceased 10 years ago. Her family history was significant for a brother who had a myocardial infarction at 70 years old. Her past medical history included long-standing hypertension  for which she had stopped taking prescribed medication due to perceived side effects. She had no known history of atherosclerotic vascular disease  diabetes mellitus  or connective tissue disorders.  Investigations: Initial evaluation revealed a blood pressure of 200/120 mm Hg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Her physical examination revealed a diastolic murmur and varying pulse volume in both arms. An immediate 12-lead electrocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no signs of acute ischemia. Laboratory findings revealed elevated D-dimer  elevated serum creatinine  and modestly elevated troponin I levels. Chest radiography showed widening of the mediastinum. These preliminary findings raised the suspicion of aortic dissection and were later confirmed with a computed tomography (CT) angiogram which revealed a type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the distal descending aorta.  Management and Outcome: She was promptly started on intravenous labetalol to lower her heart rate and blood pressure. She was referred to cardiothoracic surgery and underwent successful emergency ascending aortic replacement with a Dacron graft. Her postoperative course was uneventful  and she was discharged in stable condition on postoperative day 15 with appropriate antihypertensive medication.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is frequently diagnosed too late  given the non-specific and variable presentation of the disease. Hypertension is the most common risk factor  as seen in this case. Regular monitoring of hypertensive patients  compliance with their medication  and early symptom recognition are key to improve prognosis and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with aortic dissection.   Learning Points: This case highlights the importance of multiple clinical aspects: the importance of a thorough history and physical  the diagnostic utility of CT in suspected aortic dissection patients  and the need for aggressive management (surgical and medical) in confirmed cases to prevent grave complications. The patient's long-standing  uncontrolled hypertension underscores the need for better monitoring and patient education about the critical importance of medication compliance in chronically ill patients.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 70-year-old African American Man with a History of Hypertension and Smoking  Introduction: We present a case of acute aortic dissection (AAD) in a 70-year-old African American male with a significant history of poorly controlled hypertension and chronic tobacco use.  Case presentation: The patient  an African American male aged 70 years  presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to his back  along with shortness of breath that he had been experiencing for nearly four hours. He is an active smoker with a 40-pack year smoking history and has a past medical history of hypertension that has been inadequately controlled for more than 15 years. Other than these  the patient has no history of surgical or other interventions.  Clinical findings: On physical examination in the ED  the patient was found to be tachycardic  with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 210/120 mmHg. He had a diminished pulse in the left upper extremity compared to the right. Chest auscultation revealed distant heart sounds.  Diagnostic assessment: 12-lead ECG showed no signs of myocardial infarction. However  his D-dimer levels were significantly elevated. A chest X-ray revealed a widened mediastinum  prompting a CT angiogram of the chest  which confirmed the diagnosis of a type A aortic dissection  extending from the ascending aorta to the iliac arteries.  Therapeutic interventions: Upon identification of the aortic dissection  the patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to reduce his blood pressure and heart rate. He was emergently taken to the operating room  where he underwent successful aortic root replacement with a composite graft and was also started on chronic antihypertensive therapy.  Follow-up and outcomes: Postoperatively  the patient's recovery was uneventful. He was discharged home on the tenth postoperative day with close follow-up in cardiology and primary care clinics. On follow-up at 1 month post discharge  his blood pressure was well controlled  and he had no recurrent chest pain or shortness of breath.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude for the care he received and verbally committed to quit smoking and to adhere strictly to his antihypertensive therapy.  Conclusion: This case highlights the role of prompt diagnosis and immediate therapeutic intervention in managing aortic dissection  especially in high-risk patients such as elderly  hypertensive  African American males with a history of smoking. This case also emphasizes the importance of stringent control of risk factors to prevent such life-threatening emergencies.

Title: Atypical Presentation of Aortic Dissection in a 62-Year-Old Man with Hypertension and Diabetes  Abstract: This is a case of a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus who was diagnosed with aortic dissection presenting with acute chest pain. This case illustrates the importance of a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection in patients with hypertension or other recognized risk factors  even when presenting symptoms may not be typical.  Case Report: A 62-year-old Caucasian male attended the emergency department complaining of an abrupt severe chest pain. The pain was anterior and radiating to the back  sudden in onset  and described as ""tearing"". He had no history of smoking  alcohol abuse  or illicit drug use. However  he had a past medical history of hypertension which was partially controlled with Lisinopril and a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled by Metformin and lifestyle modifications. There was no family history of aortic or cardiovascular disease.  The patient had a blood pressure of 175/95 mmHg  a heart rate of 105/min  respiratory rate of 20/min  and a room air oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination showed equal radial pulses  no neurologic deficit  or marfanoid features.  Laboratory tests showed elevated D-dimer and a mild elevation in serum creatinine. EKG showed no signs of myocardial ischemia. Chest radiography demonstrated a widened mediastinum. A subsequent computerized tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed a Stanford type A  DeBakey type I aortic dissection extending from the aortic valve to the level of the kidneys.   The patient was stabilized with aggressive blood pressure management. The cardiothoracic surgical team was immediately consulted  and the patient underwent successful emergency surgery involving aortic valve replacement and aortoplasty. The patient tolerated the procedure well.  Conclusion: This case represents a challenging diagnostic and therapeutic scenario of acute aortic dissection  underlining the need for early recognition  risk stratification  and timely management. This case emphasizes the importance for clinicians to maintain a high level of suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with severe chest pain coupled with cardiovascular risk factors such as poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes.

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in an Elderly Hypertensive Patient  Introduction: Aortic dissection presents as an acute but potentially curable condition that warrants early diagnosis and immediate management. It occurs predominantly in men  and patients aged 60 to 80 years are frequently affected. The most common risk factors include hypertension  atherosclerosis  and genetic conditions.   Case Presentation:  Mr. X is a 72-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  who presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to his back. The patient rated the pain a 10 out of 10  describing it as tearing and ripping and worsening with movement.   Mr. X had a blood pressure of 190/86 mmHg upon arrival to the ED. Physical examination revealed a systolic murmur best heard over the right second intercostal space and a decreased upper extremity pulse. His medical history noted that he had been started on lisinopril five years ago but was non-compliant due to recurrent episodes of syncope.   Diagnostic Assessment: An urgent computed tomography angiography (CTA) identified an intimal flap in the ascending aorta with flap extension into the aortic arch  consistent with a Stanford Type A aortic dissection. Electrocardiography showed no obvious myocardial ischemic changes. The troponin level was within the normal range.  Treatment: Mr. X was immediately started on intravenous labetalol to achieve a target heart rate below 60 beats/min and systolic blood pressure in the range of 100-120mmHg  and surgical consultation was urgently sought for. After discussing the substantial operative risks  the decision was made to proceed with an emergent aortic dissection repair.  Outcome and Follow-Up: Surgical correction of the aortic dissection was carried out successfully. Postoperatively  the patient developed transient renal insufficiency and required hemodialysis for two weeks. His recovery was otherwise uneventful  and he was discharged on post-operative day 28 with orders to resume lisinopril and start amlodipine for blood pressure control and instructed to follow up in the cardiac surgery clinic and nephrology clinic.  Conclusion: This case highlights the severity and urgency that an aortic dissection represents  particularly in high-risk groups such as older adults with hypertension. It underscores the need for immediate diagnosis and surgical correction and the crucial role of long-term hypertension management.  (List of abbreviations: ED: emergency department; CTA: computed tomography angiography; ECG: electrocardiogram)

Case Report: Aortic Dissection in a 60-year-old Male  Introduction  This is a case description of a 60-year-old Caucasian male presenting with the features of aortic dissection. The patient had a significant past medical history of hypertension  former tobacco use  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. He lived in an urban setting  worked as a senior engineer  and had a sedentary lifestyle with little physical activity. He consumed moderate amounts of alcohol socially but was a long-term quitter from smoking.  Case Presentation  The patient presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset severe tearing chest and back pain radiating to the abdomen. The pain was described as continuous and of increasing intensity over-proceeding hours. The patient also reported shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and palpitations. He had no history of trauma. The patient had a diagnosis of hypertension for the past 15 years  well-controlled on medication; he had quit smoking ten years back. Vital signs were significant for hypertension with a blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute.  Clinical Findings  On examination  the patient appeared anxious and distressed by the pain. His breath sounds were reduced in the left side lower zone; other systemic examination findings were unremarkable. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed non-specific ST-T wave changes  but did not show evidence of ischemia or infarction.  Diagnostic Assessment  Laboratory investigations revealed slightly increased white blood cell count and elevated D-dimer levels. An emergency contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest and abdomen revealed an intimal flap with a false lumen consistent with type B aortic dissection  starting just distal to the left subclavian artery and extending to the renal arteries.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was promptly initiated on pain control and IV anti-hypertensives to control the blood pressure and heart rate in order to limit the progression of the dissection. The vascular surgery department was consulted  and the patient was managed conservatively considering his type B dissection  stable vitals  and lack of complications such as malperfusion or rupture.  Follow-up and Outcomes  During his hospital stay  the patient's symptoms and blood pressure were well-controlled. Follow-up imaging showed stable aortic dissection with no evidence of expansion or complications. Antihypertensive therapy was planned for long-term maintenance  and the patient was educated about implications  risks  and signs of complications related to dissection.  Discussion  This case underscores the importance of considering aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis of acute severe chest/back pain  especially in patients with risk factors such as hypertension and tobacco abuse. A high index of suspicion and timely diagnosis can significantly impact the outcomes in this life-threatening emergency.  Patient's Perspective  The patient was satisfied with the management he received and was keen to alter his lifestyle to avoid any future cardiac events. Regular outpatient department follow-ups were planned to ensure successful long-term care.   Informed Consent  Informed consent was taken from the patient for anonymously using his case for academic discussion.

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year-Old African-American Male with Hypertension  Case Report:  Patient Information  A 65-year-old African-American male was brought to the emergency department complaining of severe chest and back pain. The pain was described as sudden in onset  severe  and tearing  radiating from the front to the back. The patient did not have a history of trauma  high-risk behaviors  or family history of aortic dissection or connective tissue diseases. He was a nonsmoker but had uncontrolled hypertension  resisting compliance with prescribed medications.  Clinical Findings  On clinical examination  the patient was agitated and diaphoretic. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg and a pulse rate of 102 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed a subtle diastolic murmur  and a differential pulse was observed. This includes unequal pulse strength in different vascular locations. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment  Electrocardiography did not reveal any evidence of acute ischemic changes. However  given the abrupt onset of the patient's severe pain  the decision was made to do computed tomography angiography (CTA).  CTA revealed an intimal flap in the ascending aorta  extending to the aortic arch and descending aorta  consistent with Stanford Type A aortic dissection. No evidence suggested the involvement of the coronary or cerebral vessels.  Therapeutic Intervention  After the diagnosis  the patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to decrease heart rate and blood pressure and to relieve stress on the aortic wall. The patient was admitted to the cardiac surgical unit for immediate surgical intervention. Emergent open ascending aortic and hemiarch replacement with a Dacron graft was performed successfully.   Follow-Up and Outcomes  Postoperative recovery was uneventful. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10 on multiple antihypertensive medications  which he promised to comply with. He was referred to a hypertension clinic for regular monitoring. At the 6-month follow-up  the patient's blood pressure was well controlled and there was no complication related to the surgery.   Learning Points  This case underscores the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients with uncontrolled hypertension who present with acute chest pain. Early recognition and intervention are crucial  as untreated aortic dissection carries a high mortality rate. Furthermore  this case highlights the importance of medication adherence for hypertension management to prevent catastrophic consequences such as aortic dissection.

Title: A Case Report: Stanford Type A Aortic Dissection in a 60-year-old African American Female   Patient Information: The patient is a 60-year-old African American female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type 2. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) was recorded at 32 (classified as obese).   Clinical Findings: She presented to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to her back. She described the pain as a tearing or ripping sensation. The patient's blood pressure reading was significantly different in each arm  and a murmur was revealed upon physical examination.  Diagnostic Assessment: An EKG was conducted  which did not show any signs of myocardial ischemia. Blood tests detected elevated d-dimer levels  prompting further diagnostic investigation. A computed tomography angiography (CTA) was then performed  clearly demonstrating a Stanford Type A aortic dissection (involvement of the ascending aorta).   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to reduce heart rate and blood pressure  thereby minimizing the propagation of the dissection. Emergency cardiothoracic surgery was urgently arranged for surgical repair of the dissection.   Follow Up and Outcomes: The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient responded well to the surgical intervention. The patient was discharged after stabilization  with instructions for regular follow-up and the need for lifelong antihypertensive medication and monitoring.  Teaching Points: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening emergency and should be considered in patients presenting with severe chest pain  particularly with a history of hypertension. Differences in blood pressure between limbs and widened mediastinum on chest X-ray are classic clinical clues. Immediate medical and often surgical intervention is necessary to decrease mortality.   This case report underscores the need for healthcare providers to be vigilant in recognizing the signs and symptoms of aortic dissection  especially in high-risk populations such as hypertensive  elderly  African American patients. Further  it highlights the importance of managing risk factors such as obesity  hypertension  and diabetes to prevent aortic dissection.   Lastly  although aortic dissection is often fatal  timely diagnosis and appropriate intervention  as demonstrated in this case  can result in successful outcomes.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 67-Year-Old African-American Male with Pre-existing Hypertension: A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic dissection refers to a serious condition characterized by a tear in the inner layer of the aorta  allowing blood to surge throughout the wall of the aorta  leading to severe pain and life-threatening complications. This case report presents a 67-year-old African-American male diagnosed with acute aortic dissection.   Case Presentation:  A 67-year-old African-American male presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden severe chest pain  radiating to the back  alongside symptoms of shortness of breath and profuse sweating. He appeared anxious and fearful. The patient's medical history included longstanding hypertension  borderline diabetes  and was a former smoker  having quit 10 years prior. He had no family history of aortic dissection or any connective tissue disorders.  Vital signs on presentation were blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 102 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Physical examination demonstrated a weakened pulse in the left arm compared to the right  and an early diastolic murmur was also appreciated.  Immediately  workup  including an electrocardiogram and bedside echocardiogram  were performed. Based on the findings from the echocardiogram  suspicion of aortic dissection was high. This was confirmed by a subsequent computerized tomography (CT) scan of the chest  which revealed an ascending aortic dissection involving the arch but sparing the coronaries and descending aorta  classified as Stanford Type A.  The patient was immediately managed with intravenous labetalol to control his blood pressure  targeted at systolic blood pressure of 100-120 mm Hg. He was then promptly referred to cardiothoracic surgery for emergent repair of the aortic dissection.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection is particularly common among males aged between 60 and 70. Hypertension  as in the case of this patient  is a well-documented risk factor for aortic dissection. This case underscores the fundamental steps for the early recognition and management of aortic dissection  a medical emergency where timely intervention can significantly impact the prognosis.  This patient's case was a typical presentation with sudden severe chest pain  a high blood pressure reading  and a clearly defined discrepancy in pulses. This case also underscores the need for a high index of suspicion in patients  especially those hypertensive  presenting with sudden chest or back pain.  Conclusion:  This case report highlights the importance of early recognition and management of aortic dissection. Clinicians should maintain a high clinical suspicion when encountering older patients with a history of hypertension presenting with severe  sudden-onset chest pain. Timely diagnosis and appropriate surgical intervention can significantly reduce mortality related to this condition.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 54-Year-old Male: A Case Report  Patient Profile: The patient is a 54-year-old African American male  residing in Minneapolis  Minnesota. He is a clerk at a local supermarket and a self-reported non-smoker  with a moderate intake of alcohol. The patient is single  without children  and lives with his older sister.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  controlled with beta-blockers and diuretics  and hyperlipidemia managed with statin drugs. His family history includes a father who died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 56. There is no known history of connective tissue disorders or aortic diseases in the family.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset  severe chest pain that started approximately 2 hours ago. The pain  described as 'tearing' and 'sharp ' was radiating to his back. He also complained of shortness of breath and diaphoresis.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared anxious and exhibited signs of respiratory distress. His blood pressure was significantly higher in his right arm (200/110 mm Hg) compared to his left arm (150/80 mm Hg). Heart sounds were regular with no significant murmurs or rubs. The remainder of the physical examination was noncontributory.  Diagnostic Evaluation: An electrocardiogram showed no signs of myocardial ischemia or infarction. Laboratory tests showed slight leukocytosis. An urgent computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed an ascending aortic dissection  classified as Stanford Type A.   Management and Outcome: The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers and nitroprusside to control his blood pressure. He was then promptly referred for emergency surgery  which was successfully performed without complications. The patient recovered well during the post-operative period and began a cardiac rehabilitation program.  Discussion: Aortic dissection  although rare  can be fatal if not promptly diagnosed and managed. Our patient's risk was elevated due to his history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and familial history of cardiovascular disease. This case emphasizes the importance of a high clinical suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with acute chest pain  especially if the individual has risk factors for this condition.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this report and accompanying images.  Ethics Committee Approval: This study was conducted in line with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. Approval was granted by the Ethics Committee of the health institution. We confirmed that the patient's anonymity was preserved.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 68-year old Male with a History of Hypertension: A Case Report   Introduction:   Aortic dissection  a serious condition characterized by a tear in the aorta's inner layer  poses a significant risk to patient health often presenting with severe pain. Here  we report a case of aortic dissection in a 68-year old Caucasian male with a notable past medical history.  Case Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the Emergency Department (ED) with presenting symptoms of severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain initiated suddenly and was characterized as tearing and sharp. The patient had difficulty breathing  appeared pale  sweaty  and anxious.   Past Medical History:  Prior to this episode  the patient was generally healthy. Nonetheless  he had been diagnosed with moderate hypertension five years back  and was prescribed Lisinopril  which he had inconsistently complied with. He had a ten pack-years history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. No history of diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  illicit drug use  or family history of early coronary artery disease. He had no history of surgical procedures.   ED Examination:  On physical examination  his Blood Pressure (BP) readings were 170/110 mmHg and 160/95 mmHg on the right and left arms  respectively. Heart rate was 110 bpm  respiratory rate at 22 breaths per minute  and SPO2 reading at 94% on room air. Cardiovascular examination palpated a bounding carotid  jugular veins were not distended  and heart sounds revealed tachycardia without a murmur. His chest was clear on auscultation. Abdominal and neurologic examination findings were normal.  Investigations:  Electrocardiogram (EKG) at presentation revealed a left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern but no features of ischemia or infarction. Emergency blood samples for full blood count  serum electrolytes  creatinine  glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c)  and troponin levels were within normal range.   Due to high suspicion for aortic dissection  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the thorax was conducted. The CTA confirmed the clinical suspicion showing an ascending aortic dissection from the aortic root to the origins of the renal arteries (Stanford Type A).  Treatment:  The patient was immediately referred for emergent surgery. The patient underwent successful Bentall procedure with replacement of the aortic valve  aortic root  and ascending aorta using a composite graft.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Post-surgery  intense monitoring in the ICU was conducted for four days followed by general ward care. On subsequent follow-up visits  the patient reported substantial improvement in health status. Regular echocardiograms were planned for assessing the durability and function of the aortic valve replacement.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the critical role of early recognition and prompt intervention in managing aortic dissections  particularly among patients with a history of hypertension. It also underscores the importance of medication adherence in managing chronic diseases to prevent such catastrophic events.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Woman with a History of Hyperlipidemia  Introduction:   Aortic dissection is defined as a tear in the inner lining of the aorta. It is a medical emergency that can potentially result in death if not promptly diagnosed and treated. Most cases are observed in men above 60 years with hypertension  although rare  it can also occur in women and younger individuals. We discuss the case of a middle-aged Caucasian woman with hyperlipidemia and a sudden presentation of aortic dissection.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hyperlipidemia. She works as a regional manager in a sales company and has lived in Texas her entire life. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. The patient has two children  both of whom are developed and healthy. Recently  she has noticed an increase in her cholesterol levels in her yearly medical checkups. Despite these readings  she has not been taking any medications  nor has she ever had a prior episode of chest pain or any cardiovascular diseases.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back. She also reported feeling a tearing sensation in the chest. The blood pressure was notably higher on the right as compared to the left. Physical examination found equal peripheral pulses bilaterally  mild diaphoresis  and an anxious demeanor.  Diagnostic Assessment:  On suspicion of aortic dissection  she underwent Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) which confirmed a Type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the iliac arteries but sparing the coronaries. Her blood cholesterol levels were measured to be higher than the optimal values  indicating uncontrolled hyperlipidemia.
