Therapeutic Intervention:  She was immediately taken to perform an emergency open surgical repair of the ascending aorta  aortic arch  and the proximal descending aorta with a synthetic graft. Post-surgery  her blood pressure and cholesterol were managed with a regiment of statins  beta-blockers  and ACE inhibitors. She was also advised to make lifestyle changes such as engaging in regular exercise  reducing sodium and cholesterol intake  and maintaining a healthy weight.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Follow-up after six months showed stabilized cholesterol levels with no recurrent chest pain. An ultrasound scan revealed no abnormal aortic dilation or dissection. Through self-commitment to lifestyle adjustment and medication adherence  the patient demonstrated an optimal recovery.  Conclusion:  Aortic dissections can sometimes be seen in individuals with no standard risk factors such as hypertension or age  as demonstrated in our patient. It is crucial to consider aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis in patients with chest pain regardless of age  sex  or traditional risk factors  especially when it occurs with typical radiations or associated symptoms. Due to its high mortality rate  timely diagnosis and treatment of aortic dissection significantly contribute to patient outcomes.

Title: A Case of Acute Aortic Dissection in a 62-Year-Old African-American Male with a History of Persistent Elevated Blood Pressure  Case Report:  A 62-year-old African-American male presented to the hospital with extreme pain in his chest and back. His vitals upon arrival show a blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg and a heart rate of 105 beats per minute.   Past Medical History: The patient has a documented 20-year history of hypertension  which is inconsistantly controlled due to lapses in medication compliance. He is also a 40-pack-year smoker and has type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  diagnosed six years prior. He has no history of bicuspid aortic valve or connective tissue disorders.  Upon arrival  the patient appeared pale and sweaty  describing the pain as sudden  sharp  and also radiating to his back between his shoulder blades. The patient's ECG showed no signs of acute myocardial infarction.  A CT scan with contrast was ordered  which provided a confirmation of Stanford Type B aortic dissection  originating from the left subclavian artery and ending just proximal to the celiac artery. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was also performed  revealing a dilated aortic root and root dissection.  The patient was promptly transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) and started on intravenous labetalol to control his blood pressure with a goal systolic pressure of less than 120 mmHg. Cardiothoracic surgery was consulted  and the patient was immediately prepared for open aortic repair. The patient's post-operative course was complicated by acute kidney injury but otherwise stable. He was discharged in stable condition to a sub-acute rehabilitation facility on post-op day 8  and a follow-up was scheduled in two weeks.  This case is an example of acute aortic dissection  a cardiovascular emergency which has been associated with hypertension  smoking  and other vascular risk factors. It underlines the importance of accurate diagnosis and immediate control of hypertension in these patients  as well as the role of early surgical intervention in preventing life-threatening complications.  Key Takeaways: Timely diagnosis and aggressive management of acute aortic dissection  particularly in patients with elevated risk factors such as hypertension  smoking and T2DM  can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality. Comprehensive care should include immediate blood pressure control  rapid surgical consultation  and pertinent follow-up in the post-operative period. Lastly  this case also stresses the public health issue of medication noncompliance  especially in patients with critical conditions like hypertension.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Female: A Case Report  Patient Information:  A 56-year-old Caucasian female presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to her back.  Clinical Findings:  The patient described the pain as 'tearing' in nature  and rated it 10/10 on the pain scale. The pain was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. She additionally reported associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. On physical examination  she was found to be hypotensive  sweating profusely  and pale. A discrepancy was noted in the blood pressure values in her left and right arms. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur. Neurological findings were within normal limits.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed non-specific ST and T wave changes but no signs of an acute myocardial infarction. Laboratory findings were normal except a slight increase in serum D-dimer levels. The patient underwent computed tomography angiography (CTA) which confirmed the diagnosis of Type A aortic dissection  involving the ascending aorta.  Therapeutic Intervention:  After stabilization  the patient was urgently transferred for surgical management  involving replacement of the ascending aorta and aortic arch with a Dacron graft.  Follow-Up and Outcome:  The patient tolerated the procedure well  and postoperative transthoracic echocardiography showed normal functioning of the aortic valve with no signs of aortic dissection. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10 and arranged for follow-up in the outpatient clinic. At three months follow-up  the patient remained asymptomatic  and a CT scan showed no evidence of recurrent aortic dissection.  Past Medical History:  The patient had a history of hypertension  which was poorly controlled. She was also a smoker with a 20-pack year history. She had no previous history of cardiac diseases  Marfan's syndrome  or family history suggestive of aortic diseases.  Discussion:  This case highlights the significance of recognizing the classic symptomatology in a patient presenting with aortic dissection  immediate diagnostic evaluation using a multimodality approach  and timely surgical intervention.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief at her successful recovery and committed to quit smoking and better manage her blood pressure.   Informed Consent:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.   Keywords: Aortic dissection  chest pain  hypertension  computed tomography angiography  surgical management.

Title: Case Report: Acute Stanford A Type Aortic Dissection in a 52-year-old Caucasian Male  Introduction: Aortic dissection pertains to a serious condition where there is a tear in the inner layer of the aorta  leading to blood surging through the opening  causing the inner and middle layers of the aorta to dissect.   Case Presentation: A 52-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. X  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe  sudden onset anterior chest pain radiating to the back  which started approximately two hours prior to coming to the hospital. Associated symptoms included lightheadedness  diaphoresis  and shortness of breath. There were no associated symptoms of fever  cough  dysphagia  or trauma. Mr. X works as a construction supervisor and is a 30 pack-year smoker. His past medical history includes systemic hypertension and high cholesterol levels  controlled with daily administration of antihypertensive (Lisinopril) and statins (Atorvastatin).   Clinical Findings: In the ED  he was found to be hypertensive with a blood pressure of 210/115 mmHg and an irregular heart rate of 90 bpm. Physical examination revealed a diaphoretic patient with a difference in blood pressure in both arms. A loud diastolic murmur was noted in the precordial area  and weak bilateral carotid and femoral pulses.  Investigations & Diagnosis: An immediate 12-lead ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy and no evidence of acute ischemia or arrhythmia. Urgent transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) was performed which showed an intimal flap in the ascending aorta consistent with Stanford Type A aortic dissection. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest confirmed the TEE findings.  Treatment: Following the diagnosis  the patient was immediately started on intravenous antihypertensive treatment (Labetalol) to reduce blood pressure and alleviate the shear forces on the aortic wall. Once stable  he was taken to the operating room for emergency surgery where he underwent successful ascending aorta and aortic valve replacement with a mechanical prosthetic valve.   Follow-ups & Outcomes: He made an uneventful recovery and was discharged home on postoperative day 10 on Furosemide  Warfarin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He was counseled to quit smoking and given advice on appropriate diet and lifestyle changes. Regular outpatient clinic follow-up at 1 month  3 months  and subsequently every 6 months post-discharge was recommended for monitoring his condition.   Conclusion: This case underlines the critical importance of a high index of suspicion and early recognition of aortic dissection given the patient's history and associated risk factors. Timely diagnostic steps and immediate interventions can significantly increase the chance of survival and reduce the risk of devastating complications.

Title: Case Report on an Aortic Dissection in an Elderly Hypertensive Male   Patient Profile: The patient is a 71-year-old African American male who presented at the emergency department with complaints of severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back and difficulty in breathing. He has lived in the urban city of Baltimore  Maryland  all his life. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)  there is a higher prevalence of hypertension among African Americans in the US compared to other racial or ethnic groups.  Past Medical History: Patient had a history of chronic uncontrolled hypertension for more than a decade. He was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 57 but was poorly compliant to prescribed medication and lifestyle modification. Documented blood pressure measurements consistently exceeded 140/90 mmHg. Additionally  he has had a history of smoking and excessive alcohol consumption until five years ago. The patient had no documented history of congenital heart diseases  Marfan syndrome  or any connective tissue disorders. He also reported no family history of cardiovascular disease or sudden deaths.   Case Description: Upon arrival  the patient appeared very uncomfortable and reported the pain to be a '10' on a scale of 0 to 10. He was sweating and had a heart rate of 105 beats per minute  blood pressure of 150/100 mm Hg  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and a temperature of 98.6°F (37°C).   An immediate ECG was performed and did not reveal any acute ischemic changes. Chest x-ray showed a widened mediastinum. With the clinical suspicion of aortic dissection  he was urgently taken for a CT angiogram which confirmed a type A aortic dissection beginning just above the aortic valve and extending into the right common carotid artery and down to the level of the renal arteries.   Outcome: After a thorough consultation with a cardiovascular surgeon  he underwent successful emergency surgery for replacement of the ascending aorta. Postoperative course was notable for transient acute kidney injury that resolved with intravenous fluid hydration. After an uneventful recovery  the patient was discharged home on postoperative day 10 with medications including beta-blockers and angiotensin receptor blockers to reduce blood pressure and prevent future aortic dissection. Lifestyle changes and medication compliance were strongly emphasized at discharge.   Significance: This case encapsulates how uncontrolled chronic hypertension  a common and potentially modifiable risk factor  can lead to life-threatening conditions like aortic dissection. It also underscores the importance of recognizing the clinical signs and symptoms in order to facilitate quick diagnosis and prompt surgical management which can often be lifesaving.   This report also highlights the need for improved therapeutic strategies  diligent patient education  and monitoring due to higher prevalence and severity of hypertension among African American males as documented by public health sources. With proper interventions  lifestyle modifications  and medicinal compliance  a reduction in rates of serious complications can be expected in this demographic.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Hypertensive African-American Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  We present the case of a 60 year-old African-American male diagnosed with an acute aortic dissection (AD). The patient  with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and habitual smoking  presented with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to the back.  Case Presentation:  A 60-year-old African-American man with a 15-year history of untreated hypertension and a 20 pack-year smoking habit presented to the emergency department with a three-hour history of severe anterior chest pain that radiated to the back. The patient denied any other associated symptoms such as shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  and dizziness. The patient was a retired construction worker  lived with his wife  followed a high-sodium diet and had a family history of cardiovascular disease.  On initial assessment  the patient appeared distressed and anxious  with a BP of 190/110mmHg and a heart rate of 108 bpm. The physical examination was significant for an early diastolic murmur appreciated over the right second intercostal space. There was no evidence of neurological deficit  acute limb ischemia  or pulsus paradoxus. His EKG showed only left ventricular hypertrophy.  Given the presented symptoms  clinical suspicion of an aortic dissection was high. Hence  a CT angiogram was ordered which confirmed a Stanford type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the brachiocephalic trunk  left common carotid and left subclavian arteries.  Emergency surgical consultation was sought  and the patient underwent an emergent ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement with a Dacron graft. His postoperative course was complicated by transient acute kidney injury that resolved with supportive management. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 15 on dual anti-hypertensive therapy.  Discussion:  This case report highlights the risk factors for aortic dissection including untreated hypertension  smoking  and African-American ethnicity. It also underscores the importance of early diagnosis and treatment in acute aortic dissection that often presents with nonspecific symptoms making diagnosis challenging.  Majority of aortic dissections occur in men  aged 60-70 years  with hypertension being a significant risk factor. African American men are also reported to have higher rates compared to other ethnicities. Therefore  this case report demonstrates an accurate demographic representation as found in literature. Given the associated morbidity and mortality  early diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention remain crucial to a successful outcome in aortic dissection.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of considering aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis of severe chest or back pain  especially amongst middle-aged African-American men with hypertension. Prompt diagnosis and management in such cases can significantly contribute towards reducing morbidity and mortality.

Title: Aortic Dissection: A Sudden and Severe Condition Needing Immediate Medical Attention - A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic dissection is a serious condition in which the inner layer of the aorta  the large blood vessel branching off the heart  tears. It is often characterized by severe chest pain and is considered a medical emergency. Middle-aged to older adults  specifically men  have the highest incidence. We report a case of a 60-year-old African-American man presenting with symptoms suggestive of acute aortic dissection.  Case Presentation:  Mr. S  a 60-year-old African-American male  with a past history of hypertension  borderline diabetes  and 40 pack-year smoking behavior  presented to the Emergency Department with acute  severe chest pain radiating to the back. He is a skilled worker and reported occasional alcohol consumption.  His chest pain was tearing in character  and there were no particular aggravating or relieving factors. There was no history of trauma. His blood pressure was 180/110 mmHg  pulse rate 100/minute  and other vitals were within normal limits. Electrocardiogram did not show any acute ischemic changes.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a 20-year history of hypertension which is mostly controlled with Amlodipine and Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with prediabetes 5 years ago  which has been managed with lifestyle changes and Metformin. The patient also has a longstanding smoking history.  Upon examination  the patient had a discrepancy in blood pressure readings in both arms. With the patient's history of uncontrolled hypertension  prediabetes  a significant smoking history  and his current symptoms  a probable diagnosis of aortic dissection was made.  Investigation:  A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest was ordered  which showed a Stanford type A aortic dissection from the aortic root extending into the ascending aorta. No branch vessel involvement was seen.  Treatment and Follow-Up:  The patient was immediately administered intravenous antihypertensives to lower blood pressure and prevent further tearing. He was prepared for emergency surgery to repair the dissected aorta which included a successful replacement of the ascending aorta and aortic valve.  Post-operative recovery was uneventful  and his blood pressure was maintained around 130/80 mm of Hg. The patient was discharged with recommendations for complete cessation of smoking  regular blood pressure monitoring  and strict blood glucose control. Regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor his condition.  This case highlights the rapid diagnosis and management of an acute aortic dissection in an individual with major risk factors  including hypertension  prediabetes  and smoking.  Conclusion:  High suspicion of aortic dissection in patients presenting with unexplained severe chest or abdominal pain  especially in those with established risk factors  is crucial for a timely and accurate diagnosis. Early diagnosis  controlling blood pressure  and prompt surgical intervention can remarkably reduce mortality and morbidity associated with this condition.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 62-Year-Old Male: A Case Report   Patient Information:  Mr. J  a 62-year-old Caucasian male presented in the emergency room with sudden onset of severe chest pain described as tearing and radiating to the back.  Demographic Information:  Mr. J is retired. He is a resident of upstate New York and has a family history of aortic diseases and aneurysms. He is a former smoker with a smoking index of 40 pack years and a reformed alcoholic. He lives with his wife in the suburbs and has two adult sons.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed significant hypertension with a blood pressure reading of 180/100 mmHg. No signs of neurologic deficits  leg weakness or bowel/bladder symptoms were present. Cardiac auscultation was normal with no murmur heard  and lung examination revealed clear lung fields.   Diagnostic Assessment:  The electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm without evidence of myocardial ischemia. Chest X-ray presented a widened mediastinum. Due to the family history and symptoms  a computed tomography angiography (CTA) was promptly scheduled and revealed ascending aortic dissection from the aortic root to the aortic arch with no involvement of coronary arteries and intact pericardium  confirming the diagnosis of Type A Aortic Dissection.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Following hemodynamic stabilization with an intravenous beta-blocker  the patient was urgently referred to cardiovascular surgery. An emergency ascending aortic replacement with a synthetic graft was performed successfully under cardiopulmonary bypass and hypothermic circulatory arrest.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  After the post-operative period in the ICU with regular follow-ups  Mr. J was discharged on the 14th day. After 6 months  he follows up in the outpatient clinic. He remained asymptomatic and without complications. His hypertension is controlled with an antihypertensive and he attends regular cardiac rehabilitation following prescribed lifestyle modifications.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of a high suspicion index for aortic dissection in older patients presenting with chest pain  particularly those with a history of hypertension and familial predisposition to aortic diseases. The role of an immediate confirmatory imaging procedure followed by urgent surgical intervention is crucial in improving outcomes.    Patient Consent: A written informed consent was obtained from Mr. J for the publication of his case details.  Ethical Approval: This study complies with the guidelines for human studies and was conducted ethically in compliance with the World Medical Association's Declaration of Helsinki.  Author Contributions: The author confirms sole responsibility for the following: study conception and design  literature review  clinical studies  data acquisition  data analysis  and preparation of manuscript.

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in a 64-year-old African-American Male: A Case Report  I. Introduction: Aortic dissection is a rare yet life-threatening condition  with the highest incidence among males of African descent and individuals in their 60s and 70s. This report presents a case of a 64-year-old African-American male diagnosed with acute Type A aortic dissection.  II. Demographic and Clinical Features: Mr. X is a 64-year-old African-American man  retired construction worker  who presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of sudden severe chest pain which had started approximately 2 hours prior. The pain was described as ""sharp "" ""tearing "" radiating to his back  and was not relieved by nitroglycerin prescribed for his known coronary artery disease (CAD).  III. Past Medical History: Mr. X’s significant past medical history included hypertension  CAD  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. His medication regimen included a beta-blocker  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor  aspirin  nitroglycerin  metformin  and atorvastatin.   IV. Clinical Examination and Diagnosis: On physical examination  Mr. X was anxious  diaphoretic with a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 180/95 mm Hg  respiratory rate of 20 per minute  and had a harsh systolic murmur. Neurological examination and chest X-ray were unremarkable. Electrocardiogram showed no new ST or T wave changes. Due to high suspicion of aortic dissection  he underwent an urgent CT aortogram which showed an Intimal flap in the ascending aorta confirming the diagnosis of Stanford Type A aortic dissection.  V. Patient Management and Prognosis: The patient was promptly started on intravenous beta-blockers to reduce blood pressure and heart rate. An emergent cardiothoracic surgery consult was placed. Given the patient's high risk of rupture  he underwent emergent surgical repair of the aortic dissection. His postoperative course was complicated by respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation but improved with medical management. He was discharged home on day 15 post-surgery  on strict blood pressure and diabetes control with close follow up outpatient appointments planned.  VI. Discussion: Mr. X's case demonstrates the classic presentation of an acute Type A aortic dissection  emphasizing the importance of suspicion and timely intervention in high-risk patients. His history of hypertension  CAD  and age made him particularly susceptible to aortic dissection. His subsequent postoperative course and management also highlight the potential complications and the need for intensive care in these patients.   VII. Conclusion: This case report emphasizes the importance of early recognition and management of aortic dissection in high-risk groups  such as African-American males with a history of hypertension and CAD. It also highlights the critical role of secondary preventive measures  like tight blood pressure and blood glucose control  to avoid such catastrophic events.

Title: A Case Report of a 68-Year-Old Male with Type B Aortic Dissection  Introduction: Aortic dissection is a critical  potentially life-threatening vascular pathology widely considered as a cardiovascular emergency. The rapid recognition of the clinical manifestations followed by urgent therapeutic interventions can make the difference between life and death.  Patient Information:  Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired mechanic  with a known history of long-term uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco smoking for the last 25 years; two significant risk factors for aortic dissection.   Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with a sudden onset of severe chest pain  which he described as 'tearing' in nature  radiating to his back. He was also experiencing shortness of breath  fatigue and was profusely sweating. Upon evaluation  his blood pressure was markedly high (190/110 mm Hg) and heart rate was elevated (110 bpm).  Diagnostic Evaluation: The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy without any ST-segment deviation or T-wave inversion  often seen in myocardial infarction. Immediately  a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest was ordered  which revealed an intimal flap in the descending thoracic aorta indicative of Type B aortic dissection  extending to the renal arteries without any involvement of the ascending aorta.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was subsequently admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with immediate initiation of beta-blockers to control his hypertension and heart rate. Given the Type B aortic dissection  an initial conservative management approach with aggressive blood pressure lowering and heart rate control was adopted. Regular monitoring of the patient's vital signs  neurological status  and renal function was performed.  Follow-Up: The patient's chest pain significantly improved with control of blood pressure. Serial CT scans were performed to monitor progression of the dissection  and no indication for surgical intervention was needed. He was discharged with instructions for strict blood pressure control  cessation of smoking  regular follow-up and immediate return to the ED if his chest pain reoccurred or worsened.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of prompt recognition and strategic management of aortic dissection. It underscores the need for aggressive risk factor control  especially hypertension  in patients at risk for this potentially fatal condition.  Keywords: Aortic dissection  Hypertension  Type B  Case Report  Emergency.

Title: Case Report: A Clinical Presentation of Type B Aortic Dissection in a Middle-aged Caucasian Male  1. Patient Information:  The patient  Mr. Z  is a 57-year-old Caucasian male working in financial services in a medium-stress role. The patient is a resident of a suburban area of Massachusetts  USA and has two children. His social history includes mild alcohol consumption and a 30-year history of tobacco use  smoking half a pack per day.   2. Chief Complaint and History of Presenting Illness:  Mr. Z presented to the emergency department (ED) with an acute onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating towards his back. He had no episodic angina  palpitations  syncope  or alleviating/aggravating factors. He further reported feeling unwell for several weeks with progressive fatigue and intermittent  non-specific thoracic discomfort.  3. Past Medical History:  Mr. Z had been diagnosed with systemic hypertension since his late 30s  which was poorly controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. He had undergone a hernia repair surgery in his 40s. Moreover  he has a significant genetic history - his father had an unexpected death in his early 60s from a suspected myocardial infarction.   4. Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient showed mild diaphoresis with blood pressure recorded at 220/110 mmHg while his pulse rate was 70 beats per minute. No abnormalities were detected on chest examination and his heart sounds were normal. Auscultation revealed no bruits over the carotid artery and his peripheral pulses were symmetrical.   5. Diagnostic Assessment:  Based on the clinical presentation  aortic dissection was strongly suspected. An emergency computed tomography angiography (CTA) was performed  confirming a diagnosis of Type B aortic dissection starting immediately distal to the left subclavian artery  and propagated for the length of the descending thoracoabdominal aorta. Laboratory tests displayed elevated D-dimers.  6. Therapeutic Intervention and Follow-Up:  The patient was immediately administered intravenously with beta-blockers and nitroprusside to control his blood pressure. Following these interventions  his blood pressure normalized and pain significantly decreased. He was admitted to the cardiothoracic surgery department and managed conservatively with optimal medical therapy  as recommended for uncomplicated type B aortic dissections.   7. Outcome and Prognosis: Mr. Z survived the acute event and his follow-up imaging 3 months later showed stable dissection without any signs of aneurysmal dilatation or rupture. He was discharged with regular outpatient follow-up instructions.  8. Lessons Learned: This case raises awareness about aortic dissection  especially in hypertensive male smokers with non-specific thoracic discomfort. Prompt diagnosis using CTA and immediate pharmacologic intervention are pivotal in managing such life-threatening conditions.  9. Patient Consent: Written informed patient consent was obtained for the publication of this case report.  10. Confidentiality: Patient confidentiality was maintained by omitting identifying information.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Adult: A Case Report  Introduction:   Aortic dissection is a medical emergency characterized by the separation of the layers of the aortic wall  causing blood to flow in between them. This disease often manifests in hypertensive patients  taking a higher toll on males and older individuals.  Case Presentation:  Mr. X is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a history of longstanding hypertension who presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back. He described it as a sharp  tearing sensation. He also reported weakness in his lower extremities and shortness of breath.  The patient is a retired police officer and a smoker for the past 30 years. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. His family history reveals that his father died of a stroke at the age of 65  and his mother had hypertension and passed away from heart disease.  On examination  the patient appeared pale and had profuse sweating. His blood pressure at presentation was 210/120 mmHg  and his heart rate was 110 bpm. He had a diastolic murmur  and his pulses were diminished in his lower extremities.  Investigations:  Electrocardiogram revealed no signs of myocardial ischemia. Laboratory tests showed a slightly elevated D-dimer. Chest X-ray showed mediastinal widening  suggestive of aortic dissection. Computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta  descending thoracic aorta  and the arch (Type A dissection).  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous antihypertensives to manage his blood pressure. Emergency surgery was performed successfully to repair the dissected aorta. The postoperative period was uneventful  and the patient was discharged on oral antihypertensives. Regular follow-ups were scheduled  and the patient was strongly advised to stop smoking  control his blood pressure  and regularly monitor his cardiovascular health.  Discussion:  This case underscores the critical nature of early diagnosis and treatment of aortic dissection. It is a condition that primarily affects males and those over 50 years old. The sudden onset of severe chest or back pain  often described as tearing or ripping  accompanied by other symptoms such as fainting  shortness of breath  or weakness or paralysis of one side of the body  requires immediate medical attention.   As evidenced by this case  early detection and immediate medical intervention can lead to effective management and positive outcomes for patients. Timely surgery  followed by adequate management of blood pressure and lifestyle modifications  are crucial in reducing the morbidity and mortality associated with aortic dissection.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 62-Year-Old Caucasian Male with Hypertension—A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic dissection (AD) is a critical condition affecting the aorta and often has an unanticipated onset. It predominantly affects males over the age of 60  and hypertension is the most common risk factor. This case report details a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension diagnosed with acute aortic dissection.   Patient Information:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with acute onset severe chest pain radiating to the back. The patient was a long-term smoker (up to 20 cigarettes per day for 40 years)  had a medical history of hypertension  and reported no previous cardiovascular symptoms. He was non-diabetic and did not report symptomatic cardiovascular disease or connective tissue disorder in his family history.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination indicated elevated heart rate (102 beats/min)  decreased blood pressure in the right arm compared to the left (right: 98/62 mmHg  left: 146/88 mmHg) and a faint diastolic murmur over the aortic area. Neurological examination showed clear cognition and no signs of focal neurologic defects  which excluded acute stroke symptoms.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Blood tests showed slightly raised D-dimer levels (0.92 mg/L)  which can be an indicator for AD. An immediate Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of Stanford Type A AD  with the intimal tear located in ascending aorta extending to the aortic arch and descending aorta.   Therapeutic Interventions:  The patient was emergently referred to cardiac surgery. An urgent operation on the ascending aorta was performed (Bentall procedure) and postoperative course was managed with antihypertensive therapy to maintain systolic blood pressure below 120 mmHg.   Follow-up and Outcome:  The patient had an uneventful recovery post-operation. The patient showed good progress at a six-month follow-up  with CTA confirming the absence of AD progression. He was counseled about the importance of maintaining strict blood pressure control and ceasing smoking. He also provided referrals to smoking cessation services and nutritionist for lifestyle modification.  Conclusion:  This case emphasized the critical role of early diagnosis and interventional treatment in patients with Stanford Type A AD. Proper risk factor management  especially hypertension and smoking cessation  is crucial to prevent such severe cardiac events.   Note: This case report serves as an educational tool and provides insight into the diagnostic and treatment strategies  as well as the continuum of care for AD management. As always  patient privacy and consent should be followed rigorously in drafting case reports.

Title: Sudden Severe Chest Pain in an Elderly Patient: A Case Report of Aortic Dissection   Patient Information: J.D. is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the Emergency Department with sudden  severe chest pain which started approximately 3 hours prior.  History of Present Illness: J.D. described his chest pain as feeling ""like a tearing sensation"" in the middle of his chest  which then radiated to his back. The onset was sudden  occurred at rest  and did not diminish with any position. He also reported feeling dizzy and short of breath but denied any other symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  or sweating.   Past Medical History: J.D. had a significant history of hypertension  which had been controlled with daily medication (Losartan 100mg daily) for 15 years. He also had a history of hypercholesterolemia  for which he took Atorvastatin 40mg daily. J.D. was a non-smoker and rarely consumed alcohol. He had no known drug allergies. No previous history of chest pain or cardiovascular disease had been reported in his family.  Physical Examination: On examination  J.D. appeared anxious with a BP of 175/105 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6°F and oxygen saturation of 93%. His chest examination revealed a diastolic murmur  heard best at the left second intercostal space.  Diagnostic Assessment: Immediate ECG showed no signs of acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Further diagnostic investigation using a computed tomography angiography (CTA) demonstrated a dissection beginning in the ascending aorta and extending distally to the abdominal aorta  indicating Stanford Type A aortic dissection.  Treatment: An emergency thoracic surgery consultation was obtained  and J.D. was urgently taken to the operating theatre for open surgical repair of his dissecting aorta.  Outcome and Follow-up: J.D. survived the procedure and transferred to intensive care for post-operative management which included maintenance of blood pressure with anti-hypertensive medication and pain management. Postoperative echocardiography showed that the diameter of the proximal aorta returned to normal with no leak of the aortic valve present.   Patient was later discharged and has attended several follow-up appointments without complication and with significantly lower blood pressure (130/85 mmHg).  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the need for high clinical suspicion and prompt investigation for aortic dissection in patients  especially elderly ones with hypertension  presenting with acute  severe chest pain.   Take-Home Message:  Despite being a relatively rare condition  misdiagnosis can lead to high mortality rates. Aortic dissection must hence be considered in the differential diagnosis of severe chest pain. Early detection and immediate surgical intervention can significantly enhance survival rates.

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in a 60-Year-Old Male with a History of Hypertension  Introduction: Aortic dissection  a serious and sometimes fatal cardiovascular condition  affects two to three individuals per 100 000 every year. This condition predominantly affects men between the ages of 60 and 80 years.  Case Presentation: A 60-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset chest pain that radiated to his back. The patient has a clinical history of chronic hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use. He does not have a personal or family history of connective tissue disorders. His medications include amlodipine and simvastatin.   Examination: Upon presentation  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 200/130mmHg  heart rate regular at 110/min  respiratory rate at 18/min  and oxygen saturation at 92% on room air. Physical examination revealed a grade II/VI decrescendo diastolic murmur on the left sternal border and weakened peripheral pulses. There were no neurological deficits.  Investigation: The ECG demonstrated non-specific changes. Troponin-I levels were within normal limits  ruling out myocardial infarction. A D-dimer test was performed given the high suspicion for aortic dissection  which was significantly elevated. Subsequently  a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan was performed confirming the diagnosis of Stanford Type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta.  Management: The patient was immediately started on intravenous (IV) beta-blockers and sodium nitroprusside to control his blood pressure and heart rate. After stabilization  the patient was transferred to a higher center for emergency cardiothoracic surgery. Post-operative recovery was uneventful and the patient was discharged on postoperative day 10. He was prescribed amlodipine  metoprolol  and atorvastatin. The patient was advised to quit smoking and maintain regular follow-ups.  Discussion: Hypertension is the most significant risk factor for aortic dissection  present in up to 75% of cases. Older age  primarily amongst males  tobacco use  and atherosclerosis  all of which were evident in our patient  are also notable factors. In cases  such as the one described  where the patient presents with classic symptoms and risk factors  early diagnosis and immediate surgical treatment are crucial for improving chances of survival.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the importance of a high index of clinical suspicion in diagnosing aortic dissection particularly in high-risk individuals. Early recognition  prompt control of blood pressure  and timely surgical treatment are vital for favorable outcomes.

Title: Case Report: Presentation and Management of Aortic Dissection in a 58-year-old Hispanic Male Patient.  Introduction: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the inner layer of the aortic wall tears  causing blood to surge into the wall of the aorta. Though relatively uncommon  it is frequently lethal  necessitating prompt diagnosis and management.  Case Report: Patient Information: A 58-year-old Hispanic male presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden  severe  tearing chest pain that had started 6 hours prior. The patient was a smoker and had a case history of hypertension  having irregular blood pressure control despite anti-hypertensive medication. Albiet overweight (BMI 27)  the patient had no reported other medical conditions  notably no past histories of connective tissue disease  family history of aortic disease  or history of illicit drug use often associated with aortic dissection.  Clinical Findings: Initial assessment revealed a pale  sweaty man in obvious distress. He was conscious  confused  and oriented to time  place and person. His blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg in the right arm and 160/90 mmHg in his left arm  with a regular pulse of 100 bmp. Physical examinations showed interscapular pain on palpation. Heart sounds were normal and there were no audible murmurs.  Diagnosis: Given the clinical presentation of hypertension and severe chest pain  an emergency CT angiography was ordered  which confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection  Stanford Type A. The tear originated from the ascending aorta propagated to the descending aorta.  Intervention and Outcome: The patient was sent for emergency open-heart surgery  where a successful repair of the ascending aortic dissection was performed by replacing the damaged section with a prosthetic graft. After surgery  he was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) where he was stable and responded well to conservative management. He was extubated on the following day of the surgery and slowly returned to normal vitals. Post-operative echocardiography showed no apparent aortic insufficiency or pericardial effusion.  The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10 with a prescription for lifelong antihypertensive therapy  tailored lifestyle modification advice  follow-up appointments  and the recommendation of regular cardiac imaging surveillance.  Discussion: This case emphasizes the importance of maintaining suspicion of aortic dissection in hypertensive patients presenting with sudden  severe  tearing chest pain  even without other classic findings. Early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention remain paramount to a successful outcome in these often catastrophic presentations.  Conclusion: While this case had a successful outcome through early recognition and intervention  aortic dissection remains a high-mortality condition. Regular follow-ups  compliance with hypertensive therapy  and lifestyle modification are deemed necessary for this patient to diminish the risk of future cardiac complications. Hence  it underscores the significant role of primary health providers in recognizing early-warning symptoms and promptly referring patients to dedicated emergency facilities.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:  Mr. S is a 65-year-old African-American male  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe chest pain. He is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife. They have three grown children. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol use.  Chief Complaint:  The patient has been suffering from intense chest pain radiating to his back for the last few hours. He described the pain as a 'tearing' sensation  unlike anything he had previously experienced.  Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of hypertension for which he has been prescribed beta-blockers. He has controlled type 2 diabetes and had an MI 5 years ago. His surgical history is relevant for a hernia repair 10 years ago. He has no known drug allergies.  Family History:  His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 73  while the patient's mother suffered from hypertension and passed away at the age of 80 due to stroke. One of his brothers has type 2 diabetes and primary hypertension.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  Mr. S appeared uncomfortable. His blood pressure was found to be significantly different between his arms  which is a potential sign of aortic dissection. His heart sounds were regular but brisk. No murmurs or bruits were appreciated on auscultation. His breath sounds were clear bilaterally.  Investigations:  Initial ECG showed no signs of myocardial ischemia  but his troponin levels were slightly elevated. A bedside transthoracic echocardiography raised suspicion of aortic dissection. Further validation by computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of a Type A aortic dissection extending from just above the sinotubular junction down into the abdominal aorta.  Treatment and Outcome:  Due to the type and location of the dissection  emergent surgical intervention was recommended. Mr. S underwent successful aortic root replacement and ascending hemiarch repair surgery a few hours following diagnosis. During the post-operation period  the patient's blood pressure was strictly controlled to prevent propagation of the dissection. His postoperative course was uneventful and he was discharged on post-operative day ten.  Discussion:  The case illustrates a common presentation of aortic dissection  a potentially fatal condition that requires immediate recognition and intervention. Mr. S's advanced age  male gender  African-American race  and history of hypertension and prior cardiovascular disease place him at an increased risk for this condition. His diagnosis was primarily delayed due to his atypical presentation but was validated promptly using imaging  emphasizing the importance of clinical vigilance and high suspicion in these patients. This case also highlights the importance of controlling risk factors to prevent aortic dissection  in particular  strict blood pressure control in patients with hypertension.  Follow Up:  At 6-month follow-up  the patient was doing well with no recurrence of chest or back pain and blood pressure within the normal range. He was counseled regarding the importance of regular follow-ups and a healthy lifestyle  with emphasis on consistent blood pressure control and optimal glycemic control to manage his risks.

Title: A Case Report on Aortic Dissection in a 65-year-old Male Patient  Abstract: We report a case of a 65-year-old African American male who was diagnosed with aortic dissection after presenting with acute chest pain. The case evaluation gives light to the presentation  diagnosis  and management of aortic dissection in a senior patient with a complex medical history including hypertension and diabetes.  Case Presentation:  Mr. A  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The pain started approximately 6 hours prior to his ED visit. The patient has a known medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. There was no significant family history of cardiovascular disease.  On examination  he was conscious  anxious  and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg in his right arm  and 160/95 mmHg in his left arm. Pulse rate was 104 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 22 per minute. Examination of the cardiovascular system revealed a regular rhythm and no murmur.  An electrocardiogram was done immediately  which showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no acute ischemic changes. Laboratory tests revealed an elevated D-dimer level. Due to the differential blood pressures and elevated D-dimer levels  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was ordered  which confirmed the diagnosis of an ascending aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the descending thoracic aorta.  Mr. A was managed aggressively in the ED with intravenous antihypertensives to control his blood pressure. Emergent bedside consults with cardiothoracic surgery and cardiology were obtained. He underwent emergent surgical repair of the aortic dissection.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that lies hidden behind common symptoms such as chest pain. It requires a high index of suspicion for early diagnosis and effective management. It is more commonly seen in individuals with hypertension  as in our patient  the prevalence is higher in men and increases with age.   As reported in literature  African Americans are disproportionately impacted by aortic dissection  which matches our case report. The patient had a significant past medical history and presented with classic symptoms of aortic dissection. His hypertension  the presence of diabetes  and being African American  possibly contributed as risk factors.  The diagnosis was confirmed with a CTA and immediate intervention was performed  which is the standard care for aortic dissections. His outcome emphasizes the necessity for early intervention in such high-mortality conditions.  Conclusion:  This case report underlines the importance of understanding that aortic dissection can mimic other pathologies and it demands a vigilant approach. Prompt recognition of the condition and appropriate referral for further diagnostic evaluation and treatment is likely to improve survival rates.   Keywords: Aortic Dissection  Hypertension  Diabetes Mellitus  Case Report

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in a 55-year-old Hypertensive African American Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic dissection  a potentially fatal medical condition marked by a tear in the aorta's wall  presents a significant risk to hypertensive individuals. Health disparities have resulted in underrepresentation of African Americans in cardiovascular disease literature  despite experiencing high rates of cardiovascular disease  including hypertension. This case report presents an underrepresented demographic  a middle-aged African American male  to emphasize the importance of early detection and management.  Patient Information:  Mr. C  a 55-year-old African American male patient  presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to his back  exacerbated on physical exertion. He has a past medical history notable for hypertension  which was poorly controlled despite medication. The patient's non-pharmacological management was erratic due to socioeconomic challenges  including unstable housing and limited access to healthful food options.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious  diaphoretic  and pale. Vital signs recorded were: blood pressure 190/110mmHg  heart rate 112 bpm  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and temperature 37.2°C. His cardiovascular exam revealed an early diastolic murmur  suggestive of aortic regurgitation. There was also an inconsistency in pulse character between the upper and lower limbs.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent computerized tomography angiography (CTA) was arranged due to acute onset severe chest pain with features suggestive of aortic dissection  which revealed a Stanford Type A dissection with involvement of the ascending aorta. Laboratory results indicated mildly elevated cardiac enzymes and a D-Dimer level of 2500 ng/ml.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately treated with intense pain relief using morphine and nitroprusside initiated to reduce blood pressure and to decrease the sheer stress on the aortic wall. After stabilization  he was rushed for an emergency ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement under deep hypothermic circulatory arrest  which was successful.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was followed up in the Cardiothoracic Surgery Clinic after discharge. He started an antihypertensive medication and was advised lifestyle modifications  such as adopting a low-salt  low-fat diet  along with consistent medication use. He was also offered social support to better manage his hypertension and generally improve his lifestyle.  Conclusions:  This case report underscores the importance of recognizing aortic dissection promptly in hypertensive patients and provides insight into this condition's presentation among African American males. The follow-up care emphasizes a comprehensive approach  including surgical intervention  pharmacological control of blood pressure  lifestyle modifications  and social supports  in effective aortic dissection management.  Patient Perspective:  Mr. C reported that his experiences had increased his awareness of managing his health conditions. He was eager to improve his health and engage more actively with support services to maintain his health and quality of life.

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year-Old African American Male with a History of Hypertension  Case Report:  Introduction:  Aortic dissection  a relatively rare cardiovascular condition  instigates a tear in the inner layer of the aorta. It is more prevalent in males and individuals over the age of 60  with hypertension being a major risk factor. This event primarily affects older Caucasian males  but the severity and lethality is often greater in African Americans.  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for chronic  poorly controlled hypertension and smoking. Despite medication  his blood pressure has consistently stayed above 145/95 mm Hg. He has not had any previous surgeries and does not have any known allergies. He retired as an engineer  is widowed  and lives with his adult daughter. The patient is a current smoker with a 45-year pack history.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to the back  neck  and jaw  associated with palpitations  dyspnea  and diaphoresis beginning an hour prior to arrival. No noted loss of consciousness  numbness  or bladder or bowel incontinence.   On examination  he appeared diaphoretic and distressed. Vital signs on examination showed a blood pressure of 180/110 mm Hg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Pulses were symmetrical and full in all extremities.   Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiogram (EKG) demonstrated left ventricular hypertrophy but no acute ischemic changes. Lab tests were remarkable for elevated troponin. Computerized tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest was obtained  which revealed a Stanford Type A aortic dissection beginning from aortic root  extending to the arch and descending thoracic aorta.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was promptly started on intravenous Esmolol for heart rate and blood pressure management. Cardiothoracic Surgery was consulted emergently and the patient was taken to the operating room for an emergent Ascending Aorta and Hemiarch Replacement surgery. The procedure was performed without complications  and the patient was subsequently transferred to the Cardiothoracic Intensive Care for post-operative management.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient was kept under close monitoring in the ICU. Post-operatively  his blood pressures were well controlled with medication. He was discharged on post-operative day 10  after ensuring stable cardiovascular status on oral beta-blocker and ACE inhibitor therapy.   Patient was advised to have close follow ups with Cardiology and Cardiothoracic Surgery for monitoring. Smoking cessation was greatly emphasized  and counseling for the same was arranged. He was also referred to the Hypertension Clinic for better control of his blood pressure  to avert future cardiovascular events.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of prompt recognition and surgical intervention in Acute Type A aortic dissection  especially in high-risk groups like hypertensive African American males.

Title: Spontaneous Ascending Aortic Dissection in a Young Asian Male with No Previous Medical History – An Unusual Presentation   Introduction:  The true incidence of aortic dissection (AD) is challenging to estimate due to its diverse presentations and the unfortunate fact that it can be swiftly fatal. However  it’s estimated to range between 2.6-3.5 cases per 100 000 persons-years.  Patient Information: A 26-year-old Asian male  fit and well  an accomplished athlete with no previous illnesses or medical conditions  presented to the hospital. He is an occasional smoker and his family history was unremarkable with no history of connective tissue disease or early cardiac disease.   Clinical Findings: The patient was presenting with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that radiated to his back  mimicking myocardial infarction (heart attack). The pain was described as stabbing and worsening with each heartbeat. He was also experiencing severe shortness of breath and was noticeably anxious and diaphoretic.  Diagnostic Assessment: Initial EKG showed no signs of myocardial ischemia. Lab tests indicated a slight elevation in his troponin levels. A CT angiogram was conducted and showed an intimal flap within the thoracic aorta  diagnostic for AD. The Stanford Classification was type A as the dissection involved the ascending aorta. No other organ damage or secondary issues were identified  suggesting he arrived before a catastrophic event could occur.   Therapeutic Intervention:  He was started on beta-blockers and immediately referred for emergency cardiothoracic surgery - an ascending aorta replacement with a Dacron graft. The operation  although risky  was successful. Post-operative echocardiography confirmed the absence of AD and no aortic regurgitation.   Follow-up and outcomes:  Postoperatively  the patient's recovery was without complications. Regular follow-up with CT scans was recommended. The patient was also referred to a genetic counselor due to the high index of suspicion for an underlying connective tissue disease despite the unremarkable family history.   Patient Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude for the fast diagnosis and immediate intervention and was compliant with his follow-up appointments and lifestyle changes.   Discussion: Though aortic dissection is relatively common  this case is of interest due to the patient’s young age  lack of medical history and family history  and Asian ethnicity where the incidence is considered to be lower compared to Caucasians. However  his smoking might have been a contributing risk factor. An underlying genetic cause could not be ruled out  hence the need for genetic counselling.   Conclusions:  This report emphasizes the significance of considering AD in the differential diagnosis in young patients presenting with severe chest pain  regardless of risk factors.

Title: A Case Report of Standford Type B Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year-Old Caucasian Male with a History of Hypertension and Smoking  Introduction: Aortic dissection is a relatively uncommon but often life-threatening condition in which a tear occurs in the inner layer of the aorta. This case highlights the diagnostic and therapeutic challenges encountered in managing this patient and underscores the role of relevant risk factors in the setting of aortic dissection.  Case Presentation: A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset  severe upper-back pain. The pain commenced while the patient was sitting at home  and was continuous  sharp in nature  and radiated to the chest. The patient had no history of trauma or heavy lifting prior to the onset of pain. He had a 20-year history of uncontrolled hypertension  a 45-pack year smoking history and a daily alcohol intake of about 30 grams. He was on medication for hypertension  but compliance was poor. The patient’s father had suffered an aortic dissection at 67.  Upon presentation  the patient’s blood pressure was significantly elevated  with a higher reading in the right arm than in the left. His heart rate was 90 beats per minute  and his physical examination was otherwise unremarkable  with clear lungs on auscultation and a regular heart rhythm with no murmur or Fremitus. Lab results demonstrated an elevated D-dimer level  indicative of a possible clotting disorder. Otherwise  blood work  including complete blood count  chemistry  and coagulation studies  were within normal limits.  Considering the medical history and presenting symptoms  a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) was performed  which revealed a Standford type B aortic dissection beginning just distal to the left subclavian artery and extending into the abdominal aorta.   Treatment: Given that the patient’s dissection was Stanford classification type B  the primary treatment consisted of aggressive blood pressure and heart rate control  with medications to quickly lower his high blood pressure and prevent further dissection. The patient was admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and medical management.   Outcome and Follow-up: He responded well to the treatment and his blood pressure was successfully controlled within the following days. The patient was discharged from the hospital after 2 weeks and referred to a smoking cessation program and cardiologist for optimal hypertension control. Further imaging studies will be conducted continuously to keep a close check on the aortic dissection and monitor any potential complications.   Discussion: This case underscores the significance of identifying and managing modifiable risk factors such as hypertension and smoking in preventing aortic dissection. Attention to out-of-range vitals  physical examination  and relevant past medical history may raise suspicion for this potentially catastrophic diagnosis in an appropriate clinical setting.

Case Report: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 58-year-old Caucasian Male  Patient Information:   The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian man  married with two children. He is employed as a truck driver and has a history of smoking and alcoholism. The patient is overweight and leads a sedentary lifestyle. His family history reveals that his father died of a heart attack at 62  and his mother suffers from high blood pressure.  Presenting Issue:   The patient reported severe chest pain radiating to the back  along with shortness of breath and vomiting. He described the pain as a severe ""tearing"" sensation. The sudden onset and severity of the pain had been a new experience for him  thus brought to Emergency Department.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  his blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  and his pulse was 120 beats per minute. There was no significant difference in blood pressure between the two arms. Pulses in all extremities were palpable and symmetrical. He appeared pale  with diaphoresis. Auscultation revealed no heart murmurs. His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed slight left ventricular hypertrophy but no signs of myocardial infarction.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  The differential diagnosis was acute aortic dissection  myocardial infarction  and pulmonary embolism. Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history  an urgent CT scan of the chest was ordered  which confirmed the presence of an aortic dissection starting just above the aortic root extending into the descending aorta.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  The patient was transferred to Cardiovascular Surgical unit for emergent surgical intervention. The surgery involved removing the area of the aorta that was damaged and replacing it with a synthetic tube. Patient tolerated the procedure well  and the dissection was successfully repaired.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Patient was managed postoperatively in Intensive care unit (ICU). His blood pressure was controlled with labetalol and iv fluids were titrated to maintain adequate cardiac output. The patient was monitored carefully for any sign of postoperative complications including paraplegia  renal insufficiency  and visceral ischemia.   After remaining stable  he was transferred to the ward after two days. Following another week in the ward  he was discharged with instructions for strict blood pressure control  follow-up appointments  medication adjustments  and lifestyle changes including quitting smoking  limiting alcohol consumption  adopting a healthy diet  and increasing physical activity.  He was also recommended to attend genetic counselling to assess the risk for his children. At six-month follow-up  the patient remained symptom-free  demonstrating improvement in lifestyle behaviours  and his blood pressure was well-controlled on medication.  Informed Patient Consent: Obtained.  Patient’s confidentiality: In respect of the patient's privacy  identifying information was excluded from this case report.  Concluding Remarks:  This case underlines the importance of considering aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis in patients presented with acute chest pain  particularly if the pain is described as ""tearing""  and there is a history of hypertension. Prompt diagnosis and management are critical in patients with aortic dissection due to the potentially fatal nature of the condition.

Title: Case Report of Aortic Dissection in a Middle Aged African-American Male with a History of Hypertension  1. Patient Information:  The patient is a 55-year-old African-American male reporting severe chest pain that started abruptly.  2. Clinical Findings:  The patient presented to the emergency department accompanied by his wife  who stated that the patient had awoken from sleep with the acute onset of tearing  knife-like chest pain radiating to his back. He reported a pain severity of 10 on a scale of 1-10. His past medical history was significant for untreated hypertension but denied a history of smoking  obesity  or substance abuse  and there was no family history of connective tissue disorders or heart disease.  3. Timeline:  The patient began to experience the symptoms during the early hours of the morning around 2 am. He was brought to the emergency department within 45 minutes of symptom onset.  4. Diagnostic Assessment:  Initially  ECG showed minimal changes. However  upon performing an on-site transthoracic echocardiogram  which proved inadequate due to patient's body habitus  a subsequent CT angiogram confirmed a diagnosis of a type A aortic dissection  extending from the aortic root cardiac chamber to the level of the left subclavian artery. Laboratory data revealed a slightly elevated troponin and aberrations in his complete blood count  renal function  and coagulation panel  likely secondary to the acute aortic dissection.  5. Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately transferred to the cardiothoracic surgery team for emergent surgical repair of his type A aortic dissection. Post-operative transesophageal echocardiography showed a successful repair with no evidence of an intimal flap or pericardial effusion.  6. Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient’s postoperative course was uneventful. He was discharged home on postoperative day 10 with medication adjustments including the addition of a beta-blocker and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor for better blood pressure control. The patient agreed to regular follow-ups with his primary care doctor to regulate his blood pressure  along with quarterly visits with his cardiologist for postoperative monitoring. He was also referred to cardiac rehabilitation for regular exercise therapy and lifestyle modification counseling.  7. Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed gratitude for the level of care he received and pledged to pay more attention to his blood pressure control and to lead a healthier lifestyle post-recovery.  8. Teaching Points:  Aortic dissection is a serious condition often associated with a history of hypertension  particularly in the African American population. This case emphasizes the importance of early detection through imaging and prompt surgical management  alongside modifiable risk factor control  all of which significantly improve patient outcomes.   The case also alerts primary care clinicians on the critical consequences of uncontrolled hypertension and the importance of regularly monitoring blood pressure in high-risk patients to prevent such catastrophic events. Furthermore  this case supports the need for routine cardiac rehabilitation post-surgical repair  which significantly contributes to the management of lifestyle modifications and better long-term outcomes.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 50-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Abstract:  We present the case of a 50-year-old Caucasian male with a diagnosis of acute ascending aortic dissection on a background of hypertension.  Case Presentation:  Mr. A  a 50-year-old Caucasian male  arrived at the emergency department (ED) of our hospital complaining of severe chest pain radiating to the back that had started approximately four hours prior to his arrival. The pain was described as ""tearing"" and was associated with shortness of breath. His medical history disclosed a 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension  but no other significant diseases were reported.  At presentation  the patient was anxious. His vitals were: blood pressure of 200/110 mmHg  irregularly regular pulse rate of 90 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. His physical examination revealed asymmetric radial pulses and a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Electrocardiography (ECG) revealed non-specific ST segment changes.  The high suspicion of acute aortic dissection led to immediate computed tomographic angiography (CTA) of the chest  which confirmed the diagnosis of an ascending aortic dissection classified as Stanford Type A. The dissection extended from the ascending aorta into the transverse arch but did not involve the coronary or carotid arteries.  The patient was immediately started on intravenous antihypertensive therapy with labetalol to manage his blood pressure and taken to the operating theatre for emergency surgical intervention. Following a successful ascending aortic graft replacement  the patient's hospital course was uneventful.  On follow-up  the patient was enrolled in a cardiovascular rehabilitation program. He was counseled on the importance of rigorous blood pressure control and adherence to his medication regimen. Adjustments made to his antihypertensive regimen resulted in improved hypertension control  and he reported a significant decrease in stress levels.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the potentially fatal condition of aortic dissection  which usually occurs on a background of long-term hypertension. It underscores the importance of quick diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention in ascending aortic dissection  along with subsequent long-term management of hypertension to prevent any recurrence.  Keywords: Aortic Dissection  Hypertension  Ascending Aortic Graft Replacement  ECG  CTA.

Title: Management of Type A Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year Old Caucasian Female  Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  known hypertensive for 15 years residing in Boston.  Clinical Presentation: The patient came to the emergency department (ED) with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to her back  accompanied by feelings of dizziness and shortness of breath. No history of trauma or physical exertion was reported.  Medical  Family  and Psychosocial history including pertinent genetic information: The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and high cholesterol levels but no known hereditary disorders. Neither her parents nor siblings had a known history of aortic diseases. She is a widow with two grown children and lives alone  and she's currently under stress due to financial constraints. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Physical Examination: The patient appeared to be anxious  diaphoretic  and in severe pain. Her blood pressure was elevated at 180/90 mmHg  heart rate was 90 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiography showed nonspecific ST-T wave changes but no evidence of myocardial infarction. Chest radiography revealed mediastinal widening  prompting an urgent computed tomography (CT) scan. The CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of ascending (Stanford type A) aortic dissection  starting just above the aortic root and extending up to the brachiocephalic artery.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on antihypertensive medications to control blood pressure and reduce aortic wall tension. Following the timely diagnosis  she was rapidly transferred to the cardiothoracic surgery team. An emergency surgical repair of the ascending aorta was conducted successfully  with subsequent postoperative care in the intensive care unit (ICU).  Patient's Perspective: The patient stated that she had been managing her hypertension poorly due to financial strains and the stress of her recent retirement  both of which saw her neglect her health. She was grateful for the lifesaving care she received and pledged to be more proactive in her health care  including medication compliance.  Informed Consent: Informed written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and any accompanying images.  Take-Home Messages: This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and intervention in aortic dissection  which is often fatal if left untreated. It also emphasizes the relevance of managing modifiable risk factors  such as hypertension  to prevent such devastating complications. It underlines that physicians should consider aortic dissection in their differential when patients present with unexplained severe chest or back pain.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 57-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction: This report describes the clinical presentation  diagnosis  and management of a case of aortic dissection in a 57-year-old Caucasian male. According to available literature  Aortic dissection is more common in males  with incidence peak in the 6th and 7th decades of life  which makes this case not uncommon regarding demographic representation.   Patient Information: The patient is a 57-year-old Caucasian male  a resident of Dallas  Texas  with a 20-year history of hypertension. Professionally  he is a solicitor. He has no tobacco use history  but admits to excessive alcohol consumption occasionally. The patient's father died in his early sixties due to a myocardial infarction.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden severe chest pain radiating to his back. The patient described it as 'tearing' and that it began at rest. Accompanying symptoms included diaphoresis and dyspnea.  Diagnostic Assessment: Upon physical examination  his blood pressure was found to be elevated (185/105 mmHg) with a pulse rate of 98 beats per minute. An electrocardiogram showed no MI signs  but a chest radiograph showed mediastinal widening. His D-Dimer level was markedly elevated  necessitating an immediate transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) which confirmed the presence of an ascending aortic dissection starting just above the aortic root extending up to the aortic arch.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to reduce blood pressure and heart rate  followed by nitroprusside to further reduce blood pressure. He underwent emergency surgical repair  specifically  an ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement with a Dacron graft.   Follow-Up and Outcome: Postoperatively  the patient was managed in the intensive care unit. His blood pressure was carefully monitored and his recovery was uneventful. Before discharge  the prescription included a beta-blocker and angiotensin receptor blocker to control his hypertension. He was advised to undergo a regular follow-up with cardiology for blood pressure control and surveillance scans for potential changes in the residual dissected aorta.  During the 12 month postoperative follow-up  the patient remained asymptomatic with well-controlled blood pressure. Follow up Computed Tomography (CT) confirmed stable residual dissected aorta.  Patient Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of considering aortic dissection in differentially diagnosing patients presenting with chest pain. Early diagnosis with prompt and suitable interventions can result in favorable outcomes even in high-risk surgical candidates such as our patient  who has hypertension.   Acknowledgment: Thanks to the cardiovascular team and nursing staff for their valuable contribution.  References:  [References related literature reviews or similar case reports].

Title: Acute Type B Aortic Dissection in a 72-Year-old Caucasian Female: A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition characterized by a tear in the lining of the aorta. This allows blood to flow between the layers of the aorta  forcing the layers apart. It is associated with hypertension and other heart conditions.  Case Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest and back pain radiating to her abdomen. The patient described the pain as ""tearing” and rated it as 10 on a scale of ten. She also reported profuse sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. The patient lives in suburban Michigan and is a retired teacher. She has a history of hypertension  mild obesity (BMI of 31)  and hyperlipidemia but no known allergies or family history of aortic diseases. She is a non-smoker  consumes moderate alcohol and has no history of illegal drug use.
