Clinical Findings:  On examination  her blood pressure was notably different between arms (160/90 mm Hg on the left and 145/85 mm Hg on the right). The pulse in her right arm was less vigorous compared to the left. She appeared anxious  pale  diaphoretic  and slightly short of breath. Cardiac examination revealed a regular rate and rhythm  normal heart sounds  and no murmurs.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An electrocardiogram (EKG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no ischemic changes. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the chest and abdomen was performed  which revealed a type B aortic dissection beginning just distal to the left subclavian artery and extending to the renal arteries.  Therapeutic Intervention:  She was immediately started on intravenous labetalol to control her hypertension and the pain was managed with morphine. Given her stable condition  she was evaluated for endovascular repair but was deemed not as a candidate because the dissection sandwiched both renal arteries. Thus  a conservative approach with intense blood pressure control was undertaken; she was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Her hospital course was uneventful  and her blood pressure and pain were well-controlled. Transthoracic echocardiograms done at her one-month follow-up visit showed no progression of the dissection. She was advised to continue her antihypertensive medication and follow an appropriate diet and lifestyle changes to manage her weight and cholesterol levels. She continues monitoring through periodic imaging.  Conclusion:  This report highlights the importance of prompt recognition and management of aortic dissections  even in patients who might not typically be considered high risk. A high index of suspicion and timely use of appropriate diagnostic tools can significantly impact patient outcomes in this serious condition.

Title: A Case Report: Aortic Dissection in a 65-year-old Caucasian Male   Introduction:  Aortic dissection is a severe condition involving a tear in the wall of the aorta  which can subsequently cause blood to flow between the layers of the aorta wall  forcing the layers apart. Mortality rates are high  especially in elderly populations.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the Emergency Department with severe chest pain radiating to the back. The patient expressed that the onset of the pain was sudden  describing it as a sharp and tearing sensation.  Demographics: The patient is retired  married with three adult children  and lives in the suburbs. He is a former smoker (quit 10 years prior) and consumed alcohol moderately (1-2 drinks/week). He is relatively sedentary  and his typical diet is rich in sodium and unhealthy fats.  Medical History: The patient's medical background includes a 20-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and was on medication (amlodipine 5mg once daily). Additionally  he was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago and was prescribed metformin. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having suffered a stroke at the age of 60.   Physical Examination and Diagnostic Assessment: Upon physical examination  the patient's blood pressure was found to be significantly higher in the right arm versus the left. Heart sounds were normal  but a diastolic murmur was audible. His pulses were palpable but weaker in the lower extremities compared to the upper extremities.   A rapid ECG did not indicate any signs of myocardial ischemia. Laboratory findings demonstrated slightly elevated D-dimer levels  prompting immediate CT Angiography. The imaging study uncovered an aortic dissection starting just above the aortic root and extending into the descending aorta. Following the DeBakey system  this is classified as a type II dissection.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was promptly started on medication to lower his blood pressure and heart rate  including labetalol and nitroprusside to prevent further enlargement of the aortic dissection. Given the severity and extent of the aortic dissection  the patient was quickly scheduled for an emergency surgical intervention - ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The surgery was performed without any complications. Post-operative care included pain management  continuation of anti-hypertensive medication  and regular monitoring of vital signs and heart function. The patient was discharged on the tenth postoperative day with instructions for follow-up CT angiography and outpatient rehabilitation.   Conclusion: Accurate and quick diagnosis is vital in aortic dissection cases  as timely intervention can significantly lower the otherwise high mortality rate. More widespread education among health care providers on recognising the signs and symptoms of aortic dissection could improve patient outcomes considerably.  Ethics Statement: Written informed consent for publication of their clinical details and/or clinical images was obtained from the patient.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Male  Patient Information: Mr. N  a 58-year-old married Hispanic male  was brought to the hospital with complaints of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the back. He works as a construction worker and lives with his wife in the suburbs of Houston  Texas. He has a history of consuming alcohol and smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years. He also has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for ten years but reports non-compliance with his hypertensive medication.  Clinical Findings: On presentation  Mr. N's pain was described as “tearing” and “sharp "" with an intensity of 10 on the Visual Analogue Scale. His blood pressure was found to be 190/105 mm Hg with a pulse rate of 96 beats/min. Other vitals included respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min and SpO2 98% on room air. There were no significant findings from the physical examination except for pain on palpation in the epigastric area.  Timeline: Mr. N was transferred to the Emergency Department (ED) within 15 minutes of his arrival at the hospital. Initial lab investigations and Chest X-ray were done within the first hour of his arrival at the ED. The Chest x-ray did not reveal any abnormalities. His EKG did not show any signs of myocardial ischemia. Blood tests showed slightly elevated D-dimer.  Diagnostic Assessment: In view of the elevated D-dimer  sudden onset severe chest pain and a history of uncontrolled hypertension  a CT aortogram was decided  which confirmed the diagnosis of ascending aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending to the arch.  Therapeutic Interventions: Considering the ascending location of the dissection  surgical intervention was deemed necessary. Mr. N underwent an emergency ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement with a Dacron graft under hypothermic circulatory arrest. His postoperative period in the ICU was uneventful  and he was discharged home on postoperative day 7 after a brief rehabilitation period.  Follow-up and Outcomes: He was prescribed anti-hypertensives and was strictly counseled on compliance with the medication. He was also advised to quit smoking and moderate his alcohol consumption. Follow-up appointments were scheduled. On his first-month follow-up  he reported cessation of smoking and compliance with medicines  which substantially reduced his blood pressure to 135/85 mmHg.  Discussion: This case study highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with sudden chest pain  particularly in those with hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors. Prompt diagnosis and management via a multidisciplinary approach remain key for survival. Further  this case underscores the importance of counseling and follow-up to ensure medication compliance and lifestyle modification  such as smoking cessation  to manage long term cardiovascular risks. Another thing to note is the greater frequency of aortic dissection in males compared to females and the increased prevalence in the sixth decade of life. Hispanic patients such as Mr. N also tend to experience a higher prevalence of uncontrolled hypertension  a crucial risk factor for aortic dissection  highlighting the need for more proactive care in this population demographic.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection in 55 Years Old Afro-Caribbean Male  Patient Information:  Mr. AA is a 55-year-old Afro-Caribbean male  living in an urban environment and working as a financial consultant. He is a non-smoker and a social drinker  consuming alcohol moderately during weekends. He is married with 2 children and lives with a supportive family.  Observation:  The patient was presented to the Emergency Department with sudden and severe chest pain radiating to the middle of his back along with shortness of breath. The pain was sharp  tearing type and started while he was at work. He also reported a history of hypertension for the past 10 years  controlled with oral anti-hypertensives.  Medical History:  Mr. AA has been diagnosed with systemic hypertension in the past and has been on antihypertensive medication (Losartan 50mg once daily) for the last 10 years. His blood pressure was typically controlled around 130/80 mmHg as per his primary care provider’s notes. He also had a family history of heart disease with his father having passed from a myocardial infarction at the age of 58.  Investigations:  Immediate investigations revealed high blood pressure (170/100 mmHg) and a fast heart rate (110 per minute)  with no other significant signs or symptoms. An Echocardiogram (ECHO) was ordered on an urgent basis to understand the cause of the chest pain. The ECHO confirmed aortic dissection involving the ascending thoracic aorta leading to an immediate consultation with Cardio-thoracic Surgery.  Treatment:  The patient was started on an intravenous beta blocker to control his blood pressure and heart rate. Due to the location and complexity of his aortic dissection as well as his systemic hypertension  they decided to proceed with an emergent surgical intervention  involving aortic root  ascending aorta  and hemiarch replacement under hypothermic circulatory arrest.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Postoperative recovery was uneventful in the ICU and his blood pressure was controlled. He was transferred to the ward on the 4th postoperative day. He was booked in for regular follow-ups to monitor his recovery  blood pressure control  and his wellbeing. The patient was also referred to the outpatient cardiac rehabilitation program to assist with his recovery.  Learning Points/Discussion:  This case underlines the importance of controlling hypertension  which remains a significant risk factor for aortic dissection  particularly in males of African-Caribbean descent. This case represents the typical demographic | profile for individuals who experience aortic dissection – males over the age of 50  with systemic hypertension. It also reminds clinicians to consider aortic dissection in patients presenting with sudden  severe chest pain and a history of hypertension.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year Old African-American Male with A History of Hypertension and Myocardial Infarction  Introduction:  We present a case of a 65-year-old African-American male who was admitted to the emergency department with severe  acute-onset chest pain  a presentation showing symptoms of aortic dissection. This case is crucial as it offers an insight into the challenging facets of diagnosis & treatment in elderly patients with cardiovascular issues. It also stresses the need for ongoing surveillance and the appropriate management of hypertensive patients to potentially prevent life-threatening conditions such as aortic dissection.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: A 65-year-old African-American male.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with severe  sharp chest pain radiating to the back. The onset of the pain was sudden and had escalated over a few hours. The patient also reported dyspnea.  Diagnosis Assessment: Physical examination revealed an elevated blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  with a pulse rate of 95 beats per minute. Neurological examination was normal with no focal deficits. Labs showed slight myocardial enzyme elevation and raised D-Dimer. Urgent chest CT angiography was conducted showing Stanford type A aortic dissection  that involved ascending aorta  descending thoracic aorta down to just above the renal arteries and arch vessels.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initially treated with intravenous Beta-blockers to control heart rate and blood pressure. The patient was then taken for an emergency surgical repair of ascending aortic dissection  performed successfully. He was also started on a regimen of beta blockers and ACE inhibitors post-surgery.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Upon one month follow-up  the patient demonstrated clinical improvement with adequate blood pressure control. He was maintaining a healthy lifestyle and had joined a cardiac rehab program.  Patient Perspective: The patient reported feeling considerably better after the surgery in terms of resolution of chest pain. Feeling somewhat overwhelmed by the suddenness and gravity of his condition  but was committed to making changes.  Clinical Relevance: This case highlights the importance of comprehensive and nonlinear thinking in the face of chest pain  and emphasizes the role of prompt diagnosis  considering the high morbidity and mortality rate associated with aortic dissection. It also underscores the need for intensive management of hypertension  a significant risk factor of aortic dissection.  To conclude  physicians should maintain a high degree of suspicion for aortic dissection in hypertensive patients  particularly in elderly individuals presenting with acute-onset chest pain. Further  proactive monitoring and stringent control of blood pressure  as well as adoption of healthy lifestyle habits can prevent such severe cardiovascular complications.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 70-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  I. Introduction  Aortic dissection is a potentially lethal medical emergency typically seen in males over the age of 60  with risk factors including hypertension  atherosclerosis  and congenital conditions such as Marfan Syndrome. Its timely identification and treatment are of paramount importance.  II. Patient information  Demographics  We present a case of a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented with a sudden and severe chest pain.   Presenting complaint  The patient described the pain as tearing  radiating to the back. He also complained of shortness of breath but denied any episodes of syncope  lower extremity weakness  or parasthesias. His Blood Pressure (BP) was 210/110 mmHg on presentation.  III. Clinical Findings  The patient showed signs of distress and was diaphoretic on physical examination. His pulse was irregular  with a rate of around 110 beats per minute. He had high blood pressure and an early diastolic murmur was heard on auscultation.  IV. Timeline  History/ Past Medical History  The patient had a 20-year history of uncontrolled hypertension  a documented history of mild aortic stenosis  and had no known drug allergies. There was no family history of Marfan syndrome or any other connective tissue diseases that could predispose him to aortic catastrophes.  V. Diagnostic Assessment   The EKG showed a left ventricular hypertrophy consistent with his long-standing hypertension. His chest X-ray showed a widened mediastinum. The definitive diagnosis was reached with the help of a CT angiogram  which showed an Intimal flap in the ascending aorta and descending thoracic aorta with a false lumen  revealing a Stanford Type A aortic dissection.  VI. Therapeutic Intervention   The patient was taken urgently to the operating room for a successful Bentall procedure to repair his dissected aorta. His post-operative course was uneventful  and he was discharged on lifelong beta-blocker therapy to control his hypertension and reduce shear force on the vasculature.  In summary  this case highlights the importance of considering an aortic dissection in geriatric patients presenting with sudden unexplained severe chest or back pain  especially in the setting of uncontrolled hypertension. The patient's age  gender  and hypertension are consistent with documented risk factors for aortic dissection. Thoughtful management and multidisciplinary collaboration are the cornerstones for successful outcomes.  VII. Follow-up and Outcomes  The follow-up assessment after six months revealed the patient to be asymptomatic with well-controlled blood pressure. The Chest CT done after six months showed no signs of re-dissection.    VIII. Patient Perspective  The patient reported substantial improvement in his quality of life post-surgery and expressed gratitude for lifesaving intervention and continued postoperative care.   IX. Conclusion  This case reinforces the ongoing challenge that aortic dissection presents in clinical practice. A high index of suspicion and prompt diagnostic escalation is required given the potentially fatal consequences of missed or delayed diagnosis.

Title: A Case of Acute Aortic Dissection in a 67-year-old African American Male with a History of Hypertension  Introduction:  This case report presents a 67-year-old African American male patient diagnosed with acute aortic dissection. He was previously diagnosed with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and was a former smoker  giving up the habit 10 years prior to his aortic dissection diagnosis.  Case Presentation:  The patient was brought to the emergency department due to sudden  severe chest and back pain described as ""tearing"" in nature. His symptoms included vomiting  profuse sweating  slight tingling in his left arm  and difficulty in breathing. He reported the pain as most intense in his chest  particularly in the upper region and extending to his back. He was conscious  oriented  slightly tachypneic but not cyanotic upon admission.  His records revealed he had been on treatment for hypertension (carvedilol) and hyperlipidemia (atorvastatin) for the past 12 years. The patient was a retired steelworker and led a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement. Despite his regular medical treatments  his blood pressure had been poorly controlled over the past year  with recent readings frequently exceeding 160/90 mmHg. His body mass index (BMI) calculated to be 29 indicating overweight. He had quit smoking roughly ten years ago  after a 30-year smoking history.  A physical examination revealed a blood pressure reading of 190/100 mmHg in his right arm and 150/90 mmHg in his left arm. Heart and lung auscultation identified minor differences in breath sounds  but no murmur was detected. His EKG showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no signs of myocardial infarction.  An urgent Transthoracic Echocardiogram was indicative of an intimal flap in the ascending aorta  which was further confirmed by a CT angiogram. Subsequently  an acute Stanford type A aortic dissection was diagnosed.  Intervention:  Emergency surgical repair was performed  which involved replacing the ascending aorta. Post-operation  the patient received intensive care  including blood pressure control with labetalol  pain management  and anticoagulation therapy. His post-operative course was uneventful.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of appropriate management of hypertension and cardiovascular risk factors  given the association with life-threatening conditions like aortic dissection. It also emphasizes the need for high clinical suspicion and appropriate diagnostic measures to ensure timely diagnosis and management.  This case also presents a unique instance within the general demographic as African Americans are less frequently diagnosed with aortic dissection compared to their Caucasian counterparts.   Patient confidentiality was strictly maintained; all personally identifiable information was removed.

Title: Emergency Management of Type A Aortic Dissection in a 56-Year-Old White Male: A Case Report  INTRODUCTION:   This case report describes a patient who presented to the emergency room with severe chest pain and was subsequently diagnosed with type A aortic dissection.   CASE PRESENTATION:  The patient was a 56-year-old Caucasian male who was seen in the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain was described as tearing in nature  and it was associated with profuse sweating and shortness of breath. The patient was a long-standing smoker with a 20 pack-year history and had uncontrolled hypertension for five years. His family history showed that his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 50.  On examination  his blood pressure was found to be significantly different between the two arms with the higher measurement on the right arm. Physical examination also revealed a diastolic murmur in the aortic area that could indicate an aortic insufficiency. Otherwise  his physical examination was unremarkable.  Given the symptoms and differential blood pressure  a working diagnosis of acute aortic dissection was made. Confirmation of diagnosis was achieved using a computed tomographic angiography (CTA)  which confirmed an ascending aortic dissection (Stanford type A) extending towards the right common iliac artery.  The patient was immediately transferred to the cardiac surgical unit for emergency surgery. After a successful ascending aortic graft replacement and aortic valve resuspension  the patient was transferred to ICU for post-operative management.  DISCUSSION:  The patient's smoking history and unmanaged hypertension increased his risk for developing an aortic dissection. Studies indicate a higher prevalence of aortic dissections among white males over 40  due to hypertension and other risk factors like genetic conditions  high cholesterol levels  or atherosclerosis. This case exemplifies the necessity of early detection and the essential role of imaging in confirming the diagnosis.  CONCLUSION:  This case emphasizes the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients presenting with acute chest pain  particularly in those with risk factors such as hypertension or who have a significant difference in bilateral arm blood pressures. Prompt diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention remain critical for survival.  KEYWORDS: aortic dissection  type A aortic dissection  emergency surgery  chest pain  hypertension.

Case Report -  Patient Identification and Demographic Data:   - A 65-year-old Caucasian male   Chief Complaint:   - Sudden  severe chest pain which he described as a tearing sensation in the upper back region.  Past Medical History:  - The patient has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol for which he has been on medication (lisinopril and atorvastatin  respectively). He also reported a history of smoking  consuming an estimated half pack of cigarettes a day for the past 35 years. The patient reported no allergies to any medication. There was no family history of cardiovascular disease.   Present Illness History:  - The patient reported that the pain began suddenly while he was mowing his lawn and it persisted despite taking rest. The patient was immediately transported to the emergency department. On his arrival  he appeared in severe distress  pale and diaphoretic.   Investigations:  - Initial vitals revealed a blood pressure of 170/92 mmHg and heart rate of 102 beats/min. In the electrocardiogram  there were non-specific ST changes  and cardiac enzymes were normal. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) demonstrated an aortic dissection commencing in the ascending aorta and extending to the iliac arteries.   Diagnosis:   - Type A (Stanford Classification) Aortic Dissection  Management:  - The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blocker (esmolol) to control heart rate and blood pressure. An urgent surgical consult was acquired and an emergency surgical procedure  open repair with graft placement  was performed on the same day.   Outcome:  - The patient tolerated the procedure and was monitored in the Intensive Care Unit postoperatively. The patient was gradually weaned off from the ventilator and inotropic support and was shifted to the ward on the 5th postoperative day. The recovery was uneventful  and the patient was discharged on the 15th day after providing medication instruction (including continuing his previous hypertension and cholesterol medications) and lifestyle modification advice. Regular follow-up appointments were scheduled with both the surgeon and cardiologist.     Conclusion:   - This case indicates the importance of early recognition and management of aortic dissection  especially in patients with risk factors such as hypertension  high cholesterol  and smoking history. Immediate surgical intervention remains the treatment of choice for type A aortic dissection and can effectively prevent fatal outcomes. Regular follow-ups for meticulous blood pressure control are crucial in the postoperative period.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a Hypertensive Elderly Male: A Case Report  Case Description:  Patient Information:  Mr. A  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the emergency department of our hospital. He is a retired lawyer  living with his wife in a suburb and is financially stable. His wife reported that he has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He drinks alcohol moderately and has no known allergies.  Clinical Findings:  The patient reported experiencing sudden  severe chest pain that started about an hour before arrival. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and ""ripping""  radiating to his back. On presenting at the ER  his blood pressure was found to be elevated at 170/95 mmHg  and his heart rate was at 110 beats per minute. Physical examination revealed diaphoresis and distress due to pain but no obvious deformities or disabilities.   Medical History:  The patient has been suffering from hypertension for the past 15 years  which has been moderately controlled with a routine regimen of hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin. He has no history of diabetes or any major surgeries. His family history includes the death of his father from a stroke at the age of 68  and his mother suffers from hypertension and dementia.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given the presenting symptoms and history of hypertension  a suspicion of aortic dissection was considered. A CT angiogram was urgently ordered  confirming the diagnosis of Stanford Type A aortic dissection. Other relevant lab findings included elevated D-dimer levels and mild renal impairment indicated by elevated creatinine levels.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous labetalol to control his blood pressure and heart rate. After initial stabilization  he was referred for emergent surgical treatment. An ascending aorta replacement with a synthetic graft was performed successfully.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  The patient made an uneventful recovery postoperatively. His blood pressure was well controlled on labetalol and losartan. At a 3-month follow-up session  the patient reported adhering to his antihypertensive medications and lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation.  Discussion:  This case underscores the significance of considering aortic dissection in elderly patients with a history of hypertension who present with severe chest pain. Early recognition and prompt medical and surgical intervention are key in improving the prognosis.  Conclusion:  This case report suggests the critical role of primary care physicians and ER doctors in being vigilant about aortic dissection in hypertensive patients  especially considering that prompt diagnosis and management can significantly impact survival.   Patient Consent: A written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images.

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in a 66-year-old Caucasian Male with a History of Hypertension and Smoking  Abstract: This case report discusses an incident of acute aortic dissection (AD) in a 66-year-old Caucasian male with a documented history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking. Aortic dissection is a critical condition often linked to hypertension and tobacco use. The patient's demographics  comorbidities  clinical course  diagnosis  and management are detailed.  Case Presentation: Mr. X  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the hospital with severe  sudden-onset chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as tearing and migrating. The patient’s medical history included uncontrolled hypertension  a smoking habit of 20 cigarettes a day for the last 45 years  and no reported history of heart disease or diabetes in his family. The patient also reported no recent trauma.  Upon physical examination  the patient had disparate upper and lower extremity blood pressures  with an absence of femoral pulses. He was mildly tachycardic  and an ECG showed nonspecific ST-segment changes. There were no signs of heart failure  though the patient was hypertensive and his extremity examination was consistent with peripheral vascular disease.  A chest X-ray indicated an enlargement of the mediastinal silhouette. Subsequent tests  including a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest  confirmed the diagnosis of an acute ascending (Type A) aortic dissection  beginning just above the aortic root and extending into the descending thoracic and abdominal aorta.  Management: Once diagnosed with Type A aortic dissection  the patient was promptly administered beta-blockers and nitroprusside to control his blood pressure and heart rate. He was immediately transferred to a higher-level cardiac care center where he underwent successful emergency surgery for the dissection. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was later transferred to the intensive care unit for observation.  After the operation  the patient was put on a long-term management plan of antihypertensive and lipid-lowering therapy  coupled with lifestyle changes  including smoking cessation  a low-salt diet  and a regular low-impact exercise routine.  Conclusion: This case underscores the life-threatening nature of aortic dissection  the critical role of early diagnosis  and the need for appropriate intervention. Acute aortic dissection being a rare condition  this detailed case study provides valuable insight into the course of a speedy diagnosis and successful treatment of a 66-year-old Caucasian male patient suffering from acute aortic dissection with a history of hypertension and smoking. It also highlights the importance of long-term management to prevent recurrence.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 70-year-old Hispanic Male with a History of Uncontrolled Hypertension: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 70-year-old Hispanic male presented to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: The patient complained of severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 20 years. He also suffers from type II diabetes mellitus  but denied any history of familial cardiovascular diseases or any connective tissue disorder.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient was conscious but visibly distressed and diaphoretic. His vitals showed blood pressure of 190/110 mmHg and an irregular heart rate of 96 bpm. A difference in blood pressure between his arms was noted  with the left arm having lower readings than the right.  Diagnostic Assessment: The electrocardiogram revealed no signs of acute myocardial infarction. However  chest X-ray showed an enlarged mediastinum. A subsequent contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the chest confirmed an aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta  the aortic arch  and descending aorta (type A aortic dissection). Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels  contributing to the diagnosis.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on intravenous antihypertensive drugs to ensure blood pressure and heart rate control. Following stabilization  he underwent emergent surgical repair which included an ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement alongside coronary reimplantation due to involvement of the coronary ostia.   Outcome: The immediate postoperative period was uneventful. The patient was transferred to the recovery ward and gradually weaned off from the support. His postoperative CT scan after a week showed successful repair without any residual dissection. He was started on lifelong antihypertensive medication and was discharged home in a stable condition with the advice of regular follow-ups.  Conclusion: This case underlines the critical role of a timely diagnosis and intervention in patients presenting with aortic dissection. Given the high mortality rate associated with aortic dissection  a high index of suspicion  particularly in patients with long-term hypertension  can be lifesaving. Additionally  prompt surgical intervention remains the mainstay of management  especially in type A aortic dissection  as in our patient case.

Title: Case Report on Acute Aortic Dissection in an Elderly Female Patient   Patient Information: Ms. M is an 89-year-old Caucasian female  a widower with 2 adult children. She is a retired nurse  lives alone  and manages her daily activities independently. She has a 45-pack-year smoking history  until she quit at the age of 65. Additionally  she has a history of chronic hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has no prior history of heart diseases.  Presenting Complaint: Ms. M presented in the emergency department (ED) with a sudden onset of severe tearing chest pain that radiated to her back. She associated this pain with shortness of breath and feelings of anxiety.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  she was anxious  in distress with pallor  diaphoretic  and had an irregular pulse of 110 beats per minute. The Blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg in her right arm and 150/90 mmHg in the left arm. Cardiac and lung auscultation revealed no adventitious sounds. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy  but no signs of myocardial ischemia. Initial laboratory results demonstrated elevated D-dimer levels suggestive of aortic dissection. Given the classic history and hypertension  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest was promptly conducted which confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection  Stanford type A  involving the ascending aorta.  Therapeutic Intervention: She was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to decrease her heart rate and blood pressure. The surgical team was urgently consulted and she underwent successful emergency ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement with a Dacron graft. She was also started on lifelong anti-hypertensive therapy.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Postoperatively  she recovered well without any complications. Echocardiography before discharge showed a good functioning aortic valve and no pericardial effusion. At follow-up 1 month post-discharge  she remained symptom-free with well-controlled blood pressure.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of early recognition and prompt surgical intervention in acute aortic dissection. Despite her advanced age and numerous comorbidities  the patient experienced a successful outcome because of the immediate treatment measures undertaken. It is crucial for clinicians to consider acute aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis when an elderly patient presents with sudden severe chest or back pain  especially if they have a history of hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors.   This case also emphasizes the importance of postoperative management and regular follow-ups  as well as the significance of managing the underlying risk factors  particularly hypertension  to prevent further cardiovascular complications.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a Hypertensive Elderly Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic dissection is a serious condition characterized by a tear in the aorta's lining  leading to disruption of blood flow and potentially life-threatening complications. This case report presents a 72-year-old Hispanic male diagnosed with acute aortic dissection and underlying hypertension  discussing the associated clinical manifestations  work-up  and management plan.  Case Presentation:  The patient  a 72-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history of hypertension  presented to the emergency room with sudden and severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain was described as tearing and had commenced suddenly about 3 hours prior to presentation. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  pulse 90 beats/min  temperature 98.2°F and respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min.  The patient has a 30 pack-year smoking history and has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications. He disputes having any notable previous cardiac issues and denies drug allergies. His family history is significant for a brother who passed away in his 60s due to a heart attack.  Upon physical examination  there was a noted disparity in femoral and radial pulses. Chest auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur indicating aortic regurgitation. Neurological assessment revealed no abnormalities and no signs of stroke. There was no evidence of Marfan’s Syndrome  Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome  or other conditions traditionally linked to aortic dissection.  Investigations:  Laboratory findings revealed elevated D-dimer levels and Troponin-T  suggesting cardiac damage. A 12-lead ECG was normal  showing no signs of myocardial infarction. As clinical suspicion of acute aortic dissection was high  a Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) of the chest was urgently ordered  confirming the diagnosis of Stanford Type A aortic dissection  extending from the ascending to descending aorta.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was emergently taken to surgery for aortic root and ascending aorta replacement under cardiopulmonary bypass. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) post-surgery showed no dissection flap  no aortic regurgitation  and adequately functioning prosthetic aortic valve. The patient was monitored in the intensive care unit postoperatively and started on anti-hypertensive therapy and regular follow-ups were scheduled.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the need for high clinical suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with severe chest pain and a history of hypertension. Prompt diagnostic imaging and surgical intervention significantly reduces morbidity and mortality. Close blood pressure control is crucial in managing such patients to prevent recurrent dissection or rupture post-surgery. This case also underlines the importance of medication adherence  particularly among patients with chronic cardiovascular conditions.

Title: Acute Type B Aortic Dissection in a 57-year-old Asian Male with Uncorrected Hypertension  Introduction: Aortic dissection is a severe and life-threatening condition associated with hypertension and atherosclerosis  among other things. Despite improved comprehension and advancements in therapy  the mortality rate remains high  with early diagnosis and intervention being crucial in improving prognosis.  Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 57-year-old Asian male  a longstanding smoker with a 15-pack year history  originally from South Korea but now residing in the United States. His occupation involves a sedentary desk job. The patient lives with his wife  and they have no children. He reports social alcohol use but denies any illicit drug use. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases; his father died from myocardial infarction at age 60  and his maternal uncle had a stroke at 68.  The patient's medical history is remarkable for hypertension which had been undiagnosed and untreated for at least ten years. The patient rarely sought medical intervention and did not follow up as recommended. Apart from hypertension  he has hypercholesterolemia and had been non-compliant with his statin therapy. He had no history of surgeries or allergies.   In terms of review of systems  a recent sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back was reported. Pain was described as being 10 on a scale of 1 to 10  starting while at rest  with no precipitating events.  Discussion:  Upon admission  the patient's blood pressure was markedly elevated (200/110 mmHg)  with a pulse rate of 100 beats per minute. He was afebrile and had a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His weight was 98 Kg and height 175 cm  yielding a body mass index (BMI) of 31.9  categorized as obese.  Apart from elevated blood pressure  the patient’s physical examination was unremarkable. Blood tests showed slightly elevated white blood cells counts and mildly reduced hemoglobin level (12g/dL). The liver and kidney function tests  along with lipid profile and cardiac biomarkers  came back within normal ranges. Electrocardiogram showed non-specific ST-segment changes.   An emergency computed tomography (CT) angiogram of the chest was then performed revealing an acute type B aortic dissection starting just distal to the left subclavian artery and extending down to the aortic bifurcation  with no signs of rupture.  Given the patient's presenting symptoms  hypertensive status  and CT findings  he was diagnosed with acute type B aortic dissection.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of routine medical check-ups and adherence to prescribed medication therapy  particularly among hypertensive individuals. Inadequately controlled cardiovascular risk factors can lead to life-threatening complications such as aortic dissection. Even though the patient survived the acute phase of the event  his long-term prognosis is uncertain and depends on how well he can control his risk factors in the future.

Title: A Rare Case of Aortic Dissection in a 52-Year-Old Male with No Prior Cardiovascular History  Introduction:   Aortic dissection (AD) is a rare but life-threatening condition often associated with hypertension and in relatively older individuals. It is a result of separation of the layers within the aorta  affecting mostly males and those with a history of cardiac diseases. However  its sudden occurrence in a relatively younger patient  without any preexisting heart conditions  is a rarity.  Case Presentation:  Patient Description: The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male  a non-smoker  and maintains a moderate alcohol intake. His body mass index (BMI) is 24  which is considered as a healthy weight. He has no known medial allergies and his family health history does not include any cardiovascular diseases.  Past Medical History: He has been treated for Type 2 Diabetes for the past 10 years. The disease is well-controlled with metformin. Aside from this  the patient's medical history is unremarkable. He has no past history of hypertension  high cholesterol levels  or any cardiac diseases. He has never undergone any kind of surgery before. This makes him an atypical candidate for aortic dissection.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with sudden-onset chest pain that started while he was performing light physical activity (gardening). The pain was severe and radiated to his back. He described it as a ""tearing"" sensation that did not diminish with rest or over-the-counter pain medication.  Clinical Findings: On examination  his blood pressure was found to be severely elevated (190/110 mm Hg). Critical laboratory findings included: Hematocrit: 38.6%  Platelets: 184 000 per cubic millimeter  Glucose: 231mg/dL  and B-type natriuretic peptide: 81 pg/mL. An electrocardiogram showed non-specific ST-segment changes but no signs of myocardial infarction. Chest X-ray showed mediastinal widening.  Diagnosis: Computed tomography (CT) angiography of the chest revealed an aortic dissection starting at the ascending aorta and extending to the abdominal aorta. This was classified as a Stanford Type A dissection.  Treatment: The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to reduce heart rate and blood pressure. He was taken to the operating room for an emergency surgical repair involving replacement of the ascending aorta and aortic arch with a graft.  Outcome: The patient’s post-operative recovery was uneventful and he was discharged home 8 days after surgery. He has been prescribed lifelong antihypertensive medication and regularly monitored to prevent hypertension.  Conclusion:  This case underlines the importance of considering aortic dissection even in younger patients without pre-existing cardiac disease but presenting with sudden-onset severe chest pain. The patient’s diabetes may have been a contributing factor to the development of the dissection  implying a need for high clinical suspicion in such patients. Prompt diagnosis and treatment lead to a positive clinical outcome in this patient.

Title: Stanford Type A Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Asian Male: A Case Report   Case Introduction:  Mr. J  a 55-year-old Asian male with a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and chronic smoking  presented to the emergency department in severe distress. He experienced sudden onset  sharp  severe chest pain radiating to his back.  Clinical Findings:  On arrival  the patient appeared pale and diaphoretic. He reported nausea and feeling palpitations. Initial vitals pointed towards tachycardia (heart rate: 110/min) and high blood pressure (BP: 170/100 mmHg). The physical examination revealed unequal blood pressures in both arms  a diastolic murmur  and decreased peripheral pulses.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An immediate EKG showed left ventricular hypertrophy and no acute ischemic changes. Chest radiography demonstrated a widening mediastinum. The findings warranted suspicion of aortic dissection  subsequently confirmed through a CT angiogram  revealing Stanford Type A dissection beginning just past the aortic valve and extending into the ascending aorta.  Therapeutic Interventions:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous labetalol to control hypertension and heart rate. He was taken to the surgical suite for an emergency ascending aorta and aortic valve replacement surgery with a mechanical valve with an uneventful intraoperative course. The patient's postoperative story was complicated with temporary renal impairment  but he responded adequately to conservative management.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Mr. J had a considerable recovery and was discharged home after 14 days. He was advised to follow up with the cardiology and surgery departments after one month. Anti-hypertensive medication was optimized  and the importance of medication compliance was highlighted. He also agreed to smoking cessation counseling. At his 1 month follow-up appointment  his blood pressure was well controlled  and he reported no recurrence of chest pain.  Conclusion:  This case underlines the importance of recognizing the classical presenting symptoms of aortic dissection quickly  considering it in hypertensive patients who present with severe sharp chest pain  and the life-saving role of early surgical intervention. It also emphasizes the role of managing modifiable risk factors  such as hypertension and smoking  in preventing such vascular emergencies.

Case Report: Acute Aortic Disfunction  Patient Information:  A 60-year-old Hispanic male patient  a resident of Brooklyn  New York  presented with sudden onset severe chest and back pain. The patient is an ex-smoker with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient had no family history of cardiovascular diseases  but he was overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 29.   The patient worked in a high-stress environment with a sedentary lifestyle and confessed to often resorting to fast food due to work pressure. He gave up smoking years before but had failed attempts to consistently manage his hypertension  despite being on antihypertensives and statins. He expressed never having experienced such pain before and showed a level of anxiety that was consistent with the intensity of his discomfort.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient appeared diaphoretic and distressed. Initial vitals showed a blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg  pulse- 105 beats/minute irregular  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. No significant findings detected on pulmonary  cardiac  or abdominal evaluation  however  he had unequal radial pulses and blood pressure differentials between the upper limbs.  Diagnosis  Treatment  and Outcome:  Laboratory studies were normal except an elevated D-dimer test. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy and non-specific ST-T wave changes. The chest x-ray did not show any mediastinal widening. However  due to the high clinical suspicion for aortic dissection  a computed tomography angiography (CTA) was urgently performed  revealing a Stanford type A aortic dissection starting from the ascending aorta and extending to the iliac arteries.  Emergent cardiothoracic surgery consultation was made. The patient underwent successful ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement with a Dacron graft. His postoperative course was uneventful except for temporary post-operative atrial fibrillation which was managed with amiodarone. He was discharged home on postoperative day 10 on antihypertensives  statin  and regular follow up was arranged with cardiology and cardiothoracic surgery. Patient education was provided regarding the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle modifications.  In this case  all typical risk factors  i.e.  uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  age  smoking history  and male gender  converged  resulting in a potentially catastrophic aortic dissection. The early identification and management of this case highlight the importance of maintaining a high index of clinical suspicion in patients with risk factors presenting with severe chest and back pain.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of considering aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis of any patient with chest or back pain  especially if there's a history of hypertension. It also emphasizes the importance of lifestyle modification and the management of modifiable risk factors in preventing the catastrophic events.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year-Old Hispanic Male: A Case Report  Case Presentation: A 65-year-old Hispanic male presented to our emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of severe chest pain that radiated to the back for the past 3 hours. He reported feeling unusually short of breath and was visibly distressed.  Patient Information: The patient was a retired manual laborer  with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years  hyperlipidemia  and a 30 pack-year smoking history which the patient quit 5 years ago. He admitted irregular adherence to his prescribed anti-hypertensive medications. He denied any family history of cardiovascular diseases. On physical examination  the patient had asymmetric blood pressure readings in his upper extremities  a pertinent positive finding in such case.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed the patient was hypertensive  with blood pressure recorded as 165/115 mmHg in his left arm  and 145/85 mmHg on the right arm. His heart rate was 105 bpm  breathing rate 22 bpm  and oxygen saturation 94%. During auscultation  a faint early diastolic murmur was noted.  Diagnostic Assessments: An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed no signs of acute myocardial infarction. Due to the suspicion of aortic dissection  a CT angiogram (CTA) of the chest was promptly requested. It confirmed an ascending aortic dissection  categorized as Stanford type A  that extended to the descending thoracic aorta.  Therapeutic Interventions: The patient was immediately started on pain relief medication and antihypertensive drugs in the ED. Given that he had a Stanford type A dissection  emergent surgical intervention was indicated  thus a cardiothoracic surgery consultation was placed promptly. The patient subsequently underwent successful emergency ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement surgery  with minimal post-operative complications.  Follow-up and Outcomes: On the patient’s one month follow-up visit to the outpatient clinic  he reported significant improvement in symptoms. His blood pressure was well-controlled  and he showed good adherence to the prescribed medications. He has been enlisted in a cardiac rehabilitation program and is being regularly monitored.  Clinical Relevance: This case highlights the importance of early recognition and prompt intervention for acute aortic dissection  a medical emergency. Despite advances in imaging  aortic dissection remains under-recognized and is often lethal. Physicians must maintain a high index of suspicion in hypertensive patients presenting with atypical chest pain and unequal blood pressures in the upper limbs. The patient's ethnicity also sheds light on the health disparities in minority populations  with under-treatment of hypertension being frequently reported in the Hispanic community.

Title: A Case Report of Aortic Dissection in a 62-year-old Caucasian Male with a Previous History of Uncontrolled Hypertension  Demographic Information Patient: Mr. X  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Complaint: Severe chest pain radiating to the back  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which was diagnosed 10 years ago. Records show a consistent pattern of poor blood pressure control with multiple readings in the range of 160/100mmHg. In addition  Mr. X has a history of smoking - one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Past records also revealed a familial history of cardiovascular disease  with both parents dying of myocardial infarction in their early sixties. His medical history was otherwise insignificant. The patient denied any possible recreational drug use and does not consume alcohol.  Clinical Examination: On examination  Mr. X appeared in severe distress  sweating profusely and hyperventilating. He was conscious  oriented  but seemed to have pale discoloration. His vital signs on admission were: blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg  an irregular and rapid heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute (normal: 12−20 breaths per minute)  and a body temperature of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit. His BMI (Body mass index) was 28  placing him in the overweight category.   There was no symmetry in his blood pressure readings between the right and left arms - 170/110 mmHg and 155/95 mmHg respectively. On auscultating the chest  there seemed to be a distant heart sound  suggestive of a pericardial effusion. The respiratory examination was unremarkable; however  a neurologic exam indicated mild weakness of the patient's right lower extremity.   Investigations:  An immediate electrocardiogram (ECG) showed nonspecific ST-segment and T-wave changes. Transesophageal echocardiography revealed an intimal flap with a dissection that started just after the aortic valve and extended into the descending aorta. Laboratory tests demonstrated elevated D-dimer levels. A CT angiogram of the chest confirmed the presence of an aortic dissection involving the ascending and descending aorta.   Treatment: Given the involvement of the ascending aorta  the case was diagnosed as Stanford Type A aortic dissection. The patient was immediately transferred to the operating room for an emergency surgical repair  which involved a Bentall's procedure with a mechanical heart valve and graft replacement of the ascending aorta. Post-operatively  the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for surveillance.  Conclusion: The occurrence of aortic dissection in this patient underscores the importance of regular monitoring and adequate management of blood pressure  particularly in patients with a long history of uncontrolled hypertension. Early diagnosis and appropriate surgical intervention undoubtedly played a significant role in preventing potential complications and mortalities associated with this life-threatening condition.  Acknowledgements:  I would like to express my gratitude to the cardiac surgical team and the nursing staff for their quick actions and professional dedication in managing this case.

Title: Emergent Diagnosis of Acute Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year-Old Caucasian Male  Introduction  This case report presents the scenario of a 65-year-old Caucasian male who was emergently diagnosed with an acute aortic dissection  illuminating the importance of rapid diagnosis and intervention for survival rate improvement.  Demographic Information and Clinical History  Our patient  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with acute onset severe chest pain radiating to his back. He was a former smoker  and his past medical history included hypertension and a moderate aortic aneurysm detected 2 years ago  which was being regularly followed-up with echocardiography. The patient also has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of myocardial infarction at a similar age. His current medications are Lisinopril 10 mg and Amlodipine 5 mg for blood pressure control as well as daily aspirin 81 mg for primary prevention of ischemic heart disease.  Clinical Assessment  On admission  he appeared acutely ill  with diaphoresis and somewhat altered mentation. His pulse was 100 bpm  blood pressure was 210/100 mmHg  and his respiration rate was 28 breaths per minute. The other primary physical exam findings were a harsh systolic murmur and decreased breath sounds on the right side of his chest. His ECG showed nonspecific ST-wave changes but was otherwise normal.  Management and Outcome  The patient's hemodynamic instability  along with his immediate pain  initially led us to suspect acute coronary syndromes. However  given his history of hypertension  aortic aneurysm  and the presentation of his chest pain  an emergent CT angiography was ordered to rule out aortic dissection. The scan indeed revealed a DeBakey type I dissection starting at the ascending aorta and extending into the descending aorta. This necessitated an immediate transfer to a tertiary care facility for possible surgical intervention.  Surgical intervention was successful  and the patient was discharged after a 14-day hospital stay with close follow-up appointments with a cardiologist and primary care physician. The patient was started on ivabradine and within a month' follow-up his heart rate and BP were well controlled. Despite experiencing minor post-operative complications  including shortness of breath and fatigue  the follow-up echocardiogram showed a normal aortic size with no residual leak.  Discussion  This case underlines the importance of maintaining a high level of suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with acute chest pain  especially when the patient displays hypertension  family history of cardiovascular disease  and a past medical history of aortic aneurysm. Rapid diagnosis and intervention can significantly increase the patient’s chance of survival.  Conclusion  The management of acute aortic dissection is a medical emergency and remains a clinical challenge. It requires a strong index of suspicion  urgent diagnostic confirmation  and prompt treatment initiation  either surgical or medical.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 54-year-old Male with a History of Hypertension: A Case Report  Abstract: We describe the case of a 54-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with a history of severe chest pain  radiating to the back. He was diagnosed with an acute Type A aortic dissection. This patient had a known history of hypertension / high blood pressure that was poorly controlled.  Case Presentation: A 54-year-old Caucasian male patient presented to the Emergency Department with an abrupt onset of severe chest pain  which started during rest  radiating through to the back. The pain was described as sharp in nature  scored as 8 out of 10 on a pain rating scale. The patient also mentioned a history of uncontrolled hypertension. He denied a family history of cardiovascular disease or any genetic connective tissue diseases. The patient had a 30-year smoking history but denied use of alcohol or illicit drugs.   Examination and Imaging: On physical examination  he appeared anxious with a blood pressure of 180/100mmHg and a heart rate of 90 beats per minute. Heart sounds were normal with no audible murmur. There was no asymmetric pulse or blood pressure between both arms. The ECG showed non-specific ST changes but no signs of ischemia. Chest X-ray suggested a widened mediastinum. A subsequent CT aortogram confirmed a Type A aortic dissection involving the ascending thoracic aorta and descending aorta  with no evidence of rupture or end-organ ischaemia.  Management and Outcomes: After lab results were obtained and the diagnosis was confirmed  the patient was immediately started on anti-hypertensive medication intravenously to control his blood pressure  in preparation for surgery. He underwent emergent ascending aortic hemiarch replacement with open surgical aortic repair. The postoperative course was uncomplicated. The patient completed an in-hospital cardiac rehabilitation program and was discharged with prescribed life-long antihypertensive medication. Follow-up at 1  3  6  and 12 months confirmed that the patient was doing well  remaining compliant with medications  engaging in lifestyle modification as well as regular surveillance imaging.  Discussion: This case exemplifies the potentially catastrophic outcome of poorly controlled hypertension. It also highlights the importance of immediate recognition of aortic dissection symptoms  as early diagnosis and intervention are crucial in the management of such cases. Aortic dissection continues to be a challenging clinical condition with a high risk of mortality and morbidity if left untreated.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a 68-Year-Old Caucasian Male: A Case Report   Introduction:  This case report details the presentation  diagnosis  and treatment of a 68-year-old Caucasian male patient who was admitted with an aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a catastrophic cardiovascular event characterized by a tear in the intima of the aorta  which allows for blood to flow into the tunica media  creating a false lumen.   Case Presentation:  The patient  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who was a non-smoker and drank alcohol occasionally  was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of severe  sudden-onset chest pain that radiated to his back  accompanied by shortness of breath. He reported that his father had a history of aortic aneurysm and his elder brother had undergone cardiac surgery. His past medical history included hypertension and dyslipidemia  which was treated with antihypertensives and statins respectively. He had no known drug allergies.   Physical examination showed an elevated blood pressure (178/105 mmHg)  tachycardia (heart rate 111 bpm)  a normal body mass index  and no signs of heart failure. Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed left ventricular hypertrophy but no evidence of myocardial infarction. His laboratory tests revealed a slight elevation in D-dimer level and mild leukocytosis but no significant changes in cardiac enzymes (troponin).  The patient underwent computed tomography angiography (CTA) after his ECG and blood tests showed no signs inflammatory changes indicative of myocardial infarction. CTA revealed an aortic dissection starting after the arch and extending downward to the level of the renal arteries  confirming a type B  Stanford classification  a dissection.   Management:  Given his classification and compliance with medication  conservative management was initiated  including strict blood pressure control using beta-blockers  calcium channel blockers  and ACE inhibitors. The patient was also given pain medication for symptomatic relief. His blood pressure was monitored hourly to ensure optimal control.   Outcome:  The patient responded well to the treatment  with gradual relief from the pain. Repeat CTA after a week showed no progression of the dissection. He was discharged with advice on lifestyle modifications  adherence to medications  and the necessity of regular follow-up examinations  stressing the importance of immediately reporting any chest pain.   Conclusion:  In this case  a definitive diagnosis of the aortic dissection was made based on the patient's unique presentation and imaging studies. Timely conservative management led to a favorable outcome for the patient  emphasizing the importance of early recognition and treatment of this potentially fatal condition. Continuous monitoring and patient education regarding adherence to medication and lifestyle changes are necessary for preventing further complications. This case highlights the requirement of high clinical suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with acute chest or back pain  especially with a history of hypertension and familial cardiovascular disorders.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in an Aging White Male: A Case Report  Case Description:  The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  who presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden and severe tearing chest pain. The patient reports the pain commenced while watching television around two hours prior and was experiencing symptoms at rest.  Physical examination in the ED revealed a blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg in his left arm and 150/90 mmHg in his right arm. The rest of his physical evaluation  including a neurological exam  was normal  but his pain and discomfort persisted. The patient is a non-smoker  consumes alcohol occasionally  and has no history of recreational drug use. His diet is generally low in fruits and vegetables and high in processed and red meats.  Additionally  the patient has a significant past medical history. Seven years prior  he had a myocardial infarction for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 13 years prior. The patient has been on oral hypoglycemic agents to manage his diabetes and is under cardioprotective aspirin and a statin for his cardiac history.  An immediate electrocardiogram was performed  which showed no signs of ongoing myocardial infarction. Based on the presenting symptoms  the clinical suspicion of an aortic dissection was high. A subsequent computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest confirmed the presence of a type B aortic dissection extending from the descending aorta to the level of the renal arteries.  The patient's case was discussed with cardiothoracic surgery  and the decision was to manage it conservatively given the location of the dissection. Following admission to the hospital  aggressive medical management was initiated using beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors to control hypertension and heart rate  as well as close monitoring of blood pressure and pain control.  The patient responded well to initial medical treatment  and his pain was controlled adequately. The patient was educated about the signs of further dissection or rupture to seek immediate medical attention. He continues to follow-up on an outpatient basis with cardiology. His case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and management of aortic dissection for improved patient prognosis.  Based on these observations  this case falls in line with data from the International Registry of Acute Aortic Dissection (IRAD)  showing that the majority of aortic dissections occur in white males  aged over 60 years  with high blood pressure and preexisting aortic atherosclerosis. It serves as a poignant reminder to have a high index of clinical suspicion for aortic dissection in at-risk patients presenting with atypical chest pain.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 55-Year-Old African American Male with Hypertension: A Case Report  Patient Information:  Mr. SK is a 55-year-old African American male  born and living in the Detroit area of Michigan  with a history of uncontrolled hypertension.  Clinical findings: Mr. SK presented to the emergency department (ER) complaining of severe  sharp  ""tearing"" chest pain that started suddenly about 3 hours ago. It began at the center of his chest and radiated to his back  particularly between the shoulder blades. He also reported dyspnea  diaphoresis  and feelings of impending doom.  Diagnostic Assessment: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 175/100 mmHg in his right arm and 155/95 mmHg in his left arm  and a heart rate of 95 beats/min. Aortic regurgitation murmur was audible and pulses were asymmetrical. ECG showed findings suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy but no signs of myocardial infarction. Immediate bedside transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was conducted that revealed a dissection flap in the ascending aorta with complications mimicking aortic valve insufficiency. Lab results were within normal limits except for mildly elevated D-dimer and Troponin I levels. The definitive diagnosis of Type A aortic dissection (Stanford system) was confirmed by a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Emergency surgical repair was decided for the patient by cardiovascular surgery. He underwent successful Bentall procedure (replacement of aortic valve and ascending aorta with reimplantation of coronary arteries into the graft)  and the operation was uneventful.  Follow up and Outcome: His postoperative period witnessed a slow but sustained recovery. During his visit six weeks post-operation  he was in good health with controlled blood pressure. His medication regimen included beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors. He was referred to cardiac rehabilitation and was advised about lifestyle modifications (smoking cessation  dietary adjustments  regular exercise).  Patient Perspective: The patient was initially alarmed with the sudden onset of discomfort and the necessity of immediate surgery for survival. But  the successful recovery from the surgery and the considerable alleviation of symptoms eased his distress. He has expressed readiness to commit to the advised lifestyle changes to improve his health.  Teaching points: This case highlights the fact that a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection is crucial in hypertensive patients presenting with sudden  severe  and tearing chest or back pain. Rapid diagnosis with immediate surgery can significantly improve the prognosis. Patient education on lifestyle modifications is crucial  especially in older males who smoke and have hypertension.  Informed Consent: An informed consent has been obtained from the patient for the publication of this anonymized case description.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Female with Hypertension: A Case Report and Literature Review   PC: Patient Confidentiality  Introduction:  This case report outlines a middle-aged Hispanic female's encounter with aortic dissection  increasing awareness about this condition and its symptoms to enable early diagnosis and intervention.  Case Details:  The patient  a 55-year-old Hispanic woman  presented to the emergency room with severe  abrupt onset of interscapular back pain that she described as ""tearing"". The pain was associated with shortness of breath and mild chest discomfort. She had a history of hypertension and was non-compliant with her antihypertensive medications.  The patient's past medical history besides hypertension was included with controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Obesity  and the occasional use of tobacco and alcohol. She had no known allergies or familial history of cardiovascular diseases. Her father had diabetes  and her mother died of breast cancer.  Upon physical examination  the patient was hypertensive with a blood pressure of 180/110 mm Hg  the heart rate was 88 beats per minute  respiration was 22 breaths per minute. No significant peripheral pulse difference was noted. Cardiac auscultation revealed no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  The initial workup included an electrocardiogram  which showed non-specific ST-T wave changes but no evidence of myocardial infarction or ischemia. A rapid troponin test was negative. Given her history and presenting symptoms  the suspicion for aortic dissection was high  and therefore immediate imaging evaluation was performed.  A CT angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of a type A aortic dissection  involving the ascending aorta extending up to the origin of the right common carotid artery. The innominate artery  left common carotid artery  and left subclavian artery were not involved.  Immediate consultation with a cardiovascular surgeon was done  and the patient was prepared for emergency surgery. The successful surgery involved aortic valve resuspension  ascending aorta  and hemiarch replacement with hypothermic circulatory arrest.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection is a rare but life-threatening condition. The presented case highlights the importance of early recognition and timely surgical intervention in patients presenting with 'tearing' back pain in association with hypertension.  This case further emphasizes respecting patient characteristics such as age  ethnicity  and gender while managing such critical conditions. Research demonstrates aortic dissection is more common in men  Caucasians  and older patients.  Conclusion:  Despite typical demographic trends suggesting lower predisposition  clinicians should maintain a high degree of suspicion for aortic dissection in middle-aged Hispanic women presenting with severe back pain and hypertension. Early detection and prompt surgical intervention significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a Post-Menopausal Female: A Case Report  Introduction:  An aortic dissection is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by a tear in the inner layer of the aortic wall. This report describes the case of a post-menopausal woman who was diagnosed and treated for this disorder.  Case Presentation:  The patient  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her back. The pain was described as a sharp  tearing sensation. The patient reported a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which were controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively). She was a non-smoker and reported moderate alcohol use. Her family history revealed cardiovascular disease  specifically her father experienced an aortic aneurysm at the age of 74.  On examination  her blood pressure was noticeably different in both arms and her pulse was irregular. Her heart sounds were muffled on auscultation  with no audible murmur. Neurological examination findings were within normal limits.  A chest X-ray indicated an abnormal mediastinal shadow  prompting further investigation. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the presence of a Type B aortic dissection starting from the descending aorta and extending up to the iliac arteries. Mild aortic regurgitation was also noted on the subsequent TTE (trans-thoracic echocardiogram).  Management:  The patient was admitted to the ICU and commenced on aggressive blood pressure control using a continuous Nicardipine infusion  with a target systolic BP of less than 120 mmHg. The patient was also started on oral beta-blockers (Metoprolol) to reduce the sheer force on the dissection. Given the absence of malperfusion syndrome and the location of the dissection  the patient was managed conservatively in accordance with the current American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  The patient’s chest pain resolved within the next 24 hours and she remained stable throughout the duration of her stay in the hospital. A follow-up CTA after 7 days showed no progression of the dissection. On outpatient follow-up 1 month later  the patient was asymptomatic  with well-controlled blood pressure levels.  Discussion:  This case illustrates the importance of maintaining a high degree of suspicion for aortic dissection in post-menopausal women presenting with sudden  severe chest pain  even in the absence of risk factors such as smoking and diabetes. Timely diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to positive patient outcomes in aortic dissection cases  as shown by our patient’s successful recovery.  Conclusion:  Despite the rarity of aortic dissection in the general population  physicians must consider this critical diagnosis in post-menopausal women with acute chest pain  particularly those with a history of hypertension. Early detection and immediate intervention can significantly improve clinical outcomes.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Male  Patient Profile  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male presenting with acute chest pain and discomfort  profuse sweating  altered mental status  and difficulty breathing  which began suddenly approximately 2 hours before admission.  Past Medical History  The past medical history of the patient is significant with instances of untreated systemic hypertension  smoking  and dyslipidemia. The patient occasionally consumes alcoholic beverages but denies substance misuse. He has no known drug allergies and is currently not on any medications. The patient has no familial history of cardiovascular diseases but has lost both parents due to cancer-related illnesses.   Clinical Presentation  On admission  the patient was confused with a slightly slurred speech. Vital signs highlighted a blood pressure of 205/120 mmHg  a pulse of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and an O2 saturation of 90% on room air. Remarkably  there was a blood pressure difference between the right and left arm (>20mmHg).  An immediate Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed no evidence of ST-segment changes suggestive of myocardial infarction. However  due to the patient's presentation and high index of suspicion  aortic dissection was considered.  Diagnostic Assessment  An urgent Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) was ordered  which revealed a dissection starting at the ascending aorta  extending into the aortic arch and down the descending aorta  thus confirming the diagnosis of Stanford type A aortic dissection.   Treatment and Outcome  The patient was immediately taken to the cardiothoracic surgical unit for emergency surgery. The procedure entailed a successful aortic root and ascending aorta replacement using a Dacron graft. The post-operative course was challenging due to complications involving acute renal failure and neurological deficits. The patient received further treatment in the intensive care unit with dialysis assistance and physiotherapy.
