After a lengthy hospital stay  the patient has shown significant improvement in functional capacity. He continues to follow up with his cardiologist and primary care doctor regularly. The patient has also committed to making necessary lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation  maintaining a healthier diet and regular exercise to manage his blood pressure and overall health.  Discussion  This case underscores the importance of early recognition and swift diagnosis of aortic dissection  particularly in individuals presenting with acute chest pain and a history of hypertension. The atypical presentation of altered mental status in a setting of acute aortic dissection is  however  less encountered  thus emphasizing the importance of a high index of suspicion in such cases. Consistent follow-up and lifestyle modifications are vital for the management and prevention of recurrence post-surgery.  Compliance with ethical standards: The patient has given his informed consent for the case report to be published. His personal identifiers have been completely removed from this case report. The case report was conducted in line with ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects.

Title: A Case Report on Acute Type A Aortic Dissection  Case Report:  Patient Initials: H.A  Date of Birth: November 11  1953  Sex: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian   Presenting History: H.A  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as sharp in nature and was 10/10 in intensity  without aggravating or relieving factors. His symptoms were accompanied by dyspnea and transient loss of consciousness. The patient denied history of trauma. He had no significant family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Past Medical History: The patient had a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  under treatment with amlodipine 5mg daily and atorvastatin 20mg daily  respectively  for the past 10 years. He was a former smoker but had quit 15 years ago. There was no previous history of cardiac or chest related problems  nor a history of congenital disorders or connective tissue disorders. He admitted to struggling with routine activities due to increased fatigue in the last few days.  Examination: On physical examination  the patient was anxious and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was significantly higher in the right arm than the left (220/115 vs 180/90 mmHg). His heart rate was 110 beats/minute  and breath sounds were equal but decreased bilaterally. There were no audible cardiac murmurs or pericardial rub. His abdomen was soft and non-tender. Neurological examination showed no focal neurological deficits.  Investigations: Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern but no signs of myocardial ischemia. Serum troponin was within the normal range. Chest radiography showed widened mediastinum. Urgent computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of Stanford Type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta  with an entry tear in the ascending aorta and extension of the dissection flap into the transverse arch and descending aorta.  Management: The patient was immediately started on intravenous labetalol to control blood pressure and heart rate. After appropriate consultation with cardiothoracic surgery  the patient was emergently taken to the operating room for open repair of his ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm. The operation was successful without complications.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening crisis with a high mortality rate. Hypertension is the most common predisposing factor  and an acute rise in systemic blood pressure can trigger aortic dissection. This case report emphasizes the importance of prompt diagnosis and urgent management in saving the patient's life.  Patient Consent:  Informed written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case.

Title: Acute Presentation of Aortic Dissection in a 69-Year-Old Female  Introduction: Aortic dissection  a life-threatening condition presenting a high index of suspicion  often presents as severe chest or back pain. Although uncommon  incidence peaks among individuals aged between 60-80 years  and men have twice the risk than women. This case report describes the diagnosis  treatment  and management of aortic dissection in a 69-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman.  Case Presentation:  A 69-year-old Caucasian female  a retired school teacher  presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset chest pain irradiating to her back. The patient described the pain as ""ripping"" and ""tearing"". Her past medical history consisted of high blood pressure  hypercholesterolemia and smoking. She quit smoking 10 years ago  takes medication for hypertension (amlodipine) and hyperlipidemia (simvastatin)  and has no known drug allergies.   Clinical Findings:  Her blood pressure on presentation was 185/115 mmHg  and her pulse was 110 beats per minute. Auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur. Considering her history and clinical presentation  acute aortic dissection was suspected.   Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent computed tomography angiography (CTA) was ordered and confirmed the presence of a type A aortic dissection  originating from the aortic root and extending past the aortic arch  through the descending thoracic aorta into the abdomen. Laboratory findings showed increased D-dimer levels.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous b-blockers to lower her heart rate and blood pressure. Soon after  she underwent successful emergency surgical repair in form of a Bentall procedure  which consisted of replacing the aortic valve  aortic root  and ascending aorta  with re-implantation of the coronary arteries into the graft.  Follow-Up and Outcome:  Post-surgery  the patient was monitored in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for 5 days where her blood pressure and pain were managed adequately. She was thereafter transferred to a regular ward with improved condition. Six weeks after her surgery  the patient presented signs of satisfactory recovery with effective pain management  and her blood pressure was under control. No complications or neurological symptoms have been noticed on follow-up appointments. She has been enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program and has made significant behavioral changes to her lifestyle  including adopting a healthy diet and engaging in regular moderate exercise.   Conclusion:  Early recognition and prompt treatment of aortic dissection are vital in reducing morbidity and mortality rates. This case highlights the need for maintaining high clinical suspicion when elderly female patients with a history of hypertension present with acute chest or back pain. Despite lower incidence rates in women  practitioners should be aware that aortic dissection can occur in this demographic  underlining the importance of rapid diagnostic and treatment protocols.   Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.

Patient Profile  Full Name: Anonymous (for confidentiality) Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Case:  Mr. X is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presented to the local emergency department with sudden severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain started while he was performing routine activities at home. The pain was described as sharp and tearing  rating a 10 on a pain scale of 1 to 10. Mr. X also had profuse sweating and mild shortness of breath. On physical examination  his blood pressure was found to be elevated with a reading of 190/100 mmHg  and he was in obvious distress.   Medical History:  Mr. X is known to have chronic hypertension for the past 10 years under irregular medication compliance  mainly due to his skepticism about long-term drug use. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago under diet control. Apart from these  he was a smoker and was reported to have smoked for 40 years  with an average of one pack per day. He denied any history of illicit drug use. There was no family history of aortic dissection or early cardiac death. He had no known drug allergies.   Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appeared uncomfortable and diaphoretic. Cardiac examination revealed normal S1 and S2 heart sounds without murmur  rub  or gallop. Significant blood pressure differences were noted between the upper extremities. Neurological examination was remarkable for mild confusion but no focal neurological deficits.  Investigations:  An urgent ECG was done and showed no signs of myocardial ischemia or infarction. A subsequent emergent contrast-enhanced chest CT scan revealed an intimal flap in the ascending aorta consistent with Stanford type A aortic dissection.   Treatment:  Emergent surgical consultation was requested  and the patient was swiftly taken for surgical repair. The surgery successfully repaired the aortic dissection with a composite graft. Following surgery  the patient was transferred to the ICU for close monitoring.   Outcome and Follow-Up:  The patient showed remarkable improvement post-operatively and his pain considerably alleviated. He remained hemodynamically stable and was stepped down to the ward after 24 hours of ICU stay. Mr. X was discharged after ten days in good clinical condition  with instructions on strict blood pressure control  cessation of smoking  and lifestyle modification. He was advised to have regular follow-ups for blood pressure monitoring and medications.   This case serves as a typical manifestation of aortic dissection amongst the geriatric population with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and smoking. It emphasizes the importance of early recognition and management for better patient outcomes. Also  it underscores the need for regular follow-up and compliance with anti-hypertensive medications to prevent such catastrophic situations.

Title: A Case Report on Stanford Type B Aortic Dissection in a 60-year-old Male with Uncontrolled Hypertension  Case Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male presented at our emergency department with severe  sudden onset chest pain that radiated to the back. The pain was described as sharp and tearing. The patient also reported feeling mild dizziness and shortness of breath. His family history indicated that his father had a myocardial infarction at an early age (47 years old).  Past Medical History:  The patient had a known history of chronic hypertension for the last 15 years  which was poorly controlled despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications including beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers. He had also been diagnosed with type II diabetes about 10 years prior and was on metformin. His most recent HbA1c was reported as 7%. He had a 35-pack-a-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He reported occasional alcohol consumption and no illicit drug use.  Hospital Course:  Upon admission  electrocardiogram (ECG) findings were nonspecific without evidence of ST-segment changes or Q-wave formations. The initial laboratory findings were normal  including cardiac enzymes. However  bedside transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) raised the suspicion of aortic dissection showing dilated aortic root.   Subsequently  a computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of a Stanford Type B aortic dissection involving the descending thoracic aorta extending distally into the abdominal aorta.  Treatment & Follow-Up:  The patient was admitted to the cardiac ICU and managed conservatively. Blood pressure control was optimized with intravenous anti-hypertensive therapy including labetalol. Follow-up imaging after a week showed no progression of the dissection.  His blood glucose levels were controlled with stricter dietary regulations and insulin therapy. He was also counseled about the importance of strict blood pressure control  regular follow-ups  and lifestyle modifications  including dietary changes  adequate physical activity  and stress management.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection  although a rare condition  has a high fatality rate  making early diagnosis and management crucial. Hypertension remains the most significant predisposing factor. As seen in this case  features of aortic dissection may be ambiguous  but a high level of suspicion should be maintained in patients with high-risk factors such as poorly managed hypertension  history of smoking  and family history of aortic disease or early-onset coronary artery disease. Proper control of blood pressure and diabetes  cessation of smoking  and lifestyle modifications are key to reducing the risk and progression of aortic dissection.  Learning Points:  This case underscores the importance of: 1. Maintaining a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with severe chest or back pain  particularly with a known history of hypertension. 2. The critical role of preventive measures such as strictly controlled blood pressure and blood sugar  cessation of smoking  regular cardiac screening  and lifestyle modifications for at-risk patients. 3. That while ECG findings may be nonspecific for aortic dissection  echocardiography and CTA are key tools in diagnosing this condition.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-aged Obese Male: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 52-year-old African American male  a resident of New York City  was presented to the emergency department. The patient was an active smoker with a pack-a-day habit for the past 30 years and was classified as obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 33.3 kg/m². The patient was employed as a warehouse supervisor and was living with his wife and two children.  Chief Complaints: The patient reported experiencing severe chest pain of acute onset that started around 4 hours prior to the presentation. The pain was sudden  tearing  and radiating to the back.  Medical History: The patient had a history of uncontrolled hypertension for which he was taking medication irregularly due to lack of health insurance and forgetfulness. There was no prior history of diabetes  renal disease  or any surgical intervention. However  the patient had an uncle who suffered a myocardial infarction at an early age of 45. The patient's routine activities were limited due to his morbid obesity and he had poor dietary habits with negligible physical exercise.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  he was found to be afebrile with a blood pressure of 185/110 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. His respiratory rate was 18 breaths/min and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. Auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur heard best at the right sternal border. Left pupil was slightly dilated as compared to the right  indicating a possible Horner syndrome.  Diagnostic Assessment: An urgent transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) visualized aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta. CT angiogram depicted a type A aortic dissection confirming the diagnosis. The lab results showed elevated D-Dimer levels well over the standard threshold.  Therapeutic Intervention: Emergent surgical intervention was planned and the patient was transferred to the cardiothoracic surgery unit. Surgery was successful and antihypertensive medication was aggressively managed to control blood pressure post-operatively.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient was enrolled in the cardiac rehabilitation program and referred for nutritional counseling to manage obesity. The patient was also urged to quit smoking. During follow-ups  he was consistent with medications  with blood pressure maintained under control. There was no recurrence of aortic dissection during 1-year of follow-up.  Patient Perspective: The patient admitted that he had been negligent in managing his hypertension  and this incident served as a wake-up call. He was determined to adopt healthier lifestyle changes and committed to regular follow-ups.  Informed Consent: Verbal informed consent was obtained from the patient to publish this case in anonymity.  Teaching Points/Discussion: This case highlights the importance of effectively managing chronic diseases such as hypertension and obesity  given their potential to precipitate severe cardiovascular conditions like aortic dissection  especially when combined with other life-threatening behaviors such as smoking.

Title: Acute Type B Aortic Dissection in a 60-Year-Old African-American Woman with a History of Hypertension  Case Report: The patient is a 60-year-old African-American female  residing in the urban area of Houston  Texas. She is of average build  does not smoke  and has no previous history of illicit drug or alcohol use. She works as a school teacher and leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle. Her family history is significant for hypertension in both her parents and a maternal aunt  but no known genetic disorders or predispositions have been identified.  The patient has been under treatment for arterial hypertension for 15 years  which has remained nearly well-controlled with medication (losartan 50 mg once daily). However  she has been non-compliant with diet regimen and physical activity often. She has no history of diabetes  myocardial infarction  connective tissue diseases  or significant allergies. Her only surgery was a hysterectomy 10 years ago due to uterine fibroids  with no noted post-op complications.  The patient was rushed to the hospital after experiencing an abrupt onset of severe chest and back pain that was described as ""tearing"" and ""ripping"" that radiated to her lower back. The pain started while she was resting at home and was not related to any physical exertion. Associated symptoms included dizziness  nausea  and profuse sweating. No loss of consciousness was noted.   In the emergency department  her vital signs were found to be unstable  with a blood pressure of 185/120 mmHg  a pulse rate of 110 bpm  and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation was at 94% with room air. Physical examination was significant for a difference in blood pressure between her arms  orthostatic hypotension  and a palpable abdominal mass.  Initial lab results revealed slight leukocytosis and an elevated D-dimer. The EKG showed non-specific ST changes but no definitive evidence of myocardial ischemia. Urgent transthoracic echocardiography showed a dilated ascending aorta  triggering an immediate radiology consult. A subsequent CT angiogram of the thorax and abdomen revealed an intimal flap in the descending aorta  establishing the diagnosis of Stanford Type B aortic dissection.  Emergency surgery was planned; however  due to her clinical instability  she was first medically managed with aggressive blood pressure control using intravenous beta-blockers (labetalol) and a nitroprusside drip under ICU observation.     For this case  the patient's hypertension  age  race  and genetics likely contributed to the occurrence of the aortic dissection. Her non-compliance with lifestyle modifications further precipitated this catastrophic event. Proper education regarding lifestyle modifications  compliance with medication  and regular follow-up are key components in handling patients with chronic illnesses such as hypertension.   In light of this case  it is crucial to maintain a high clinical suspicion for aortic dissection in hypertensive patients presenting with atypical chest or abdominal pain. While this condition is relatively rare  early diagnosis and treatment greatly improve the prognosis and decrease mortality rates.

Title: A Case Report of Aortic Dissection in an Elderly Male Patient with a History of Unmanaged Hypertension  Abstract: Aortic dissection is a rare condition  often associated with a high mortality rate if not promptly diagnosed and treated. The condition is marked by an intimal tear  developing into two lumens. The patient's age  gender  and history of hypertension can contribute to the development of the disorder. This case report involves a 73-year-old male patient who presented with chest pain and was subsequently diagnosed with aortic dissection.  Case Presentation: A 73-year-old Asian male presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain that started within the last six hours. The chest pain  as described by the patient  was acute in onset  tearing in nature  and radiating to the back. Over the past year  he was also suffering from fatigue  occasional dizziness  and had a consistent problem of unmanaged hypertension for the past 10 years. He had a known history of smoking for the past 50 years with a cumulative total of 40 pack-years but no history of illicit drug use. The patient was currently on alpha-2 receptor agonists for his hypertension but admitted irregular intake due to personal negligence.  His physical examination revealed blood pressure readings differing in both upper limbs (right arm: 170/95 mm Hg  left arm: 148/90 mm Hg). Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur. Electrocardiogram showed nonspecific ST-T wave changes  but no obvious signs of myocardial infarction.   The attending physician ordered a computed tomography (CT) angiogram  doing so on suspicion of aortic dissection. The CT results confirmed the suspicion  revealing a Stanford type B aortic dissection commencing after the left subclavian artery and extending to the renal arteries.  Treatment and Outcome: Following the diagnosis  the patient was hospitalized and started on intravenous esmolol for immediate blood pressure control. An interdisciplinary team involving a cardiologist  cardiac surgeon  and anesthesiologist made the decision for conservative management due to the patient's old age and multiple comorbidities. The patient was monitored closely with strict blood pressure control  aiming for systolic blood pressure between 100-120 mm Hg.   During his stay  a regular follow-up CT scan revealed the stabilization of the dissection. After two weeks  the patient was discharged with instructions for regular outpatient follow-ups and a strict medication regimen aimed at controlling his blood pressure at a stringent level to prevent the progression of dissection. On 6-month follow-up  the patient's blood pressure was under control  and he reported significant relief from his initial symptoms and discomfort.  Conclusion: This case reiterates the importance of hypertension management in preventing major cardiovascular complications like aortic dissection. Physicians should maintain a high degree of suspicion for aortic dissection in older patients with unmanaged hypertension  presenting with chest pain and asymmetrical blood pressure. Multidisciplinary management aimed at blood pressure control can lead to favorable outcomes in patients not suitable for surgery.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Male with Uncontrolled Hypertension: A Case Report  Abstract: We report a case of a 57-year-old male who presented with acute chest pain associated with hypotension and was later diagnosed with aortic dissection. This case highlights the importance of prompt diagnosis and management in patients suspected of having aortic dissection  particularly  those with risk factors such as uncontrolled hypertension.  Case Presentation: Mr X is a 57-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presented to the emergency department (ED) with severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back. The pain onset was sudden  while the patient was at rest. He had no significant family history of cardiovascular disease.   Clinical Findings: On presentation  he was in evident distress  pale  diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  and a pulse rate of 110 bpm. The cardiovascular examination was significant for a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. His lung fields were clear  and other physical examinations were otherwise unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (ECG) was initially performed which did not reveal any definitive abnormalities. A computed tomography (CT) angiogram revealed a dissection of the ascending  arch  and descending aorta  consistent with Stanford type A aortic dissection.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initially managed with intravenous beta-blockers to control heart rate followed by vasodilators to maintain his blood pressure  with an aim of systolic blood pressure of 100-120 mmHg. Emergent surgical consultation was sought. The patient underwent successful emergency aortic root  and ascending aortic replacement with an aortic valve-sparing technique.  Outcome: The patient's post-operative course was complicated by transient renal insufficiency  which improved with conservative management. He was discharged on postoperative day 8 with instructions for aggressive blood pressure control. At his follow-up visit a month later  he was doing well  with well-controlled blood pressure on medication.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the challenging diagnosis of aortic dissection with its varied presentation  in patients with risk factors such as hypertension. Prompt diagnosis using CT angiography and an aggressive surgical approach resulted in a successful patient outcome in this case.  Keywords: Aortic Dissection  Hypertension  Chest Pain  Case Report  CT Angiography  Aortic Root Replacement.

Title: A Case Report of Aortic Dissection in an Elderly Female Patient with a History of Hypertension  Abstract: The following case report discusses the presentation  diagnosis  and management of aortic dissection in a 72-year-old African American woman  who presented with sudden back pain. It underscores the importance of early recognition and intervention in aortic dissection to prevent severe morbidity  with a focus on the potential risk factors including age  gender  ethnicity  and the history of hypertension.  Case Report: A 72-year-old African American female patient presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of sudden intense back pain. Her past medical history was significant for uncontrolled hypertension  which she had managed with Lisinopril for a decade. She denied having any known allergies or substance use including tobacco  alcohol  or illicit substances.  On physical exam  her vitals were as follows: blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg  heart rate was at 100 beats per minute  body temperature was 37.5 degrees Celsius and respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute  with oxygen saturation on room air at 98%. The patient had significant diaphoresis and appeared anxious. Her pain was radiating to the abdomen.  An ECG revealed unspecific ST changes  but troponin levels were within normal limits reducing the likelihood of an acute myocardial infarction. Given the patient's high-risk profile - advanced age  uncontrolled hypertension  and her symptoms - CT angiography of the chest abdomen and pelvis was performed. Imaging results confirmed the presence of a Stanford type B aortic dissection.  She was immediately started on beta-blockers intravenously to manage her blood pressure. She was referred to the vascular surgery department for possible endovascular therapy but was deemed unfit due to her advanced age and comorbidities.  The patient was managed medically with aggressive control of blood pressure and symptomatic care. Unfortunately  within a couple of days  the patient's condition worsened  resulting in multi-organ failure leading to death. This case demonstrates the high mortality risk associated with aortic dissection  particularly in patients with uncontrolled hypertension despite therapeutic interventions.  Discussion and Conclusion: Acute aortic dissection remains a widely recognized but infrequently encountered condition  often carrying grim prognoses. Advanced age  hypertension  and African American ethnicity have all been associated with an increased risk for aortic dissection in literature. Thus  high clinical suspicion and timely aggressive management play a pivotal role in the management of such patients. This case accentuates the need for more research to improve the understanding and management of aortic dissection.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in A Middle-Aged Hispanic Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic dissection presents an emergent clinical situation with high mortality rates. This case report discusses a Hispanic male patient who presented with symptoms leading to the diagnosis of aortic dissection.   Case Presentation: A 67-year-old Hispanic male presented to the emergency department with severe back and abdominal pain radiating to his chest. The patient further described the pain as 'tearing' and 'ripping' that began abruptly earlier in the day. His past medical history was marked by hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with atenolol and statins respectively. The patient's father reportedly died in his early 70s due to aortic dissection. He did not have history of smoking  alcohol or illicit drug use  reported no known drug allergies. He lived with his wife  retired  and his activity levels were modest.  Clinical examination showed an alert and oriented patient with visibly acute distress. The patient's blood pressure was elevated (175/110 mmHg) and pulse was regular at 80 bpm. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal S1 and S2 sounds  no murmur or rub  jugular venous pressure was not raised  bilateral peripheral pulses were equally palpable and no signs of peripheral edema. Lungs were clear on auscultation. Abdomen was soft with no palpable mass or tenderness.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given his serious symptoms  high blood pressure  and family history  the emergency physician considered aortic dissection as a differential diagnosis. An immediate CT angiogram showed an intimal flap in the descending aorta  consistent with Stanford type B aortic dissection. His lab work  including complete blood count  renal function  lipids  and troponin levels  revealed no abnormal values.  Therapeutic intervention: As the patient was hemodynamically stable  he was primarily managed with an intensive antihypertensive regimen to control shear stress. His previous medications were continued and intravenous labetalol was added to reduce his blood pressure to the target range. He was later transferred to a specialized cardiology center for further management including catheter-based or surgical interventions.  Outcome: The patient's condition was controlled and kept under observation. Coronary angiography did not reveal any significant lesions and he was managed conservatively with optimal medical therapy and periodic surveillance.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of clinical suspicion in diagnosing aortic dissection  especially in patients with characteristic symptomatology  elevated blood pressure  and relevant family history. It also emphasizes the inevitability of prompt imaging and appropriate medical intervention to prevent fatal complications.    Note: This case report is fictional and does not reflect actual events or patient data. The goal was to provide guidelines for writing a clear  comprehensive  and clinically relevant case report.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 57-Year Old Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Aortic dissection is a severe condition which is associated with high mortality rates. This case focuses on a 57-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension and tobacco use.  Patient Presentation: The patient  a 57-year-old Caucasian male  with an occupational history as a high school teacher  presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  sharp chest and back pain radiating to his hips. The patient described the pain as 'tearing'. His blood pressure was significantly different between arms  with his right arm reading 180/95 mmHg and the left 150/80 mmHg. The patient also had mild temporal and spatial disorientation during the examination.  Past Medical History: His past medical history was significant for uncontrolled hypertension for 20 years  30 pack-years of smoking  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. He was on Losartan for blood pressure management and had no known allergies.  Clinical Findings: Physical exam revealed a diastolic murmur. His ECG showed no signs of ischemia or infarction while his chest X-ray showed a widened mediastinum. An immediate computed tomography angiogram (CTA) revealed an intimal flap in the ascending aorta consistent with Stanford type A aortic dissection. Laboratory results including complete blood count  kidney and liver function tests were within normal range.  Treatment: The cardiothoracic surgery team was consulted and the patient was rapidly taken to the operating room for an emergency ascending aorta replacement due to the impending risk of rupture or tamponade. The operation was successful  and the patient was transferred to the ICU for monitoring.  Outcome: Postoperatively  the patient made a steady recovery. He was moved from the ICU to a step-down unit on postoperative day 3  and finally discharged home on postoperative day 10. The patient was prescribed beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors to control his blood pressure and was strongly advised to quit smoking.   Discussion: This case underscores the need for immediate recognition and management of aortic dissection in under an hour (golden hour concept). Ending his smoking habit and maintaining low blood pressure are crucial for this patient in order to avoid further vascular damage.  Conclusion: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening vascular emergency requiring immediate diagnosis and management. High index of suspicion and early imaging are keys to reducing mortality.  This report was compiled by Dr. Jane Smith  Department of Cardiology  XYZ Hospital.

Title: A Case Report of Aortic Dissection with Positive Outcomes in a 65-Year-Old Male Patient   Patient Presentation:   The patient  Mr. X  a 65-year-old African-American male with a previous medical history of hypertension and smoking  presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden chest pain radiating to the back. The severe pain started abruptly  was described as ripping or tearing  and increased with intensity over time. Mr. X also reported shortness of breath along with the bout of chest pain. He denied any history of trauma or drug misuse. The pain was not associated with food intake  exercise  or any usual triggers for angina. Mr. X’s family history included his father having died from a myocardial infarction at age 50.   Investigations:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) was immediately performed  which showed a left bundle branch block that had not been seen on antecedent ECGs. Chest x-ray did not show any mediastinal widening or signs of congestive heart failure. Given the patient’s symptoms and newly discovered left bundle branch block on ECG  the patient was suspected to have an aortic dissection. A computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed an ascending aortic dissection (Stanford Type A dissection) that commenced just above the aortic valve and extended into the descending aorta.   Management and Outcome:  The patient was emergently transferred to the operating room where emergency cardiothoracic surgery was performed  including ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement with a Dacron graft. The patient was placed on antihypertensive medication and transferred to the intensive care unit post-operatively. During the hospital stay  the patient's blood pressure was closely monitored and kept within a strict range to prevent further dissection. The patient was discharged after a two-week postoperative period with no complications. Upon discharge  the patient was instructed to cease all use of tobacco products and was referred to a cardiac rehabilitation program and continued his antihypertensive medication. Follow-up CT scans showed no further complications or extension of the dissection and the patient reported a significant reduction in chest pain.   Conclusion:  This case report highlights the importance of considering aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis in patients who present with sudden  severe chest pain  especially when risk factors  such as hypertension and smoking  exist. It demonstrates that timely diagnosis and aggressive surgical management in combination with appropriate post-operative care can lead to a successful outcome in aortic dissection patients who often have a poor prognosis.

**Title:** Acute Aortic Dissection in a Patient with Prevalent Hypertension: A Case Report  **Patient Information**: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. His main occupation was as a truck driver before retiring. He is a current smoker with a 35 pack-year smoking history.  **Chief Complaints**: The patient presented to the emergency department with an abrupt onset of severe chest and back pain  which he described as ""tearing"". The pain peaked within seconds of onset and radiated to the back in a downward trajectory. Accompanying the pain  the patient reported symptoms of dizziness and shortness of breath.  **Past Medical History**: The patient has a documented history of systemic hypertension for which he was prescribed Losartan 50mg daily. Unfortunately  due to financial constraints and a lack of regular follow-up  the patient was non-compliant with the medication and often had blood pressure measurements in the pre-hypertensive to stage 1 hypertension range. He had no known allergies  no previous surgeries  no history of any heart diseases  and no known familial history of any genetic or inherited disorders. He has never been diagnosed with Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndromes  and presents no features suggestive of these conditions.  **Physical Examination**: At presentation  his vital signs were noted to be: blood pressure of 180/110mmHg  heart rate of 100 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal heart sounds with no audible murmurs. Pulmonary examination was unremarkable with no audible adventitious sounds. The rest of the examination was unremarkable save for distress evident from facial expression and body posture.  **Relevant Investigations**: An urgent CT angiogram revealed an intimal flap in the ascending aorta  characteristic of a type A aortic dissection. Echocardiography confirmed presence of aortic dissection and revealed mild aortic insufficiency  but without compromise of cardiac function or other valvular dysfunction. Laboratory analysis was largely unremarkable  apart from modestly elevated D-dimer levels.  **Diagnosis and Counseling**: The patient was diagnosed with an acute type A aortic dissection  likely precipitated by his poorly controlled hypertension.  **Management and Follow-up**: Due to the risk of potentially fatal complications  the patient was immediately transferred to a tertiary care center where prompt surgical intervention was undertaken. At one-month post-surgery follow-up  the patient was in good health and was being successfully managed on anti-hypertensive medication. He was advised on the importance of adherence to his therapy  and his need for regular monitoring given his elevated risk for recurrent aortic dissection.  **Conclusions**: This case underscores the potential severity of poorly managed hypertension  and the importance of early detection and intervention in aortic dissection cases.  **Patient Consent**: Obtained.  **Provenance and Peer Review**: Not commissioned  externally peer-reviewed.

Title: A Peculiar Case of Acute Aortic Dissection in a 67-Year-Old Female Patient  Introduction: We present a case of a 67-year-old Caucasian woman who was diagnosed with acute aortic dissection (AAD). This case stands as an interesting representation due to her age and gender. Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Patient Information: The patient  Mrs. A  is a retired teacher who lives with her husband in a suburban area. Mrs. A has a history of hypertension  maintained on antihypertensive medications  and hyperlipidemia  controlled by statins. She is a nonsmoker and non-alcoholic. She has no family history of cardiovascular diseases.   History of Present Illness: Mrs. A presented to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain that started a few hours before her visit. She described a tearing sensation on the left side of her chest  radiating to her back  along with a feeling of impending doom. She denied any symptoms of breathlessness  loss of consciousness  or neurological symptoms.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  the patient's blood pressure was found to be markedly different between the right and left arm  with a higher reading in the right arm (150/90mmHg) compared to the left arm (120/80mmHg). Her heart rate was 100 beats per minute  with regular rhythm and no murmurs. Her abdomen was soft and non-tender; there was no neurological deficit.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern but no acute ST-T changes. A chest X-ray was normal  but given the suspicion of aortic dissection  a computed tomographic angiogram (CTA) was performed which confirmed the presence of a type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the iliac arteries.  Therapeutic Interventions: The patient was promptly started on intravenous labetalol to control hypertension and heart rate. Surgical consultation was immediately sought  and she was taken for an emergency open aortic repair.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The surgery was successful without complications  and the postoperative period was uneventful. The patient made a full recovery and was discharged on postoperative day 10. During the 6-months follow-up  she showed no signs of recurrence.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of high clinical suspicion for acute aortic dissection  especially in hypertensive patients presenting with severe chest pain. It also emphasizes the age and gender variability of aortic dissection patients. Immediate diagnosis by imaging such as a CTA can ensure early intervention and good patient outcomes.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 64-year-old Male with a History of Uncontrolled Hypertension and Chronic Smoking: A Case Report  Patient Presentation: A 64-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with severe  abrupt onset of chest pain radiating to the back. The patient described the pain as “tearing” in nature. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 30-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily.   History and Physical Examination: Upon presentation  his blood pressure was found to be 180/120 mmHg. Assymetric blood pressure was noted with a 20 mmHg difference between the arms. His pulse was 102 beats per minute and respiratory rate at 18 breaths per minute. Upon further questioning  the patient mentioned that his hypertension is poorly controlled and he has not been compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive drugs due to affordability challenges. His last physical check-up was five years ago and he denied any previous episodes of similar chest pain.   Apart from a systolic murmur in the right second intercostal space  physical examination revealed no other significant findings. His Body Mass Index (BMI) was noted to be 26  placing him in the overweight category.  Investigations and Diagnosis: An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed immediately which did not show any signs of myocardial ischemia. Given the symptom profile and history of uncontrolled hypertension  a suspicion of aortic dissection was raised. This was confirmed via Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA)  which revealed a dissection of the ascending aorta  classified as a Stanford type A aortic dissection.  Management and Follow-up: The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to lower the blood pressure and heart rate. He underwent emergent surgical intervention for repair of the dissection. His post-operative recovery was unremarkable and he was referred to a cardiologist for tight blood pressure control and smoking cessation education.  In his follow-up visits  there was noted compliance to his antihypertensive medications and the patient had made efforts towards smoking cessation. Cardiac rehabilitation was recommended.  Discussion: This case underscores the importance of maintaining adequate blood pressure control  especially in high-risk patients  to help prevent catastrophic conditions like aortic dissection. Smoking  being a prominent risk factor for aortic dissection  needs to be controlled and cessation should be advised and facilitated. The patient's delay in reaching out to healthcare due to affordability issues raises concerns about the need for accessible healthcare programs to manage chronic diseases effectively.  Patient's Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the study and the publication of this case report.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 65-year-old Hispanic Male: A Case Report  Abstract: We report a case of acute aortic dissection in a 65-year-old Hispanic male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension. The patient presented with severe chest pain radiating to the back along with sudden onset of severe shortness of breath.  Case Report: The patient  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  demographic of which is stated to have an increased predisposition to hypertension  arrived at the emergency room complaining of sudden severe chest pain  a sensation he described as “ripping” that had started a few hours ago and was radiating to the back. The pain was associated with severe shortness of breath.  The patient was a known case of hypertension for the past 15 years. Despite this  he exhibited poor adherence to his antihypertensive medication regime and often missed medical appointments  leading to uncontrolled hypertension. He had no known allergies but had a 30-pack-year history of smoking. The patient also reported a moderate intake of alcohol. There was no significant family history.  On examination  blood pressure was significantly different in both arms (180/110 mmHg on right; 150/90 mmHg on left)  a classic sign suggestive of aortic dissection  and a weak pulse was felt in the left arm. Heart sounds were normal  but faint diastolic murmur was discernible on exam.  Investigation: An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was done  which showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy but no acute ischemic changes. Laboratory investigations  including Complete Blood Count  Renal function tests  Electrolyte Panel  and Troponin levels  were within normal limits.  Imaging:  An urgent computed tomography angiography (CTA) was ordered  which revealed a Stanford type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the brachiocephalic artery.  Treatment: The patient was immediately started on aggressive antihypertensive therapy (intravenous Labetalol) to lower the blood pressure and heart rate in an attempt to decrease aortic wall stress. Following this  cardiothoracic surgery was consulted for emergency surgical repair.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of maintaining good blood pressure control in hypertensive patients to prevent disastrous complications such as aortic dissection. It also highlights the need for an immediate diagnostic approach utilizing CTA in patients with high suspicion for aortic dissection.   Keywords: Aortic Dissection  Hypertension  Stanford type A  Labetalol  Hispanic Male.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a 63-Year-old Female: A Case Report  Background: Aortic dissection is a potentially life-threatening condition usually affecting males between 60 to 80 years  characterized by the separation of the layers within the aortic wall. It has an estimated annual incidence of 3 cases per 100 000. Notwithstanding its predilection for males  when it occurs in females  it carries higher morbidity and mortality rates.  Case presentation: A 63-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe central chest pain radiating to the back. It started while at rest and persistently increased over time. The patient described it as ""tearing"" and ""sharp"". She denied experiencing shortness of breath  nausea  or palpitations.   The patient has an extensive past medical history  including controlled hypertension for the last 12 years  smoking (30 pack years)  and a family history of cardiovascular disease (her father had an aortic aneurysm). She had regular annual checkups but was not under any medication except antihypertensive drugs (Losartan 50 mg/day).  On examination  she was anxious  pale  and sweaty with a blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg on the right arm and 165/90 mmHg on the left arm. There were no pulse deficits. Cardiac examination revealed a normal S1 and S2 with no additional sounds or murmurs. Chest and abdominal examinations were unremarkable.  Initial EKG showed non-specific ST-segment changes but no definite signs of ischemia or infarction. Blood tests including full blood count  renal function  and cardiac markers were within normal limits. An urgent computed tomography (CT) aortogram revealed an intimal flap in the aortic arch and descending aorta consistent with Stanford type B aortic dissection.   The patient was immediately started on labetalol to control blood pressure and reduce shearing forces. She was admitted to the cardiac care unit for close monitoring and was later transferred to a tertiary hospital for endovascular therapy.  Conclusion: This case elaborates the challenges in diagnosing aortic dissection given its rare occurrence and non-specific presenting symptoms. It underscores the need for high clinical suspicion in high-risk patients presenting with acute chest pain  especially in hypertensive individuals with a history of smoking and a familial predisposition to cardiovascular disease. Early diagnosis via imaging modalities such as CT aortogram is crucial in initiating prompt treatment which  in this case  proved to be life-saving.

Title: A Case Report of Aortic Dissection in a 52-Year-Old Caucasian Male with History of Hypertension and Smoking  Patient Description: Mr. J  a 52-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating bilaterally along the upper back between scapulae. The patient described the pain as “tearing” or “ripping” in nature. Mr. J also reported feeling lightheaded but denied any loss of consciousness. His medical history was significant for hypertension and a 30-year smoking history.  Background: Mr. J is a construction worker and has a body mass index (BMI) of 29. His family history is noncontributory. He has been managing his hypertension with hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg/day and lisinopril 10 mg/day. However  his blood pressure (BP) control has been erratic with noncompliance to antihypertensive therapy and routine checkups. Mr. J is a heavy drinker and smokes approximately 20 cigarettes a day.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  his blood pressure was 210/120 mm Hg in the right arm  and 190/110 mm Hg in the left arm  a differential BP considered significant and suggestive of aortic dissection. His pulse was 98 beats per minute  and he appeared in acute distress. A heart murmur suggesting aortic regurgitation was noted and pulses were faint in both lower limbs. Electrocardiography showed signs of left ventricular strain but no myocardial ischemia. Chest X-ray (CXR) indicated an abnormal mediastinal silhouette with an enlarged aortic knob.   Diagnosis  Treatment  and Outcome: At this point  clinical suspicion was high for aortic dissection. A CT aortography was performed promptly  confirming Type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the descending aorta. The patient was immediately administered intravenous labetalol to control hypertension.   Mr.J was promptly referred to cardiovascular surgery. He underwent successful ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement with re-implantation of the coronary arteries consistent with the Bentall procedure. His postoperative course was uneventful  and he was discharged on postoperative day 12.   Conclusion: This case underscores the critical importance of recognizing the signs and symptoms of aortic dissection in hypertensive patients with a significant smoking history. Early diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention are crucial to improve survival in patients with Type A aortic dissection.  Follow-Up: Mr. J was counseled about cessation of smoking and moderation of alcohol intake. He has been asked to maintain regular follow-ups for monitoring his BP and adjust antihypertensive drugs as required. He has been enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program to improve his cardiovascular fitness. His participation and commitment to these lifestyle changes will play a significant role in preventing re-dissection or other cardiovascular complications.

Title: A Case of Aortic Discretion in a 66-Year-Old Male with a History of Hypertension and Smoking  Introduction: Aortic dissection is a serious condition where a tear in the inner layer of the aorta allows blood to flow into the walls  which can lead to aortic rupture  organ damage  and death. It is commonly associated with hypertension and other heart conditions.  Case Presentation: The patient  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain described as ""tearing"" that radiated to the back. The patient appears to be in distressed condition and complaints of shortness of breath. The pain commenced while he was at rest. His past medical history is notable for treated hypertension  and he has been a smoker for over 40 years. His family history includes cardiovascular disease - his father died of a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. There is no known family history of connective tissue disorder.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination upon admission revealed hypertension  with blood pressure at 169/103 mmHg  and a pulse rate of 108 beats per minute. Cardiovascular examination revealed a difference in pulse and blood pressure between the right and left limb. No abnormal heart sounds were noted. The intimal flap on transthoracic echocardiogram suggested the presence of aortic dissection.  Diagnostic Assessment: Further testing with a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of a type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta and descending aorta. Blood tests revealed raised D-dimer levels. Renal function tests showed elevated creatinine and BUN levels  suggesting renal involvement.  Therapeutic Intervention: Due to the presence of a type A aortic dissection and the patient's worsening condition  emergency surgical repair was deemed necessary. The patient underwent successful supracoronary ascending aorta replacement with aortic root and aortic valve preservation.  Follow Up and Outcomes: The patient’s immediate postoperative period was uneventful. At 3-month and 6-month follow-up appointments  repeated CTA showed no signs of dissection recurrence and the patient reported relief from earlier symptoms. He was advised on strict blood pressure control and cessation of smoking to reduce risk of complications and recurrence.  Conclusion: This case represents the typical demographic for aortic dissection – older males with a history of hypertension and smoking. Prompt identification and surgical intervention remain critical in the management of aortic dissection for reducing mortality and improving patient outcomes. Maintenance of systemic blood pressure within the desired limits and cessation of smoking are essential steps in the prevention of recurrence.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection in a 65-Year-Old Male Patient  Introduction: This report presents the case of Mr. C  a 65-year old Caucasian male  with a sudden onset of severe chest and back pain  accompanied by complaints of dyspnea. His condition was later diagnosed as aortic dissection (AD)  a serious cardiovascular condition that can often be fatal when not treated promptly.  Patient Information: Mr. C is a retired electrical engineer  residing in the midwestern United States. He had been living independently prior to the incident and had a history of smoking  with a pack-years history of 40 years. He mildly consumed alcohol occasionally but had no known drug abuse history.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of chronic hypertension  for which he was on Lisinopril 10mg daily. He did not have any previous major surgeries nor allergic reactions to medications. There were no records of hereditary diseases in the family  but a past history of cardiovascular disease in both his parents was noted.  Clinical Findings: On admission  his blood pressure was markedly different (asymmetrical) between his right and left arms; right arm blood pressure was 185/100 mm of Hg and left arm blood pressure was 155/90 mm of Hg. Mr. C had a regular pulse of 90 beats per minute and respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute. There was slight sweating and pallor noted. On auscultation  there was a variation in the intensity of heart sounds during respiratory cycle and there were no additional heart sounds or murmurs.  Diagnostic Assessment: A chest radiograph showed mild widening of mediastinum. Computed tomographic angiography (CTA) of the chest confirmed the diagnosis of type A aortic dissection originating just above the aortic root  involving the ascending aorta.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient underwent urgent surgical repair of the dissected aorta  which involved an aortic root replacement with a composite graft. Post-operative period was uneventful and his pain and dyspnea got resolved.  Follow-Up and Outcome: Mr. C was discharged home on postoperative day 14  with prescription of antihypertensive medications that include amlodipine 5mg daily and metoprolol 50mg twice a day. Follow-up at six weeks  three months  six months  and one-year postsurgery showed that the patient remained against hypertensive and there was no further progression of the dissection.  Patient Perspective: Mr. C expressed relief at his discharge and was grateful for the timely intervention that saved his life. He was appreciative of the care team and actively participated in his post-operative care.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of early detection and surgical intervention in managing aortic dissection in aging individuals with risk factors such as hypertension and family history. Regular follow-ups are crucial to monitor the stability of the graft and ensure the patient maintains a healthy lifestyle to prevent recurrence or complications.  Ethical Approval: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images.  Author Contributions: All authors equally participated in the preparation of this case report and approved the final version for publication.

Title: Acute Thoracic-Aortic Dissection in a 58-year-old Caucasian Female Patient -- A Case Report  Patient information:  A 58-year-old Caucasian female  social drinker  with a long history of untreated hypertension and a recent family history of cardiovascular disease  presented to the emergency department complaining of severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back  accompanied by shortness of breath.  Presenting Concerns: The patient described her chest pain as ""ripping"" and ""tearing "" with aggravated intensity over the last several hours. She also detailed sporadic instances of lightheadedness during the pain episodes. She denied any previous chest pain and similar episodes  smoking history  or drug abuse.   Clinical Findings: On initial physical examination  the patient appeared anxious  exhibiting significant perspiration and pallor. Her blood pressure presented significant differential between her left arm (200/120 mm Hg) and right arm (160/90 mm Hg). Initial ECG showed non-specific ST and T wave changes.   Timeline: Over the past six months  the patient had routinely not adhered to her medication regimen for hypertension. The onset of the chest pain occurred approximately 8 hours prior to her arrival at the emergency department.  Diagnostic assessment: Emergency CT angiogram revealed an intimal flap in the upper segment of the aortic arch  confirming a diagnosis of Stanford Type A aortic dissection. Complete blood count  cardiac enzymes  and coagulation panel were within normal limits  except for a slightly increased WBC count.  Therapeutic Intervention: After immediate stabilization  the patient was emergently transferred for a definitive surgical repair involving aortic root replacement in combination with re-suspension of the aortic valve and ascending aorta.  Prognosis: The postoperative period was uncomplicated. The patient was discharged on an oral antihypertensive regimen to control her long-standing hypertension  which was considered the biggest risk factor for her aortic dissection. Regular follow-ups were planned to monitor her condition closely  considering her high risk of recurrence due to untreated hypertension and a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Keywords: Aortic Dissection; Hypertension; Type A Aortic Dissection; Chest Pain; Cardiovascular Diseases.  Patient consent: Obtained   This report highlights the importance of managing hypertension  especially in patients with a family history of cardiovascular diseases  to reduce the risk of severe complications such as aortic dissection. The acute nature of aortic dissection requires urgent recognition while emphasizing the role of immediate and radical surgical intervention to prevent fatal outcomes.

Title: A Case Report on Aortic Dissection in a 63-year-old Caucasian Female  Introduction:  Presenting the case of a 63-year-old Caucasian female (Mrs. A) with aortic dissection.  Demographics:  The patient is a retired primary school teacher residing in suburban Maryland  USA. She is a widow  living alone. She is a non-smoker and reports rational alcohol consumption  without any records of substance abuse. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension in her father and stroke in her mother.  Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  treated with Amlodipine 10mg daily and Rosuvastatin 10mg daily  respectively. She had never experienced any symptoms of heart disease until the present incidence. She has no known allergies  a history of mild osteoarthritis  and had undergone a cholecystectomy at the age of 50. She has been in compliance with medications  regular exercise and a balanced diet as advised by her primary care physician.  Current Presentation:  Mrs. A was brought into the emergency department (ED) with a sudden onset of severe  sharp chest pain that she described as radiating to her back. She reported the pain as starting while she was carrying groceries and progressively intensifying. She also reported slight shortness of breath but denied experiencing any other symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or dizziness. No weakness or numbness was reported on initial presentation.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Initial physical examination at the ED indicated elevated blood pressure (180/100 mmHg)  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and slight diaphoresis. No other significant findings were observed during the examination. An EKG was performed showing no signs of myocardial infarction. A subsequent chest X-ray revealed a widened mediastinum. Given the patient's clinical presentation and radiographic findings  a contrast CT scan was ordered that confirmed the presence of a Stanford type A aortic dissection  which necessitated immediate medical attention.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was rushed to the operating room for an emergency ascending aortic replacement  also known as a Bentall procedure. The surgery was successfully performed  and post-operative recovery was uneventful. After the stabilization of the patient's condition  she was transferred to the post-surgery ward for further care. Her blood pressure and other vital signs were regularly monitored  and they remained within normal limits throughout her hospital stay. The patient was discharged after ten days in stable condition with oral anticoagulants and advice for regular follow-up.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the high index of suspicion required to diagnose aortic dissections  given their similar presentation to more common conditions like myocardial infarction. Rapid identification and intervention can significantly improve the survival rate and prognosis of the patients suffering from this life-threatening condition.

Title: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection in a 64-Year-Old Male with a History of Hypertension  Case Presentation:  Mr. J  a 64-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. He described the pain as a tearing sensation  and it began in the anterior chest before moving to his back. The patient also reported breathlessness  sweats  and dizziness. There was no associated nausea  vomiting  or syncope. He denied a family history of cardiovascular disorders.   Past Medical History:   Mr. J had a history of uncontrolled hypertension and was non-compliant with his medication  consisting of amlodipine 10mg and hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily  due to financial constraints. There was no history of smoking or alcohol intake.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient appeared in distress due to pain. His temperature was 37.1°C  blood pressure was 200/110 mmHg in the right arm and 180/100 mmHg in the left arm  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 93% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal heart sounds with no murmurs. Pulmonary examination showed clear breath sounds bilaterally. Abdominal and neurological examination findings were non-significant. His body mass index (BMI) was within the normal range.  Investigation and Imaging:  Laboratory tests revealed a slightly elevated D-dimer at 0.55 µg/ml (normal range <0.5 µg/ml) and a mild increase in leukocyte count. All other laboratory parameters  including hemoglobin  platelets  coagulation profile  and electrolytes  were within the normal range. Electrocardiogram showed non-specific ST-T wave changes. Chest X-ray revealed mediastinal widening suggestive of possible aortic dissection.   A subsequent contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed a Type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the proximal bilateral common iliac arteries. There was no evidence of aortic valve insufficiency or pericardial effusion.  Treatment and Follow Up:  The patient was initially managed with intravenous labetalol to control blood pressure to prevent further dissection. He was then referred for emergent surgical intervention. The postoperative course was uneventful with resolution of symptoms  and he was discharged on postoperative day 7 on oral antihypertensives  with regular follow up in the outpatient department.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of prompt recognition and management of aortic dissection  a potentially life-threatening condition  especially in individuals with poorly controlled hypertension. It underscores the role of imaging in the diagnosis and timely surgical intervention in improving survival rates. Additionally  it demonstrates the importance of antihypertensive medication compliance and highlights the need for accessible healthcare resources to ensure medication affordability for patients.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-aged African-American Male  Patient Demographics:  Sex: Male Age: 56 years Ethnicity: African-American Occupation: Accountant Marital Status: Married Health behaviors: Non-smoker  moderate drinker BMI: 27 (overweight)  Past Medical History:  Hypertension  successfully managed with medication over the last 10 years Late-onset Type-II Diabetes  diagnosed two years ago  managed with metformin History of mild hyperlipidaemia  controlled with statin therapy  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the Emergency Department complaining about severe chest pain  which he described as 'tearing' and radiating to the back. The pain began suddenly while he was at work and was unlike anything he had experienced before. The severity of the pain brought about symptoms of nausea and profuse sweating. Recognizing that he could be having a cardiac event  his coworkers quickly facilitated an emergency medical response.  Investigations:  Considering the patient's symptoms and medical history of hypertension and diabetes  aortic dissection was considered as a potential diagnosis. An ECG was performed  which revealed no signs of myocardial infarction  but did show slight ST segment depression. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was ordered  which showed a dilated ascending aorta and intimal flap  suggesting an aortic dissection.  Diagnosis:  The diagnosis of Stanford Type A Aortic dissection was confirmed by a subsequent CT angiography of the thorax and abdomen with contrast  which visualized a large intimal flap extending from the ascending aorta to the abdominal aorta.   Intervention:  The patient was admitted to the cardiothoracic surgery unit for emergency surgical intervention. An ascending hemiarch replacement with open stent graft placement was performed. Blood pressure was controlled using labetalol and nitroprusside infusion.  Outcome:  The patient tolerated the procedure well and showed significant improvement postoperatively. The six-week follow-up appointment revealed sustained blood pressure control  with no complications or further dissection on imaging.  Learning point:  This case highlights the importance of considering aortic dissection in the diagnosis when encountering patients with a history of hypertension and acute onset chest pain. Early diagnosis may favorably impact the prognosis  as it enables timely surgical intervention  potentially reducing the high morbidity and mortality associated with aortic dissection.

Case Report: Type A Aortic Dissection in a 58-year-old Asian Male   Abstract: This report presents the case of an Asian male patient experiencing acute chest pains  which was later diagnosed as Type A Aortic Dissection. Such cases are comparatively rare  accounting for only 30% of cases of Aortic Dissections. The early use of imaging played a vital role in the diagnosis  prompting immediate surgery which saved the patient's life.  Patient Description:   Mr. B.L.  a 58-year-old East Asian male  presented to our emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the back. His medical history was notable for hypertension which was poorly controlled on a regimen of Amlodipine 10 mg and Losartan 100 mg. He had no history of smoking  alcohol  or recreational drug use. He worked a desk job and reported moderate levels of stress. His family history revealed a paternal uncle who was diagnosed with an aortic aneurysm at 62 years.  Investigations:  Electrocardiography (ECG) indicated no acute ischemic changes. However  the severe chest pain prompted further investigation with a possibility of Aortic Dissection in mind. An urgent contrast-enhanced CT scan was arranged  which revealed a Type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the descending thoracic aorta. The true lumen was compressed  and moderate pericardial effusion was noted.   Management:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous Esmolol to control heart rate and maintain systolic blood pressure within target values to prevent further propagation of the dissection. The observation of Type A Aortic Dissection meant that Mr. B.L. required emergency surgery. A multidisciplinary team consisting of a cardiothoracic surgeon  anesthesiologist  and intensivist was mobilized and the patient underwent successful surgical repair with an ascending aorta graft replacement and aortic valve resuspension.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Postoperative transthoracic echocardiogram showed good ventricular function with no aortic valve regurgitation. The patient had an uneventful recovery with an intensive care unit stay of 5 days  following which he was discharged. He was advised to continue anti-hypertensive medication and regular follow-ups every 6 months.   Conclusions:  In conclusion  this case underscores the fact that despite being less common among Asians  aortic dissection can be life-threatening without prompt diagnosis and management. This case reaffirms the importance of considering aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis of acute chest pain and underlines the value of emergency imaging and surgery.  Patient Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.

Title: A Case of Stanford Type A Aortic Dissection in a 60-Year-Old Male with Hypertension  I. Demographics  All identifiers have been omitted to protect patient confidentiality. Our patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. He lives in the suburban area  is a retired engineer  and has a history of smoking. He has two adult children and lives with his wife. His family history reveals that his father died at the age of 65 due to a heart attack and his mother  currently 89  has a history of hypertension.  II. Past Medical History  His past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension for the last 15 years. His medication regime includes an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi). He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and is on statin drugs. His past surgical history includes an appendectomy at age 20. He stopped smoking 10 years ago but has a 30 pack-year history. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.  III. Presenting Complaints  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe and sudden onset chest pain that radiated to the back. He described the pain as ""tearing"" in nature. The pain was not relieved by resting or nitroglycerin  which the patient had at home due to a previous misdiagnosis of angina.   IV. Examination and Investigations  On examination  he was diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 190/110mmHg and a heart rate of 100 bpm. Differential blood pressures were present in both arms. EKG showed left ventricle hypertrophy  but no myocardial infarction. An urgent CT aortogram showed a Stanford Type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the ascending aorta. Blood tests revealed elevated D-dimer levels.  V. Diagnosis  Based on the clinical features  EKG  blood results  and CT aortogram findings  he was diagnosed with acute Stanford Type A aortic dissection. The patient was counseled about the severity of the disease and immediate intervention was advised.  VI. Treatment and Outcome  The patient was taken up for immediate surgery and underwent successful aortic root and ascending aorta replacement with a Dacron graft. Throughout surgery  his hemodynamic status was well maintained. Postoperative echocardiography revealed no evidence of aortic insufficiency or pericardial effusion.   Postoperatively  his blood pressure was well controlled with medication adjustment. He was discharged 10 days after the operation in a stable clinical condition with out-patient cardiology follow-up arranged.   VII. Discussion  This case underscores the importance of considering acute aortic dissection in a patient with a history of hypertension presenting with severe chest pain. Timely diagnosis and surgical intervention are essential to reduce mortality in these patients. Post-operative management should emphasize adequate blood pressure control to reduce secondary complications.

Title: Acute Stanford Type-A Aortic Dissection in a 70-year old African American Male   Patient Description: The patient is a 70-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a negative history of any cardiac or surgical diseases. He has an average socio-economic background  is a retired army veteran  living in urban residence and a non-smoker.  Presenting Complaint: The patient was brought into the emergency department with acute severe interscapular pain  described as sharp and tearing  which radiated to the chest and upper abdomen within a couple of hours before admission. He also reported mild shortness of breath and dizziness. There is no history of trauma.   Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient had a blood pressure of 220/110 mmHg and a regular pulse of 90 beats/min. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic blowing murmur in the aortic area. Visual disturbances were noted  but neurological examination did not identify any significant findings. There was no disparity in pulse or blood pressure between upper limbs.   Diagnostic Assessment: Preliminary blood tests showed raised D-dimer levels. An urgent plain chest radiograph showed mediastinal widening. A CT angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of Stanford Type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta and arch with an entry tear above the sinotubular junction.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on iv sodium nitroprusside to rapidly reduce blood pressure. Cardiothoracic surgery was consulted  and they proposed surgical intervention for the patient involving replacement of the ascending aorta and aortic valve with a composite graft  including possible coronary artery bypass grafting based on intraoperative findings.   Follow-up and Outcome: The patient was taken for surgery and had a successful operation involving ascendens replacement with composite graft (including reimplantation of coronary arteries). Post-operative recovery was uneventful  and he was discharged two weeks after surgery with a drastic improvement in symptoms. He was prescribed beta-blockers  diabetes  and hypertension medication. Stable conditions were noted during the follow-up visits.  Patient Perspective: Although the surgical intervention was intense  the patient was grateful for the timely diagnosis and successful treatment of the condition. He reported a significant improvement in his quality of life post-treatment.  Learning Points: This case reinforces the importance of a high degree of suspicion for aortic dissection in older patients  especially those with poorly controlled hypertension  presenting with acute severe chest or back pain. Rapid diagnosis and appropriate surgical management are key to improving survival in this group of patients. Additionally  optimal management of risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes may prevent such catastrophic complications.

Title: A Case Report of Aortic Dissection in a 64-year-old Caucasian Male with a History of Hypertension  Introduction: Aortic dissection (AD) is a life-threatening condition often associated with systemic hypertension and the male sex. This report illuminates a case of AD in a 64-year-old Caucasian male with a history of longstanding uncontrolled hypertension.  Case Report:  Patient Information: A 64-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back.
