He was a retired engineer  a non-smoker with a history of poorly controlled hypertension  and he was not under any medication for the condition.  Clinical Findings: Upon arrival to ED  the patient was diaphoretic with severe distress due to the pain. His blood pressure was 220/130 mmHg  heart rate 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. Auscultation revealed a regular rhythm without any murmurs or added sounds. His neurological examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: An immediate electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern  but no evidence of ischemic changes. Chest x-ray showed mediastinal widening. Labs were notable for a raised D-dimer level. The combination of the patient's symptoms  hypertension  and widened mediastinum on chest X-ray led to the suspicion of aortic dissection. A Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) of the chest confirmed a type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the iliac arteries.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on intravenous labetalol for strict blood pressure control and was taken urgently to the operating room for surgical intervention  where he underwent an emergent ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement with a Dacron graft.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Postoperatively  the patient was initially managed in the intensive care unit and then transferred to the ward. He made a slow but steady recovery  with his blood pressure falling to more acceptable levels. During the follow-up visits at 1 month and 6 months post-surgery  his graft was patent and he confirmed improved adherence to his new antihypertensive medication regimen. He remains free of any new cardiovascular complaints.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is often deadly if not recognized and treated immediately. Patients with uncontrolled hypertension  like ours  are at a significant risk. The case highlights the importance of rapid diagnosis and management in AD  lending credibility to the phrase ""time is the aorta."" The emergent surgical intervention was the lifesaving measure in this case emphasizing the paramount importance of early recognition and high index of suspicion for this catastrophic disease.   Conclusion: This case of aortic dissection in a hypertensive patient underscores the severe implications of hypertension and the importance of its effective management to prevent life-threatening complications such as AD. Healthcare practitioners must maintain a high index of suspicion and act swiftly to diagnose and treat such conditions in hypertensive patients.

Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a Middle-Aged Male with a History of Hypertension: A Case Report  Patient Information and Demographics: Mr. X is a 56-year-old African American male  an office worker by occupation and a resident of New York. He is a non-smoker and claims moderate alcohol consumption. He has a history of untreated stage 1 hypertension but no known family history of cardiovascular diseases. The patient's BMI is recorded to be 28  classifying him as overweight.  Presenting Complaint: The patient arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden severe chest pain that had begun a few hours prior. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and stated that it had radiated to his back.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient was anxious and diaphoretic. His blood pressure readings were asymmetric; it was 180/100 mmHg in the right arm and 150/90 mmHg in the left arm. There was also a diminished pulse in the left arm compared to the right. Heart sounds were normal  without murmur. The neurological examination also revealed no abnormal findings.  Timeline: The patient was promptly sent to the radiology department upon arriving at the emergency department. A CT angiogram was done  which revealed an intimal flap in the ascending aorta  confirming the diagnosis of Stanford A aortic dissection.  Diagnostic Assessment: In light of the patient's symptoms  physical exam findings  and radiographic evidence  Mr. X was diagnosed with acute aortic dissection  Stanford type A.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was emergently taken to the operating room for surgical repair of the aortic dissection  as is the standard management for Stanford type A dissections. During surgery  an ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement were performed using a Dacron graft.  Follow-up and Outcome: Post-procedure  the patient was monitored in the ICU for two days. His recovery process was uneventful. He was discharged home on the seventh day after surgery and prescribed antihypertensive medications. He was also referred to a cardiologist for long-term management of his hypertension and periodic monitoring of his aortic health status.  Patient Perspective: Mr. X admits that he ignored hypertension management due to his busy work schedules  but vows to take his current and future health condition seriously.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was taken from Mr. X for publishing this case report for academic and scientific purposes.  In conclusion  this case emphasizes the vital importance of managing chronic hypertension to prevent severe complications like aortic dissection  which harbors significant mortality risk. It also underscores the need for timely diagnosis and management of aortic dissections to improve patient outcomes.

Title: Aortic Dissection in a Middle-aged Hypertensive Male: A Case Study  Introduction:   Aortic dissection  a serious condition arising from a tear in the inner layer of the aorta  accounts for substantial morbidity and mortality globally  occurring more commonly in males aged 60-80 years  particularly those with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and related cardiovascular diseases.  Case Presentation:  The patient  a 67-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department (ED) with an acute onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. He described it as a ""tearing"" pain that began a couple of hours ago while at home. The patient was obese with a BMI of 32  a known hypertensive for over a decade  and non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication. He had no prior history of smoking  alcohol use  or usage of any illicit substances. His family history was significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease.  On physical examination  the patient appeared uncomfortable  pale  and diaphoretic. Initial vital signs showed a blood pressure of 195/115 mmHg  heart rate of 108 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur best heard over the right sternal border.  Differential diagnosis included acute myocardial infarction  aortic dissection  and pulmonary embolism. Immediate lab tests were ordered which revealed a markedly elevated D-dimer and a negative troponin-I. Chest X-ray showed mediastinal widening. An ECG displayed nonspecific ST-T wave changes but no evidence of ischemia or infarction.   Given the severity of presenting symptoms  a history of hypertension and the results of the initial investigations  a CT angiogram of the chest was ordered which confirmed the diagnosis of type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta.   Discussion:  The patient was emergently taken to the operating room for an aortic arch replacement along with a concomitant Bentall procedure. His postoperative course was complicated by transient acute kidney injury  but he showed gradual improvement with aggressive management. Upon discharge  he was educated on the importance of blood pressure control and adherence to medications. A multidisciplinary team approach involving cardiology  cardiothoracic surgery  and a nurse case manager was utilized for comprehensive care coordination.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates the catastrophic potential of aortic dissection  particularly in patients with uncontrolled hypertension. Early recognition and immediate management are critical for survival. It also underscores the need for patient education and engagement in managing chronic hypertension to prevent deadly complications such as aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 62-year-old African-American male  with a BMI of 29  presenting with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. The pain was described as an intense  tearing sensation that began abruptly. He has a significant history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years  with an average BP range of 156/92 mmHg. He has been non-compliant with his hypertension medication  lisinopril  and has not been diligent about lifestyle modifications suggested by his previous physicians. He also has chronic kidney disease (stage 3) and is a 20-pack-year smoker.  Family history is significant for his father who died from myocardial infarction at the age of 64 and a younger brother (59-year-old) diagnosed with abdominal aortic aneurysm. He reports having a stressful work environment and locomotion deficits due to osteoarthritis  contributing to minimal physical activity. He admits to consuming a high-salt and high-fat diet often due to convenience though he is aware this may not be best for his health conditions.  On examination  heart rate was 85 bpm and blood pressure was 190/115 mmHg in his right arm and 160/100 mmHg in his left arm  generating suspicion. A trace of blood was found in his urine during a urinalysis exam. An urgent transesophageal or transthoracic echocardiogram showed a tearing in the intimal layer of the aorta.  The sudden onset of severe pain  hypertension history  discrepancy in blood pressure readings between arms  and findings from the echocardiogram led to the diagnosis of an aortic dissection.   The patient was immediately started on medication to reduce his blood pressure and heart rate  namely labetalol  and was planned for emergency surgery. Family members were briefed about the high-risk procedure and the need for lifetime commitment towards comprehensive management of the patient's hypertension. Developing a proper diet  cessation of smoking  stress management  and an appropriate exercise regimen were discussed for future management. Future consultations with a rheumatologist for osteoarthritis management and a psychiatrist for dealing with job-related stress were also recommended.   The presentation presented above is a depiction of a true aortic dissection case  which is more commonly found in African-American populations  men  and individuals with hypertension. History of smoking  CKD  and family history of cardiovascular diseases makes the patient more vulnerable and supports the necessity of an integrated approach to management.

Patient Case Presentation: Aortic Dissection   I. Introduction  Mr. Johnson is a 64-year-old African-American male presenting with complaints of severe chest and back pain  which he describes as ""ripping"". Aortic dissection is more common in males and the prevalence is higher in the African American population. The symptoms started about 2 hours prior  during his usual morning walk.   II. Past Medical History  Patient has a known history of hypertension for the last 20 years  which is poorly controlled due to non-adherence to medication. He is a smoker (30 pack-years history) and consumes moderate alcohol. He does not have a history of illicit drug use. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years back and underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG).   III. Family History  Mr. Johnson's father died at the age of 70 due to a stroke  and his mother died at 60 due to heart disease. His elder brother  aged 70  is diagnosed with diabetes and cardiovascular disease.  IV. Social History  He worked as a mechanic till he retired 4 years back. He lives with his wife  and they have 2 adult children who are healthy. He admits not following an exercise regimen and regularly consumes high fat  high sodium food.  V. Physical Examination  The patient appears anxious and diaphoretic on examination. His blood pressure is found to be 200/110 mm Hg in right arm  and 160/90 mm Hg in left arm. His heart rate is 110 bpm  with regular rhythm. Cardiac auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur  and chest examination shows reduced breath sounds in the left lower zone.  VI. Diagnosis   Based on the patient's symptoms of severe  tearing chest and back pain along with his past history and clinical examination  a provisional diagnosis of aortic dissection was made.   VII. Investigations   CT angiogram of the chest was ordered which confirmed the diagnosis of Type A aortic dissection. Echocardiogram showed a dilated aortic root  and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide levels indicating left ventricular dysfunction.  VIII. Treatment  The patient was immediately started on beta-blockers and nitroprusside to reduce blood pressure and heart rate. He was taken to the operating room for emergent surgical repair.  IX. Conclusion  This case illustrates the importance of early recognition of aortic dissection  a life-threatening but potentially treatable condition  especially in patients with risk factors like male gender  age over 60  hypertension  smoking  and previous cardiovascular disease.

Patient Presentation:  Patient: Mr. Rodriguez  Age: 60-year-old  Race: Hispanic   Occupation: Retired  previously worked in logistics  Presenting Complaint: Chest pain radiating to the back  Previous Medical History: Hypertensive for 10 years  Social History: Non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  Family History: Father passed away at 65 from a stroke  Mother has diabetes. No history of cardiovascular disease.  Admission Information: Mr. Rodriguez  a 60-year-old Hispanic male  was admitted to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset of severe chest pain  which he described as ""tearing"" in quality and radiating to the back. His pain started about 2 hours before. He describes it as the most severe pain he has ever experienced.   On examination  Mr. Rodriguez’s was anxious with pain score of 10. The blood pressure in his right arm was significantly higher than his left arm. There were normal heart sounds with no murmurs  but with slight diastolic decrescendo murmur. His lower limbs were cold and pulses were diminished.  Diagnostic Procedures: He had a computed tomography (CT) done which showed an aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta. Hemoglobin and hematocrit were within normal range  d-dimer was elevated. His kidney function tests were slightly raised and liver function tests were normal.  Treatment Plan: Given the nature of his condition  Mr. Rodriguez was taken to the operating suite for an emergent aortic repair after his hemodynamic situation was stabilized with Intravenous fluids and Intra-arterial nitroprussides. Post-operatively  he will be followed up in the cardiology clinic and given medications to control his blood pressure.  Conclusion: This case underscores the crucial importance of recognizing the characteristic features of acute aortic dissection. Any acute severe chest pain with differences in blood pressures among arms should alert the clinician to the possibility of aortic dissection. This condition is a life-threatening emergency and requires immediate surgical intervention  especially when it involves the ascending aorta. It should be suspected particularly in hypertensive patients who present with chest pain.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male TC  who is an ex-smoker with a 30-pack year history and a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic alcoholism. He reports to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  sharp chest and back pain that started approximately 2 hours ago while he was in his garden. The pain is rated at a 10 on a 10-point scale and radiates to his upper abdomen.  TC's vital signs show an elevated blood pressure of 185/110 mmHg  a pulse rate of 105 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. He appears acutely ill and is visibly anxious. The pain is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. There is a discrepancy in blood pressure between his right and left arms.  Past Medical History: TC has been under treatment for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years. He has been non-compliant to his medication regimen (amlodipine  hydrochlorothiazide  and rosuvastatin)  which has been noted on multiple clinic visits. He also has a 30-year history of alcoholism but quit smoking ten years ago.  Family History: TC's father died at the age of 73 from a myocardial infarction. His mother  aged 86  has been diagnosed with chronic heart failure. He also has a younger brother who suffers from diabetes.  Investigations: Electrocardiogram shows no signs of myocardial infarction. Transthoracic echocardiogram performed in ED indicates a dilated aortic root and an aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta extending into the descending aorta. Laboratory findings reveal raised cardiac enzymes and slightly impaired renal function.  Management and outcome: TC was immediately started on intravenous labetalol for his hypertensive crisis. A cardiovascular surgery consult was placed  and he underwent successful emergent surgical repair of his aortic dissection. Post-surgical recovery was complicated by transient acute renal failure  likely due to the compromised blood supply secondary to the dissection. However  TC's renal function improved with medical management.  The patient was discharged home with prescriptions for amlodipine  metoprolol  atorvastatin  and aspirin. He was extensively counseled on the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle modification  regular follow-up  and blood pressure monitoring.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the potentially fatal nature of aortic dissection  especially in patients with poorly controlled hypertension. Timely identification and intervention saved the patient’s life  but it emphasizes the need for regular monitoring and compliance to treatment in patients with hypertension to prevent such emergencies.  (Note: Certain details were assumed for the purpose of this case presentation)

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 60-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden and severe sharp pain in his chest and upper back  radiating down to his abdomen. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and rated it a 10 on a 0-10 scale. He also reported shortness of breath  fainting spells  and weakness in one side of his body.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a significant past medical history of hypertension  which has been poorly controlled despite being on two antihypertensive medications. He also has a history of tobacco use  consuming a half-pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years. He quit smoking two years ago upon the advice of his primary care physician. He has no history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  or other cardiovascular diseases.  Family History: His father died from a stroke in his early sixties  and his mother has been diagnosed with hypertension. His younger brother underwent coronary artery bypass grafting at the age of 55 and has since managed his heart health through diet  exercise  and medication. There is no known family history of aortic dissection or other aortic diseases.  Physical Examination and Diagnostics: On examination  Mr. Johnson appeared in severe distress. His blood pressure was significantly elevated with differing readings on both arms. Heart sounds were normal  but a diastolic murmur was detected. EKG showed no signs of myocardial infarction. Laboratory findings revealed slightly elevated D-dimer levels  and complete blood count (CBC) and comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) were within normal limits. A computed tomography angiography (CTA) was performed  which confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection.  Plan: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with a Stanford type A aortic dissection  an emergent condition. He was stabilized with medication to control his blood pressure and promptly referred to cardiothoracic surgery for surgical management.  Discussion: This case illustrates the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients presenting with uncontrolled hypertension and severe chest or back pain  especially with a history of smoking. The prevalence of aortic dissection is significantly higher in males and increases with age  aligning with Mr. Johnson’s demographic. African-Americans have a higher risk of developing the disease compared to other racial groups. Furthermore  hypertension is the most common risk factor  present in up to 75% of cases. If left untreated  aortic dissection can lead to aortic rupture and death  emphasizing the importance of timely diagnosis and management.

Patient Presentation  Patient X  a 65-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with acute  severe chest pain. The pain was described as a tearing sensation  starting from his chest and radiating to his back. Upon medical consultation  the patient revealed a history of hypertension and smoking. His blood pressure at presentation was markedly high  reading 175/95 mmHg. He had no record of regular medications  reflecting poor control of hypertension. Family history revealed his father had died from a stroke  possibly suggesting a familial susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases.  The patient's symptoms and past medical history aroused a strong suspicion for aortic dissection  an often-fatal condition that has a predilection for elderly males  specifically within the African-American population. Patient X was immediately sent for a computed tomography (CT) scan which revealed an aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending to the descending aorta classifying it as Stanford Type A aortic dissection  a medical emergency.  The patient's past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension likely contributed to his current diagnosis. Chronic hypertension causes considerable stress on the heart and the blood vessels  leading to several cardiovascular complications  including aortic dissection. His smoking habit could also have played a contributory role  as smoking is a recognized risk factor for atherosclerosis and subsequent cardiovascular disease.  The patient was promptly started on medication to urgently lower his blood pressure. Simultaneously  the cardiothoracic surgery team was consulted for an emergent surgical evaluation considering the patient's classification and ongoing symptoms.  In summary  Patient X's case presents an example of a high-risk demographic for aortic dissection  which is typically seen in elderly  hypertensive African-American males with a family history of cardiovascular disease. The importance of regular hypertension control  lifestyle modification such as smoking cessation in these demographics cannot be overstressed considering the potentially catastrophic consequences of uncontrolled hypertension.

Case Presentation:  Demographics and History: Patient X is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who retired five years ago from a bank job. He is married  has two adult children and lives in a suburban environment. Patient X is a non-smoker with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are controlled with medication- Thiazide diuretic and a statin  respectively. He has no known drug allergies. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 75 and his mother had a history of stroke before passing away at 78.  Presenting Issue: The patient presented to the emergency department with severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back that started suddenly while performing yard work in his garden. His blood pressure was found to be elevated in his right arm compared to his left arm. This symptom  combined with his previous medical history and the nature of his pain  led to a suspicion of aortic dissection.  Evaluation and Diagnosis: Upon examination  the patient appeared pale and sweating  but without signs of neurological deficit  pulmonary rales  or limb ischemia. An electrocardiogram displayed no signs of myocardial ischemia. Chest X-ray revealed a widened mediastinum. With suspicion of aortic dissection  a Computerized Tomography Angiogram (CTA) of the chest was ordered  which confirmed the diagnosis of a Stanford Type A aortic dissection extending from the aortic root to the aortic arch.  Current Status and Plan: The patient was transferred to the surgical ICU and referred to a cardiothoracic surgeon. Medical management was initiated immediately to control heart rate and blood pressure with intravenous medications – Metoprolol for heart rate and Nitroprusside for blood pressure control.  Conclusion: This case presents a patient who is at higher risk of aortic dissection due to hypertension and a family history of cardiovascular diseases in the setting of sudden severe chest pain. Prompt diagnosis using a CTA of the chest was critical in identifying the aortic dissection and warranted immediate surgical consultation. His management focused on immediate stabilization of hemodynamics  prompt surgical consultation given the high risk of rupture associated with type A dissections  and appropriate preoperative medical therapy.  References:  Parikh N  Trimarchi S. Acute aortic dissection. Cardiol Clin. 2017;35(3):331-345. doi:10.1016/j.ccl.2017.03.004  Erbel R  Aboyans V  Boileau C  et al. 2014 ESC guidelines on the diagnosis and treatment of aortic diseases. Eur Heart J. 2014;35(41):2873-2926. doi:10.1093/eurheartj/ehu281

Case Presentation:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 67-year-old African American male with a BMI of 32. He lives in an urban community and is retired from a mid-level laborer position.  Chief Complaint: Severe chest pain  radiating to his back.  History of Present Illness: The patient reported to the ER with complaints of a sudden onset of intense  tearing chest pain that started approximately 3 hours ago  and has gradually increased. The pain radiates to his back and left arm. Accompanied by sweating  nausea  and dyspnea.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of hypertension  which has been poorly controlled over the years. He has a 30-year history of cigarette smoking  but quit 10 years ago. Previous medical records also reveal an episode of transient ischemic attack five years ago.  Family History: The patient's father passed away from a stroke at age 72  and his mother passed away at age 78 from congestive heart failure. He has a younger brother  age 62  who has no significant cardiac history.  Physical Examination: On examination  blood pressure in the right arm was found to be more than 20 mm Hg higher than that in the left arm. His heart rate was rapid and irregular. There was a diastolic murmur audible over the right second intercostal space.   Investigations: A CT scan confirmed a diagnosis of aortic dissection. An EKG indicated left ventricular hypertrophy but no evidence of an acute myocardial infarction. Blood tests showed slightly elevated cardiac enzymes.  Treatment and Management: The patient was immediately started on beta-blockers to control blood pressure and decrease shear stress on the aorta  and later underwent emergency surgery to repair the dissected aorta.  Conclusion: This patient’s long-standing history of hypertension along with his smoking history significantly increased his risk for aortic dissection. It underlines the fact that stringent blood pressure control is pivotal in preventing such catastrophes. This patient's son  given the family history  should be advised regarding the genetic predisposition and need for regular check-ups.   This case emphasizes the need for an immediate and accurate diagnosis and treatment of aortic dissection  which is a life-threatening condition. It also underscores the importance of chronic hypertension management and smoking cessation.

Patient Identity: Male  65-year-old  African American  Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Symptoms: The patient  Mr. M  arrived at the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe tearing chest pain radiating to his back. He was also experiencing shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and dizziness.  Past Medical History: He has had hypertension for the past 10 years which is poorly controlled on medication. He has a 20-year history of smoking  consuming approximately one pack a day. He also reported a history of occasional alcohol use. There is no evidence of diabetes or any other significant illness in his medical record.  Family History: His father passed away at 70 due to a stroke  and his mother has hypertension and diabetes. He has one brother who was diagnosed with an aneurysm at an early age.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient had high blood pressure - 180/110 mm Hg. He was hyperhidrosis and dyspneic while his pulse rate was 110 beats per minute. Auscultation over the aorta revealed a diastolic murmur.  Investigation: An electrocardiogram showed no signs of myocardial ischemia. His lab tests  including complete blood count  coagulation profile  liver function test  and kidney function test were all normal. D-dimer was elevated  as expected in these cases.  Imaging: A CT angiogram of the chest confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection originating just beyond the aortic root and extending into the descending aorta.  Hospital Course: The patient was promptly transferred to the cardiac care unit. A cardiothoracic surgeon was consulted  and the patient was taken for emergency surgery to repair the aortic dissection.  Prognosis: The patient's prognosis depends on surgical outcomes and how well his other conditions  such as high blood pressure  are managed post-surgery. Timely recognition and appropriate management of aortic dissection significantly improve prognosis.  This case highlights the association of modifiable risk factors such as hypertension and smoking with aortic dissection. Both conditions were likely contributors to our patient's presentation  suggesting the need for aggressive risk factor management and patient education on potential symptoms that might suggest an aortic dissection event.  This case also underlines disparities in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality rates around the globe and  especially  among racial and ethnic groups. African Americans have higher rates of hypertension compared with other racial or ethnic groups in the U.S  and they are also more likely to experience complications from high blood pressure  which may partly explain the occurrence of aortic dissection in this patient. This racial disparity brings to light the importance of appropriate screening and management strategies  especially in high-risk groups.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J. Rodriguez  a 65-year old Hispanic male  presented with a sudden onset of severe  tearing pain in his upper back and chest. He is an ex-smoker and has a known history of hypertension which has been inconsistently controlled for about 10 years. He denies drug or alcohol abuse. Mr. Rodriguez is married  father to three adult children  and works as a mechanic.  Relevant Medical History:  On reviewing his past medical history  Mr. Rodriguez has Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) secondary to his prior tobacco use. He is marginally compliant with his antihypertensive medication (amlodipine)  and his blood pressure at previous visits ranged from 145/90 to 165/95. He denies any previous cardiac history  including myocardial infarction  congestive heart failure  or valvular diseases. There is no past surgical history to note.  Family History:  Mr. Rodriguez shared that his father passed away at the age of 70 due to myocardial infarction  while his mother had a stroke at the age of 68 and now resides in a nursing home due to vascular dementia. One of his sisters was diagnosed with breast cancer in her 50s. His family history is significant due to these instances of cardiovascular disease and malignancy.   Physical Examination:  On examination  Mr. Rodriguez appeared in acute distress  clutching his chest. His vitals revealed a blood pressure of 180/100mmHg  heart rate of 95 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F). His cardiovascular exam showed a distant heart sound but no murmur or pericardial rub was heard. The rest of his physical examination was relatively unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given his presentation and past medical history  emergency computed tomography (CT) of the chest was performed  which revealed an aortic dissection from the level of the aortic arch down to the renal arteries  consistent with Stanford Type B Aortic Dissection. His blood tests including full blood count  liver function tests  and renal function were relatively normal  while his troponin I level was slightly elevated.  Management Plan:  Mr. Rodriguez was transferred promptly to the Intensive Care Unit for blood pressure control and was started on intravenous beta-blockers. Emergency surgery consultation was done and it was decided to manage him conservatively given the type of dissection.  Conclusion:  This case sheds light on a relatively common yet underdiagnosed cardiovascular condition. Prompt recognition and aggressive management are essential to improve outcomes. It also emphasizes the importance of adequate blood pressure control in patients with known hypertension to prevent serious complications such as aortic dissection.

Patient Case Presentation: Aortic Dissection   Demographics:   The patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension and smoking. He is retired and lives with his wife. He has three adult children and six grandchildren. The patient is well-educated and is a retired engineer. He has a consistent record of receiving medical check-ups and follows prescribed treatment plans.   Past Medical History:  He has a chronic history of uncontrolled hypertension over the past 10 years. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago  which is currently managed with Metformin. The patient had a myocardial infarction 2 years back from which he successfully recovered with mild residual left ventricular dysfunction. The patient has a medical history of hyperlipidemia and peripheral vascular disease. He has a 30-year history of smoking but quit ten years ago. No history of substance abuse and no known allergies.   Family History:  His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His mother is alive and in good health. His paternal uncle died from stroke and his maternal uncle from aortic aneurysm rupture. Two of his three siblings have hypertension. No family history of connective tissue disorders or genetic syndromes.   Presenting Complaint:   The patient presented with sudden sever chest pain which he described as ripping and tearing  radiating to the back. The pain is accompanied by shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and syncope.  On physical examination  his blood pressure was found different in both arms. He had weak pulses in the lower extremities and there was a diastolic murmur noticed best at the aortic area.  Diagnostic Tests:   The electrocardiogram suggested no recent significant ischemic changes. His chest X-ray revealed mediastinal widening suggestive of dissection involving the ascending aorta. The diagnosis was confirmed by computed tomography angiography (CTA) which revealed a type A aortic dissection.  Treatment and Discussion:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous esmolol to decrease heart rate and blood pressure and reduce the shear stress on the aortic wall. Due to the presentation with a type A aortic dissection  which is a surgical emergency  the patient was quickly referred to the cardiothoracic surgeons. His family was informed and education provided about risk associated with surgery. Consent was taken and he underwent an emergent surgical intervention - a successful Bentall procedure (aortic root and valve replacement with a composite graft).  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients with uncontrolled hypertension who present with acute severe chest pain. Immediate diagnosis and prompt treatment in this case  even in the face of multiple co-morbidities  prevented the potential catastrophic outcomes associated with this condition.

Patient Presentation:  Introduction: Mr. Johnstone  a 62-year-old African American male  presented himself to the emergency department. He mentioned a sudden-onset  severe chest pain that radiated to his back  describing it as ""tearing or ripping"". His pain began 40 minutes prior to his visit while gardening at home. He further reported experiencing a shortness of breath as the day progressed.  Past Medical History: This patient was a retiree who lived alone. He had a 25-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 6-year history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus. He was a former smoker with no history of illicit drug use. His medication included Metformin and Lisinopril  which he admitted to occasionally forgetting.   Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his mother of stroke in her early 70s. His younger brother  aged 59  was recently diagnosed with prehypertension. The patient had one son who was healthy.  Physical Examination and Diagnostics: Mr. Johnstone appeared anxious; his BP was asymmetric with 170/95 mmHg on the right arm and 155/85 mmHg on the left. He was mildly tachycardic with a pulse rate of 102 bpm  had a slight diaphoresis but no fever. Pulses were also asymmetric  and there was a relatively faint diastolic murmur. Because of the severity of his symptoms and medical history  an immediate CT scan was performed revealing a Type B aortic dissection.  Hospital Course: Mr. Johnstone was admitted in the Cardiac Intensive Care Unit  initiated on intravenous (IV) beta blockers to lower his blood pressure and decrease the sheer stress on the aortic wall  and IV analgesia for pain management. Following cardiologist consultation  the patient was managed conservatively with aggressive blood pressure control and monitored closely. He remained stable and was discharged on oral medications with plans for outpatient surveillance.  Discussion: Mr. Johnstone's demographic profile and medical history align with the typical features seen in patients with aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is more prevalent among African American individuals and in males with ages between 60-80. It has an increased association with hypertension  contributing to an estimated 75% of cases. This patient’s uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  stressful activity  and significant family history of cardiovascular disease are all contributing risk factors.     Preventive strategies should focus on controlling the blood pressure and perhaps stricter medication adherence to prevent such a serious issue could be suggested to Mr. Johnstone.

Case Presentation Demographics: Mr. A  a 65-year-old Caucasian male patient  presented to the hospital complaining of severe chest pain that started while he was gardening at home. He is a retired New York lawyer and lives with his wife.   Past Medical History: His past medical history reveals that the patient is hypertensive; a condition well-managed with a beta-blocker (Metoprolol). He is also a former smoker  having quit for the last decade  but still has a smoking history of 35 years. His last recorded blood pressure a month ago was 135/85 mmHg. There were no reports of dyslipidemia  diabetes  cardiovascular disorders  or any other significant past medical condition.  Family History: There is a noted family history of cardiovascular diseases  with Mr. A's father having passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and a brother who had a stroke at 58.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. A complained of tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as sudden in onset and severe. His wife confirmed that he appeared pale  anxious  and sweaty at the time the symptoms occurred.  Clinical Examination & Investigations: On physical examination  Mr. A had unequal blood pressures in both arms (Left arm BP was 150/90 mmHg  while the right arm BP was 130/80 mmHg) with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and his respiratory rate was 20 breaths per min. Heart sounds were normal with no murmurs.  An immediate ECG was done in the ER. It was normal  ruling out myocardial infarction. However  considering the acute onset of symptoms and the unequal blood pressures  a CT angiogram was performed  which showed a dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending to the descending thoracic aorta  indicating a Stanford Type A aortic dissection.   Treatment & Follow Up: Mr. A was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to control his heart rate and blood pressure  then was taken to the operating room for surgery. The surgical procedure was successful and postoperatively; Mr. A was started on long-term antihypertensive medications. He is being monitored closely in follow-up appointments every month.  Summary: This case showcases the crucial importance of considering aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis for all patients presenting with acute chest pain  especially when the clinical history includes hypertension and a family history of cardiovascular diseases. Furthermore  measuring blood pressure in both arms can be a vital tool for initial clinical evaluation.

Case Presentation:  Patient: 70-Year-old African American male   Presenting Complaint: Sudden severe chest pain  described as tearing or ripping  radiated to his back  along with a feeling of faintness and shortness of breath.   Past Medical History: Notably  the patient has a history of uncontrolled high blood pressure (hypertension) over the past 10 years  despite prescribed medication. He was also diagnosed with Marfan Syndrome in his early 40's and has managed the condition with regular follow-ups. Additionally  he had a brief smoking history during his mid-30’s but quit smoking 30 years ago. He reports moderate alcohol use and an unremarkable drug history.   Current Medications: Lisinopril (for hypertension)  Aspirin (for cardiac prophylaxis)  Propranolol (for Marfan syndrome).  Family History: His father passed away from a heart attack and his mother was diagnosed with hypertension. Marfan syndrome is also found within his family line with his mother and younger sister reporting the same diagnosis.  Physical Examination: Pale and sweaty  appears acutely ill. Blood pressure reading is significantly different between both arms  with the right arm recording at 170/95  and the left at 145/90. Pulse is rapid and irregular. Diagnosis was confirmed through a CT scan showing an abnormal widening or ballooning of the aorta with an intimal flap.  Treatment: The patient was emergently managed with intravenous beta blockers to lower his heart rate and blood pressure. He was also started on pain management. Surgery was decided upon consultation with the cardiothoracic surgeon to repair the dissection.  Discussion: This patient's case is typical of aortic dissections  as the demographic most likely to have an aortic dissection are men in their sixties and seventies. Hypertension is a risk factor for developing this condition  and Marfan syndrome  a genetic disorder affecting connective tissues also increases the risk of aortic dissections. Early intervention and management of hypertension could have potentially mitigated the development of this dangerous complication.   Education and Support Measures: The patient was counseled on the importance of adhering to medication regimes and maintaining regular follow-ups. Lifestyle modifications  including diet  exercise  reducing alcohol  and quitting smoking  were duly emphasized. Genetic counseling was also considered for the immediate family members.   Emergency preparedness in case of potential further episodes to respond to symptoms promptly was also communicated to the patient and his family. Follow-up care plans  including continued medication  aortic imaging  lifestyle modification  and monitoring for complications  were set in place.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  aged 65 years  presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest and back pain that began while he was lifting a heavy object at home. He describes that the pain is significantly worse while lying down and feels slightly better when sitting up and leaning forward. Mr. Smith rates the pain as an ""11"" on the scale of ""10"". Checks revealed his heart rate at 100 bpm  blood pressure at 180/95 mmHg in the right arm  and 165/90 mmHg in the left arm. He had no fever and was slightly diaphoretic.  Demographics:   Mr. Smith is a light-skinned American of European descent  hailing from the Midwest region  with a lower-middle-class background.   Past Medical History:  He reports a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 10 years for which he takes Lisinopril and Amlodipine. He also has a 35-pack year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He is a retired industrial worker and reports chronic pain in his lower back and osteoarthritis with a history of right knee and hip replacement 2 years ago.  Family History:  There is a significant family history of heart disease; his father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at 72 and his younger sister is under treatment for heart failure. Mr. Smith reports no known genetic disorders in the family.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  there were bilateral carotid bruits and a grade III/VI systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right intercostal space. His pulses were mildly asymmetric with the left brachial and radial pulses being slightly weaker than the right. MRI ordered showed a dissection in the ascending aorta  thus diagnosing Mr. Smith with Stanford type A aortic dissection.   Discussion:  Mr. Smith's case of aortic dissection is likely related to his long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension  his previous smoking habit and family history of heart disease. A review of literature confirms that the most common symptom of aortic dissection is severe chest or back pain  with hypertension being the most common comorbidity  followed by smoking. Furthermore  men aged 60-70 and individuals with a family history of heart disease or genetic conditions influencing the vascular system  like Marfan syndrome  are at a higher risk.  Mr. Smith's treatment plan would involve immediate and aggressive control of his blood pressure  likely in the ICU  followed by prompt surgical intervention to repair the dissection which is the recommended treatment for Stanford type A aortic dissections.

Case Presentation  Patient Profile Mr. John Smith is a 64-year-old White-American man of Irish descent living in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a retired civil engineer  and he is known to have a 30-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications for years  with the argument that they make him feel uncomfortable. He has no history of diabetes  kidney disease  or cancer. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases; his father passed away at the age of 70 from a heart attack and his mother had a stroke at age 68. He smoked for about 20 years but quit 15 years ago and consumes alcohol socially.  Presenting Complaints Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that started while he was doing yard work. He described the pain as ""tearing"" that radiates to his back. Additionally  he reported feeling shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and temporary blurred vision at the onset of the pain.  Clinical Findings His vitals on presentation were as follows: BP- 200/110 mmHg  Pulse- 110/min  RR- 22/min  Temp- 37.1 C  Saturation- 95% on room air. Physical examination revealed evidence of acute aortic regurgitation (diastolic murmur over the left sternal border) and decreased peripheral pulses.  Investigations  His lab results showed normal cell count  kidney function  liver function  and electrolytes. EKG showed no sign of ischemia or any acute event. However  the CT angiogram of the chest was performed due to suspicion of aortic dissection  which confirmed the diagnosis  showing a Stanford Type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta.  Management Given the emergent nature of the disease  he was immediately prepared for surgery and was transferred to a tertiary referral center. He underwent successful emergent surgery for his aortic dissection. Post-surgery  he was put on beta-blockers  angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors  and statins  to control his blood pressure and hyperlipidemia.  Educational Points and Summary This case illustrates:  1. The potential fatal consequences of uncontrolled chronic conditions like hypertension and hyperlipidemia. 2. The importance of complaint with medication despite the side effects. 3. The significance of classic presentation—severe  tearing chest pain radiating to back in recognizing aortic dissection in patients presenting with chest pain.  4. This case similarly stresses the essence of early recognition of symptoms  prompt imaging diagnosis  and appropriate management of aortic dissection to prevent devastating complications like aortic rupture and cardiac arrest.

Patient Information:  Mr. Ramos is a 60-year-old male of Hispanic ethnicity. He is a retired firefighter and lives with his wife in the suburbs. He has been a non-smoker for the last 10 years. However  he used to smoke one pack a day for 30 years before quitting. He consumes alcohol occasionally and exercises regularly.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Ramos has been managing hypertension for the past ten years and has type 2 diabetes mellitus for about five years. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia. Ramirez has been on amlodipine and carvedilol for hypertension  metformin for diabetes  and statins for hyperlipidemia. His blood pressures  blood sugars  and cholesterol levels are well controlled.   Family History:  There's a pertinent family history as his father passed away in his late 60s following a heart attack  and his maternal uncle suffered from a stroke in his early 70s.   Presenting Issue:  Mr. Ramos presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back  beginning approximately 4 hours before arriving at the ED. The pain is described as 'tearing' and 'ripping' in nature  extremely severe  and unlike any pain experienced before. There was associated shortness of breath  but no associated nausea  vomiting  dizziness  or loss of consciousness.   Physical Examination & Diagnostic tests:  His blood pressure was 165/89 mmHg and 150/85 mmHg in the right and left arms  respectively. His heart rate was slightly elevated at 98 beats per minute  with no significant difference between radial and femoral pulses. A chest X-ray raised suspicions of an aortic aneurysm with mediastinal widening. A subsequent contrast CT scan confirmed an acute type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the level of the renal arteries. Troponin levels were normal  ruling out a concurrent myocardial infarction.  Impression & Plan:  Mr. Ramos was diagnosed with acute type A aortic dissection  likely due to long-standing hypertension and atherosclerotic disease. This is a surgical emergency  requiring an immediate consultation with a cardiothoracic surgeon for potential surgical intervention. Additionally  the management plan includes strict blood pressure control using IV labetalol and adequate pain control. His family was informed of the condition  and they consented for any necessary surgical intervention.   This case underscores the importance of a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection in patients with hypertension who present with acute severe chest pain. It is also a reminder of the role of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia as potential risk factors for aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. T  a 62-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to his back. He described the onset of the symptoms as sudden and intense. Concurrently  he reported shortness of breath and a feeling of impending doom. He has a history of hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril. He has a twenty-year history of smoking but quit smoking ten years ago. He reports being non-compliant with his medication regimen due to side effects.  Detailed Information:  Mr. T is a retired civil servant with Medicare insurance. He lives with his wife of 35 years. He is a father to three adult children  and two of them live out of state. He has three grandchildren. He is originally from the southeastern United States but resides in a large urban metropolis.  In regards to his social history  Mr. T has a twenty-year history of smoking cigarettes but quit ten years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.   His family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases - his father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 58  and his elder brother had a stroke at 65.  On physical examination  he appeared acutely distressed  with mild respiratory distress. Initial vitals were Blood Pressure- 180/100 mmHg  Pulse- 110/min  Respiratory rate- 20/min  and Oxygen Saturation- 96% on room air. On cardiovascular examination  a harsh systolic murmur was heard at the right upper sternal border. The auscultation of the lungs was clear with no adventitial sounds. His ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy  and the Chest X-ray showed a widened mediastinum.  Laboratory studies showed a normal complete blood count  renal function test  and liver function test. Cardiac Troponin I was within normal limits. The d-Dimer level was significantly elevated.  A contrast-enhanced CT angiography of the thorax was performed  which confirmed the diagnosis of a Type A Aortic Dissection.  Given the patient's condition and discomfort  the surgical team was urgently consulted for a surgical intervention.  Reflection on the Patient:  Mr. T's case falls into the demographic distribution for aortic dissections  which are most common in males aged 60-70 years with a history of hypertension. Noncompliance to antihypertensive medication regimen can cause severe complications. While he does not have connective tissue disorders or a family history of aortic diseases  which contribute to about 20% of cases  he does have a significant cardiovascular disease family history. This case also highlights the cardinal features of aortic dissection - sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the back  elevated blood pressure  and widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.   This case underlines the importance of recognizing the symptoms of an aortic dissection promptly to reduce the patient's morbidity and mortality rate. Even though it is often misdiagnosed due to its varied presentations  keeping a high index of suspicion in someone with a similar demographic presentation and severe sudden chest or back pain would be key to reduce associated high mortality rates.

Patient Information Patient Initials: J.D. Sex: Male Age: 58-years-old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Accountant Insurance: Private insurance  Living Situation: Lives with wife in suburban area  Presenting Problem & Symptoms J.D. presented at the Emergency Department with acute onset of severe chest pain. Describes pain as ""tearing"" and ""ripping"" that started suddenly about an hour ago.  Medical and Family History J.D. has an extensive medical history which includes untreated hypertension  type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and obesity (BMI of 30 kg/m2). He is a former smoker (quit 5 years ago) and continues to consume alcohol modestly. His daily medications include Metformin  Atorvastatin  and Lisinopril but admits he is not always compliant. Family history reveals his father had an aortic aneurysm and died at an early age (60). His mother has type 2 diabetes and is being treated for hypertension.  Clinical Findings On examination  J.D. appeared distressed  pale  and diaphoretic. Vital signs on presentation were: BP 220/120mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respiratory rate 20 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Cardiovascular examination showed irregular heartbeats and a loud diastolic murmur best heard over the right second intercostal space. CT angiogram was performed after initial suspicion of aortic dissection  which confirmed a Type A (ascending) aortic dissection.   Impression & Plan This patient is diagnosed with a Type A aortic dissection  which is an emergency. The uncontrolled hypertension likely contributed to the development of the aortic dissection. The condition is life-threatening and requires immediate surgical intervention. J.D. was immediately referred to a cardiothoracic surgeon and started on medication to reduce his blood pressure and heart rate. He will need extensive follow-up care  including regular monitoring of blood pressure and lifestyle modification  including dietary changes  physical activity  stress management  smoking cessation  and alcohol moderation.   Discussion Aortic dissection is a rare  but severe condition occurring most commonly in males in their 60s and 70s. Risk factors for aortic dissection include hypertension  smoking  dyslipidemia  pre-existing aortic aneurysm  family history  and specific genetic disorders. The most common symptom is severe  sudden onset chest pain. Early diagnosis  aggressive lowering of blood pressure and heart rate  and immediate surgical intervention significantly reduce mortality. Unfortunately  aortic dissection often presents late due to its rare occurrence and nonspecific clinical features  leading to delayed diagnosis: underlining the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion in patients with uncontrolled hypertension and severe  unusual chest pain.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old African American male  presenting to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe  tearing chest pain that radiated to his back.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of chronic hypertension  which has been proven to be the most important risk factor for aortic dissection. He also has a 15-year history of smoking  with a pack a day  which further contributes to the risk. In addition  the patient reports a history of high cholesterol  intermittent claudication  previous peripheral angioplasty in the right leg  and height of 6ft (1.83m) which  according to recent studies  can increase the risk of this condition. Despite his advanced age  the patient has no known history of diabetes or cardiovascular diseases.  Demographics:  In general  aortic dissection is more common in men; it often occurs in the sixth and seventh decades of life  according to the literature. This patient falls within this demographic range. African American individuals have a higher risk than other racial or ethnic groups  and this patient is of African American descent.  Family History:  The patient has a family history of aortic dissection; his father died suddenly at age 65 from an undissected aortic aneurysm. Studies have revealed that 20% of patients suffering from aortic dissection have a family history of this condition.  Current Presentation:  Upon arrival at the ER  the patient was diaphoretic and distressed. His blood pressure was notably higher in his right than in his left arm  and there was a delay in the femoral pulse compared to the radial pulse  both signs indicative of aortic dissection. The patient required immediate transfer to critical care for further management.  CBC  metabolic panel  coagulation profiles were all within normal limits  with the exception of elevated d-dimer. Immediate CT angiography revealed Stanford type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the proximal part of the abdominal aorta  confirmed the diagnosis.  Case Discussion:  The patient's history  presenting symptoms and the subsequent radiological findings were all consistent with an acute aortic dissection. Given the patient's advanced age  chronic hypertension  smoking history  family history  and his height  he falls into a high-risk group for aortic dissection. Considering the life-threatening nature of aortic dissection  immediate surgical intervention was warranted.   Conclusion:  This case illustrates the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients with a combination of risk factors and a classic clinical presentation of unexplained severe pain  differential blood pressure measurements  and a suspicious family history. Early diagnosis and management can significantly improve the prognosis in this otherwise deadly condition.

Patient Introduction  The patient is a 63-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  tobacco use  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. He is retired from a shipping and logistics company and lives with his wife. The patient presented with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back.  Medical History  The patient is overweight with a BMI of 32. He was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and currently takes a daily anti-hypertensive medication. He has been a smoker for 40 years and drinks alcohol occasionally but does not have any known drug allergies. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) about five years ago  with full recovery. His daily medications include an aspirin  a beta-blocker  and a statin.  Family History  The patient's father died in his early 50s due to a heart attack  and his maternal uncle had a stroke at the age of 60. His mother is alive and has hypertension and type 2 diabetes. The patient is unaware of any family history of aneurysms or connective tissue disorders. His elder brother has a history of cardiac arrhythmia.  Clinical Presentation  The patient arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden  excruciating chest pain which began an hour ago. The pain was described as tearing and radiates to his back. Considering his age  history of hypertension  smoking  and the described nature of his symptoms  a high-level suspicion for aortic dissection was established.   Diagnostic Evaluation  On physical examination  the patient appeared in significant distress but was alert and oriented. ECG demonstrated left ventricular hypertrophy. His blood pressure was notably different in both arms with the left arm recording a significantly higher reading. Laboratory tests showed a moderately raised D-dimer level. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of Stanford type A aortic dissection that started just above his heart and extended into his descending aorta.  Treatment Plan  The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to lower heart rate and blood pressure to reduce stress on the aorta. Subsequently  due to the nature and location of the dissection  he was referred for emergency surgery  which he successfully went through.  Conclusion  The patient's undiagnosed and controlled hypertension along with his extensive smoking history puts him at a high risk for aortic dissection. Early recognition of this potentially life-threatening condition and immediate treatment with antihypertensive therapy and surgical intervention dramatically improved the prognosis of this patient. The patient will subsequently be referred to a smoking cessation program and weight loss plan to reduce his cardiovascular risk further. This case reveals the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients with chest pain and risk factors  to prevent devastating complications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Martinez is a 68-year-old Hispanic male who presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of sudden and severe chest pain radiating to the back  described as tearing. His past medical history is significant for uncontrollable hypertension and he has a 25-year history of heavy smoking which he quit five years ago. One month ago  he had an episode of syncope with no clear diagnosis at another hospital and was advised to follow up with a cardiologist but could not do so due to lack of insurance.   On physical examination  the patient was pale  sweating  and in visible distress. His blood pressure was 210/110 mm Hg and pulse rate was fluctuating between 100-120 bpm  which is above the normal range indicative of tachycardia.  Laboratory findings revealed a WBC count of 12 000 cells/µL  mildly elevated troponin levels  and a D-dimer value exceeding 1000 ng/mL. An electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated left ventricular hypertrophy with strain but no overt signs of ischemia.  Chest computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the suspicion of aortic dissection  which showed an intimal flap extending from the ascending aorta to the iliac arteries consistent with Stanford type A aortic dissection.  Mr. Martinez's family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases. His father died at the age of 52 due to myocardial infarction and one of his two elder brothers had undiagnosed chest pain and died suddenly at 56. A younger sister is alive and has well-controlled hypertension.  Mr. Martinez’s case represents a common demographic for aortic dissection as literature shows it affects people chiefly in their 60s and 70s and more often in males. It is usually associated with hypertension and smoking. His lack of medical follow-up due to insurance issues also highlights a crucial societal problem that can lead to delayed or missed diagnosis  with potentially fatal consequences.  Management:  The emergency department clinicians promptly initiated antihypertensive therapy with intravenous beta-blockers and nitroprusside which led to the lowering of blood pressure to 120/80 mm Hg and control of heart rate. Mr. Martinez was emergently taken to the operating room for open repair of the dissected aorta in order to save his life.  This case underscores the importance of early recognition of aortic dissection in the ED  the role of vigilant monitoring and aggressive blood pressure control in the management  and timely surgical intervention. Mr. Martinez’s case also importantly highlights how healthcare access issues can play a critical role in patient outcomes.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Santiago  a 65-year-old Hispanic man  presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back. He describes the pain as sharp and tearing.  Past Medical History: Mr. Santiago has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and high cholesterol levels. He was a former smoker who quit 10 years ago  but he admits to being non-compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive medications. He is otherwise healthy with no history of surgeries. He is not diabetic nor does he have a history of any pulmonary diseases  liver diseases  or cancer.  Family History: His father experienced a similar complaint in his late 60s and passed away due to an aortic aneurysm - though it's unclear whether this was related to dissection or not. His mother and two sisters are healthy. His brother  however  suffers from hypertension and coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination and Findings: On examination  Mr. Santiago appears distressed due to the pain. He is found to be hypertensive with blood pressure reading of 180/110 mm Hg. There's no significant blood pressure difference in his upper limbs. His heart sounds are normal without any audible murmur. His distal pulses are palpable and equal bilaterally.  Investigation and Diagnosis: Given his symptoms and familial history of aortic aneurysm  a clinical suspicion made towards acute aortic dissection. Abdominal ultrasound and chest x-ray were inconclusive but then he underwent a CT angiogram of his aorta  which confirmed Type B aortic dissection.   Treatment: He was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to control his blood pressure. The vascular surgery team was consulted  who decided on an initial conservative management given that it’s a Type B dissection. They recommend monitoring his vitals and regular imaging. However  they also noted that if there’s any uncontrolled hypertension  worsening pain  or signs of malperfusion  immediate surgical intervention would be considered.  Discussion: This case highlights the importance of considering acute aortic dissection as a differential diagnosis in patients like Mr. Santiago presenting with unexplained chest pain especially when histories of hypertension and family related aortic illness are present. This condition often has high mortality if left untreated  but survival rates increase significantly with prompt diagnosis and appropriate management. Hence  the complication highlights that primary prevention through blood pressure control and promoting medication compliance is of utmost importance.   References: - Family history  an important risk factor for patients with type A aortic dissection. Tian L  Fan X  Zhu J  Liang Y  Li J  Yang Y. Heart Vessels. 2018 Jul;33(7):693-698. - Aortic Disease in the Hispanic Population. Teixeira PG  Woo K. Ann Vasc Surg. 2016 Apr;33:105-14.

Patient Presentation:  Demographics: Ms. Sarah Lee is a 68-year-old Asian female who is a retired elementary school teacher.  Past Medical History: She has a history of high blood pressure (hypertension) for the past 15 years for which she takes antihypertensive medication irregularly. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago; diabetes is managed with medication and diet. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia. She is a non-smoker  occasionally drinks alcohol  and has a BMI within the normal range.  Presenting Complaints: Ms. Lee was admitted to the ER with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to her back. She described the pain as ""tearing"".  Family History: Both her parents died at a young age due to cardiovascular complications. Her father passed away from a myocardial infarction at age 64 and her mother from a stroke at age 67. One of her two brothers was diagnosed with an aortic aneurysm at age 70.  Objective Findings: On admission  her blood pressure was high (195/110 mmHg)  with a difference between the two arms. The heart rate was slightly elevated (87 beats per minute)  and other vital signs were within normal limits. Examination revealed unequal pulses in the upper limbs. Chest auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur suggesting aortic regurgitation. The remainder of the physical examination was normal.   Investigations: The ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no signs of acute ischemia. An urgent CT angiogram detected a type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending to the descending aorta. Her blood tests showed high levels of D-dimer and slightly elevated cardiac troponin levels but were otherwise normal.  Diagnosis: Based on the patient's symptoms  physical findings  and imaging result  a diagnosis of aortic dissection was established.  Comments: This case presentation of an older Asian female with multiple risk factors features the acute onset of chest pain leading to the detection of a life-threatening aortic dissection. Her hypertension (possibly uncontrolled due to medication non-adherence)  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and family history of aortic aneurysm likely contributed to the development of aortic dissection.

Patient Profile: Mr. J  is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  a retired engineer residing with his wife in the suburbs. He is a non-smoker but drinks socially. Mr. J has been battling hypertension for the last ten years and has been on medication. There is no history of drug abuse. His father had a history of heart disease and passed away from a heart attack at the age of 60.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. J visited the ER  complaining of a sudden onset of severe chest pain  described as sharp and 'tearing' in nature  radiating to his back for the last three hours. He admitted to feeling light-headed but denied any loss of consciousness. No associated symptoms like breathlessness  palpitations  or sweating were seen. He denied any recent trauma  strenuous activity  or heavy lifting.  Clinical Examination: Physical examination showed high blood pressure (170/95 mmHg)  an irregular heartbeat  and a murmur over the chest. The rest of his physical examination was non-contributory.  Investigations: To confirm the suspicion of an aortic dissection  a Computerized Tomography Angiogram (CTA) was conducted. The CTA indicated an aortic dissection starting just after the aortic valve and extending into the descending aorta - classified as Stanford type A.  Management: Given the acute onset and confirmation of Stanford Type A aortic dissection  Mr. J was treated as a medical emergency. He was immediately started on medications to reduce his blood pressure and slow his heart rate. Urgent surgery was considered per guidelines and the cardiac surgical team was consulted.  Follow-up: Following surgery  a plan for the aggressive management of his hypertension  regular cardiac follow-ups including imaging studies  counselling on maintaining a heart-healthy lifestyle  and the need for early presentation if similar symptoms reoccur were enforced.  This case reflects that sudden  severe chest pain  particularly in patients with a history of hypertension and a family history of heart disease  necessitates consideration of aortic dissection among the differential diagnoses. Timely diagnosis can be lifesaving in such patients.   References:  La dissection aortique. Diagnostic et prise en charge. (2012). Journal de Radiologie Diagnostique et Interventionnelle  93(7-8)  545–557. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jradio.2011.09.022 Shrestha  M.  & Fleischman  D. (2017). Management of acute type A dissection. Annals of Cardiothoracic Surgery  6(4)  395–399. https://doi.org/10.21037/acs.2017.06.04

Patient Profile  Mr. J.A. is a 64-year-old retired African American male  living in the urban area of Chicago  Illinois. He was a former mechanical engineer and has been living alone since his wife passed away three years ago. He is a non-smoker and reports minimal alcohol intake. His children live in different states but check on him regularly through phone calls and occasional visits.   Presenting Problem and Symptoms  Mr. J.A. presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  sharp  and tearing chest pain that radiates to his back and was accompanied by shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and episodes of syncope. The chest pain started suddenly while he was carrying groceries from his car to his apartment.  Medical History   He has history of hypertension for which he takes oral medications. His blood pressure at home usually ranges from 140-150/80-90 mmHg. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and diabetes Which are currently under control with oral medication. Mr. J.A does not have a documented history of cardiac or thoracic conditions  but he has been non-compliant with his medication over the past month due to financial constraints.  Family History  There is a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases on his mother’s side. His mother died at the age of 70 due to myocardial infarction  and his elder brother was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm that was managed surgically. No other significant family health issues were reported.  Clinical Findings and Diagnosis  The initial EKG displayed non-specific ST and T wave changes. Blood tests  including troponin levels and D-dimer assay  were conducted. The D-dimer levels were significantly elevated. Further imaging studies  including a CT angiogram of the thorax  confirmed the diagnosis of ascending aortic dissection (Stanford Type A).  Management Plan  Due to the severity and type of aortic dissection  Mr. J.A. was promptly scheduled for emergency surgical repair. His hypertension was managed aggressively to keep his blood pressure at a stable level before the surgery. His case was discussed with a multidisciplinary team  and he will require continuous monitoring and follow-up appointments to manage his chronic conditions and prevent potential complications.  Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of prompt diagnosis and management of aortic dissection  a life-threatening cardiovascular emergency. It also highlights the challenge of managing chronic diseases amid financial constraints  prompting the necessity for more viable healthcare solutions.

Patient Presentation  Name: John Doe Age: 66 years Race: Caucasian Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer  Clinical History: Mr. Doe is a 66 year old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that was described as sharp and ""tearing"" in nature  radiating to his back. The pain started while he was lifting a heavy object at his home. He also reported feelings of nausea and shortness of breath. He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and was a smoker for over 30 years  although he quit five years ago.   Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Doe appeared anxious and in pain. His blood pressure was elevated at 172/98 mmHg and heart rate was rapid at 105 bpm. He had dissimilar pulses and blood pressures in extremities. Auscultation of the chest revealed a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic insufficiency.  Diagnostic Assessment: An EKG showed non-specific ST segment changes. Urgent CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta (Type A) which is an emergency situation.  Family History: Mr. Doe's older brother  aged 70 years  had a myocardial infarction two years ago  and his father had passed away from a stroke at the age of 75 years. There is no known family history of connective tissue disorders.  Course of Treatment: Mr. Doe was immediately started on IV beta-blockers to lower his blood pressure and to control his heart rate. After multidisciplinary discussion  he was rushed to the operating theatre for definitive surgical repair under cardiopulmonary bypass  given that his dissection involved the ascending aorta and the functional impairment of his aortic valve suggested by a diastolic murmur.  Prognostic Outlook: Type A aortic dissection is a medical emergency with a high mortality rate  particularly if left untreated. With the surgery and close post-operative care  the immediate prognosis can be considerably improved. It's expected that Mr. Doe will follow a prescribed regimen of anti-hypertensives and lipid-lowering agent along with lifestyle modifications including low salt  low cholesterol diet and encouragement to maintain regular physical activity. Regular echocardiography follow-up at six  twelve months  and annually thereafter to monitor for aneurysm development and other complications is advised.   Patient Teaching: Mr. Doe and his family were educated on the seriousness of his condition and the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle modifications and regular echocardiogram follow ups to prevent recurrence and complications. They were also advised on signs of possible recurrence like sudden severe chest or back pain and to immediately seek medical attention.    Ethical Consideration: Privacy and confidentiality of the patient was maintained throughout the process. Mr. Doe gave informed consent for all procedures and was included in decision-making processes. Family members were also actively involved  as per Mr. Doe's wishes.
