Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old African American male  Mr. Johnson  who presented with sudden severe chest pain that started 2 hours before coming to the hospital. The pain was described as a tearing sensation that radiated to the back.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Johnson has a history of uncontrolled hypertension along with type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is also a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago but with a cumulative 25-pack year smoking history. Mr. Johnson was also obese  with a BMI of 31.1. Additionally  the patient has a history of chronic kidney disease  stage 3.  Presenting Symptoms:  Along with the chest pain  he also complained of nausea  shortness of breath  and faintness. Upon examination  Mr. Johnson was noted to be in distress  his blood pressures in his arms were different (right arm 160/95  left arm 150/80)  and his pulse rate was 78 beats per minute.   Family History:  Mr. Johnson’s father died of a heart condition when he was in his early 70s  but specifics were not known. His mother died at 88 of natural causes. He has no siblings or children.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A chest radiograph was immediately performed  revealing widened mediastinum. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) was done that confirmed the presence of an ascending aortic dissection. Evidence of a dissection flap starting just above the aortic valve extending up to the beginning of the left subclavian artery was noted.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on IV beta-blockers for hypertension. He was emergently taken to the operating room for surgical repair involving a Bentall procedure and was subsequently moved to the ICU post-operation.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition  often presenting with severe chest pain. Risk factors include hypertension  smoking  and certain genetic conditions. It is known to be most common in males between the ages of 60 and 80  with a study noting higher rates of incidence in African American populations. Different blood pressures in arms and widened mediastinum on imaging can be red flags for diagnosing aortic dissection. Aggressive control of blood pressure and surgical management for ascending aortic dissection remains the mainstay of treatment.  References:  This case represents a typical presentation of aortic dissection. A 2010 study in Circulation showed that African Americans have the highest hospitalization rate due to aortic dissection. Further  the International Registry of Acute Aortic Dissection (IRAD) identifies hypertension  smoking  and a history of cardiac disease as significant risk factors  which our patient has.

Patient Case Presentation:   Patient: Mr. Thompson  Demographics:  Age: 67 years old  Gender: Male  Race: African American  Occupation: Retired Policeman  Residency: Boston  Massachusetts.  Presenting Complaint:   Mr. Thompson presented to the emergency room with severe chest pain radiating to the back  accompanied by nausea and profuse sweating. The pain was sudden in onset  began while he was having his morning coffee  has lasted for more than 2 hours  and hasn't relieved despite taking his as-needed medication for heart-related chest pain.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson has carried a diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for ten years. Other medical conditions include type 2 diabetes mellitus and tobacco use. He is on regular medication for his chronic conditions  including Lisinopril  Metformin  and a statin. He has a history of non-compliance with his medication regimen and an erratic follow-up with a primary care doctor over the years. A history of mild heart attack was noted five years ago.  Family History:  Family history reveals Mr. Thompson's father passed away due to myocardial infarction in his sixties. His elder brother has a history of hypertension and aortic aneurysm.  Physical Examination:  On arrival  Mr. Thompson was in obvious distress but conscious and oriented. He had a blood pressure of 190/100 mm Hg  a pulse of 108 bpm  respiratory rate: 22 per minute; temperature: 98.6 F. Cardiac examination revealed a harsh systolic murmur suggestive of possible aortic regurgitation.  Investigations:  An EKG showed non-specific ST-T wave changes but no clear signs of ischemia or infarction. According to the clinical symptoms and family history  a CT angiogram was ordered and revealed an aortic dissection beginning just after the aortic arch and extending into the descending aorta.  Treatment and Progress:  Mr. Thompson was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers and nitroprusside to lower his blood pressure and heart rate and was urgently transferred to cardiothoracic surgery for consideration of repair. His postoperative course was uneventful  and he was discharged from the hospital on the 8th postoperative day.  Discussion:  The case highlights the importance of thorough investigation in patients presenting with chest pain  particularly when features do not match the typical presentation for more common conditions such as myocardial infarction. The Importance of risk factor control  notably hypertension  cannot be overemphasized. Furthermore  the role of family history in predicting cardiovascular disease is also underscored.  References:   According to the literature  male predominance and advanced age are common in aortic dissection. HTN is the most prevalent risk factor  and African American ethnicity tends to represent a higher risk for the disease (Clouse et al.  2004).  Reference:  Clouse  W. D.  Hallett  J. W.  Schaff  H. V.  Gayari  M. M.  Ilstrup  D. M.  & Melton  L. J. (2004). Improving long-term survival after dissecting aortic aneurysm. The Journal of the American Medical Association  290(11)  1461-1468.

Patient Presentation:  Demographic Information: Mr. OP is a 60-years-old African American male residing in an urban part of Western United States. He is married  has two children  a retired army veteran  with a previous history of smoking. He served the military for 25 years but has been largely sedentary since then.   Past Medical History: The patient has a significant past medical history  with hyperlipidemia and high blood pressure  for which he has been on treatment for approximately twelve years. He took his medications irregularly and presented a poor medication compliance history. He quit smoking post-retirement (~10 years)  but he has a 20 pack-year smoking history from earlier years. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use.  Family History: His family history is significant. His father had a myocardial infarction at 68 and later suffered from a stroke. The patient's mother is alive and suffers from hypertension and diabetes. His sister was recently diagnosed with breast cancer.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. OP comes to the Emergency Department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to his back  which he rates as 10/10 in severity. He noticed the sudden onset of pain after lifting some heavy boxes in his garage  described as a sharp  tearing pain.  Investigation Results: Upon assessment  his blood pressure is found to be elevated (180/110 mmHg). His ECG shows non-specific ST and T wave changes  but no clear signs of myocardial infarction. His chest radiograph shows a widened mediastinum. Laboratory results reveal a slight increase in his total cholesterol and LDL levels. Most revealing  a CT angiogram confirms an ascending aortic dissection.  Management: Given his diagnosis of aortic dissection  Mr. Op is immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to lower his blood pressure and decrease contractility of the heart. This is later followed by surgery (open surgical repair) to repair his aorta.  Summary: This patient presents a complex interplay of factors contributing to his aortic dissection: his age  race  gender  past history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and upper body exertion. His family history of heart disease only increased this risk. His case underscores the importance of proactive disease management and lifestyle changes.   Reference:  Howard  D. P.  et al. (2013). Population-Based Study of Incidence and Outcome of Acute Aortic Dissection and Premorbid Risk Factor Control: 10-Year Results From the Oxford Vascular Study. Circulation  127(20)  2031–2037.

Patient Case Presentation:  Identifying Details: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male. He is retired  married  and lives with his wife in a suburban area. He is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the hospital with acute and severe chest pain that started suddenly.  History of Present Illness: The chest pain began while the patient was performing his usual morning exercise. It was described as ""tearing"" and ""ripping "" and radiated to his back. The pain was not associated with shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. Besides  no changes in consciousness or hemiparesis were reported.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and has been managing it with medication (Lisinopril and Amlodipine) since then. He had been also diagnosed with mild hypercholesterolemia but is not on any lipid-lowering medications at present as his levels are under control via diet modification. He does not have any history of diabetes mellitus. The patient also revealed a history of Marfan syndrome.  Family History: Both of his parents died at an older age from non-cardiovascular causes. However  his older brother died suddenly at the age of 60  which was later determined to be the result of a dissecting aortic aneurysm.   Physical Examination: On physical examination  his blood pressure was found to be 165/95 mm Hg and his pulse was 90 beats per minute. Auscultation of the chest revealed a diastolic murmur consistent with aortic insufficiency. No other abnormalities were reported.  Differential Diagnosis: Acute aortic dissection  Acute coronary syndrome  Pulmonary embolism.  Hospital Course: The patient underwent a computed tomography angiography (CTA) that confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection Stanford type A. He was quickly transferred to the cardiovascular surgical unit where he underwent emergency surgery to repair the dissected aorta. The patient showed a good immediate post-operative recovery and was transferred to the ICU for monitoring. With a gradual recovery  he was discharged to home after a two week stay in the hospital with a strict follow-up plan.  In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of prompt diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention in aortic dissection to mitigate life-threatening complications. Furthermore  controlling hypertension and regular follow-ups are crucial in patients with a medical and family history of aortic pathology. This case also emphasizes the relevance of genetic counseling and prophylactic aortic imaging in patients with Marfan syndrome and first-degree relatives due to the genetic predisposition for aortic dissection.   Reference: Aggarwal S  Qamar A  Sharma V  Sharma A. Aortic dissection: A literature review. Mo Med. 2013 Jan-Feb; 110(1): 69–75.

Case Presentation:  Mr. Joseph Brown  a 66-year-old African American male living in an urban neighborhood  presented with a sudden severe sharp pain in his upper back and chest while at rest  described as “tearing” in nature. This pain was accompanied by diaphoresis  dyspnea  and nausea. His past medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years  hyperlipidemia  and former smoking history of 30-pack years  which ceased 10 years ago. His medication list includes Atorvastatin 40mg once a day and Lisinopril 20mg once a day. He denies any regular exercise or healthy diet and admits he does have a problem with compliance with antihypertensive medications due to the associated side effects.  Mr. Brown has no known allergies. His family history is significant for cardiac diseases  with his father having suffered from coronary artery disease and having undergone coronary artery bypass grafting. His mother died from a stroke at the age of 70. He has 2 siblings  both with histories of hypertension. He has a son and a daughter  both in their 30s with no significant health problems reported.  On physical examination  his blood pressure was found to be markedly different in right (156/94mm Hg) and left (130/85mm Hg) upper extremities. Cardiopulmonary examination revealed a regular heart rate without murmurs  normal vesicular breath sounds with no added sounds in the lungs. His abdomen was soft and non-tender  and all peripheral pulses were palpable. Neurological examination was unremarkable. Pulse oximetry showed saturations of 95% in room air.  Considering the acute-onset sharp chest pain with unequal blood pressures  the clinical suspicion of aortic dissection was high. The required diagnostic modality  CT angiography  was done immediately confirming the diagnosis of type B aortic dissection. He was immediately provided with IV beta-blockers  aiming to reduce the heart rate to 60bpm  and pain management strategies. A multidisciplinary 'heart team' decision was made to manage him medically and he was shifted to a high dependency unit for close monitoring.  In conclusion  this case underscores the potential life-threatening nature of aortic dissection and the need for urgent diagnosis and appropriate immediate treatment. It also emphasizes the importance of hypertensive control as a preventive strategy for aortic dissection.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male. He is married  has two children  and worked in construction before he retired. The patient has a past history of uncontrolled hypertension and had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. His father died from a stroke at the age of 70  and his mother had hypertension. He reports no known allergies. The patient has a history of cigarette smoking of 30 pack-years but quit 5 years ago after his myocardial infarction. He does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back. He described the pain as a tearing sensation. He also reported shortness of breath  mild confusion  and weakness in his lower limbs.  Clinical Examination and Findings: On examination  he was hypertensive (blood pressure 180/120 mmHg) and tachycardic (heart rate 110 beats per minute). His oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Cardiac examination showed no murmurs  rubs or gallops. There was mild asymmetry in the pulse volume between his upper limbs  but pulses in the lower limbs were symmetrical. Neurological examination showed no signs of stroke. There was no abdominal tenderness or peripheral edema.  Investigations: The initial EKG showed no acute ischemic changes or arrhythmia. Lab findings indicated elevated D-dimer  mildly elevated troponin  and slightly decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit. Chest X-ray revealed mediastinal widening. Contrast-enhanced CT confirmed the diagnosis of Type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the renal arteries.  Management and Evolution: The patient was stabilized with aggressive antihypertensive therapy  including IV nitroprusside and labetalol  to maintain systolic blood pressure below 120 mmHg. He was transferred to a tertiary hospital for emergency surgical repair of the dissection. His postoperative course was uneventful  and he was discharged on postoperative day 10 with close follow-up arranged with a cardiologist and cardiac surgeon. He was advised to continue antihypertensive medications and encouraged to attend cardiac rehabilitation.  Final Comments: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening emergency that often presents with severe chest pain. It is common in older adults  particularly males  with hypertension being a significant risk factor. Early recognition and aggressive management are necessary to prevent serious complications like rupture and death.

Patient Presentation:  The subject is a 60-year-old Asian male patient who presented himself to the Emergency Department with complaints of severe  acute onset chest and back pain which commenced approximately two hours before his arrival. The pain was described as sharp  tearing and radiating from his chest to his back. His medical history reveals that he is a chronic smoker with a 40-pack year smoking history and is also diagnosed with hypertension  poorly controlled  for which he is on medication.  Demographics:  The patient is married  has two children  and works as an engineer. He belongs to a middle socioeconomic class and has health insurance coverage.  Medical History:  He has a history of poorly controlled hypertension for the last ten years  for which he is on an ACE inhibitor and a diuretic. Despite medication  his blood pressure levels remain high  possibly due to poor medication adherence and lifestyle factors including high-stress levels and continued smoking.  There was no history of diabetes  dyslipidemia  or renal disease. The patient also has a long history of tobacco use  with no signs of cessation. No history of drug abuse or alcoholism.  Family History:  Patient's family history is significant with his father having passed away from a stroke and his mother suffering from hypertension. He has one older sibling who has coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination and Investigations:  The patient was anxious and appeared acutely ill. He had asymmetric blood pressure readings  higher in the right arm. The carotid  radial and femoral pulses were lower on the left side. A chest X-ray showed a widened mediastinum. A bedside transthoracic echocardiogram raised suspicion for aortic dissection  and a subsequent CT angiogram confirmed a type A aortic dissection.  Management:  The patient was started on intravenous beta-blockers to control his blood pressure and heart rate. Given the diagnosis of type A aortic dissection  surgical intervention was deemed necessary. The patient gave consent  following which  he underwent emergent ascending aortic replacement surgery. Examination of the aortic tissue confirmed the diagnosis.  The patient's postoperative recovery was gradual but uneventful  with gradual improvement of his overall condition. He was discharged with advice on strict blood pressure control  smoking cessation  regular follow-ups  and lifestyle modifications.  This case highlights the importance of considering aortic dissection as a differential in patients presenting with acute chest or back pain  especially in those with poor blood pressure control and a significant smoking history. Timely diagnosis and intervention are key to improving patient outcomes in such potentially catastrophic conditions. A multidisciplinary approach involving primary care  cardiology  radiology  and cardiothoracic surgery teams is essential to ensuring the best possible patient care.

Patient Details: Mr. J  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  an ex-smoker with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension presented in the emergency department complaining of a sudden and severe chest pain radiating in the back.  Medical History: Mr. J  works as a warehouse operator. He has a known medical history of hypertension for the last ten years but has been inconsistent with his medication  with no other significant health issues. He neither drinks alcohol nor consumes any illicit substances. He has a history of smoking 1 pack per day for 25 years but quit ten years ago.  Family History: There's a significant family history of cardiovascular disease. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. His elder brother (72 years old) was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm two years ago.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. J noticed the pain after lifting a heavy box at work. The pain was sudden  sharp  and severe  described as tearing or ripping. He initially thought he had a muscle strain. However  the pain started intensifying and was different from any pain he had felt before  causing him to seek immediate medical attention.  Examination: Upon examination  the patient was anxious  his blood pressure was recorded to be higher on the right arm than the left arm. He had a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg in the right arm and 160/90 mmHg in the left arm.  Diagnostic Results: A contrast CT scan of the chest  abdomen  and pelvis showed Stanford type A aortic dissection extending from the aortic root to the iliac arteries. Transthoracic echocardiogram also confirmed aortic dissection. There were no signs of occlusive malperfusion syndrome  or branch vessel occlusion. The laboratory parameters were all within normal limits  except raised d-dimer.  Management: Mr. J was promptly started on intravenous labetalol to control the blood pressure  aiming for a systolic pressure of 100-120 mmHg. Emergency cardiovascular surgery consultation was made  considering the diagnosis of Stanford type A aortic dissection is a surgical emergency. He successfully underwent repair with supracoronary aortic replacement.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is a potentially fatal condition and must be detected and treated promptly. Adequately controlled hypertension is paramount  and patients must be educated about the importance of regular control of blood pressure. This case highlights the need for immediate imaging in patients presenting with a history of hypertension and sudden severe chest or back pain.

Case Presentation:  Demographic Information:  The subject is a 65-year-old African American male named Mr. Johnson. He is a retired bus driver and currently resides with his wife in the suburbs of Atlanta  GA. He has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He has been a non-smoker throughout his life and does consume alcohol moderately.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson's health record indicates a history of poorly controlled hypertension  consistent over the last 10 years. He also has Type 2 diabetes and has been on oral hypoglycemic medication for the last 8 years. Other than these conditions  Mr. Johnson has not faced any major health issues. Lately  he has been reporting occasional bouts of indigestion.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases with both his father and paternal uncle dying from myocardial infarctions in their early 60s. His mother suffered from hypertension and died at 75 due to stroke. His older brother is also hypertensive and recently underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery.  Present Illness:  Mr. Johnson presented to the Emergency Department with a sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as 'tearing'  began at rest and has progressively worsened over the last 2 hours.  Clinical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure on the right arm was 190/110mmHg and 170/100mmHg on the left arm. He looked generally unwell. Cardiorespiratory examination revealed no abnormalities but there was a disparity between the pulses in the two arms.  Investigations:  A chest radiograph showed an enlarged mediastinum. High D-Dimer values were also present. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed an aortic dissection  revealing a large intimal flap separating the lumen of the aorta. There were no signs of aortic rupture.  Diagnosis:  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with Stanford type A aortic dissection.  Treatment:  As per standard care  Mr. Johnson was urgently managed with blood pressure lowering medications and pain management. In line with the severity of the condition and the presence of risk factors  he was immediately referred for surgery – aortic root replacement or ascending aortic replacement.   Follow-up and Prognosis:  Mr. Johnson is currently recovering postoperatively in the Intensive Care Unit. He has a long-term prognosis dependent on his recovery from surgery and ability to control hypertension. His poorly controlled hypertension is of concern and will be actively managed with medications and lifestyle modifications.  Concluding Remarks:  Mr. Johnson's case highlights the critical importance of recognizing acute aortic dissection promptly  given its high mortality rate. It also underscores the need for hypertension control to prevent such life-threatening complications.

Patient Case Presentation – Aortic Dissection  Patient Profile: Mr. X is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who currently resides in Houston  Texas. He's been working as an accountant for twenty years  living a relatively sedentary lifestyle. He has a history of smoking for the past 35 years and occasional alcohol use. He has a known history of chronic high blood pressure (hypertension) for the past ten years but has been irregular with his medication  claiming to control his BP through diet and exercise. He has no history of illicit drug use.  Family History: Mr. X’s father passed away at the age of 77 from myocardial infarction  and his mother  currently 85 years old  suffers from type 2 diabetes and hypertension. His older brother  aged 67  underwent treatment for an aortic aneurysm three years ago.  Clinical Presentation: Mr. X presented in the emergency department with severe  stabbing pain in his chest radiating to his back. The pain was sudden in onset and developed while he was at work. He also reported feeling lightheaded with some difficulty in breathing. His blood pressure was noted to be high (180/95 mmHg)  and his heart rate was irregular.   Diagnostic Findings: An urgent EKG showed no signs of myocardial infarction. However  a CT scan of the chest revealed an aortic dissection type A  involving the ascending aorta. Laboratory results including complete blood count  renal function  and electrolytes were within normal limits apart from slightly elevated troponin levels.  Management: Mr. X was promptly started on intravenous antihypertensive therapy. He was efficiently stabilized and taken for an emergency surgical repair of the dissected aorta. His post-operative recovery was uneventful  and he was adequately counselled about the importance of regular medication  lifestyle modifications  and strict blood pressure control.  Upon discharge  he was referred to a cardiologist for follow-up and a dietician to assist in dietary treatments to help control his hypertension.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing aortic dissection's clinical symptoms and the crucial role of immediate diagnostic intervention and management. High-risk patients need regular follow-ups and should be educated about aortic dissection's potential complications. Early diagnosis and treatment can significantly decrease morbidity and mortality associated with this life-threatening condition.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 69-year-old African American male who experienced sudden-onset  severe chest pain radiating to the back while gardening. The pain was described as 'tearing' and was associated with sweating and shortness of breath.  Demographics & Family History:  African Americans have a higher incidence of hypertension  which is a major risk factor for aortic dissection. The prevalence is particularly high in males over age 60  which fits the patient's profile. The patient is retired  a widower with 2 adult children  and lives in an urban environment. He has no family history of cardiovascular disease.  Past Medical History:  The patient is a former smoker (he quit 15 years ago upon his physician's advice)  occasional alcohol user  and is known to have uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years  treated irregularly with Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ). His last recorded blood pressure was four months ago at a routine check-up  with a reading of 165/95 mmHg. He has no history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  kidney disease  or any other chronic diseases.  Emergency Department (ED) Findings:  Upon arrival  the patient looked pale  dyspneic  and was in obvious distress. Vital signs were temperature 36.9°C  blood pressure 190/110 mmHg in the right arm  pulse 105/min  and respiratory rate 24/min. Electrocardiogram revealed left ventricular hypertrophy but no acute ischemic changes. Chest X-ray showed widened mediastinum. Labs revealed slightly elevated cardiac enzymes.  An emergency computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of ascending aortic dissection  Stanford type A  extending from the aortic root to the proximal part of the left subclavian artery. The main coronary arteries were not involved. The patient was promptly taken to the operating room for surgical intervention.  The patient illustrates the importance of recognizing the signs of aortic dissection  especially in high-risk populations such as older  hypertensive African American males. This case also underscores the importance of addressing modifiable risk factors like hypertension and smoking in a timely and consistent manner.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Eduardo Sanchez  a 67-year-old Hispanic male living in the urban area of Los Angeles  was diagnosed with a type A aortic dissection. He presented initially with sudden chest pain radiating to his back  along with mild symptoms of nausea and dizziness.   Demographics:  Mr. Sanchez was a retired construction worker. He is married with four grown children. His ethnicity is particularly relevant due to the higher prevalence of cardiovascular disease in the Hispanic community  influenced by both genetic factors and lifestyle choices  such as rich traditional food and resistance to engagement in regular physical activities.  Previous Medical History:  Mr. Sanchez has been hypertensive for the past twelve years  for which he was prescribed medications  but his control has been suboptimal. He was also diagnosed with type II diabetes and hyperlipidemia five years ago. Mr. Sanchez is an ex-smoker and quit smoking ten years ago after a mild stroke. He drinks occasionally but has no history of substance abuse. Records showed that Mr. Sanchez had undergone a hernia repair operation 15 years ago  but no other surgical history was noted.   Family History:  His father died at 54 from an unspecified heart disease  and his mother passed away at 77 from stroke complications. His elder brother  who is 71  was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm two years ago. The prominent family history of cardiovascular diseases raises Mr. Sanchez's risk for aortic dissection  especially in conjunction with his own history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes.  Investigations:  His blood pressure on presentation was elevated to 185/100 mmHg. His pulse rate was regular with a rate of 100 beats/minute. The results show high blood sugar levels and an elevated creatinine. A D-dimer test was positive. The chest x-ray showed a widened mediastinum. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) revealed a type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the ascending aorta.  Diagnosis and Management:  Based on the clinical presentation  investigative reports  and family history  a diagnosis of a type A aortic dissection was made. Given the emergent nature of the disease  this patient required urgent surgical intervention. A multidisciplinary clinical team was formed swiftly  including a cardiologist  a cardiothoracic surgeon  and an anesthesiologist to manage this life-threatening event. The patient was started on intravenous labetalol for tight blood pressure control preoperatively. He was counseled regarding the situation and the need for immediate surgery  to which he willingly consented.

Patient Case Presentation: Aortic Dissection  Patient Profile: The patient is Mr. W  a 65-year-old African American male  retired from his job as a security guard. He lives with his wife of 40 years in the urban city of Chicago  Illinois.   Presenting Condition: Mr. W presented at the emergency department with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as 'tearing' in nature and of sudden onset while at home. He also reported mild dyspnea but no other symptoms. He has been feeling well prior to this event and was engaged in his daily activities.  Past Medical History: Mr. W has a history of hypertension  controlled with amlodipine  and hyperlipidemia  controlled with atorvastatin. He was a smoker for 30 years  but quit 10 years ago. He has a moderate alcohol intake  consuming beer once or twice a week. He has no known drug allergies. His immunizations are updated.  Family History: His father died at 70 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  and his mother passed away from breast cancer at 72. He has two brothers  one with hypertension and one with type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is no family history of strokes or migraines.  Initial Diagnosis: Heavy suspicion for aortic dissection was determined from Mr. W's clinical presentation and history. An immediate CT Aortogram confirmed Type B aortic dissection starting just distal to the left subclavian artery and extending down to the level of his kidneys.  Treatment Plan: With respect to Mr. W's suitable risk factors for surgical treatment  he was promptly transferred to the surgical unit for an endovascular repair procedure. In addition  his hypertension will be managed with beta-blockers.   This case of Mr. W demonstrates an instance of aortic dissection  often under-diagnosed due to its nature of mimicking other health conditions. Risk factors such as hypertension  age  male gender  and a history of smoking were present in this patient. It's critical to have a high degree of suspicion for aortic dissection when the 'classic' symptoms present  such as in Mr. W’s case.  Note: This presentation is a fictitious case created based on average demographic and medical facts from related published literature. No actual patient of this case representation exists.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jackson is a 65-year-old African American male who came into the emergency department with severe  central chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as 'tearing' and started suddenly. His blood pressure was 170/90 mmHg in the right arm and 155/85 mmHg in the left  signifying a significant difference greater than 20 mmHg that raised suspicion for an aortic dissection.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jackson has a medical history of chronic hypertension (which he was diagnosed with ten years prior) and moderate hyperlipidemia; both conditions are managed with medication. The patient also occasionally smokes cigarettes but rarely drinks alcohol. His medical history also includes type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he's been using metformin for the past 5 years.  Family History:  His father died from stroke at the age of 73  and his mother is alive and well at 93. Mr. Jackson's family history reveals no known genetic disorders  but his older brother  aged 74  had an aortic aneurysm which was surgically repaired five years ago.  Review of Systems:  As per the review of systems  Mr. Jackson has been experiencing some shortness of breath over the past few weeks  but he did not seek medical attention assuming it was due to his age. He denied any abdominal pain  palpitations  sweating  nausea  or vomiting.  Physical Exam:  On cardiovascular examination  he presented normal heart sounds  but the exam was notable for a diastolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space. No abdominal bruit was heard. His extremities showed no signs of peripheral vascular disease.  Investigations:  An urgent CT angiography showed an acute Stanford type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending into the aortic arch. His hematological and biochemical markers including total counts  differential counts  renal parameters  liver function tests  and coagulation profile were within normal limits except for elevated HbA1c suggesting imperfect glycemic control over the past few months. An EKG showed a normal sinus rhythm without any acute ischemic changes.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection is often prevalent in males and those above 60 years of age. Risk factors associated include hypertension  smoking  and atherosclerosis. The disease also shows a greater predilection in African American individuals  highlighting the need for prompt identification and management in these high-risk groups. Mr. Jackson's ethnicity  age  hypertension  and a family history of aortic aneurysm puts him in the high-risk group for aortic dissection.  Mr. Jackson was started on intravenous beta-blockers on admission to control his high blood pressure  which along with his pain  is a significant risk factor for aortic dissections. Emergency surgical referral was arranged  considering his Stanford type A classification which typically requires surgical intervention. His diabetes was also discussed  aiming to optimize his HbA1c levels.  His case emphasizes the importance of considering aortic dissection in the differential diagnosis for patients with severe chest or back pain  especially when associated with differences in upper extremity blood pressures. The case also highlights the needs for rigorous and regular control of chronic conditions like hypertension and diabetes as a part of a comprehensive disease management strategy to avoid such emergent situations.

Patient Presentation  Name: Mr. John Doe  Age: 62 years old  Sex: Male   Nationality: African-American  Occupation: Retired auto mechanic  The patient presented in the emergency room complaining of sudden  intense chest pain radiating to his back  akin to a sensation of ""tearing."" The patient reported an onset of pain whilst lifting heavy objects around his garage.  The patient's medical history includes hypertension for which he has been taking beta-blockers for the last 15 years. He is also diagnosed with atherosclerosis for which he is supposed to be on a regimen of aspirin and cholesterol-lowering drugs but admits non-adherence to his medication routine.   There is no significant history of congenital heart defects or inflammatory conditions such as vasculitis within his medical history.   Patient's family history reveals that his father had a history of untreated hypertension and died at the age of 65 from a stroke. His oldest brother  who is 67 years old  also suffers from high blood pressure but is well-managed with medication therapy.  The patient is a former smoker  averaging about a half pack a day for 30 years  but quit at 50. He drinks alcohol occasionally and does not exercise regularly.  Upon physical examination  an aortic murmur can be heard through auscultation along with unequal radial pulses. His blood pressure readings show a variation using his right and left arms. His right arm reading shows a systolic pressure of 165 mmHg and the left arm shows a reading of 148 mmHg. Other symptoms include cold  pale legs and signs of shock including sweating  paleness  and an increased heart rate.  Given the notable symptoms  an immediate CT scan is ordered and confirmed the suspicion of aortic dissection.  Note: Mr Doe’s case is representative of the typical demographics of an aortic dissection patient. According to the literature  men  particularly those over the age of 60  have a higher propensity for this condition. The African-American population is also at higher risk and hypertension is virtually always a factor  in addition to smoking. Non-adherence to medication is a common issue that exacerbates the risk.

Patient Presentation:  Presenting is Mr. Thomas G  a 70-year-old African American male who is a retired army veteran. He arrived at the emergency department complaining of severe and acute chest pain  radiating to his back. His medical history indicates hypertension for over 15 years  during which he has been irregular with his medications. Furthermore  he is a former smoker with a 40-pack-a-year history but quit smoking ten years ago. His BMI categorizes him as overweight. Additionally  he has an extensive family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having died from a fatal stroke at the age of 75. He does not have diabetes and his lipid profile has been normal consistently.  He denies any recent trauma  significant falls  or remarkable physical exertion preceding the chest pain. He reported experiencing bouts of nausea and lightheadedness  but denied symptoms of cough  fever  shortness of breath  palpitations  or swelling of legs.  Physical Examination:  Mr. Thomas looked anxious and in distress. Vital signs revealed high blood pressure (182/98 mmHg)  rapid pulse (105 bpm)  respiratory rate was normal (16 breaths/min)  and his body temperature was normal (98.7°F). Heart sounds were normal but a low-grade murmur was noted. Upper body pulses were symmetrical  but femoral pulses were weak. There was no peripheral edema or cyanosis.  Investigations:  An EKG initially showed ST-segment changes suggestive of ischemia. A chest radiograph indicated an abnormal mediastinal widening. Urgently  a CT angiography was conducted  which confirmed the presence of a Stanford Type A aortic dissection originating few centimeters above the aortic valve and extending to the right common iliac artery.  Treatment & Prognosis:  Given the nature of the dissection  an urgent surgical consultation was sought. The surgical team recommended immediate surgical intervention to prevent any fatal complications like aortic rupture. This included replacement of the ascending aorta and aortic valve with a composite graft. After the successful surgical procedure  Mr. Thomas was transferred to the cardiovascular intensive care unit for close monitoring. He received medication to maintain his blood pressure at desirable levels and prevent complications. He was advised regarding lifestyle modifications  regular follow-ups  and the importance of medication adherence.  In conclusion  given Mr. Thomas' age  history of hypertension  and family history of heart disease  he falls within the population demographic most likely diagnosed with aortic dissection  more prevalent in older  hypertensive males  particularly those of African American ethnicity according to the reported literature. This case demonstrates the importance of proactive management and awareness of associated risk factors in mitigating the complications of this life-threatening condition.

Patient Profile:  Mr. R is a 58-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department (ED) with severe chest pain. The pain is described as an acute onset of a tearing sensation in the upper back that radiates to the chest.   Past Medical History:  Mr. R has a documented history of uncontrolled hypertension and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus ten years ago. He also had a myocardial infarction (heart attack) five years ago. He is on Metformin for his diabetes and Atenolol for his blood pressure. His medication compliance has been inconsistent according to his primary care doctor's notes.  Family History:  Mr. R’s family history reveals his father died in his early sixties from a stroke  and his mother in her late seventies from complications associated with diabetes. His older brother  in his mid-sixties  was diagnosed with heart disease and underwent a triple bypass surgery about two years ago. There is no known genetic disorder in his immediate family.   Social History:  Mr. R is a seasoned marketing executive living in the urban setting of Chicago with his spouse. He is a former smoker  having quit five years ago  post his myocardial infarction. However  he continues to consume alcohol moderately and has a relatively sedentary lifestyle. There is no known drug abuse.   Physical Examination: Upon initial evaluation  Mr. R appears anxious and diaphoretic. His vital signs are remarkable for blood pressure of 210/120 mm Hg. Heart rate is 98 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur.   Given the patient’s symptoms  history of hypertension  and the physical exam findings  a differential diagnosis of aortic dissection was considered. A CT aortogram was performed revealing a type A aortic dissection. He was subsequently referred for emergent surgical consultation.  This case presentation represents an aortic dissection  which is more common in males and among those aged 50-70 years. Risk factors include hypertension  smoking  and a family history of vascular diseases. The significant aspect of this case is the association of aortic dissection with uncontrolled hypertension and a family history of cardiovascular disease. Prompt diagnosis and management can help improve the outcome in such cases.

Patient Presentation: Mr. S  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as tearing and ripping  10/10 on the pain scale. The patient looked pale and was sweaty. His medical history revealed that he has been suffering from uncontrolled hypertension for the past ten years and follows a consistent smoking habit. He denied any illicit drug abuse. He refuses medication or medical advice often  due to previously existing mistrust towards the medical field.   Father died at 58 due to a cardiac event  mother is alive and has hypertension  diabetes  and a history of stroke. His older brother suffered from an aortic rupture at 60 years of age. There is no known familial connective tissue disease. Patient has three adult children  all of whom are healthy.   Clinical Examination & Diagnosis: Mr. S’s blood pressure was found to be 220/120 mmHg  pulse 110/min  and respiratory rate was 22/min. Upon physical examination  he was found to have a difference of 20 mmHg in blood pressure between his right and left arms and a diastolic murmur was evident.  An immediate CT scan was conducted  which confirmed the Type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the aortic arch and descending thoracic aorta.  Management: Mr. S was immediately started on intravenous labetalol to lower his high blood pressure. In concert with cardiology and cardiothoracic surgery consults  he was promptly taken to surgery for an emergency aortic dissection repair. Post-surgery  Mr. S was moved to the intensive care unit for monitoring. He was started on a long-term medication plan of beta-blockers (metoprolol)  ACE inhibitors (lisinopril)  and statins (atorvastatin). Smoking cessation and hypertension management was discussed with him and his family.  Follow-up: Mr. S's recovery was monitored over several weeks. He showed compliance with his treatment regimen  did stop smoking  and his BP was controlled around 130/80 mmHg. Furthermore  his family was advised to get screened for potential aortic diseases due to the history of aortic rupture in the brother and now aortic dissection in the patient.  Risk and Prognosis: Uncontrolled hypertension and smoking are the major risk factors that potentially led to aortic dissection in Mr. S. Although Mr. S underwent successful surgical repair of his aorta  he remains at high risk for aneurysm development or recurrent dissection  especially since he has a family history of aortic pathology. Hence  control of hypertension  lifestyle modifications  and regular follow-ups are crucial components of the long-term care of Mr. S.   This case of Mr. S illustrates aortic dissection in an African American male with uncontrolled hypertension and significant familial cardiovascular history  which coincides with demographics commonly associated with higher risk in medical literature.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Z  a 64-year-old male  presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden severe chest pain radiating to his back. The patient described the pain as 'tearing' and of sudden onset. On arrival  his blood pressure was 170/95 mmHg  pulse rate was 100 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute. He had a BMI of 28 and reported shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Z has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 10 years and type II diabetes mellitus. Despite being on antihypertensive medications  compliance was questionable due to missed doses. He had been a smoker for 15 years but quit 10 years ago. Mr. Z is also diagnosed with mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) but had no routine follow-ups and treatment for COPD.  Family History:  The patient’s father died from a stroke at the age of 76  and his mother died from complications related to diabetes. He has two brothers  one of whom had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Clinical Intervention:  On suspecting aortic dissection based on the nature of pain and his medical history  a computed tomography angiography (CTA) was ordered that confirmed the diagnosis of type B aortic dissection. The patient was immediately started on medication to lower his blood pressure and heart rate. He was admitted into the ICU for close monitoring. Vascular surgery was consulted  who suggested managing the patient's case medically  considering the patient's age and the type of dissection.  Conclusion:  Aortic dissections are a surgical emergency and are associated with high mortality rates. They are commonly seen in patients like Mr. Z  with uncontrolled hypertension and a history of smoking. It is crucial to manage these patients swiftly and accurately to prevent fatal complications. Management of such cases highlights the significance of strict blood pressure control  particularly in patients with known risk factors. In addition to surgical intervention  ensuring medication compliance and effective heath education for patients with chronic diseases like hypertension is of paramount importance.   References: 1. Chiappini B  Schepens M  Tan E  et al. Early and late outcomes of acute type A aortic dissection: analysis of risk factors in 487 consecutive patients. Eur Heart J. 2005;26(2):180-186. 2. Hagan PG  Nienaber CA  Isselbacher EM  et al. The International Registry of Acute Aortic Dissection (IRAD): new insights into an old disease. JAMA. 2000;283(7):897-903.

Patient Identification: Mr. J is a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. J presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with complaints of sudden severe sharp pain in his chest area that radiated to his back. He rates the pain at 9/10 in intensity.  Past Medical History: Mr. J's past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been non-compliant with his anti-hypertensive and lipid lowering medications. Other medical history includes obesity and a 20 pack-year smoking history.  Family History: His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. His father died from a myocardial infarction and his elder brother has undergone a coronary artery bypass graft surgery.   Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. J was found to be anxious  diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg in his right arm and 160/95 mmHg in the left arm. Cardiac auscultation revealed no abnormal sounds  and his respiratory examination was unremarkable aside from mild tachypnea.  Diagnostic Findings: An electrocardiogram (ECG) ruled out acute myocardial infarction. Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels. A subsequent Computerized Tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed an ascending aortic dissection.  Treatment: Mr. J was immediately referred for surgical repair. His medications were revised to strictly control his hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Smoking cessation programs and lifestyle modifications were emphasized for him.  Discussion: Mr. J's demographic aligns with the common age group (65-70 years) for aortic dissection as reported in literature. Hypertension  particularly uncontrolled  in conjunction with the patient's smoking history forms the significant risk factors for the development of his condition. His family history of cardiovascular disease could suggest a genetic predisposition to atherosclerosis and arterial damage  predisposing him further to the condition. This case presentation highlights the importance of strict control of hypertension  smoking cessation  and medication compliance among such patients.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old African American male presenting to the Emergency Department with a sudden and severe onset of chest pain. The pain is described as ""tearing"" and ""ripping"" in nature and is radiating through to his back. He reports feeling extremely anxious  weak  and diaphoretic. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea and dizziness. He denies any calf pain or erythema  recent trauma or falls.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension which he self-reports as being poorly compliant with prescribed antihypertensive medication. Additionally  he has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago. Other significant history includes a myocardial infarction (MI) about 10 years back and an ongoing treatment for Type II Diabetes Mellitus. He doesn’t report any known drug allergies.   Family History:  The patient's mother died at an early age from a cerebrovascular accident  and his father died of a myocardial infarction. His only sibling  a younger brother  has been diagnosed with hypertension and suffers from chronic kidney disease.  Social History:  He is retired but had a previous occupation as a truck driver. He consumed moderate amounts of alcohol in the past but quit approximately the same time when he quit smoking. He lives alone in a rural area.   Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the patient is in moderate distress. His blood pressure is significantly higher in his right arm compared to his left. Auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the right sternal border. The remainder of the exam is noncontributory  revealing no abdominal or flank tenderness or evidence of peripheral vascular disease.  Initial Diagnostic Assessment:  The EKG shows no clear signs of ischemia or any other acute changes. Blood tests  chest x-ray and CT angiogram confirm the diagnosis of aortic dissection. The dissection involved the ascending aorta and was therefore classified as a Stanford type A dissection. His blood test reports were significant for a mildly elevated D-dimer and a moderate rise in the troponin level.   Case Conclusion:  This patient's advanced age  hypertension  history of smoking and heart disease provide a substantial likelihood of an aortic dissection. He was immediately sent for a cardiothoracic surgery consult and was taken for emergent repair of the dissection to prevent fatal complications such as aortic rupture and cardiac tamponade.

Patient Profile: The patient  Mr. Antonio Delgado  is a 60-year-old Hispanic male  a retired factory worker  living in Texas  with a median income of around $45 000 per annum. He lives with his wife and has three adult children. His wife reports that he has been a heavy smoker for about 30 years and has been diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally. Mr. Delgado is 5’8”  moderately obese weighing 220lbs.  and does not exercise regularly.  Past Medical History: Mr. Delgado has had hypertension which was controlled with medication. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia but was not prescribed any medications for it. His prior medical records showed borderline diabetes for which lifestyle modification was advised  but compliance was inconsistent. He was also diagnosed with osteoarthritis in his left knee 2 years ago and has been on an analgesic for pain management. He does not have any known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaint & Clinical Findings: Mr. Delgado was brought into the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain radiating to his back  along with difficulty in breathing. On physical examination  his pulse was found to be uneven and his blood pressure was high. An electrocardiogram revealed abnormalities  and a chest X-ray showed a widened mediastinum  suggestive of possible aortic dissection.  Investigational Results & Diagnosis: A confirmatory CT angiogram was immediately ordered  which revealed a type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending to the abdominal aorta. The diagnosis was severe aortic dissection  a life-threatening medical emergency due to a tear in the inner layer of the aorta.  Family History: His father died in his late 50s due to coronary artery disease  and his mother has hypertension. One of his brothers was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.  Treatment & Progress: Mr. Delgado was rushed to surgery for life-saving emergency repair. He tolerated the procedure well and was moved to the ICU for close monitoring. His family was explained about his condition  prognosis  and future management  including lifestyle changes.  Discussion: This case highlights the importance of swiftly recognizing and diagnosing aortic dissection  especially in patients with existing cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  smoking  and family history of cardiovascular diseases. Given the patient's Hispanic ethnicity  it is important to consider the demographic factors as per current literature  where Hispanics are known to have higher rates of hypertension compared to non-Hispanic whites. Prompt medical attention  immediate surgical intervention  and intensive post-operative care are crucial to survival and recovery in such cases. It also emphasizes the need for effective control of associated comorbid conditions and encouraging healthy lifestyle habits.

Case Presentation:  The patient is a 62-year-old African-American male named Mr. Smith  who reports to the ER with severe  sharp upper chest and back pain that has been progressing over the past four hours. The patient describes the pain as being 9 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain is radiating to his shoulders and abdomen. He also reports a sense of breathlessness.  Demographics: According to the literature  he is a part of a demographic group which has the largest incidence of aortic dissection. African-American males above the age of 60 are seen to have a higher incidence of cardiovascular diseases as compared to other races.  Past medical history: Mr. Smith has hypertension and atherosclerosis. He has a 35-year history of smoking about one packet daily and a moderate history of alcohol consumption. He also has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  which he has been non-compliant with medication. His last recorded BP was 180/110 mmHg during a regular checkup two months ago.  Family history: Both of Mr. Smith's parents had a hypertension. His father died from a heart attack in his mid-70s and his older sister is being treated for heart disease.  On examination  the Patient appeared diaphoretic  breathing heavily. His blood pressure varied between his arms  165/95mmHg in the right and 140/90mmHg on the left. He has a noticeable early diastolic murmur characteristic of aortic regurgitation.  Based on his history and presentation  an immediate CT angiography scan was ordered which confirmed the diagnosis of type A aortic dissection  extending from the ascending aorta to the level of the renal arteries. Laboratory tests showed elevated D dimer levels  confirming the scan.  Recommendation: Mr. Smith was immediately referred for immediate emergency surgical intervention. He was also counselled to quit smoking  reduce alcohol consumption and adhere to his medication regime post-surgery for better health outcomes. His family was informed and educated about the hereditary nature of Hypertension.  This case highlights the importance of prompt recognition and management of aortic dissection  especially in high-risk individuals with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and atherosclerosis  characteristic demographic factors and family history.

Patient Case Presentation:  Patient Identifiers/Demographics:  Mr. Johnson  a retired Caucasian man of 68 years residing in Southern California  presented with sharp chest pain radiating to his back.   Past Medical History: He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 15 years. Other relevant past medical history includes evidence of atherosclerosis  smoking (30 pack-years)  obesity (BMI 34)  and a stressful life event - retirement from his occupation a few months ago.  Presentation: Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department complaining of an acute severe chest pain that began while he was gardening. The pain was sudden  sharp  and severe in intensity  and it radiated to his back. He also reported mild dyspnea but denied any symptoms of faint  nausea  vomiting or sweating. His blood pressure measurement revealed a reading of 180/90 mmHg.  Family History: Mr. Johnson's father died at 70 due to heart disease  and his mother succumbed to complications due to stroke at 73. His older brother had suffered from a myocardial infarction at 67.   Workup and Diagnosis: With a suspicion of aortic dissection  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of his chest was conducted  which confirmed the diagnosis of a type A aortic dissection. Other significant findings included mild coronary artery disease and aged pulmonary effusion.  Management: Given the emergent nature of the diagnosis  Mr. Johnson was immediately taken to the operating room for surgical intervention. The post-surgical period was uneventful  and he was discharged a week after the operation with strict instructions for controlling his blood pressure  improving his lifestyle  and adhering to regular follow-ups.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is a serious condition often linked with hypertension  smoking  and atherosclerosis. This case underscores the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with severe chest or back pain  especially in the context of an elevated blood pressure and relevant personal and family medical history. Immediate diagnosis and management significantly improve the prognosis of patients with aortic dissection.   References: This case presentation is representative of typical patients diagnosed with aortic disection as described in medical literature and does not refer to an actual patient.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 55-year-old Caucasian male from the Southeastern United States who presents with severe  sudden onset chest pain that radiates to his back and a sensation of ""tearing."" He was brought to the emergency department (ED) by his wife  who reported noticing that her husband appeared suddenly unwell  perspiring profusely  and had difficulty breathing.  Patient History:  Mr. J has a known history of hypertension and smoking. He has been on antihypertensive medication for the past ten years but reports having difficulty in compliance due to medication side-effects. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. He does not have a history of diabetes or any other cardiovascular disease. The patient’s father died of a heart attack at the age of 59  and his mother is currently living with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).  Physical Examination:  On initial evaluation  Mr. J was hypotensive  with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. His heart rate was irregular at 110 beats per minute  and his oxygen saturation was 88% on room air  necessitating supplemental oxygen. Mr. J appeared anxious  sweaty  and pale  and there was evidence of distal limb ischemia. A difference in blood pressure was noted between the right and left arms.  Diagnostic Evaluation:  An immediate bedside transthoracic echocardiogram performed in the ED demonstrated intimal flap in the ascending aorta  suggesting an aortic dissection. Furthermore  chest X-ray showed widening of the mediastinum. A D-dimer test was significantly elevated. Laboratory tests also showed increased white cell counts and serum troponin levels.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical presentation and echocardiographic evidence  Mr. J was diagnosed with a Stanford type A aortic dissection. It is a medical emergency that necessitates urgent surgical intervention.   Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to reduce his blood pressure and heart rate. He was referred to a cardiovascular surgeon and was taken to the operating theatre urgently for aortic root replacement surgery.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients with sudden onset  severe chest or back pain  especially in a high-risk population such as those with poorly controlled hypertension and smoking history. Early diagnosis and timely surgical intervention are key factors influencing the outcome in aortic dissection.  In this case presentation  considerable effort was made to include accurate demographic representation and relevant patient information  so as to provide accurate context for the diagnosis and management of aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information:   A 60-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department with an acute onset of severe chest pain  described as a ""ripping"" and ""tearing"" sensation. The pain radiated to his back. He has a known medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  a smoking habit of 20-pack years  and previous history of cocaine misuse. He maintains a sedentary lifestyle with a high-stress job and has a BMI of 28. His father died of a heart attack at 64 and his mother had a stroke at 67.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  he exhibited an elevated blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg with pulse rate of 90 beats per minute. Blood pressure in the right and left arms differed by 30 mmHg  supporting a diagnosis of aortic dissection. Upon auscultation  a diastolic murmur was noted  indicative of aortic regurgitation. He appeared in discomfort  anxious  and sweaty.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An emergency transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a suspicious intimal flap in the descending thoracic aorta  satisfying the criteria for Stanford Type B. The Electrocardiogram (ECG) was normal ruling out acute Myocardial Infarction (MI) with no signs of ST elevation or Q waves. His chest X-ray showed an enlarged mediastinum. Blood tests including full blood count  renal function tests and troponin were normal. A CT angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of an acute aortic dissection originating from the descending aorta and extending to the level of renal arteries.  Therapeutic Intervention:   He was immediately administered intravenous beta-blockers to manage hypertension and pain. An aggressive antihypertensive regimen was initiated with sodium nitroprusside infusion. Stat consultation with cardiovascular surgery was requested  but due to the Type B dissection (starting after the left subclavian artery)  a conservative approach was preferred over surgical management unless complications arise such as rupture or malperfusion.  Follow-up and Outcomes:   The patient's pain was well-controlled with analgesics and strict blood pressure control was achieved with medications. He was discharged after 10 days with recommendations for lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation and moderation of alcohol consumption  along with strict blood pressure control in outpatient follow-up. He was educated about the warning signs of complications and advised to follow up regularly.   Discussion:  Aortic dissection is an uncommon but catastrophic cardiovascular event. Men are affected twice as much as women and African Americans have the highest incidence rate  especially those with elevated blood pressure. Risk factors in our patient included age  gender  race  hypertension  and a lifestyle that involved cocaine use and smoking.   Despite being an emergency  aortic dissection can demonstrate a wide range of signs and symptoms. A high index of suspicion along with timely management can significantly reduce the mortality associated with this condition.   This case highlights the importance of adhering to risk factor reduction in patients with uncontrolled hypertension to prevent such catastrophic events in susceptible individuals. Regular follow-up  patient education and lifestyle modifications are an essential part of patient management.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. Raúl Gomez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain was described as tearing and began two hours prior to visit.  Background Information:  Patient is retired from his work as a construction worker  currently living with his wife. He is a former tobacco smoker  having quit five years ago after smoking 40 pack years. He drinks alcohol occasionally. He denies any illicit drug use. He is obese with a BMI of 34.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of poorly managed hypertension. Despite being prescribed medication  his compliance has been inconsistent. He also suffers from type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with metformin  but has suboptimal glycemic control. His history also includes hypercholesterolemia.  Family History:  His father had an ischemic stroke at the age of 75 and mother had type 2 diabetes. His older brother died from myocardial infarction at the age of 64. There is no known family history of connective tissue disease.  Clinical Findings: On examination  his blood pressure was significantly higher in his right arm vs his left (200/130 mmHg vs 150/95 mmHg). His pulse was 110 beats per minute and regular. Auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur heard best in the right upper sternal border. Neurological examination was normal.   Diagnostic assessment: Based on the history  physical examination  and his risk factors  a tentative diagnosis of aortic dissection was made. CT angiogram was performed which confirmed Type A (DeBakey Type II) aortic dissection. Blood tests revealed raised D-dimer levels.  He was started on intravenous beta blockers to manage his blood pressure and heart rate. He was deemed a surgical candidate and underwent successful ascending aortic replacement.   Overall  despite several risk factors including hypertension  smoking  and diabetes  the patient's aortic dissection remained undiagnosed until the acute onset of symptoms  reinforcing the importance of regular follow-ups and health check-ups in patients with high risk for cardiovascular diseases.  Follow-Up: Post-surgery  the patient was recommended to engage in a cardiac rehabilitation program to optimize his cardiovascular health and continue managing his other chronic conditions. Furthermore  increased adherence to antihypertensive medication was reinforced. He was counselled on maintaining a healthy diet  weight management  and regular exercise to manage his comorbidities. His family was suggested to undergo screenings due to the potential genetic risk of cardiovascular diseases.

Patient Presentation  Patient: Mr. J. Anderson Age: 61 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Marital Status: Married Occupation: Retired Mechanical Engineer   Chief Complaint: Sudden and severe chest pain.  History of Present Illness:  Mr. Anderson presents with sudden-onset  severe chest pain that started while he was mowing the lawn. The pain radiates to his back and is described as a tearing sensation. He also appears pale and is profusely sweating.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Anderson has a significant history of hypertension for 15 years  which is summarily controlled with oral antihypertensives. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus five years ago. He has also undergone a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 3 years back due to ischemic heart disease. No known allergies. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  consuming approximately 20 cigarettes per day.  Family History:  His father died at the age of 65 due to myocardial infarction. His mother  diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes  passed away at 73. He has one elder sister who is currently battling breast cancer. His two children are healthy.  Physical Examination:  Initial BP: 200/110 mmHg on left arm  160/98 mmHg on the right arm. Pulse: 105 bpm. Breathing rate: 18 breaths per minute. He was alert and orientated  but quite anxious. Heart sounds are normal with no murmur heard. Lung fields clear bilaterally. No abdominal or lower limb abnormalities noted.  Investigations:  ECG shows no signs of acute myocardial infarction. Chest X-ray reports a wide mediastinum. A Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TOE) and a Computed Tomography (CT) angiogram confirmed the type B aortic dissection. Blood works showed an increased WBC count and slightly elevated troponin levels.  Assessment & Plan:  Mr. Anderson is diagnosed with a type B aortic dissection likely related to his long-standing poorly-controlled hypertension complicated by his smoking history. An urgent referral to cardiothoracic surgery was made. The patient is kept on antihypertensive medications (beta-blockers  ACE-inhibitors) to manage the blood pressure aggressively. Also  adequate pain management and regular monitoring have been initiated.  Plan of care includes cessation of smoking and better control of hypertension and diabetes. Rehabilitative intervention and genetic counseling for other family members may also be considered  given the history of cardiovascular problems in his family.  Literature Review:  Aortic dissection commonly affects men between 60 to 70 years of age and is strongly associated with hypertension  making Mr. Anderson's case typical (Crawford  2006). Tobacco use  as in this case  can synergistically increase the risk alongside hypertension (Goldfinger et al.  2014). A family history of vascular diseases is also a risk factor (Hiratzka et al.  2010). Therefore  Mr. Anderson's comprehensive case is indicative of demographic and risk factor representation for this condition as found in literature.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. James Wilson  is a 68-year-old African American male  living in an urban area. He is a retired school teacher and lives with his wife. The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension (high blood pressure) and hyperlipidemia (high blood levels of fats)  both of which have been managed with medications for the last 15 years.  Mr. Wilson reported sudden severe chest and back pain that he described as ""tearing"" and ""ripping "" which began at rest while watching television at home. He also reported feeling light-headed and short of breath. He has no known allergies  does not smoke  and drinks alcohol occasionally. His father passed away at an early age from a heart attack and his mother has diabetes. They were both hypertensive.  On examination  his blood pressure was notably higher in the right arm compared to the left. Investigations using chest x-ray revealed that his mediastinum was widened  and an electrocardiogram (ECG) ruled out myocardial infarction (heart attack).  He was immediately taken for computed tomography (CT) angiogram which confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection. The dissection was identified to begin just after the origin of the left subclavian artery extending down to the abdominal aorta (Type B Aortic dissection).  Given his stable condition and the type of dissection  the patient was medically managed with medications to control his blood pressure. He was admitted to the Cardiovascular Intensive Care Unit (CICU) and closely monitored.  Throughout his admission  the patient and his family were educated regarding the seriousness of his condition and the importance of blood pressure control to lower the risk of further aortic dissection.  This case underlines the vital role of early diagnosis and immediate management of aortic dissection to prevent catastrophic events. With appropriate and timely intervention  the prognosis for patients like Mr. Wilson can be significantly improved. Continuing monitoring and control of hypertension are important for preventing an adverse event in the future.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain described as ripping and radiating to the back. He had a history of long-standing uncontrolled hypertension and was a life-long smoker. He did not have any records of regular medical check-ups and it was his first hospital visit in years. Mr. Rodriguez had a BMI of 28 and a past medical history of high cholesterol. However  he had no history of surgeries or other known health conditions. His family history was notable for a father who underwent surgery for aortic valve disease in his late 70s.   On examination  his blood pressure was elevated with asymmetrical readings between both arms. Pulse was palpable but weak and irregular. Normal breath sounds were present in all lung fields. No murmur  gallops  or rubs were detected on cardiac auscultation. Extremities were cool to touch bilaterally.  Work-up and Diagnosis:  Due to the nature of his symptoms and a significant history of uncontrolled hypertension  a suspicion of aortic dissection was made. An urgent computed tomography angiography (CTA) revealed a Stanford Type B aortic dissection extending from the left subclavian artery to the level of the superior mesenteric artery  confirming our suspicion. The client's laboratory results revealed a slightly elevated D-dimer level.  Treatment and Follow-up:  Mr. Rodriguez was immediately started on intravenous antihypertensives to bring down the blood pressure and prevent further propagation of the dissection. The cardiology team was looped in for further management and decided to proceed with non-surgical management owing to the type and location of the dissection. He may be a candidate for endovascular repair if the dissection grows larger over time or if complications arise. A plan was made for close follow-ups with cardiology and strict blood pressure control.  Discussion:  Mr. Rodriguez’s case is a typical example of aortic dissection  a life-threatening diagnosis that frequently presents in emergency departments. Males are more susceptible  especially in the age group of 60-70 years. Hypertension remains the most significant risk factor  followed by smoking  as in this case. Family history of aortic disease also increases the risk as seen in Mr. Rodriguez’s history. Prompt recognition and patient management is critical to survival  where rapid diagnosis  frequent examination  and early initiation of therapy or surgical intervention when needed  can be life-saving.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith. He is a lifetime smoker  and his family has a significant history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died prematurely of a myocardial infarction. Mr. Smith works as a high-stress finance job  has a history of hypertension  and has a BMI indicative of obesity.  Presenting Problem: Mr. Smith visited the emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain. The pain was severe  described as tearing that radiated to his back. He also reported feeling nauseous and was noticeably sweating profusely.   Medical History: Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with uncontrolled hypertension  for which he has been inconsistent in taking his prescribed antihypertensives. He has a history of smoking 1 pack/day for the last 40 years and a previous history of high cholesterol treated with statins. However  he stopped using statins one year ago of his own accord. To his knowledge  he does not have any known allergies.   Family History: Besides his father's premature death due to myocardial infarction  his mother had a stroke in her late 70s.
