His older brother  aged 65  currently has coronary artery disease and had undergone a coronary artery bypass graft procedure two years ago.  Pertinent Clinical Findings: Upon examination  his blood pressure was found asymmetrically high in his right arm compared to his left and heart rate was 110 bpm. The pain remained unaltered with changes in position or during the Valsalva maneuver. Lab tests showed elevated levels of D-dimer. An echocardiogram and computed tomographic angiography confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection  with a tear in the ascending aorta.  Treatment and Progress: Mr. Smith was immediately started on intravenous antihypertensive medication to control his blood pressure. He was taken to the operating room and underwent emergent surgical repair  whereupon an aortic graft was successfully placed without any immediate complications. Post-operative recovery will include medication to manage high blood pressure and cholesterol  lifestyle modifications  smoking cessation  and regular follow-ups with a cardiologist.  Education and Counseling: Mr. Smith was educated about the importance of adhering to his medication regimen and maintaining his blood pressure within the normal range. He was also informed about the importance of quitting smoking and recommended a weight management plan to lose weight sensibly. Dietary changes  including reducing salt and fat intake  were emphasized. Consequently  he was encouraged to engage in regular moderate-intensity exercise  aiming for at least 30 minutes on most days of the week  pending physician's approval.  Follow Up: Upon discharge  he is to continue with his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering drugs and participate in ongoing monitoring of his health status. A follow-up appointment has been scheduled with his cardiologist within the next two weeks.   Outlook: The patient’s prognosis will greatly depend on his ability to maintain consistent blood pressure control  adhere to a healthier lifestyle and diet  and his compliance in taking his medications regularly.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Williams  a 62-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of severe chest pain which he described as 'tearing' radiating to the back. He is a truck driver by profession.  Past Medical History: Mr. Williams has a history of hypertension for the past 10 years for which he's taking Lisinopril 20mg daily. He also has hyperlipidemia  maintained on Simvastatin 20mg daily. He is a smoker for more than 35 years  smoking approximately one pack daily  and consumes alcohol occasionally.   Family History: His father died from a myocardial infarction (heart attack) at the age of 50. His mother is alive and diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes.  Examination in ED: On arrival  his blood pressure was found to be significantly high: 200/110 mmHg  pulse rate 100 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 91% on room air. Upon physical examination  he was sweating  appeared anxious  complaining of pain intensity escalating to a ‘9 out of 10’.  Diagnostic Assessment: A CT angiogram was done urgently which confirmed the diagnosis of type A aortic dissection beginning just above the aortic valve and extending up to the point where the arteries supplying the brain split off. The left ventricle was normal in size and function  no signs of myocardial infarction were present.   Hospitalization and Treatment: Due to the critical nature of his condition  Mr. Williams was admitted to the cardiac care unit. Cardiothoracic surgery was consulted  and he was immediately taken to the operating room for an emergency ascending aortic dissection repair. Post-operatively  he was started on a strict blood pressure management protocol to maintain systolic BP between 100-120mmHg. He was also given Nicotine replacement therapy for smoking cessation counseling.  In the light of the patient's racial background  it's important to note that studies have shown that African Americans have higher rates of hypertension  which if uncontrolled increases the risk of acute aortic dissection. It's recommended that effective BP control and lifestyle modifications are needed for such patients.   This case highlights the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients with a history of hypertension presenting with excruciating chest pain. Thus for Mr. Williams  immediate and accurate diagnosis along with surgical intervention were life-saving.  Patient Education and Follow-Up: Mr. Williams will require lifelong antihypertensive medications and should aim to maintain a blood pressure of less than 130/80 mmHg. Regular follow-ups with his cardiologist every three months are necessary to monitor his health condition. In line with clinical guidelines  he'll be advised on smoking cessation  diet change  and regular exercise. Furthermore  his first-degree relatives are recommended for hypertension and cardiovascular risk factor screening given the family history.

Patient Presentation  Mr. John Davis  a 67-year-old African American male from Houston  Texas  visited our Emergency Department (ED) presenting sharp  tearing chest pain that had migrated to his back over a 2-hour period. Mr. Davis rated his distress level at an 8 on a pain scale of 10  with ten representing the most severe pain. He described his pain as ""sharp"" and ""tearing "" which intensified with movement and alleviated slightly upon reclining.  Medical History  Mr. Davis has a 10-year history of hypertension but only adheres to his medication sporadically due to financial constraints. He also was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes five years ago  which he manages with diet and a once-daily oral hypoglycemic agent. No documented history of high cholesterol  asthma  or heart disease. He is a former smoker  with a 20 pack-year history and ceased smoking ten years ago. He's not a regular alcohol consumer but has a history of moderate alcohol use in his younger years.  Family History  Mr. Davis’ father passed away at 72 due to myocardial infarction  while his mother died at 65 due to stroke. His older brother  age 72  is currently being treated for coronary artery disease. The patient has two children  both in good health.  Laboratory Tests  Upon initial examination  Mr. Davis’ vital signs showed a blood pressure reading of 180/120 mm Hg  a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute  and SpO2 of 92% on room air.  The ECG study presented ST segment changes  but no clear evidence of myocardial infarction. Laboratory tests revealed elevated levels of d-dimers. A CT scan showed an intimal flap located in the ascending aorta; thus  confirming the diagnosis of Stanford type A aortic dissection.  Management  Mr. Davis was immediately started on antihypertensive medication. Furosemide was given for emergency blood pressure control  along with beta-blocker metoprolol  chosen for its proven efficacy in aortic dissection cases. As this condition falls into a surgical emergency  Cardiothoracic surgery had been arranged urgently.  Summarization  Mr. Davis represents a fairly prototypical example of a patient with aortic dissection  considering his age  gender  and race. Literature suggests that aortic dissection is more prevalent among men aged 60 to 70 years and is found to be relatively higher in the African American community. In line with this  hypertension remains the most common risk factor in almost 75% of cases  just as in Mr. Davis' situation  making his case an example of typical demographic presentation.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Richard is a 65-year old Caucasian man who presently resides in Chicago  Illinois. He is a retired engineer  his body mass index indicates that he is slightly overweight  and he has a history of smoking about 15 cigarettes daily for 40 years. He has hypertension which had been poorly controlled. He has no known allergies. Richard has been a widower for 8 years and has two children  both are healthy and live independent lives. He admits to an alcohol intake of around 2 drinks daily.  Chief Complaint:  Richard was rushed to the ER complaining of severe and sudden onset of chest and abdominal pain.  Medical History:  Richard has a past medical history that includes poorly controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) as a result of his smoking habit  and Type 2 Diabetes. He is currently on Lisinopril for the hypertension  Statins for hyperlipidemia  Metformin for Diabetes  and Salmeterol for COPD.  Presenting Condition:  Given Richard's reported sudden onset chest and abdominal pain  hypertension history  and chest x-ray results  an aortic dissection was suspected. A computed tomography angiography (CTA) scan confirmed the diagnosis: a Type B  distal  aortic dissection. The affected aorta starts at the level of the left subclavian artery and extends down to the bifurcation of the aorta. The true lumen is compressed and there is partial thrombosis of the false lumen.  Family History:  Richard reported that his father died from a myocardial infarction in his 70's  and his older sister  now 70  is living with ischemic heart disease and hypertension. However  there is no family history of aortic dissection  aneurysm  or any genetic connective tissue diseases like Marfan's Syndrome.  Social History:  Richard leads an inactive lifestyle  spending most of his time doing sedentary activities. He has a poor diet that is high in fat and sodium. He also has moderate alcohol consumption.  Impression:  Richard's poorly controlled hypertension likely contributed to his development of aortic dissection. His smoking habit and sedentary lifestyle also place him at further risk of complications. The family history of cardiovascular diseases raises the possibility of a genetic predisposition  but in the absence of a family history of aortic dissection  this may not be a significant factor in his case.  This case highlights the need for effective blood pressure control  alongside lifestyle modifications such as diet improvement  exercise  smoking cessation  and moderate alcohol consumption. Prolonged hypertension  if not managed  can lead to severe complications like aortic dissection. Furthermore  immediate medical attention and possibly surgical intervention are crucial to manage aortic dissection and prevent life-threatening complications.

Patient Profile: “Mr. Romero”  Patient Background Mr. Romero is a 65-year-old Hispanic male who resides in an urban residence in the southern United States. He is a retired construction worker with a history of chain smoking for over 30 years. He has recently quit smoking for the past two years. However  he continues to consume alcohol moderately. His BMI shows that he is overweight  but not obese.  Presenting Problem Mr. Romero presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden  severe chest pain that radiated to his back and dyspnea. The pain was described as “tearing” and had worsened over a period of few hours.   Medical History Mr. Romero has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus that have been treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and metformin  respectively  but he has been non-compliant with medications and follow-up appointments due to financial and transportation issues.   Family history Apart from his sister diagnosed with hypertension  there are no significant illnesses that run in the family.   Investigations and Diagnosis Given his symptomatology and medical history  an immediate CT scan was conducted that revealed an intimal flap in his thoracic aorta  confirming the diagnosis of an aortic dissection. Further echocardiography revealed an ascending aorta dissection (Type A).  Management and Follow-up Mr. Romero was immediately started on IV beta-blockers (esmolol) and vasodilators (sodium nitroprusside) to control his blood pressure and alleviate the mechanical stress on the aortic wall. Due to the nature of his condition and considering the risks involved  Mr. Romero was referred for an emergency surgical intervention - open repair of the ascending aorta and aortic valve replacement with aortic graft.  After surgery  Mr. Romero was closely monitored in the ICU setting. His pain  blood pressure  and heart rate were gradually stabilized over the first 24 hours. He was instructed to continue his blood pressure medications and to attend regular follow-ups with his primary caregiver. Mr. Romero was also advised to seek immediate medical attention if he experiences similar chest pain in the future.  Public Health Implications Aortic dissection is an emergency condition that requires immediate medical attention. Though quite rare  it tends to occur more frequently in men than in women and the risk increases with age. Uncontrolled hypertension is a significant risk factor  and this case emphasizes the urgent need to address hypertension management  particularly in underserved communities where access to healthcare and health literacy may be limited. Education on the necessity of regular health check-ups  medication compliance and lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation  regular physical activity  and alcohol moderation must be provided to reduce the risk of such cardiovascular events.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old African-American male  referred to the emergency department for severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back. He describes the pain as 'tearing' and it has been gradually worsening over the past few hours.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension  with poor medication adherence. He was diagnosed with moderate atherosclerosis at the age of 60 and smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the last 50 years. His other past medical history includes hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Family History:  The patient’s father experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. His mother died of a stroke at age 65. His brother  two years elder  underwent a coronary artery bypass surgery and his sister was diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes. All his siblings are still alive.  Social History:  He is a retired automobile mechanic  is married with four children. His wife is a hypertensive and diabetic too. He smokes but does not consume alcohol.   Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the patient had weak pulses in his right radial artery compared with his left. His pulse was 110 per minute  blood pressure was 180/100 mm Hg  body mass index was 30.2 kg/m2  and respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute. He appeared sweaty  anxious and in distress.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  His emergent electrocardiogram did not show signs of myocardial ischemia or infarction. An urgent transthoracic echocardiogram evidenced an evaluation of aortic dissection. A follow-up Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) of the chest was performed confirming a Stanford Type A aortic dissection.  Treatment and Prognosis:  He was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to decrease his blood pressure and reduce the shearing force on the aorta. He was rushed to surgery for emergency aortic repair. A more aggressive post-op BP control plan was decided for him given his extensive family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection is more common in males above 60 years of age  with a higher prevalence in African Americans. In this patient  his long history of smoking  hypertension  atherosclerosis  hyperlipidaemia  and family history of cardiovascular diseases constituted the risk factors for his development of aortic dissection. The clinical presentation simulates that of a myocardial infarction  which often leads to delay in diagnosis and treatment.

Patient Presentation  Patient’s Initials: K.L. Age: 65 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Presenting Problem:   Mr. KL recently visited the ER with severe  sharp chest pain which radiated to his back. His heart rate was elevated  and he showed signs of high blood pressure. The initial ECG was unclear  but a CT scan confirmed an aortic dissection.  Past Medical History:  He was diagnosed with chronic hypertension twenty years ago but was non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications. He admits to an unhealthy diet  a sedentary lifestyle  and smoking. Five years ago  he was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia. He has no known allergies.   Family History:  His family history is significant for hypertension and heart disease. His father died from heart failure  and his mother had a stroke.  Social History:  He is a retired construction worker  divorced for the last ten years  and has two grown children. He lives alone and admits to having a hard time quitting smoking  despite numerous attempts.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  his vitals showed a heart rate of 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  blood pressure of 180/100 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Physical examination revealed asymmetrical pulses and a diastolic heart murmur.  Diagnostic Findings:  The CT angiogram showed a dissection starting just above the aortic arch (Stanford Type A). It also indicated a moderate pericardial effusion and coronary artery disease. Elevated troponin level indicated myocardial involvement.   Treatment:   Given the patient's clinical condition  he immediately underwent emergent cardiac surgery  where a synthetic graft was used to repair the dissection. He was also started on a beta-blocker to better control his hypertension.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that mainly affects men in their 60s and 70s with hypertension being the major risk factor. This case underscores important points: the need for regular medical follow-ups  compliance with medication  lifestyle modifications  and early detection of potential consequent diseases associated with hypertension.   Conclusion:  Despite the patient's success in managing his aortic dissection  it's important to recognise the overall management of his health for long-term success. Hypertension control  lifestyle modifications  and regular follow-ups for his cardiac status are essential to mitigate further potential complications like heart failure  stroke  or renal failure.

Patient Presentation   Patient Information:  A 65-year-old Hispanic male  a retired construction worker with a history of hypertension and smoking (30 pack-years)  presented to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain.  Clinical History: The patient was previously diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago  which was moderately controlled with medication. He followed a poor diet and continued smoking  despite doctors' repeated advice to quit. He reported being relatively active  participating in light physical activities.  Present Illness: The patient stated that he suddenly felt a sharp  severe pain in the chest that seemed to radiate to the back. He described the pain as a feeling of ""tearing"" in his chest. The pain started while he was lifting a heavy object at home. Fearing a heart attack  his wife immediately brought him to the emergency department.  Physical Examination: The patient was visibly distressed  diaphoretic (excessive sweating)  and had an elevated heart rate (tachycardia) with observed difference in blood pressure readings between arms. No other abnormalities were noted on examination.  Investigations: An initial electrocardiogram (ECG) did not show typical signs of myocardial infarction (heart attack)  which directed suspicion towards other conditions. Bloodwork was remarkable for mild renal dysfunction and elevated D-dimer levels. A computed tomography angiography (CTA) was ordered which demonstrated an aortic dissection beginning just after the aortic valve and extending into the descending thoracic aorta.  Family History: The patient's father died in his 70s from complications of a stroke  and his mother lived into her 80s with hypertension and diabetes. He has no siblings.   Discussion: Aortic dissection is a critical condition that often presents with sharp tearing chest pain. Hypertension  advanced age  and smoking are high-risk factors for aortic dissection. Among racial and ethnic groups in the United States  aortic dissection is more common in non-Hispanic white men rather than Hispanic men. However  the onset in Hispanic men population is not uncommon.   Immediate management of this case included controlling blood pressure and heart rate  and immediate surgical consultation for a potential aortic repair procedure. The patient's hypertension  lifestyle choices  and neglect towards medical advice seemed to have contributed significantly to his current condition.

Patient Case Presentation:   Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Asian male who goes by the name of Mr. S  a retired professor living with his wife. He is generally healthy  although has a moderately sedentary lifestyle with mild recreational alcohol use on weekends. He denies smoking habits.  Chief Complaint: Mr. S was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) with acute onset of severe central chest pain radiating to the back which he described as a “tearing” sensation. The pain began while he was reading in the morning and has become progressively severe.  Past Medical History: Mr. S has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years and takes no medication. He was diagnosed with high cholesterol levels five years ago but was not regular with his medications. There is no known history of diabetes or kidney disease. He was a case of Myocardial Infarction  approximately seven years ago  managed successfully by drug treatment without any intervention.  Personal and Family History: He has no known allergies. His father died at the age of 70 due to heart failure and his mother suffered from hypertension. One of Mr. S's two elder siblings has type 2 diabetes  and the other has no known health conditions.  Physical Examination: On arrival  his blood pressure was significantly higher (BP=190/110mmHg). He was conscious  alert  but showed signs of distress due to severe pain. Electrocardiogram was normal. His pulses were palpable and equal in both the upper and lower limbs.  Diagnostic Evaluation: Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels but normal cardiac enzymes. An urgent computerized tomography (CT) angiogram confirmed the presence of aortic dissection starting just after the origin of the left subclavian artery extending to the iliac arteries bilaterally.  Management: Mr. S was immediately managed with pain control and antihypertensive medications to reduce BP and was referred to cardiothoracic surgery for emergent surgery consideration.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition  often presented as severe chest pain with radiation. Factors contributing to this condition in our patient may include chronic uncontrolled hypertension coupled with his history of myocardial infarction and high cholesterol. Asian populations  particularly men  are shown to have a higher incidence of aortic dissection. This case emphasizes the importance of regular monitoring and effective management of cardiovascular risk factors  particularly hypertension.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile - Sex – Male Age – 69 years Race – Caucasian Residence – Urban  Occupation - Retired Engineer  Family History -  The patient has a family history of heart disease. His father passed away due to myocardial infarction in his 70s  and his sister has been diagnosed with hypertension.   Past Medical History -  The patient had long standing uncontrolled hypertension and a known history of smoking and occasional alcohol intake. Two years prior  he was diagnosed with mild-to-moderate aortic stenosis.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient was rushed to the ER with sudden  severe chest pain that developed at rest  described as tearing and radiating to the back. He also complained about shortness of breath.  Investigations: Upon examination  the blood pressure reading in his right arm was notably higher than his left. His heart rhythm was normal  but a diastolic murmur was noted. An EKG showed no signs of myocardial ischemia. A chest X-ray revealed widened mediastinum. A CT angiogram was urgently done which confirmed the diagnosis of Type A aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta.  Management: Immediately  antihypertensive medication was administered to decrease blood pressure and heart rate. The patient was then transferred for emergency cardiothoracic surgical intervention as required for Type A aortic dissections.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is a serious condition where there is a tear in the inner layer of the aorta  leading to separation of layers  forming a secondary channel of blood flow within the vessel wall. Risk factors include hypertension  connective tissue disorders  aortic stenosis  and lifestyle factors such as smoking and alcohol. Although aortic dissections can occur at any age  the patient's demographic (older  male  Caucasian) is typically more at risk according to literature. Early diagnosis and treatment  as in this case  is crucial for survival.   In this case  the patient's previous history of hypertension and aortic stenosis  along with his lifestyle choices  notably increased his risk of aortic dissection. Shared decision-making with patients is critical in personalizing care  including risk factor modifications  and planning for close surveillance for new or worsening symptoms.

Patient Profile: M.K. is a 65-year-old African American male residing in Cook County  Chicago. He lives with his wife and retired from his job as a school principal 3 years ago. M.K. is a non-smoker but had consumed alcohol socially throughout his life. He has a sedentary lifestyle and has a history of poor dietary choices  leaning towards foods high in cholesterol and fats.  Medical History: M.K. has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension (HTN) and hyperlipidemia that were diagnosed 10 years ago. However  he has poor adherence to prescribed medications and visits to his primary care provider are sporadic. He has no history of surgeries or other significant diseases.  Presenting Issue: M.K. presented to the emergency department with an acute onset of severe  tearing chest pain which started approximately 2 hours prior to arrival.  Family History: M.K.'s father died of a stroke at 72  and his mother died at 67 due to complications related to diabetes and HTN. He has one older sister who is alive at 68 and receiving treatment for breast cancer. There is no known family history of aortic disease.  Examination: On examination  M.K had unequal blood pressure readings in his arms along with a pulse deficit. Auscultation revealed an early diastolic murmur. His EKG showed no signs of myocardial infarction.  Diagnosis: Given the patient's history  physical examination  and initial imaging findings  a diagnosis of aortic dissection was made. Types A (involving the ascending aorta  regardless of where the initial tear is located) and B (not involving the ascending aorta) are the two types based on the Stanford classification system. In M.K.'s case  he was diagnosed with Type A aortic dissection.  Treatment and Prognosis: An emergent surgery is planned to repair the ascending aorta and aortic valve. M.K. is being started on beta blockers to control his blood pressure prior to surgery. The overall prognosis largely depends on the patient's age  underlying comorbidities  and the extent and type of aortic dissection.   The above case represents a rather typical aortic dissection case based on demographics with a higher prevalence among older males  African Americans  and those with hypertension.

Subject: Case Presentation (Aortic Dissection)  Patient Profile: Mr. Robert Sanders  a 58-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of severe  sudden chest pain radiating to his back. He is a long-term resident of Chicago  Illinois  and is an active member of his community. He is married and has two adult children.  Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension for the last 15 years  which is partially controlled by medication (Losartan 50mg daily). He has type II diabetes mellitus under control with Metformin 1000mg twice daily. He also has a 35-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking five years ago. He had an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) six months ago but did not have any permanent neurological deficits. He has no history of surgeries.  Family History: His father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at the age of 62  and his mother is a survivor of stroke. He has one brother who has no significant health issues. His older sister has hypertension and diabetes mellitus. There's no known family history of connective tissue disorders.  Examination and Investigations: On examination  Mr. Sanders appeared to be in severe pain. His blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg  heart rate 100 bpm  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  and his oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. Physical exam was significant for asymmetrical pulses between the upper limbs. The rest of the physical investigation was untravelled.    An urgent CT Angiogram revealed an aortic dissection originating just above the aortic valve and extending to the abdominal aorta. ECG showed no signs of ischemia or infarction. Complete blood count  electrolytes  kidney function  and cardiac enzymes were within normal limits.  Management and Outcome:  Mr. Sanders was immediately started on intravenous labetalol with a target to lower his systolic blood pressure to below 120mmHg. He was swiftly transferred to the Cardiothoracic Unit for emergency surgery. The surgery was successful with no intraoperative complications.   He was transferred to the ICU for postoperative management. On the third postoperative day  he was transitioned to the medical floor and was deemed stable for discharge on the eighth postoperative day with close monitoring and outpatient follow-ups scheduled.   Conclusion: Mr. Sanders' case underscores the significance of prompt diagnosis and aggressive management of aortic dissection  especially among patients with multiple risk factors  such as hypertension  smoking history  and family history of cardiovascular diseases.   Regular follow-ups were advised  especially focusing on strict blood pressure control and management of his diabetes to avoid complications. He was strongly advised to adhere to his medication and lead a healthy lifestyle to lessen the risk of complications in the future.   This case also serves as a reminder for clinicians to consider aortic dissection in differential diagnosis when patients present with acute chest pain  especially when they have ongoing hypertension and a family history of cardiovascular diseases.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. B  Age/Sex: 65/Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Civil Servant  Presenting Problem: Mr. B arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden severe chest and back pain which began 2 hours prior to presentation. He described the pain as tearing and radiating to his back. He also reported feeling lightheaded  but denied any loss of consciousness  nausea  or shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Mr. B has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  and he recently discontinued his anti-hypertensive medication  lisinopril  due to perceived side effects. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes 5 years ago  currently managed by metformin. Additionally  there’s a record of smoking a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years; though he admitted trying to quit several times  he has not been successful.  Family History: His father died of a stroke at the age of 73 and his mother lived to be 80 but suffered from coronary artery disease. He has one brother who is still alive and suffered a myocardial infarction in his late fifties.   Physical Examination: On initial examination  Mr. B appeared to be in severe distress secondary to pain. His blood pressure was 200/115 mmHg  heart rate was 98 beats/min  and his respiratory rate was 22 breaths/min. There was a discrepancy in blood pressure reading between his two arms. During examination  there were no clinical findings of pulse deficit  neurological deficits or murmur.   Investigations: A subsequent computerized tomography angiography (CTA) revealed a Stanford Type A aortic dissection beginning just above the aortic valve and extending into the descending aorta. Blood work including complete blood count (CBC)  electrolytes  creatinine and cardiac biomarkers were within normal limits except for elevated blood glucose levels.  Plan: Mr. B was emergently transferred to cardiovascular surgery for an ascending aorta and hemiarch replacement given the diagnosis of Type A aortic dissection. The patient's hypertension and diabetes are to be managed more aggressively postoperatively  with referral to a dietician and social work for smoking cessation help.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition most commonly associated with hypertension. The classic presentation is sudden onset severe chest or back pain with a ripping or tearing quality. This case underscores the importance of pain characterization and taking a thorough history in the evaluation of chest pain  as these features led to a more comprehensive work-up for aortic dissection. Evidence suggests that Caucasian males  particularly those with uncontrolled hypertension  smoking history and a family history of cardiovascular diseases  are more susceptible to aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation: Patient N is a 68-year-old African-American male who presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset chest pain that radiated to his back. He described the pain as tearing and sharp. He has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which have been managed with medication for 15 years. He smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years but quit 15 years ago. There is a family history of aortic aneurysm noted in his father  who died suddenly at the age of 69.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient's blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg  and there was a difference in blood pressure between his right and left arms (more than 20 mmHg)  and an early diastolic murmur was heard on the left sternal border. There were no other significant physical findings.   Tests and Investigations: An electrocardiogram showed no signs of myocardial infarction. To confirm the suspected diagnosis of aortic dissection  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest was ordered  which showed a Stanford type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the proximal aortic arch.  Diagnosis: Based on his symptoms  clinical findings  and CTA imaging results  Patient N was diagnosed with a type A aortic dissection. This severe condition puts him at higher risk of complications like rupture of the aorta that can lead to life-threatening bleeding  organ damage due to lack of blood flow  stroke  or heart failure.  Plan & Treatment: Given the diagnosis of a Stanford type A dissection  the patient was immediately referred for surgical intervention to prevent potential aortic rupture. Postoperatively  strict blood pressure control will be initiated to prevent extension of the dissection. Surveillance imaging will also be part of his ongoing management  to monitor the status of the aorta over time.  Discussion: Aortic dissection has a high mortality rate if left untreated  and hypertension is a significant risk factor. African-American individuals  as well as male gender  have been identified in the literature as demographic risk factors for aortic dissection. Furthermore  genetics also play a role  as evident in this case where the patient had a family history of aortic aneurysm. Long term management focuses on controlling blood pressure and regular follow-up imaging. It's also essential to educate the patient regarding the importance of maintaining strict control over his blood pressure and cholesterol level  avoiding tobacco use  and attending regular follow-up visits.

Patient Case Presentation: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information: Demographic: A 60-year-old African-American male Occupation: Retired truck driver Initial presentation: Sudden severe chest and back pain described as tearing or ripping  Personal Medical History: He is a known hypertensive for 20 years and has been non-compliant with his anti-hypertensive medication  Losartan. He also has a 30-year history of smoking two packs a day  consuming alcohol moderately  and a sedentary lifestyle. No history of diabetes  asthma  tuberculosis  or any surgeries.  Family History: There is a significant history of cardiovascular disease in his family  his father died of a myocardial infarction at age 52  and his older brother was diagnosed with a stroke at 55.   Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  there was a significant difference in the blood pressure readings between the right and left arms. Furthermore  exam revealed early signs of an aortic regurgitation murmur  indicating worsening aortic dissection. He had slightly diminished pulses in his lower extremities as well.  Diagnostic Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus rhythm with no ST changes. Chest x-ray demonstrated mediastinal widening. Computerized tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the presence of a type A (ascending) aortic dissection extending from the aortic root to the iliac arteries.  Risk Factors: The risk factors in this case are long-standing hypertension  smoking  advanced age  male gender  African American ethnicity  and family history of cardiovascular disease.   This case represents the typical demographic in aortic dissection as shown in the literature; most patients are men (about 65% of cases)  mean age of around 63 years  with hypertension being the most prominent risk factor found in 70% - 90% of the patients. Smoking and African-American ethnicity also correlate with higher rates of aortic disease  including dissection.  Management: The patient was admitted immediately to cardiovascular surgery for an urgent aortic root replacement given that he had a Type A aortic dissection  which if untreated can have a mortality rate as high as 50% within the first 48 hours.  *Please note: This is a fictional case based on known risk factors and demographics for aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anderson  a 65-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department with sudden severe pain in the upper back and interscapular area  characterized as ‘tearing’ or ‘ripping.’ Along with the pain  he also experiences poor general condition  sweating  nausea  and dizziness but no shortness of breath or chest pain.  Past History: Mr. Anderson is known to have a long-standing history of hypertension which has been poorly controlled over the years. He was advised to take anti-hypertensive medications (Calcium Channel Blockers and ACE inhibitors) but has been non-compliant and negligent in his dietary and lifestyle modifications. He also has a history of tobacco and alcohol addiction but quit smoking ten years back. There is no history of recent trauma or surgical interventions.  Family History: His father had passed away due to myocardial infarction at 68  while his mother is diagnosed with Type II diabetes. He has one younger brother who is in good health. There is no known history of connective tissue disorders or other hereditary diseases in the family.  Clinical Examination: Upon physical examination  blood pressure in his right arm was 180/120 mm Hg while in the left arm it was 165/110 mm Hg. Pulse rates were symmetric in both arms  and no audible murmur was heard. Neurological examination discovered no abnormalities. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed immediately  revealing a dissection flap in the ascending aorta.  Diagnostic Assessment: A CT angiogram confirmed an aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta (Stanford type A). Blood tests displayed elevated D-dimer levels.  Management: Being an emergent clinical condition  Mr. Anderson was rushed for immediate surgical intervention  involving graft replacement of the ascending aorta  to prevent life-threatening complications such as aortic rupture  organ failure due to impaired blood supply  or cardiac tamponade. Post-surgery  he was initiated on aggressive blood pressure control therapy with beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers to maintain his systolic pressure below 120 mm Hg.  This case emphasizes the importance of regular monitoring and adequate control of hypertension  and the compliance with anti-hypertensive treatment  as they significantly contribute to preventing aortic dissection. It also underscores the importance of immediate diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention in preventing fatal complications associated with aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. M.S  a 68-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department (ED) with chief complaints of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back  shortness of breath  and diaphoresis.   Past Medical History:  Tracing his past medical history  Mr. M.S is a known hypertensive and diabetic  with both conditions being poorly controlled due to non-compliance with medications and lifestyle modification. He had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago  but has had no follow-up cardiology appointments since then. He also has a 40-year pack history of smoking and was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 5 years ago.  Family History:  Concerning family history  his father died from a stroke aged 60  and his older brother had a ruptured aortic aneurysm at the age of 63. His mother is alive at 90 years old with no known heart disease.   Demographics:  Mr. M.S is a retired automotive worker  is widowed with two adult children  and lives alone. He is insured through Medicare. He has a significant history of non-compliance with appointments and treatments due his transportation challenges and distrust in the healthcare system.   Clinical Finding:  Upon initial vitals check-up  his blood pressure was high at 185/109mmHg  heart rate was fast at 110 bpm  and respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation was relatively normal at 97% on room air.   Based on his symptoms  history  and demographics  the ED physician suspected acute aortic dissection  which was confirmed by a computed tomography angiography (CTA) showing an ascending thoracic aortic dissection.   Discussion:  Aortic dissections have a higher prevalence in males and typically affect those over 60 years old. African American men have been shown to have a higher incidence of hypertension  a major risk factor for aortic dissection. Given Mr. M.S's history of hypertension  smoking  peripheral artery disease  and family history of aortic disease  he falls into a high-risk group for aortic dissection. These conditions have likely contributed to the development of his aortic dissection.   Healthcare providers should be cognizant of these added risks in similar patients  prioritizing early detection and intervention. Management of such patients requires a multifaceted approach including not only medical and surgical treatment  but also advocacy for their active participation in healthcare management considering their sociocultural backgrounds. Comprehensive follow-up care with regular checkups and continued education on lifestyle changes  risk factor management  and medication compliance are vital for preventing further health deterioration.

Patient Presentation  Demographics:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male residing in urban New York City. He worked as a truck driver for 35 years and has recently retired.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 15 years and tobacco use  amounting to a pack a day for the last 30 years. He also had Type 2 diabetes mellitus for approximately 10 years. His father and grandfather both had cardiac related conditions  he also appears to have a family history of heart diseases. In the past  patient used to consume alcohol but gave up few years back.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient comes in complaining of a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest and back pain  radiating to his abdomen and his back for the past several hours. The pain began while eating breakfast today. He also expresses feelings of 'light-headedness'.  Symptoms: On examination  his blood pressure was found to be 200/110 mmHg in the right arm and 170/90 mmHg in the left arm. The patient showed symptoms of respiratory distress and seemed to be in severe pain.   Diagnosis: Given the patient's history of hypertension  the disparity in blood pressure between the two arms  his symptoms  and the nature of his pain  a diagnosis of aortic dissection was considered. A suspicion was elevated by the chest X-ray results indicating mediastinal widening  and a CT Aortogram confirmed the diagnosis  revealing a Stanford Type B Aortic Dissection.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on pain relief medication and intravenous antihypertensive drugs to try to reduce the systolic blood pressure to 100-120 mmHg  as per the American College of Cardiology (ACC) recommendations. He was also immediately referred to the cardiothoracic department for further management of his condition.  Note:  It should be recognized that aortic dissection is more common in men  African Americans  and those with a history of uncontrolled hypertension. It is also highly fatal  with a mortality rate of 1.9% per hour following the onset of symptoms until definitive treatment is administered. Hence  it was crucial to manage the patient's blood pressure urgently to prevent his condition from worsening. Patient's family was also counseled about the seriousness of the condition and advised to support him quit smoking.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. X is a 62-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute onset of severe chest pain  described as ""tearing"" in nature and radiating to his back. The pain was most intense in the anterior chest and started while the patient was lifting a heavy object at his job as a construction worker. He felt clammy  short of breath and also mentioned experiencing feelings of impending doom.  Past Medical History:   Mr. X has several risk factors that put him at risk for aortic dissection. He was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago but has had poor medication adherence due to lack of awareness and socioeconomic constraints. He has a 20-pack year history of tobacco smoking but quit ten years prior to arrival. He does not report any personal history of hypercholesterolemia  diabetes  or any other vascular diseases. There's no known history of drug abuse  specifically no cocaine or other stimulant use.  Family History:  While there is no known family history of Marfan Syndrome or any other connective tissue disorders in his family  his father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 65.  Physical Examination:   Upon examination  he appeared to be in distress  with diaphoresis and labored breathing. Blood pressure was significantly different in the two arms (Right arm- 190/110 mmHg  left arm 160/90 mmHg)  suggestive of arterial occlusion in the left arm. The heart sounds were normal with no audible murmur. Examination of chest and lungs revealed no abnormalities. He was alert  oriented  and without any neurological deficit.  Diagnostic Studies:   EKG was performed which did not show any changes suggestive of myocardial infarction. The D-dimer level was raised. These findings lead to the suspicion of aortic dissection  which was finally confirmed by a Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) revealing a Stanford type A dissection  with involvement of the ascending aorta  arch  and descending thoracic aorta (DeBakey Type II).  Management and Outcome:  Considering the patient's acute condition  the cardio-thoracic surgery team was immediately consulted for emergency surgical repair. The patient was also started cautiously on intravenous beta-blockers to control heart rate and blood pressure in the ED. Despite the risk factors and lack of early intervention  the surgery was successful with no post-operative complications noted. He has now been discharged with optimal medications  including effective antihypertensives and statin therapy  and has an appointment scheduled with cardiology for follow-up.  Take-home Message:   This case highlights the importance of considering aortic dissection in at-risk patients presenting with severe chest pain. Prompt diagnosis and management can significantly improve the outcome in these patients. It also emphasizes the role of preventive care  medication adherence  and risk factor management in cardiovascular health.

Patient Presentation:  Patient: J.W.  a 58-year-old African American male  Presenting Complaint: Severe sudden onset chest pain  described as 'tearing' in nature  radiating to the back.  Past Medical History: J.W. has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years and has been poorly compliant with his antihypertensive medication. He also has a known history of smoking but quit 3 years ago and has no history of alcohol abuse.   Family History: His father died from a myocardial infarction at 60 years of age  and his mother suffers from chronic hypertension.   Social History: J.W. is married with two children and works as a postman.   Physical Examination: On physical examination  blood pressure is 180/110mmHg in the right arm and 155/95mmHg in the left arm. His heart rate is 100 beats per minute. His respiratory rate and oxygen saturation levels are within normal limits. There is a discrepancy in pulse volume between both arms. Cardiovascular exam reveals a harsh systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border.   Investigations: An urgent CT angiography confirms the diagnosis of aortic dissection involving the ascending and descending thoracic aorta (DeBakey Type II). Laboratory results demonstrate slightly elevated total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol  as well as elevated white blood cell count and CRP levels indicative of an inflammatory state.  Management: Given his diagnosis  J.W. is immediately started on medication to control his blood pressure and heart rate  including beta-blockers and nitroprusside. Subsequently  the patient undergoes successful emergency surgery to repair his ascending aorta and replace it with a synthetic graft. He is placed on follow-up for regular checks on the status of his aorta.  Discussion: Aortic dissections are often seen in patients with longstanding uncontrolled hypertension  and the disease has significant morbidity and mortality. High index of suspicion and early diagnosis are crucial to survival. In this case  the diagnosis was facilitated by the patient's severe chest pain  clinical findings suggestive of aortic pathology  and confirmed on CT angiography. Successful management included addressing the hypertension and surgical correction of the dissected aorta.  Ethnic Prevalence: Aortic dissection is relatively common in African American men aged 50-60  with hypertension being a major risk factor. Existing literature indicates that the incidence of aortic dissection is higher in African American individuals as compared to white individuals  even after adjustment for hypertension and other risk factors  suggesting a need for heightened awareness and control of cardiovascular risk factors in this population.

Patient Presentation:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Presenting complaint: Severe chest pain that started suddenly and radiated to the back  History of presenting complaint: Mr. Doe presented to the ED with a feeling of ""tearing"" chest pain radiating to his back. The pain commenced suddenly while he was watching TV at home and has lasted for about 3 hours before the patient arrived at the hospital. There has been no change in the intensity of the pain since it began. He had a similar  though less severe  episode about six months ago which he did not seek medical attention for.  Past Medical History: Hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago  for which he takes Lisinopril. He has a 10-year history of smoking (1 pack per day) and quit about a year ago. There is also a history of high cholesterol for which he is under medication. He had a minor myocardial infarction approximately 10 years ago.  Family History: Father died at the age of 62 from a heart attack; mother has a history of hypertension. His brother  aged 67  was diagnosed with an aortic aneurysm two years ago.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient is in evident distress and profusely sweating; his blood pressure is found to be elevated (170/110 mmHg in right arm  160/120 mmHg in the left arm). Pulse - irregular rapid pulse observed; Heart sounds were normal. The lungs were clear to auscultation. Abdominal and neurological examination was normal.  Investigations: CT angiography demonstrates a dissection of the ascending aorta  confirming the diagnosis of aortic dissection. His CBC  CMP  Coagulation profile  Cardiac Markers  and Lipid profile were ordered.  Treatment and Management: Mr. Doe was stabilized with IV Beta-blockers to lower the blood pressure and reduce myocardial oxygen demand. Given that the dissection involved the ascending aorta  the patient underwent an emergency surgical repair of his aortic dissection.  Outcomes and Follow-Up: Surgical repair was successful and Mr. Doe was discharged after a 10-day hospital stay in stable condition with follow up appointments with Cardiology and GP for the management of hypertension.  In conclusion  Mr. Doe's smoking history  hypertension status  family history of vascular illnesses and past history of heart disease likely contributed to his incidence of aortic dissection.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain which he describes as tearing and radiating to his back. He also reports feeling lightheaded.   Past Medical History  His past medical history is notable for untreated hypertension and a 35-year history of smoking  although he quit 10 years ago. He had a prior myocardial infarction 5 years ago  which was managed medically. No allergies were reported.  Demographics   Mr. Rodriguez is a retired teacher living with his wife in an urban area. They are socially active with their family and community. He smokes cigars occasionally and reports moderate  regular alcohol intake. He is a veteran and visits VA for regular check-ups. On examination  his weight is 70kg  with a height of 170 cm  blood pressure of 180/110mmHg in right arm  temperature of 98.5 F  and heart rate 105 bpm.  Family History  Mr. Rodriguez's father passed away from a stroke at 73  while his mother died at 78 due to heart failure. His older sister  68 years old  is currently living with hypertension and coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination & Diagnosis  On physical examination  Mr. Rodriguez looked uncomfortable  with mild distress. Heart sounds were normal with no murmurs. Pulses were symmetrical in all four extremities. CT scan confirmed a diagnosis of ascending aortic dissection.  Plan and Provisional Diagnosis  Mr. Rodriguez's presentation  coupled with his history of untreated hypertension  raises suspicion of aortic dissection. Arrangements were made for immediate transfer to the cardiothoracic surgery unit for a probable emergency surgical intervention. His wife and children were informed and stayed with him until transfer.  Comment  Aortic dissection is a serious condition  often linked to hypertension. Mr. Rodriguez's venerable age  Hispanic ethnicity  and male gender align with statistical trends for higher incidence of this condition. His history of smoking and coronary artery disease also add to his risk. Quick action and diagnosis are essential for the best patient outcome. This case emphasizes the importance of regular monitoring and control of hypertension. Additionally  it underscores the crucial role of prompt emergency care in managing acute cardiovascular events. Prompt intervention can potentially save lives in the case of aortic dissection.

Subject: Mr. X  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Severe chest pain radiating to the back  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a history of uncontrolled hypertension. He was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  however  the recent lab reports showed elevated blood pressure levels which indicated poor disease management. He also has a 30-year history of smoking (2 packs per day) and was diagnosed with emphysema 5 years ago.  Family History: Mr. X's father died of an ischemic heart attack activity while his mother died of breast cancer. His younger sister is living with type 2 diabetes.  Vitals: Blood Pressure: 160/95mmHg Temperature: 98.6 F Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths per minute Heart Rate: 90 beats per minute  Physical Examination: Mr. X shows signs of distress  he is diaphoretic and uncomfortable due to the pain  no visible signs of trauma. Upon auscultation  a distinct ""ripping"" sound is noted.  Test Findings: ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy but no signs of ischemia. Subsequent CT angiography confirms the aortic dissection from the ascending aorta to the iliac arteries.  Case Summary: Mr. X  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and smoking  came into the hospital complaining of severe chest pain radiating to the back. Clinical findings and imaging confirmed a diagnosis of aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the iliac arteries.  Patient Management Plan: The condition is considered a surgical emergency due to its ascending nature. The patient was initially managed with pain control and blood pressure lowering therapy  to decrease shear stress on the aortic wall. After stabilization  Mr. X was referred to cardiovascular surgery for definitive management.  Patient Education: Discussed the significant risk factor of tobacco use  hypertension  and the importance of regular medical follow-ups. He was also explained about the potential complications of aortic dissection including heart failure and the risk of rupture leading to potentially life-threatening bleeding. Smoking cessation interventions and hypertension control measures were also discussed for preventing future cardiovascular risks.   This case reiterates the critical aspect of managing modifiable risk factors  especially hypertension and emphasizes the need for patients to be aware of their conditions and participate actively in their care.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male  currently living in the United States  who was brought to the hospital with severe chest pain which started about three hours before his arrival. He described the pain as sudden  sharp  and “tearing” in nature starting from the center of the chest and radiating towards the back. He also reported episodes of nausea  vomiting  and profuse sweating.  Past Medical History   His past medical history highlights controlled hypertension. He has been on antihypertensives for the last five years. He also signs of early-stage chronic kidney disease.  Family History  The patient's family history includes cardiovascular disease and hypertension in multiple family members. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his older brother had an unspecified aortic aneurysm.  Social History  The patient admits to occasionally drinking alcohol but denies any illicit drug use or smoking. He is married and has three children. He is a retired school teacher living with his wife.  Clinical Findings  On examination  the patient appeared acutely ill  anxious  and pale. His blood pressure was noted to be 170/100 mm Hg  and pulse was 110 beats per minute (bpm). A loud diastolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space was noticed during cardiovascular examination.  Investigations  Considering the severity of pain and clinical findings  Computed tomography angiography (CTA) was performed which confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection  revealing a type A dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending towards the aortic arch.  Treatment and Progress  The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for immediate management of blood pressure. He underwent emergency surgery to repair the dissected aorta. His postoperative course in the ICU was complicated by transient renal insufficiency  but the patient gradually improved over time.    In conclusion  this case presentation details a typical presentation of a lethal condition affecting the geriatric population. High suspicion can facilitate early diagnosis and effective management which are crucial to improving survival in such cases.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. T. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired mechanic  whose primary language is English. He presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden  severe anterior chest pain that radiates to his back and has persisted for about 6 hours. He describes the pain as being tearing in nature. He doesn't smoke or drink and denies any illicit drug use.   Past Medical History:  His medical history includes hypertension which has been under control with medication (amlodipine 10mg daily) since he was diagnosed 10 years ago. Other medical alarming background includes slightly elevated cholesterol for which he takes atorvastatin 20mg. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. He has no history of allergies.   Family History:  His mother died of a stroke at 72  and his father died in his early sixties due to myocardial infarction. He has one brother who currently has coronary artery disease. None of his family members to his knowledge had aortic disease.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a patient in moderate distress  diaphoretic  with a blood pressure of 190/100 on his right arm and 160/85 on his left arm. The radial pulse is weaker on the left side compared to the right. Auscultation of the chest shows a blowing murmur over the aortic area. The rest of the examination is within normal limits.   Lab findings:  Troponin levels were within normal ranges. His CBC  CMP  and HbA1c came out within standard parameters.   Diagnostic Findings:  An immediate ECG was performed which did not show any signs of ischemia or infarction. Due to suspicion of aortic dissection  a CT angiography was requested  revealing an intimal flap in the ascending aorta consistent with a Stanford type A aortic dissection.   Discussion:  Mr. Johnson's presentation is typical of an acute aortic dissection. Risk factors are male sex  older age  high blood pressure  and atherosclerosis. His constant and uncontrollable hypertension is likely the predisposing factor behind this condition.   Plan:  This is a life-threatening condition and calls for immediate surgical intervention. The patient will be admitted to the cardiac surgery service in light of possible aortic dissection repair. In addition to surgery  the patient should commence on medication to lower the systolic blood pressure  thereby decreasing the sheer stress on the aortic wall. His other chronic conditions have to be managed carefully  avoiding a hypoglycemic event in the perioperative period.   Outcome measures:  The efficacy of management will be assessed by the relief of symptoms  stable vital signs  follow-up imaging after surgical treatment  and continual monitoring for complications. After discharge  regular outpatient monitoring is recommended  including imaging surveillance to detect any new or progressive vascular disease.  Patient and family education about the gravity of the situation  emergency signs and symptoms  the necessity for follow-up  and medication adherence are crucial.

Patient Profile:  Name: George Thompson Age: 65 years Race: Caucasian Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Place: New York  USA  The patient  Mr. George Thompson  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male living in New York City who initially presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain that radiated to his back  with a history of hypertension and smoking.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson has a controlled history of hypertension over the past 10 years and has been prescribed amlodipine  which he's been taking regularly. Mr. Thompson has been a heavy smoker for the past 35 years and consumed on average a pack a day. He also has a history of high cholesterol  for which he takes simvastatin. He denies any known history of heart disease or peripheral arterial disease.  Family History:  There is no reported family history of aortic dissection  aneurysm  or connective tissue disorder on both paternal and maternal sides. However  his father died of a myocardial infarction at an early age (52) and his mom is diabetic.   Presentation:  The patient complained of excruciating  tearing chest pain that began suddenly while he was reading. The pain radiated to the back and no relief was observed with rest or nitroglycerin. The patient reports no other symptoms.   Physical Examination:  On general examination  he appeared distressed due to pain. Blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg; pulse is 110/min; respiratory rate is 20 breaths per min; body temperature is 37°C. Visualization of the chest showed no visible abnormalities  except the intercostal retractions.  Emergency Diagnosis:  Given the severe  sudden-onset chest discomfort  a range of conditions were considered  including myocardial infarction  pulmonary embolism  and aortic dissection. ECG did not show any signs of myocardial ischemia.  The high resolution CT chest angiography confirmed an ascending aortic dissection starting just above the aortic root  involving the aortic arch and abdominal aorta.  Mr. Thompson was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to control his blood pressure and heart rate and plans were swiftly put in place for his transfer to the cardiothoracic unit for surgical repair of the dissection.  The case of Mr. Thompson represents the typical demographic and risk factors for aortic dissection seen in the literature  including male gender  older age  a history of hypertension  and smoking. This case especially highlights the importance of rapid diagnosis and management in aortic dissection given its high mortality rate.

Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson  a 63-year-old African-American male with a medical history of hypertension and smoking  presents to the emergency department (ED). He hails from an urban background  is divorced  and works as a truck driver. He has three adult children  lives alone  and belongs to a lower socioeconomic status. He denies having any other known familial medical conditions.  Case Presentation: Mr. Johnson was previously managed for hypertension but non-compliant with his prescribed medications. He smokes approximately 20 cigarettes a day for the last 40 years. He was brought in with a chief complaint of sudden onset  severe pain in the middle of his chest and between the shoulder blades. The pain is tearing in nature  constant  rates 8/10  and started about 3 hours ago.  On examination  there is a discrepancy in blood pressure measurements on both arms (+20mmHg on the right arm). Mild diaphoresis noted but no signs of heart failure and the lungs are clear. Neurological examination revealing no signs of stroke. He reports no episodes of fainting  no changes in vision  no shortness of breath  and no loss of consciousness.   The electrocardiogram (ECG) indicates left ventricular hypertrophy  but no signs of myocardial infarction. A rapid bedside Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) shows a dilated aortic root which heightens our suspicion of aortic dissection. Subsequently  Computerized tomography angiogram (CTA) confirms the diagnosis of Stanford Type A aortic dissection.  Family History: Mr. Johnson's father had a history of chronic hypertension and passed away from a stroke in his late 70s. His mother died of breast cancer at 68. His siblings are alive and in good health. No known family history of any inherited connective tissue disorders (e.g.  Marfan's syndrome)  aortic diseases  or other cardiovascular diseases.  Conclusion: Mr. Johnson's situation is typical  as literature reveals that the highest incidence of aortic dissection lies among males in their 60s and 70s  particularly with a background of unmanaged hypertension  smoking  and advanced age. The case emphasizes the importance of prompt diagnosis and intervention in suspected aortic dissection cases  given their potential for severe complications like aortic rupture  cardiac tamponade  or end-organ ischemia. It also brings attention to the necessity of medication compliance and lifestyle modifications in hypertensive patients. The case serves as a reminder for regular check-ups and health education  especially in socioeconomically disadvantaged segments who lack comprehensive health care provisions and knowledge.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-years smoking history. He is a retired professional  lives with his wife of 35 years  and has two grown-up children. His father passed away at the age of 70 due to a myocardial infarction and his mother has a history of hypertension. He presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  tearing chest pain that radiates to his back  which started suddenly about an hour ago.   Mr. Smith's vital signs on arrival were blood pressure 170/90 mmHg  pulse rate 105/min  respiratory rate 18/min  and SpO2 94% on room air. On physical examination  he appeared to be in severe pain and distress. His cardiovascular examination revealed uneven pulses between upper and lower extremities. The rest of his physical examination was within normal limits.  Initial workup included an EKG  which showed no evidence of myocardial infarction. However  a D-dimer test was positive. A stat CT angiogram was ordered  which revealed a dissection of ascending aorta consistent with a Stanford Type A aortic dissection.  Mr. Smith and his family were informed about his precarious condition. After consultation with cardiology and cardio-thoracic surgery  an urgent surgical repair was planned. Mr. Smith was admitted to the cardio-thoracic surgical ICU while awaiting emergent surgery.  Mr. Smith has an established history of cardiovascular risk factors including a strong family history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a significant smoking history. Early and aggressive control of these risk factors could have potentially delayed or prevented this life-threatening aortic complication. However  given the current circumstances  early detection and immediate surgical intervention are essential to Mr. Smith's survival.  Following recovery  Mr. Smith would likely benefit from comprehensive cardiovascular rehabilitation and aggressive risk factor management including smoking cessation  strict blood pressure control and lipid-lowering therapy. A multidisciplinary team approach comprising of his primary care physician  cardiologist  dietician  and physiotherapist would be beneficial for his long-term management.

Patient Overview:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back. He is a heavy smoker with a 40 pack-year history and was diagnosed with hypertension twenty years ago. His mother died from an unspecified cardiovascular event at age 75.   Presenting Symptoms and Hospital Course:  The pain started abruptly while the patient was watching television  which prompted him to seek emergency care. He rated the pain as a 10 on a scale of 0-10. The patient reported that he has never experienced this kind of pain before. His medical history reveals long-term  poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He currently takes antihypertensives and statins irregularly.  Evaluation and Treatment:  In the emergency department  his blood pressure was 180/110 mmHg and his heart rate was 98 beats per minute. An ECG was performed showing nonspecific T-wave changes  which can be seen in aortic dissections but didn't give us a definite diagnosis. Due to his presenting symptoms and hypertension history  he was suspected to have an aortic dissection.   A CT angiogram was performed  confirming a Stanford type A aortic dissection  involving the ascending aorta. The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to control his blood pressure and heart rate and was emergently taken to the operating room for surgical repair of the dissected aorta.  Post-Surgery Follow-up:  The surgery was successful  and the patient's post-operative recovery was uneventful. He was further evaluated by a cardiovascular specialist who made additional recommendations for his treatment plan  including closer management of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The importance of medication adherence was reinforced. Given his history of heavy smoking  a smoking cessation program was also recommended.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates that aortic dissections can be initially challenging to diagnose due to the nonspecific nature of the symptoms. In this case  the patient's age  sex  hypertension history  and smoking history increased suspicion for aortic dissection. Early recognition of the disease can drastically reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with the condition  and aggressive blood pressure management post-operatively is critically important for these patients. This case highlights the importance of comprehensive history taking  suspicion of diagnosis based on risk factors  and the need for efficient multidisciplinary medical and surgical management of aortic dissection patients.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 66-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department with sudden  severe chest pain. He has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  heavy smoking for 20 years  and was recently diagnosed with Marfan syndrome  a genetic disorder affecting connective tissues. The patient lives in a rural region in Southern United States and is of lower socioeconomic status  hence has limited access to healthcare facilities. He works as a construction worker and hence is involved in physically strenuous activity regularly. He remains unmarried and does not have children. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  including aortic aneurysms and dissections.   Chief Complaint:  The patient complained of severe chest pain  described as a tearing or ripping sensation  which started abruptly around an hour before. The pain radiated towards the back between the scapulae. He also endorsed instances of light-headedness and dyspnea.  Clinical Assessment:  Blood pressure revealed a difference between the arms (right arm BP: 158/94 mmHg  left arm BP: 142/86 mmHg). Physical examination showed mild diaphoresis and pallor. A systolic murmur was heard upon auscultation. Neurological examination was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Procedure and Result:  Due to high clinical suspicion of aortic dissection  a CT scan was immediately ordered which confirmed the diagnosis of acute Stanford Type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta to the level of the renal arteries. There were no signs of rupture or malperfusion. Laboratory tests revealed raised D-dimer and elevated troponin levels.  Management and Follow-up:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to reduce blood pressure and heart rate. Vascular surgery consultation led to an emergency surgical repair - an open ascending aortic replacement with a synthetic graft. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Post-operative recovery was uneventful  and he was discharged on a regimen of antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. The importance of strict blood pressure control  smoking cessation  and regular follow-up was emphasized upon discharge.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the importance of rapid diagnosis and treatment of aortic dissection. It also highlights how certain risk factors such as uncontrolled hypertension  heavy smoking  and genetic disorders like Marfan syndrome can significantly increase the likelihood of developing aortic dissection. Experts recommend routine screening for aortic disease in high-risk populations and those with a family history of aortic dissection or aneurysms.   Given the patient's sociodemographic status  comprehensive efforts must be made to ensure follow-up and adherence to the treatment plan  thereby reducing the risk of recurrence or complications.

Case Presentation  Patient Demographics:  Our patient  Mr. G  is a 69-year-old African American male with demographic factors aligned with the literature on patients more prone to aortic dissection. He lives in an urban area and is retired from his construction job. He is widowed with two adult children. In terms of socio-economic status  he is in the lower-middle class  as is consistent with the higher prevalence of aortic dissection in this group.  Medical History:  Mr. G has a significant past medical history that includes hypertension  a significant risk factor for aortic dissection. He also has hyperlipidemia and type II diabetes mellitus  both controlled under medication. He has a 55-pack-year smoking history  but he quit about a decade ago. He is neither a drug user nor a heavy alcohol consumer. There's no history of any major trauma.   Current Complaint:  Mr. G presented to the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden  severe  tearing chest pain that radiated to his back. He described it as unlike any pain he had experienced before. The pain onset coincided with him carrying a heavy bag of groceries  upon which he felt a sharp  tearing sensation in his chest. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis  but no syncope  weakness  or paraplegia.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  he appeared anxious and in distress due to pain. His blood pressure was 180/92 mmHg in the right arm and 210/100 mmHg in the left. This variation in blood pressure measurement is suggestive of aortic dissection. The cardiovascular examination revealed a slight diastolic murmur. There were no signs of neurological deficit  and his pulses were symmetrical in all limbs.   Family History:  His father reportedly died of a 'heart issue' in his early sixties  but the full medical record was not available for detailed study. There is no known family history of Marfan syndrome or any genetic connective tissue disorder linked to the increased incidence of aortic dissection.   Procedure & Diagnosis:  An urgent chest CT scan was done for Mr. G  which revealed an aortic dissection  confirmed as a Stanford Type A dissection. He was rushed into emergency surgery.   Discussion:  The patient's demographic details and medical history  including being an older male  being African American  having chronic hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  increase his risk for aortic dissection. Smoking history  even though he quit  still contributes to long-term cardiovascular damage. His immediate complaint of sudden severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back is typical of aortic dissection.
