Accurate clinical suspicion  quick diagnosis  and immediate surgery possibly saved his life.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old African-American male named Mr. Smith. He has been diagnosed with a Type B aortic dissection. His body mass index (BMI) is 28  suggesting that he is overweight according to standard BMI categories. Prior to this diagnosis  Mr. Smith had a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was non-compliant with his medications and regularly smoked half a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years.  Demographics:  Data shows that aortic dissection is more common in males and incidence increases with age  with most cases occurring between the ages of 60-80. African American race  like Mr Smith  is also associated with increased risk of aortic dissection.  Medical History:  Mr. Smith's major risk factor for aortic dissection is his long-standing history of hypertension. He had also been managing diabetes mellitus for the last 15 years. Additionally  his smoking habit contributed to his overall cardiovascular risk. There is no known history of connective tissue disorder or trauma  other common risk factors for aortic dissection.  Family History:  There is no known family history of aortic dissection  Marfan syndrome  Ehlers-Danlos syndrome  Turner syndrome  or any other genetic disorders associated with vascular disease.   Presentation:  Mr. Smith presented to the ER with severe chest pain described as a ""tearing"" sensation radiating to his back. He was also experiencing cold and numbness in his lower extremities. On examination  there was a notable difference in blood pressure between his arms  and his pulse was 110 bpm.  Investigation and Diagnosis:  An emergent CT angiogram confirmed a diagnosis of Stanford Type B aortic dissection extending from the descending thoracic aorta just beyond the left subclavian artery to the iliac arteries  without involvement of the aortic arch.  Management:  The management of Mr. Smith’s case involved aggressive blood pressure and heart rate control to decrease the aortic wall stress. This was initiated with intravenous labetalol followed by nitroprusside in the ER. He was admitted to ICU under close monitoring. Cardiothoracic surgery was consulted but initially conservative management was opted as there is no evidence of complications such as malperfusion  uncontrolled hypertension or rapid aortic growth.   In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of risk factor modification  particularly for hypertension  to prevent serious complications such as aortic dissection. Primary care physicians can play a crucial role in identifying and managing these risk factors and educating patients on the importance of medication compliance.

Patient Case Presentation  Introduction  This is a case study of a 67-year-old African-American male diagnosed with aortic dissection  a rare but serious condition where the inner layer of the aorta tears. This condition is more common in men aged 60 and above  especially African American men who make up a sizable percentage of those diagnosed per CDC data.  Patient History  Mr. Smith  as we will refer to the patient  is a retired postal worker who presented with sudden chest and back pain. He has a medical history of poorly controlled hypertension for over 25 years  and he is also a 30-year-packet-year smoker  although he quit 5 years ago. His father died of a heart attack at an early age  around 60  suggesting a family history of cardiovascular disease. He does not have any history of connective tissue disorders nor a history of recent or past chest trauma.  Evaluations  Upon physical examination  he appeared in significant discomfort. The initial blood tests  inclusive of complete blood count  renal function  electrolytes  coagulation profile  and cardiac enzymes were taken. An emergency computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was conducted confirm his condition following the suspicion raised by the sudden onset of his pain and his historical profile.  Diagnosis  The CTA revealed a type A aortic dissection extending from the ascending aorta proximally to the iliac arteries distally. Mr. Smith's elevated blood pressure was suggestive of his aortic dissection.  Treatment  Due to the location of dissection (Type A)  Mr. Smith underwent emergency surgery. A spinal drainage catheter was placed to monitor and reduce the risk of paraplegia. Beta-blockers were administered to control his blood pressure  in addition to this he was recommended to maintain a low sodium diet to manage his hypertension post-surgery.  Prognosis  Post-discharge  Mr. Smith remained stable and compliant with his antihypertensive medications. He was enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program and has been following up regularly with out-patient cardiology. He was highly recommended to maintain a healthy lifestyle  including a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  and regular check-ups to monitor his aortic health.  Conclusion  This case exemplifies the importance of rapid diagnosis and treatment in cases of aortic dissection  a life-threatening condition that presents with sudden chest or upper back pain. For patients with aortic dissection  surgery or medical management depending on the type of dissection is foundational  but the importance of continued medical management  lifestyle changes  and regular follow-up cannot be underestimated.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male  Mr. X  presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset  severe chest pain that radiates to his back and has lasted for approximately 2 hours. The pain is described as 'tearing' in nature. He states that this type of pain is unlike anything he has experienced before. His past medical history consists of hypertension  for which he has been poorly compliant with his prescribed medication due to forgetfulness and fear of side effects. He also has a history of smoking  consuming a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He denies any history of alcohol or illicit drug use.   Family history revealed that both his father and brother had experienced a heart attack at the ages of 58 and 60 respectively. His father also had a known history of high blood pressure.   On examination  his blood pressure is found to be higher in his right arm (200/120 mmHg) compared to his left (180/100 mmHg). He also displays a weak left radial pulse compared to the right. He is diaphoretic and appears to be in distress.  Lab tests reveal slightly elevated troponin (0.05 ng/mL  with the normal range being 0.00-0.03 ng/mL) and D-dimer (0.55 µg/mL  with the normal range being 0.00 - 0.50 µg/mL). His EKG shows nonspecific ST segment changes.   Due to his history  symptoms  and clinical presentation  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) is ordered  which confirms the suspicion of aortic dissection  illustrating a Stanford type A dissection starting from the ascending aorta and extending to the iliac arteries.   This case is of importance as it displays the demographic disparities seen in aortic dissection patients. African Americans and men  particularly those around 60-70 years old  are often seen in literature as being at higher risk of aortic dissection. Hypertension is also especially prevalent in this demographic and a major risk factor  making this case fairly typical. The patient's disregard for his anti-hypertensive medication and his heavy smoking habit also contribute to his elevated risk of vascular events like aortic dissection. The presence of cardiovascular disease in his family further raises this risk.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. E  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male currently living in an urban area. He presents today due to sudden  severe chest pain that he describes as ""tearing"" in nature and which started a couple of hours ago. The intensity of pain was 8/10  radiating towards his upper back. He has accompanying symptoms of mild dizziness and nausea. He has no known allergies.  Past Medical History:  Mr. E has a history of hypertension for the past ten years and is currently under medication  using Lisinopril 20mg daily and Metroprolol 50mg twice daily. He also has a history of smoking for about 30+ years which he quit five years ago. He has no other significant disease history.  Family History:  There is a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 70. He has two brothers  both of them are also hypertensive.  Social History:  He is a retired military officer  currently living with his wife. He has two grown children who are healthy. He quit smoking five years ago. His alcohol consumption is moderate  up to 2 times per week.  Physical Examination:  Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 185/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  and respiratory rate 24 breaths/minute. On physical examination  his left radial pulse is weaker than the right. Auscultation of the chest reveals normal lung sounds and a faint early diastolic murmur. There are no signs of heart failure (e.g.  peripheral edema  jugular venous distention) or neurologic deficits. The Stanford classification of aortic dissection was Type B (involving descending aorta only) according to the CT scans.  Impression:  The patient was diagnosed with aortic dissection based upon his presenting symptoms  history of hypertension  and CT findings. His case represents a typical presentation of an older  male patient with a known history of hypertension and smoking  which are among the highest risk factors for aortic dissection.  Plan:  The patient was admitted to the hospital for observation and management. A team of cardiothoracic surgery was consulted to discuss possible intervention. The patient was told to remain on absolute bed rest  with antihypertensive treatment titrated to achieve the lowest blood pressure that maintains adequate organ perfusion. He was also offered psychological comfort measures to counter fear and anxiety-related factors that could contribute to hypertension.

Patient Information: The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male  a retired lawyer residing in a suburban area of Idaho. The patient is married with two grown-up children who live separately.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for the last 10 years and was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 6 years ago. He also has a 30 pack-year history of smoking  but quit 2 years back. In his early 50s  the patient was diagnosed with coronary artery disease  for which he underwent a coronary bypass graft surgery approximately 7 years ago.  Presenting Complaint: He presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest and upper back pain. He described it as 'tearing' and 'ripping.' Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  dizziness  and profuse sweating.  Family History: The patient's father passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 72. His mother  87  is still alive with a history of hypertension and arthritis. His younger brother  aged 59  recently suffered from a stroke.  Physical Examination and Diagnostics: Upon examination  the patient appeared in distress with a noted blood pressure disparity between his arms. His left arm BP was 160/85 mmHg  while in the right arm  it was 130/80 mmHg. His heart sounds were normal  but a faint early diastolic murmur was detected. Initial ECG findings revealed a nonspecific ST-T wave abnormality.   Given the classic presentation and discrepancies in arm blood pressures  the suspicion for aortic dissection was high. A computed tomographic angiography (CTA) was performed  which revealed an extensive type A aortic dissection starting from the ascending aorta and extending into the descending thoracic aorta.  Management and Outcome: The patient was emergently taken to the operating room for surgical repair of the aortic dissection. He underwent successful procedures including a Bentall procedure with aortic valve  root  and ascending replacement. Four weeks post-op  his recovery is uneventful  and he is enrolled in a hypertension control management program  with a plan for stringent control of his blood pressure and hyperlipidemia in the future.  Discussion: This case highlights the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and other vascular risk factors who present with sudden severe chest or back pain. The emphasis should be on early diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention  which significantly improves survival rates.

Patient Presentation:  Subject: A 63-year-old African American male named Mr. Davis.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Davis arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to the back.  Past Medical History: He is diagnosed with hypertension but is inconsistent with medication and follow-up visits to his primary care physician. Yesterday  he experienced restlessness and discomfort that made him fail to sleep through the night. He has a significant history of tobacco use (one pack per day for the last 40 years) and is a social drinker but denies any illicit drug use. No known allergies are reported.   Family History: His father passed away from a myocardial infarction in his late 50s. Two of his paternal uncles were also diagnosed with heart-related conditions.  Social History: Mr. Davis is retired and lives with his wife and has two children  who are both in their late 30s.   Physical Examination: On arrival  Mr. Davis looked uncomfortable and was diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 180/110 mmHg on his right arm and 170/90 mmHg on his left arm. His radial pulse rate was regular at 110 per minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. His cardiovascular examination revealed a significant pulse differential between the upper and lower limbs.  Investigations: Laboratory tests showed elevated troponin T levels; chest X-Rays showed an enlarged mediastinal shadow. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed an intimal flap in the ascending aorta. CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis of ascending aortic dissection  Stanford type A.  Management: Given the patient's critical condition  he was stabilized with medication to control his blood pressure and referred to cardiothoracic surgery for emergency surgical intervention.  Discussion: Mr. Davis's case typifies the connection of aortic dissection with uncontrolled hypertension. His medical history  race  gender  and age align with demographic patterns observed for this condition  with men being more predisposed than women  African Americans having higher risks  and the average age group being 60-70 years. Timely intervention is crucial due to the life-threatening nature of the condition.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information:  The patient being discussed is a 63-year-old African-American male from a middle-class socioeconomic background. He is recently retired  once working as an automotive technician. The patient lives with his wife. He has three adult children  none of whom live with them. He doesn't smoke or drink  but is known to have a high-sodium diet.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of controlled hypertension for the past 15 years and has been taking antihypertensive drugs regularly. He was also previously diagnosed with high cholesterol. He doesn't have any history of any other significant disease in the past such as diabetes  kidney disease  or chest trauma. The patient suffers from obesity and a BMI of 31.5 falls into the category of Class 1 obesity.  Family History:  The patient has a family history of hypertension as his father had a stroke at the age of 70 and his mother underwent hypertensive emergencies during her later years.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient arrived at the Emergency Department complaining of acute onset of severe chest and upper back pain that started 2 hours ago. He described it as 'tearing' and 'radiating'. He also felt weak  short of breath  and nauseous but denied any loss of consciousness  speech or vision disturbances or palpitations.  Diagnosis:  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared pale and sweaty  with a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg and a heart rate of 105 BPM. Due to the clinical suspicion of an aortic dissection  a CT angiogram was immediately performed  which confirmed a Type A (ascending) aortic dissection extending from the aortic root to the level of left subclavian artery.  Management:  The patient was subsequently started on intravenous beta-blockers to lower his heart rate and reduce the force of cardiac contraction  thereby easing the pressure on the aorta. The patient was also given intravenous nitroprusside to control his blood pressure. An emergent referral to Cardiothoracic Surgery was made for definitive surgical repair of the dissected aorta.  Discussion:  Aortic dissection is a serious condition where there is a tear in the aorta's inner layer  causing blood to surge through the tear  causing the inner and middle layers to separate (dissect). If the blood-filled channel ruptures through the outside aortic wall  aortic dissection is usually fatal.  Although it can affect anyone  it's more common in men and people aged over 60. Aortic dissection is relatively rare. The condition most frequently happens in the ascending aorta (Type A) and can extend into the aortic arch  descending aorta or even the abdomen.  Risk factors include uncontrolled high blood pressure (hypertension)  atherosclerosis  age  and certain genetic conditions such as Marfan syndrome. Lifestyle factors like smoking  poor diet  obesity  high cholesterol can also contribute to the risk.  Survival and prognosis depend significantly on rapid diagnosis and appropriate management strategies. Early surgical correction is associated with better outcomes. However  despite all medical advances  aortic dissection remains a condition with high morbidity and mortality.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. X is a 60-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension and smoking  who presented to the emergency department with sudden  severe chest pain radiating towards his back. His BMI calculated at 32  indicating obesity. He has a 20-pack year history of smoking but quit 2 years prior to presentation. His hypertension has been moderately managed on Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide. He denies alcohol use and doesn't have diabetes.   Family history reveals that his father had a stroke at the age of 65 and his mother died of myocardial infarction in her late 50s. He has a paternal uncle diagnosed with Marfan's syndrome. Mr. X’s first cousin died prematurely in his 40s due to aortic dissection. There is no family history of high cholesterol or familial hypercholesterolemia.  On examination  his blood pressure was significantly different in both arms. A murmur was heard during chest auscultation and his pulses in the right leg were feeble when compared to the pulses in the left.   Investigations:  A CT angiogram revealed a Type A aortic dissection starting just above the aortic valve and extending up to the level of renal arteries. Laboratory tests showed an elevation in D-dimer level. His complete blood count  renal functions  lipid profile  and liver functions were within normal limits.   Working Diagnosis:  Given the clinical and radiologic findings  a diagnosis of aortic dissection was confirmed. His hypertension  smoking history  obesity  and likely genetic predisposition (based on his first cousin's history) seem to have significantly contributed to this diagnosis.  Management:  Mr. X was immediately started on aggressive anti-hypertensive therapy with intravenous beta-blockers and vasodilators to control the blood pressure and heart rate  reducing the force exerted on the aortic wall. Emergency surgery is being planned for aortic repair  owing to the patient's unstable condition and the dissection involving the ascending aorta.  Prognosis:  His prognosis is difficult to predict given the emergency nature of his condition  but early intervention can decrease morbidity and mortality rates associated with this condition.  The take-home message is to consider aortic dissection in patients with risk factors such as hypertension  family history  smoking  and obesity  who present with acute chest or back pain. Aortic dissection is a surgical emergency requiring prompt diagnosis and aggressive management.

Patient Profile:  The patient is a 59-year-old African American male  holding an administrative job at a local company. He is a non-smoker and drinks moderately. He has a BMI of 29  falling under the overweight category. His father and grandfather both died of heart-related issues in their 60s.  Presenting Complaint:  He presented to the Emergency Department with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the back. He described it as a tearing sensation  with a pain scale of 9/10.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension for the past 15 years  moderately managed with Lisinopril and Hydralazine. He had been non-compliant with his medication quite frequently in the last two months. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago  which is currently being managed with Metformin and a strict diet regime.  Examination:  Upon examination  his blood pressure was alarmingly high at 220/130 mm Hg  and the rest of his vitals were unstable due to acute distress. His heart sounds had a normal rhythm  and no murmur was appreciated. His lungs were clear to auscultation. A noticeable difference of pulse rates in both upper limbs was observed.  Investigations:  Lab investigations showed an increase in leukocytes  and D-dimer was significantly elevated. Electrocardiogram (ECG) did not show any acute ischemic changes. An urgent computerized tomography angiogram (CTA) showed a dissection of the ascending aorta  thus confirming an aortic dissection.  Diagnosis:  Given his medical history of hypertension  male gender  race  the sudden onset of a tearing chest pain radiating to the back  indicating a possible involvement of the aorta  high blood pressure on examination  different pulse rates in the upper limbs  and corroborated by the confirmatory evidence from the CTA  the diagnosis of an aortic dissection was made.  Management:  He was immediately managed in the ICU with aggressive blood pressure control using IV beta-blockers and sodium nitroprusside drip to keep his systolic blood pressure around 100 - 120 mm Hg. Further management entailed prompt surgical intervention  involving placement of a graft in the ascending aorta. His postoperative period was uneventful.  Social History:  On further discussion  we learned patient was under significant stress at work  leading to poor compliance to medication. Post-discharge education focused on adherence to medication  regular follow-ups  blood pressure self-monitoring  stress management  and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.  The case presentation has tried to incorporate pertinent information about the patient  reflecting the complexity of the patients typically seen in clinical practice. Because demographic representation points to a higher incidence rate in African-American males and in those with a family history of cardiovascular diseases  these elements were integrated into the patient profile. The case also emphasized the critical role of risk factors like uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  stress  and poor drug compliance in progressing to aortic discharges.

Patient Presentation  Name: Mr. Joseph Martinez Age: 58 years old  Race: Hispanic    Occupation: High School Physical Education Teacher  Residence: Albuquerque  New Mexico  USA   Chief Complaint: Sudden and severe chest pain radiating to the back.  Past Medical History: Mr. Martinez has been a hypertensive patient for the last ten years  managed on antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril). Despite recommendations for lifestyle changes  Mr. Martinez has struggled with chronic obesity (BMI 32) and has an extensive smoking history  about a pack-day for 20 years.   Family History:  There's a history of cardiovascular disease on Mr. Martinez's paternal side; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.   Presentation:  Mr. Martinez presented in the Emergency Department (ED)  complaining of sudden severe chest pain that he described as ""tearing"" which started an hour prior to his coming to the ED. The pain radiated to his back.   On examination  he was diaphoretic  pale  and appeared distressed. His blood pressure was markedly asymmetrical: 180/95 mmHg in the right arm and 150/90 mmHg in the left arm.   Further diagnostic tests  including a computed tomography angiogram (CTA)  confirmed an ascending aortic dissection  requiring immediate surgical intervention.   The patient was started on intravenous esmolol to lower his blood pressure and heart rate  following which  he was rushed to operating theatre for an emergency surgical repair.  Patient's Course: Mr. Martinez underwent successfully a Bentall procedure. Postoperative recovery was complicated by wound infection requiring prolonged hospital stay  but his recovery trajectory was otherwise favourable at his recent follow-up visit.  Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of considering aortic dissection in patients with severe  sudden onset chest pain  particularly in those with risk factors like hypertension  smoking history  family history of cardiovascular disease and older age.   Aortic dissection mortality is high  but prompt recognition and surgical intervention can significantly alter the course of the disease  as illustrated in Mr. Martinez's case. As his high school's physical education teacher  Mr. Martinez's active role in his school community and his plans to advocate for healthier lifestyles in his students may serve as an opportunity for primary prevention interventions within this community.

Patient Presentation  Patient X is a 67-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with aortic dissection. He is a retired mechanic who lives with his wife and has two grown daughters. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol socially.  Past Medical History:  Patient X has a history of hypertension  diagnosed around 10 years ago  for which he has been prescribed Lisinopril. There is mild control but the patient occasionally misses doses. In the past  he has been treated for elevated cholesterol levels  managed effectively with statins. He had been diagnosed and treated for peptic ulcer disease around 12 years ago. There are no previous surgical interventions in his medical history.  Present Illness:  He presented to the emergency department with a complaint of intermittent severe chest pain radiating to his back  episodes of shortness of breath  and occasional dizziness for the past 4-5 days.  Family History:  His father died of myocardial infarction at 72 years  and his mother had a stroke at 79 years. His older brother has been managing diabetes and hypertension  while his younger sister has an underactive thyroid.  Examination:  On examination  the patient showed varied blood pressure readings in both arms. A radiological investigation (CT) confirmed a diagnosis of aortic dissection. Laboratory findings showed mildly elevated cardiac troponins and he had an elevated D-dimer level. EKG highlighted nonspecific T wave abnormalities and left ventricular hypertrophy.   Summary:  Given the patient's age  long history of smoking  and untreated hypertension  he is in the high-risk group for aortic dissection. These factors  combined with his family's heart-related health history  justify this diagnosis. He is scheduled for emergency intervention and long-term management includes lifestyle modifications such as smoking cessation  regular medication for hypertension and regular follow-ups.  This case highlights that regular monitoring and effective control of blood pressure in hypertensive patients  especially with other risk factors  is of paramount importance to prevent severe conditions like aortic dissection.   NOTE: This case is a representative case typically found in the literature and does not disclose any information about a real patient. Always ensure to provide personalized care tailored to each patient’s individual circumstances.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: A 62-year-old African American male.  Presenting Complaint: Severe back pain  described as sharp and tearing  extending down the back  with associated shortness of breath and dizziness.  Past Medical History:  Hypertension diagnosed 12 years ago  poorly controlled. Non-smoker  occasional alcohol drinker  BMI within an acceptable range. No history of diabetes or hypercholesterolemia.  Family History: Mother died at age 72 due to myocardial infarction. A paternal uncle had an unknown cardiovascular disease.  Social History: Retired engineer  widower  lives alone  2 adult children living in another city.  Clinical Examination: On clinical examination  the patient was in distress due to pain. Vital signs showed blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  and respiratory rate of 24/min. Examination showed unequal pulses in upper limbs. The cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur. The remainder of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigations: Blood tests revealed a slight increase in D-dimer. CT angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of aortic dissection  starting just after the origin of the left subclavian artery  and extending to the common iliac arteries.  Diagnosis: Type B Aortic dissection.  Plan/Therapeutics: The patient was immediately started on intravenous beta-blockers to control heart rate and blood pressure. The patient was referred for urgent vascular surgical consultation for potential endovascular aortic repair.  In doing so with this hypothetical patient  it is important to understand his high risk for aortic dissection is primarily due to his history of poorly controlled hypertension and his family history of cardiac disease  both factors often documented in literature. The demographic background of the patient also raises interest  as studies indicate that aortic dissection has a higher incidence among males and African American individuals.  Please note:  This is a simulated case for educational purposes and should not be used as a medical reference.

Case Report: Patient Information: Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year old Hispanic male  Past Medical History: Known case of Chronic Hypertension  Moderate Alcohol usage (20 years)  and History of Cigarette Smoking.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez presented in the ER with high-intensity chest pain that began sudden and peaked within minutes of its occurrence. The pain is described as tearing or ripping in character  radiating to the back between the shoulder blades. He also reported a feeling of faintness and severe anxiety. He denied experiencing any other associated symptoms such as sweating  nausea  vomiting  or palpitations remarkably.   It's important to consider that aortic dissection occurs more commonly in males aged 60-80 years and is also more common in the Black population  but with higher mortality in the white population. Risk factors highlighted in the case  such as hypertension  smoking and alcohol use  accurately represent the risk factors found in literature.  This case should provide a good cue for students about the possibility of an aortic dissection with acute onset tearing chest pain radiating to the back  especially in patients with a history of hypertension or other risk factors. They should learn the importance of immediate diagnostic steps  considering this as a surgical emergency. An inclusion of physical exam findings like differences in upper extremity pulse or blood pressure strengths  a new aortic insufficiency murmur  neurologic symptoms and so on into the case can demonstrate the high index of suspicion required for diagnosing aortic dissection. To further complicate the scenario  the clinical case could be developed to mimic myocardial infarction symptoms  reminding students of the fine differentiation required in real-life scenarios.

Patient Case:  Patient Information: Mr. Jerry Johnson  a 65-year-old African American retired military officer  presented to the emergency department in late evening. He lives with his wife in a suburban home and is a lifelong non-smoker with a moderate alcohol intake restricted to social events.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a known diagnosis of hypertension which has been inconsistently managed over the past ten years. He has no known allergies. His family history includes a father who died suddenly in his 50s of a presumed heart attack and a brother with coronary artery disease.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Johnson reported a sudden onset of severe chest pain  like a ""ripping"" sensation  earlier in the evening  which radiated to his back and intensified over a span of hours. He reported shortness of breath and feeling lightheaded but denied sweating  nausea  or vomiting. He also mentioned a vague sensation of weakness in his legs.   Reason for demographics:  The majority of aortic dissection cases typically occur in men aged 60-80 years. It is slightly more common in African Americans than Caucasians. Hypertension is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection. While Mr. Johnson does not smoke  which is also a risk factor  his hypertension and family history of sudden death and heart disease increases his likelihood of having an aortic dissection. Representing Mr. Johnson as a retired military officer may suggest a prior lower risk lifestyle  indicating the prominence of his poorly controlled hypertension as a major risk factor in his current condition.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Mr. Thompson  a 62-year-old African-American male with a history of untreated hypertension and smoking  presented to the emergency department.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson had been diagnosed with hypertension five years ago but had been non-compliant with his medication due to financial issues. He also admitted to a 40-year history of smoking  although he has significantly reduced his tobacco use in the past decade. His family history revealed his father had died at the age of 58 from a stroke  also having had untreated hypertension.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Thompson arrived at the ER complaining of a sudden  severe chest pain that radiated to his back  describing it as ""tearing"" in nature. The pain had started roughly an hour before his presentation. He also reported a sudden onset of sweating and feelings of anxiety. Upon further questioning  the patient admitted to vague symptoms of fatigue  malaise  and shortness of breath over the last several weeks  which he attributed to his work demand.  Note: Aortic dissection is more common in men  frequently in the sixth to seventh decade of life. There is a higher prevalence amongst African Americans and those with a history of hypertension. The demographic and medical history of this case should sensitize medical students to the significant risk factors and common clinical presentation of aortic dissection.

CASE REPORT  Mr. John Davis is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with sudden  severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back.  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Davis is a retired carpenter with a history of uncontrolled hypertension despite being on regular antihypertensive medications. He also has a 30-years pack history of smoking and is known to consume alcohol occasionally. There is no known family history of aortic or other cardiovascular diseases.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: He reports associated symptoms of slight breathlessness  mild sweatiness and a light-headed feeling  but denies any nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness. He states that the pain started suddenly while he was lifting heavy furniture  describing it as the worst he's ever felt  unlike anything before.   DEMOGRAPHICS: Mr. Davis is a widower residing with his daughter and grandkids in the city for the last decade. He quit his job as a carpenter a year ago due to the declining stamina. His diet is predominantly home-cooked meals per his daughter  but uncontrolled despite medication  hypertension continues to be a problem.   SOCIAL HISTORY: Patient has a history of being a heavy smoker for the past 40 years  with a 30 pack-year history and drinks alcohol occasionally  with a weekly intake of about 6-7 drinks.  STATISTICS: Demographically  Mr. Davis's profile is similar to the majority of individuals diagnosed with aortic dissection  an occurrence more common in males than females with a ratio of 2 or 3:1. The average age at incident is 63 years old  with two peaks in those around the ages of 40 and 70  with the majority of patients being of Caucasian descent. Patients often have a history of smoking  hypertension  and high alcohol consumption.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male  retired military veteran. He is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. The patient lives with his wife and is generally independently functioning.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been on regular medication including Amlodipine (10 mg/day) for hypertension and Atorvastatin (20 mg/day) for hyperlipidemia. There is a recent history of moderate-levels of uncontrolled blood pressure. There is no known history of diabetes mellitus  ischemic heart disease  or rheumatic heart disease. His family history is significant for hypertension in his father.   Key Complaints:  The patient was brought to the emergency department with a complaint of severe  ripping  and sharp chest pain radiating towards the back  which started approximately 1 hour before his admission. He also reported trouble breathing and feeling lightheadedness. Before seeking medical attention  he had an episode of syncope. On arrival to the emergency room  his blood pressure was found to be disproportionately elevated (180/110 mmHg)  and he was conscious but seemed anxious and in distress.  By presenting this case featuring an elderly African American male  we align with reported literature that highlight increased prevalence of aortic dissections in males  individuals in their 60's  as well as those with hypertension  and more frequent among the black population.  Materials in this case report were fictitious and were used for educational purposes only. The descriptions for symptoms and characteristics of diseases were cited from ""Assessment and management of aortic dissection"" published by the Liverpool Heart and Chest hospital in 2014.

Patient Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a high-stress corporate position. He is a pack-a-day smoker with an approximate smoking history of 30 pack-years. He is a moderate drinker and leads a sedentary lifestyle. He lives in a suburban area with his wife. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father passing from a heart attack at age 65 and his brother diagnosed with aortic dissection at age 57.  Past Medical History: Patient has been diagnosed with stage 2 hypertension around a decade ago. However  patient admits to erratic compliance with his antihypertensive medication  frequently missing doses due to forgetting or dismissing its importance. He has no history of diabetes or endocrine diseases. The patient has high cholesterol levels  for which he has been prescribed statin therapy which he infrequently takes as well. He has no known allergies.  Key Complaints: The patient presented into the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden  severe chest pain that started an hour ago. He described the pain as a tearing or ripping sensation in the center of his chest  which seemed to radiate to his back between the scapulae. Along with this  the patient also felt a sense of impending doom  shortness of breath  and a faint feeling. The pain did not alleviate with rest or any changes in position. He denied any gastrointestinal or genitourinary symptoms  any trauma or any recent strenuous activity.  This case study draws upon the fact that aortic dissection occurs in a significantly disproportionate number of middle-aged to older males  particularly with Caucasians being overrepresented. The risk factors  such as hypertension  smoking  high cholesterol  high-stress occupation  and a family history of cardiovascular disease  aligns with the common demographic and health profile associated with this condition.

Patient Information:  Mr. William Smith  a 62-year-old African American male  retired engineer  who doesn't smoke and resides in Durham  North Carolina  reports to the emergency department on a Wednesday evening.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith is known to suffer from uncontrolled hypertension for the past ten years. He has been inconsistent in taking his hypertensive medications. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disorders. His father died due to aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 72. He does not have diabetes  dyslipidemia  or any known allergies. He denies alcohol or drug use.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith primarily complains of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to his back. He also mentions that he has been feeling short of breath for the past few hours. On questioning  he reports having experienced intermittent chest pain over the last week which he dismissed as a result of exhaustion. He also admits to occasional instances of unexplained dizziness and nausea over the past few days.  Mr. Smith's case represents a prevalent demographic for aortic dissection. African Americans are reportedly at higher risk to suffer from aortic dissection  especially over the age of 60. Please note that it's crucial for students to always consider social determinants of health while discerning differential diagnoses and crafting a treatment plan. Mr. Smith's inconsistent adherence to his hypertensive medication regimen and his past medical history make him particularly susceptible to conditions like aortic dissection. Therefore  recordings of his reported symptoms and signs such as severe chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  and dizziness should alert healthcare providers to consider conditions such as aortic dissection  angina pectoris  or myocardial infarction.

Patient Information: Mr. Williams  a 67-year-old African American male who works as a school janitor. He has a past medical history of hypertension which is poorly controlled  as well as a 30-year history of smoking.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain that started suddenly about two hours ago. He describes the pain as sharp and tearing  radiating to his back.  History of Present Illness:  Mr. Williams was at work when he suddenly began experiencing intense chest pain. He said the pain was unlike anything he's ever felt before. The pain intensified progressively with the exertion of his duties and was not relieved by resting. The patient also reports experiencing mild shortness of breath but no dizziness  palpitations or fainting episodes. No symptoms of tingling  numbness  or paralysis were reported. He is not on any anticoagulants.  Past Medical History:  Hypertension  poorly controlled despite medication Longstanding smoker (30 pack-years) No known allergies  Family History: The patient's father died of a heart attack at the age of 73. His mother is alive and has hypertension. He has two brothers  one of whom has diabetes  and the other has heart disease.  Review of Systems: The patient denies any history of recent trauma  headaches  syncope  seizure  stroke  changes in vision  difficulty swallowing  change in bowel or bladder habits  unusual bleeding or bruising.   Current Medications: Hydrochlorothiazide  Amlodipine.  Social History: He has smoked a pack of cigarettes every day for the last 30 years. He drinks beer socially  no illicit drug use. Lives alone since his wife passed away two years ago.  Physical Examination:  Blood pressure: 175/110 mmHg  Pulse: 105/min  Respiratory Rate: 22/min  Temperature: 98.7°F.  Patient appears diaphoretic and anxious  his skin is pale and there are signs of cyanosis in his lips.  This concise case is meant to simulate a real-life scenario of an individual with demographic risk factors - African American male  advanced age  hypertension  smoking - presenting with an aortic dissection. The case is detailed enough to create a differential diagnosis and is followed-up with thought-provoking questions and discussions about the management of such a critical cardiovascular emergency.

Patient Case Report:  TITLE: Acute Aortic Dissection in an Elderly Male Patient   Patient Demographics: Name: “Patient X”    Age: 70 years Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired teacher Residency: Urban  East Coast USA   Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension – Diagnosed 10 years ago. 2. Smoking – 40 pack-years. 3. Occasional alcohol consumption. 4. No known drug allergies.  Key Complaints: Patient X arrived at the emergency department accompanied by his daughter. He complains of a sudden onset of severe chest pain  which he described as 'ripping' in nature that started a few hours ago. The pain seems to radiate to his back  more toward the interscapular region. He also mentioned experiencing shortness of breath  mild profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. He denies any abdominal pain  nausea  or vomiting. No recent physical exertion or emotional stress was reported prior to the episode. He states that his hypertension medication helps control his blood pressure  but he has been irregular with it over the past few months.  NOTE: As per the literature  acute aortic dissection incidence is more common in males and peaks in the 7th decade of life  thus a male patient in his 70s is chosen. Hypertension is the most significant risk factor and is present in as many as 75% of cases. Smoking is also a contributing factor. African Americans are also at a disproportionately higher risk for aortic dissections. The key complaints presented are typical of aortic dissection  providing students with a hands-on learning situation.

Case Presentation:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Allen Hawthorne  a 68-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department (ED) at 8 am on the 20th of March. He is a retired lawyer  married with three adult children. Mr. Hawthorne is a non-smoker  with a moderate consumption of alcohol (i.e.  3-4 standard drinks per week). He leads a primarily sedentary lifestyle after his retirement  without any notable exercise routine.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Hawthorne was diagnosed with uncontrolled hypertension around ten years ago  resistant to multiple treatment regimens. For the last three years  Mr. Hawthorne has been on a treatment regimen of a calcium channel blocker  an ACE-Inhibitor  and a thiazide diuretic  without much improvement in his blood pressure.   He reported a myocardial infarction (MI) eight years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty. Other than cardiac disease and hypertension  he has no known history of diabetes  dyslipidemia  stroke  or any other chronic illness.   Family history includes sudden cardiac death in his father at age 62  likely secondary to aortic dissection.  Key Complaint:  His chief complaint was an acute onset severe pain  which began at 7:30 am on the day of presentation. Mr. Hawthorne described the pain as a sudden and severe sharp tearing pain in the center of his chest  which radiated to his back. He also complained of accompanying shortness of breath and palpitations  but denied symptoms of nausea  vomiting  syncope  or diaphoresis.  Mingling medical professionalism and empathy  the medical team's primary objective is to deliver prompt diagnosis and management for this gentleman  bearing in mind that individuals aged over 60  African American  male  as well as those with a history of longstanding hypertension and cardiovascular disease are at increased risk for aortic dissection as noted in existing literature.  Subsequent sessions will review diagnostic tools  management principles  and preventative strategies in aortic dissection  using Mr. Hawthorne's case as a starting point for focused learning.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection   Patient Demographics:   Mr. Williams  a 66-year-old African American male  presents himself to the emergency department. He is an ex-smoker with a 40-pack year history but quit ten years ago  drinks alcohol moderately  and is currently retired from a career in finance. He is from an urban setting and is married with grown-up children.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Williams was previously diagnosed with hypertension  controlled with medication for the past 20 years. He has no record of prior hospitalizations or surgeries  and there is no history of congenital heart disease. He has a BMI of 29  falling in the 'overweight' category. His cardiovascular risk factors include high cholesterol and a family history of heart diseases  with his father passing away from an acute myocardial infarction at the age of 70. Mr. Williams maintains a moderate activity level with brisk walking as his primary exercise.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Williams presents with an abrupt onset of severe chest pain that started approximately 4 hours before arriving at the emergency department. He describes the pain as sharp  ""tearing""  and radiating to his back  also associated with a sensation of extreme anxiety. He self-administers his usual  as-needed nitroglycerin with no relief. He also mentions feelings of shortness of breath but denies any other associated symptoms like dizziness  nausea  vomiting  or sweating. When asked  he states he has never experienced anything like it in the past.  Clinical Presentation:  On examination  Mr. Williams has a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg on the right arm and 155/85 mmHg on the left arm  pulse rate is 102 beats/min  and respiratory rate is 24 breaths/min. On auscultation  no murmurs are heard. His pain score is 9/10. Other systemic examinations are unremarkable.   Based on his clinical presentation  demographic and risk factors  aortic dissection is suspected and further diagnostic procedures are indicated.   [N.B: Aortic dissection has a higher incidence in males  and even more so in the black population. Moreover  it typically presents in the sixth to seventh decade and is commonly associated with hypertension  smoking  high cholesterol  obesity  and family history of cardiovascular diseases. Emotional stress can sometimes be a triggering factor  which is plausible in our patient's retirement life.]

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient's information: Name: John Doe Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: African-American  Past Medical History: Patient has a 15-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 10-year history of type II diabetes mellitus. In addition  he reports to have a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit 13 years ago. His father died of a stroke at the age of 72.  Key Complaints: The patient came into the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of sudden onset  severe chest pain that started at rest. The pain is described as sharp and tearing  radiating to his back. The patient also reports mild shortness of breath. He denies associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  dizziness  or loss of consciousness. Physical examination indicates a blood pressure discrepancy between arms and a weak femoral pulse.  Discussion: This case is designed to represent a typical case of a patient at risk for aortic dissection. According to literature  this condition is most likely to occur in men aged between 60 and 70 years. It is also more common in African Americans as compared to Caucasians. Risk factors include hypertension  smoking and family history  all of which are incorporated into this patient's past medical history. The key complaint of chest pain radiating to the back is characteristic of aortic dissection and should raise suspicions. The physical exam findings can further point to aortic dissection.

Case Study: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Anderson Age: 69 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Army General Location: Colorado Springs  Colorado. Insurance: Medicare  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a medical history of essential hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  which is under control with medication (thiazide diuretics) and lifestyle changes. He is also a former smoker of 30 years and stopped smoking around 20 years ago. He has mild atherosclerosis noted in his last cardiology review a year ago. He is non-diabetic  has no history of any heart disease or surgeries  and maintains a fairly active lifestyle for his age. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease with his father having had a stroke at 72.  Key Complaints: Mr. Anderson was enjoying a quiet mid-day meal when he experienced a severe  sharp  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The extreme discomfort caused him to sweat profusely and feel nauseated. The pain was sudden and did not subside on rest  unlike a chest pain typical of angina which he occasionally experienced during his morning walks. The severity of it prompted him to immediately reach out to his neighbor  who called for an ambulance. In the ambulance  the complaining of his symptoms did not relent. The paramedics noted an episode of syncope but were able to revive him with no cognitive impairment.  This case report presents a typical scenario of an aortic dissection for your medical students. The elements highlighted such as demographic information  medical history  and symptom presentation can act as potential indicators for considering aortic dissection as a diagnosis. Please note that aortic dissection is more common in males  and the average age at presentation is between 60 and 70 years of age. Risk factors include hypertension  smoking  age  atherosclerosis  and a family history of cardiovascular disease.

Patient Case:  Name: John Smith Age: 66 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Complaint: John came to the ER complaining of severe chest pain that started suddenly while watching television at home. The pain is described as sharp  ripping or tear-like  located in the center and upper part of his chest and radiating to his back. He also reports shortness of breath and excessive sweatiness.  Past Medical History: John's medical history includes hypertension  controlled with hydrochlorothiazide  which he has been taking for about 8 years. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  but he quit smoking around 20 years ago. He reports a couple of episodes of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) but no confirmed stroke or myocardial infarction. No known drug allergies. Family history of aortic dissection in his late father.  Review of Systems: On cardiovascular review  Smith admitted to intermittent episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea but denies any pedal edema or orthopnea. He has been experiencing fatigue and unintended weight loss over the past six months.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appears acutely distressed. His initial vitals show blood pressure of 200/110 mm Hg and pulse rate of 100 bpm. The pulses in his right arm are weaker compared to his left arm. No significant murmurs or pericardial rub are identified on auscultation. Lung fields are clear.  Based on the case above  students will continue with potential diagnosis  investigations  and treatment options for a patient who presents with findings suggestive of an aortic dissection.  Demographics in this case  such as age  gender  and a history of hypertension  align with epidemiological data suggesting that aortic dissection most commonly affects men aged 60-70  and hypertension is a known risk factor. John's smoking history further increases his risk  and his family history indicates a potential genetic predisposition.

Case Study: Aortic Dissection   Patient Information: Mr. J  a 65-year-old African-American male with a BMI of 32.  Past Medical History: Mr. J has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 20 years  smoking for 40-pack years  and a familial history of heart diseases. He was diagnosed with moderate arteriosclerosis three years ago. His current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril.  Key Complaints: Mr. J arrived at the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain which began three hours ago. The pain was described as sharp  tearing  and radiating to his back. He also reported shortness of breath  mild confusion  and a feeling of anxiety.  Note: Aortic dissection is seen more in males than in females  with a ratio of approximately 2 to 3:1. Also  the average age at diagnosis is approximately 63 years. Hypertension is a major risk factor  present in two-thirds of patients. Smoking represents another risk  contributing to inflammation and oxidative stress in the aortic wall  producing degeneration of its structure. Familial predispositions are noted in nearly 20% of cases of thoracic aortic aneurysms and dissections. African-American populations have higher risk for hypertensive heart disease and related complications like an aortic dissection.

Case Study: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. Albert Johnson Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: African-American  Occupation: Retired civil engineer Residential Location: Urban residence   Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension for 15 years  irregularly controlled. 2. Type II diabetes mellitus for 10 years  under control with oral hypoglycemic agents. 3. Previous smoker  having quit 5 years ago. 4. Myocardial infarction 3 years ago  managed with medical therapy and lifestyle modification. 5. Father died of a stroke in his late 60s.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Johnson repeats his earlier call to his primary care physician  informing them about severe chest pain that started about an hour ago while he was having his morning coffee. The pain is tearing and radiates to his back between the shoulder blades. He describes the onset as sudden and states that the pain's intensity is unlike anything he has ever experienced before. He also mentions feeling sweaty and has vomited once since the pain began.   This case represents a typical scenario for aortic dissection  considering our patient's age group  ethnicity  and a history of hypertension—factors that are commonly associated with the condition according to medical literature. The specific nature of the pain  its abrupt onset  and the patient's underlying cardiovascular diseases should guide learners towards considering aortic dissection in their differential diagnoses.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson is a 63-year-old African-American male. He works as a construction worker and is a habitual smoker with around 40 pack-years history.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension about eight years ago but has been non-compliant with antihypertensive medications. He states he occasionally takes Metoprolol whenever he feels his 'pressure is high'. He has had no hospitalizations or surgeries in the past. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  his father died at 65 from a heart attack. His BMI is 29 indicating overweight and living in a food desert  his diet is noticeably unhealthy.  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain that surged in intensity around an hour ago. He described the pain as 'tearing' and rated it 10/10. The pain seemed to radiate to the back  especially between the shoulder blades. He appeared diaphoretic and pale. In addition  he admitted to feeling weak and almost faint.  (Note: African Americans and males are statistically at a higher risk for aortic dissection  with a peak incidence in the 6th and 7th decades of life  hence the demographics for this case. Hypertension and smoking are major risk factors for aortic dissection.)

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. X is a 65-year-old African-American male  retired construction worker  residing in an urban environment. He is a smoker with a 40-pack-year history and has moderate alcohol consumption habits.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has a medical history significant for hypertension (well-controlled on prescribed medication)  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of early Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) in his father (died from a heart attack at the age of 53). He has no history of surgeries or allergies. The patient is on regular medication for hypertension (amlodipine) and hyperlipidemia (simvastatin).  Presenting Complaints: Mr. X presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset  severe chest pain of about 2 hours duration. He described the pain as 'tearing' that started at the center of his chest and radiated to his back. The pain was not associated with exertion and did not improve with rest. Accompanying symptoms were profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and a feeling of faintness.  This case effectively illustrates a high-risk individual predisposed to aortic dissection  considering the demographic probability  established risk factors like hypertension  smoking  and a family history of CVD. According to the literature  these elements raise the overall likelihood statistically and provide a useful teaching opportunity. The characteristic symptoms presented in this case should help medical students distinguish this medical emergency from other differential diagnoses such as myocardial infarction or musculoskeletal chest pain. This teaching case can be further used to discuss the importance of timely intervention and management of aortic dissection  thereby reducing morbidity and mortality.

Patient Case Report:  Patient Information and Demographics:   Name: Mr. J.E. Age: 63 years old Sex: Male Race: African-American Occupation: Retired University Professor  Past Medical History: -Hypertension for 15 years -High cholesterol for 10 years  -Former smoker quit 20 years ago -None known drug allergies  Key Complaint:  Mr. JE came into the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset  severe and tearing chest pain that radiated to his back. The pain started an hour ago while he was at home making breakfast. He has been experiencing occasional mild chest discomfort for the past week  but ignored it given his busy schedule. He also reported a feeling of breathlessness and was slightly dizzy since the pain started.  Discussion: Aortic dissection is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition that disproportionately affects men more than women  especially of ages 60 to 70 years old. Hypertension is the number one risk factor associated with aortic dissection. African Americans have slightly higher rates of aortic dissection compared to other racial groups  which is attributed in part to higher rates of hypertension in this population. Symptoms often include sudden and severe chest or upper back pain  often described as ""tearing"" or ""ripping "" along with symptoms like breathlessness and dizziness with potential cardiovascular collapse. It's crucial to consider aortic dissection as an important differential diagnosis in these cases since the consequences of a missed diagnosis are devastating.

Patient Information: Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  a current tobacco user with a 30-pack-year smoking history. He is a retired construction worker  living with his wife  and has three adult children.   Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension for the last 10 years and is on amlodipine 5mg daily. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and takes simvastatin 40mg daily. The patient also reports an incidental finding of a small abdominal aortic aneurysm (3.2 cm) on a CT scan five years ago that has been followed periodically with subsequent scans. Over the past five years  it has shown gradual enlargement. Additionally  his father died from a heart attack at 66 and his mother from a stroke at 70. He denies any diabetes  asthma  or any other known chronic disease.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez reports a sudden  severe  tearing chest pain that started about two hours ago while he was doing yard work. He describes the pain as the worst he has ever experienced. The pain radiates to his back and also mentions a mild associated shortness of breath but denies any nausea or vomiting. He has no reported lightheadedness  palpitations  cough  or fever. Word of the abrupt onset and severity of his pain had scared him  prompting his visit to the emergency department.   Given the patient's history  age  race  and presenting symptoms  aortic dissection should be highly considered  as Hispanic populations and males aged 60-70 are among the most affected demographic groups.  Remember that while hypertension is a risk factor for aortic dissection  it often presents with normal or even low blood pressure due to decreased left ventricular preload from redirection of flow away from the left ventricle. This will be your medical challenge.  The exceedingly sudden onset of severe pain in a hypertensive patient is the clinical hallmark of acute aortic dissection. Therefore  it is vital to consider this in the differential diagnosis urgently to initiate prompt treatment and prevent potentially catastrophic outcomes.

Case Report - Aortic Dissection:  Patient Information:  - Name: Mr. Jackson - Age: 65 years old - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: African American - Occupation: Retired military officer - Social History: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol drinker (moderate)  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension for the past 10 years - Hyperlipidemia - History of smoking (quit 5 years ago) - Family history of cardiovascular diseases (Father died at 56 due to myocardial infarction) - No history of diabetes   Key Complaints:  Mr. Jackson came to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe anterior chest pain. He described it as the worst pain he had ever experienced  and it was radiating towards his back. The pain initiated one hour prior to hospitalization  while he was watching TV.   Mr. Jackson also reported mild shortness of breath but denied symptoms of nausea  vomiting  dizziness  or fainting. He had no symptoms of infective endocarditis  including fever  weight loss  or night sweats. No past history of surgeries were noted.  The above case representation aligns with the demographic profile for aortic dissection  which is more common among males  individuals of African American descent  and particularly those above the age of 60. Factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and family history of cardiovascular diseases are known predispositions for aortic dissection. The acute onset of severe chest pain with radiation towards back is a classic symptom of aortic dissection.

Patient Case:  Patient Information:   Mr. Thomas Lane is a 65-year-old African American male. He used to work in construction; he is now retired  and lives with his wife. He has two grown children and four grandchildren. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes a day  but he stopped drinking alcohol since his retirement  5 years ago.   Past Medical History: Mr. Lane was previously diagnosed with hypertension. Despite regular follow-up visits with his primary physician  control of his blood pressure was not entirely successful. He also has a 10-year history of tobacco use. He does not have a history of diabetes  heart diseases  or any surgeries. There is no family history of cardiovascular diseases.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Lane has come into the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden chest pain. He describes it as a tearing sensation  radiating to his back. He also has slight shortness of breath and feeling flush all over his body. He denies experiencing any nausea  vomiting  or palpitations. His Blood Pressure measurement in the right arm was notably higher than in the left arm.  This case is representative from a demographic perspective  as aortic dissection is more common in men than women  and the average age at the time of disease onset is 60-70 years. The patient's history of hypertension and tobacco use align with two of the primary risk factors for aortic dissection. This case scenario also reflects the typical nature and distribution of pain in aortic dissection  which is often described as a tearing or ripping sensation in the anterior chest or back.

Case Title: Acute Aortic Dissection  Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson is a 60-year-old African-American man currently living in South Dakota. He is a retired military officer living with his wife. He is a heavy smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history  and is known to have high blood pressure for the past ten years  which is managed by hypertensive medication. He also has a family history of heart disease.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Johnson came to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden severe chest pain. He described it as a sharp  tearing sensation in his upper back  between his shoulder blades  which seemed to radiate to his chest. The pain appeared 2 hours before his ED visit  while he was carrying grocery bags.  Clinical Examination: Upon physical examination  there was noted to be a blood pressure difference between his two arms. Auscultation revealed diastolic murmur. He looked visibly distressed due to the pain and had a slight shortness of breath.  Assessment: The sudden onset of severe  cutting chest pain and the difference in blood pressure readings in both arms suggest a possible aortic dissection.  Notes for the Discussion: The case revolves around an African-American male in the appropriate age range where aortic dissections are most common. The demographic representation  including geographical location  age  race  and risk factors  has been adhered to accurately as per medical literature. This case can be utilized to educate medical students about the clinical presentation  risk factors  examination findings  and early identification of acute aortic dissection.   References: Debakey  Michael E.  and Denton A. Cooley. ""Successful resection of aneurysm of thoracic aorta and replacement by graft."" Jama 172.13 (1960): 1256-1259. Coady  Michael A.  et al. ""What is the appropriate size criterion for resection of thoracic aortic aneurysms?."" Journal of thoracic and cardiovascular surgery 113.3 (1997): 476-491.

Case Report: Acute Type A Aortic Dissection   Patient Demographics:  Mr. Johnson  a 63-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department (ED) of our teaching hospital. He is a retired navy officer  lives with his wife and has two adult children. His BMI was in the overweight range.  Past Medical History:  His medical history is significant for chronic hypertension managed with amlodipine and lisinopril for the past 15 years. He has a 20-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father passing away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 65. Mr. Johnson has not had any surgical procedures in the past. Other than that  he has no known drug allergies.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Johnson arrived at the ED complaining of experiencing sudden  severe chest pain for the past few hours. He described it as ""tearing"" and radiating to the back. He also reported mild shortness of breath but denied any other symptoms such as sweating  nausea  or dizziness. He also mentioned he felt an abrupt onset of the pain while lifting some heavy boxes at home.  This case represents an instance of aortic dissection  an emergency condition which is seen more commonly among males  in the age group of 60-70 years. Hypertension is a major risk factor  as seen in this patient  along with smoking history. African American race has also been associated with increased incidence of hypertension as well as aortic disease. The classical presentation of severe 'tearing' chest pain radiating to back should be highlighted to the medical students.  Prepared by: Medical Educator   Date: 25th January 2022

Case Report:  Name: Mr. John Thompson Age: 65 Gender: Male Ethnicity: African American  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 15 years. He is also a current smoker with a 20 pack-year history. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago and has moderate chronic kidney disease secondary to diabetic nephropathy. His medication history includes metformin  lisinopril  and hydrochlorothiazide. He has a known allergy to penicillin leading to rash and itching.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson arrived at the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe chest pain that started while he was lifting some heavy furniture an hour ago. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and ""radiating"" from the chest to his back. The pain was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. He started to experience difficulty breathing  and he had profuse sweating. No associated symptoms of palpitation  nausea  vomiting  or syncope were reported. The patient denied any recent illnesses  trauma  or changes in medication.  This case report example of aortic dissection is in line with the demographic representation in literature (older age  uncontrolled hypertension  male gender  smoking  and African-American ethnicity). It also incorporates classic presentation features such as the sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to the back.

Case Title: Acute Aortic Dissection in a Hypertensive  Smoking Older Adult Male  Patient Information:  Mr. AleX Thompson  a 67-year-old African-American male.  Primary Complaint: Presented to the emergency department (ED) experiencing severe and sudden onset chest pain radiating to his back  along with intermittent bouts of dizziness.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson has lived with uncontrolled hypertension for the past 12 years and has consistently had poor medication compliance. He is a 30 pack-years smoker and has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father experiencing a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. He denies any history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  or known connective tissue disorders.   According to the literature  hypertension is considered to be the major predisposing factor for aortic dissection (accounting for about 72% of cases). Aging  male gender  smoking  and a personal or family history of cardiovascular disease also increase risks. Black men  particularly in America  are disproportionately affected by hypertension and its complications.  Clinical findings on arrival: Mr. Thompson presented with high blood pressure (180/100 mmHg)  tachycardia (110 bpm)  and mild tachypnea. On physical examination  an apparent difference in pulses and blood pressure between arms was notable. Auscultation of the chest revealed a diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left sternal border.   The combination of his primary complaint  demographics  and clinical findings point towards a possible diagnosis of aortic dissection  but further diagnostic procedures are required to confirm this suspicion. This case  therefore  presents an opportunity to discuss differential diagnoses  diagnostic strategies  and management for aortic dissection.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection   Patient Demographics:  Mr. Albert Johnson  a 66-year-old African-American male  retired military personnel.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of persistent essential hypertension and a 25 pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit 15 years ago. His father died at 68 due to a stroke  and his mother had hypertensive heart disease. His lipid profile done a year ago showed borderline high total cholesterol and LDL levels. He is not a diabetic  does not have any respiratory illness  or any history of previous surgeries or major illnesses. Currently  his medications include thiazide diuretics and a beta-blocker for hypertension.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Johnson presented to the Emergency Department with a chief complaint of sudden-onset severe chest pain and shortness of breath. He describes the pain as 'tearing' and 'radiating to the back'. He seemed anxious and worried due to the pain severity.   In this case  we introduce Mr. Johnson  an elderly African-American male with risk factors such as long-term hypertension  previous smoking  and dyslipidemia  representing a demographic that is indeed more prone to aortic dissection  according to the literature. Moreover  his presenting symptoms align with the classic presentation of aortic dissection  a condition that can often be overlooked due to its resemblance to other cardiovascular conditions.   Preceptors can utilize this case to teach students about aortic dissection's risk factors  clinical presentation  diagnostic procedures  and management approach.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male named Mr. Williams. He is an ex-smoker but quit 5 years ago and occasionally consumes alcohol. He is married and lives with his wife in a suburban environment.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Williams has a history of uncontrolled hypertension; his recent clinic appointment revealed a slightly elevated blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus which is fairly controlled (HbA1c 7.2%). He also had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 2 years ago with complete neurological recovery. There is no known drug allergy and he is currently on an aspirin  a statin  an ACE inhibitor  and low dose metformin.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Williams presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with an abrupt onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back. He noted that the pain began while he was mowing his lawn  and it intensified over the next hour. The pain is not associated with shortness of breath  nausea  or diaphoresis. There were no symptoms of stroke or TIA. His current pain severity is about 8 on a scale of 0 to 10.  Note:  The majority of patients with aortic dissection are men  and the mean age at the time of presentation is approximately 63 years. Hypertension is the most common associated condition  present in up to 75% of cases. Aortic dissection occurs more frequently in whites  but the risk of rupture or death is higher in African Americans.  By constructing a case with a minority patient with classic but not stereotypical presentations  you can help students learn to consider a wider range of differential diagnoses and improve their understanding of who can be affected by the medical condition.

Case Study: Aortic Dissection   Patient Profile:  Mr. Richard Thompson is a 68-year-old African American male retired Army veteran  who currently works part time as a security guard. Mr. Thompson lives alone after losing his wife of 30 years to cancer three years ago. He has two adult children and four grandchildren who live out of state but visit frequently.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a known history of hypertension  managed with Amlodipine  and high cholesterol for which he takes Atorvastatin. He has maintained these regimens for five years  with his blood pressure consistently within controlled limits. A smoker for 30 years  he quit the habit 12 years ago. His dietary habits are generally poor – usually skipping breakfast  and opting for fast food options for most meals. He also rarely exercises.
