Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson visits his primary care clinic complaining of severe  sudden-onset chest pain since this morning  which he describes as 'tearing' in nature  radiating to his back. The pain has remained severe with no relief from rest or nitroglycerine spray he had leftover from his late wife's angina treatment. He also notes a sudden shortness of breath and dizziness upon standing  which he attributed at first to stress from work and lack of sleep in the past few days.   The pain is unrelated to eating  deep breathing  movement  or any particular body position. A phone conversation with his son made him realize these symptoms should not be ignored and prompted him to finally visit his physician.  In this scenario  Mr Thompson's demographics align with known statistics  given that aortic dissections are more common in males between 60 to 80  and are more frequently seen in African Americans. The key symptoms of a sudden onset severe chest or upper back pain  often described as ""tearing or ripping"" is characteristic of aortic dissection. Furthermore  uncontrolled hypertension is a major risk factor for aortic dissection  making our patient's case a high probability one.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection – Acute Presentation   Patient Demographics:  Mr. Flores  a Hispanic male aged 67 years  currently residing in San Diego  CA. He is a retired construction worker  married  with three adult children.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Flores has a 10-year history of uncontrolled hypertension. He also suffers from high cholesterol and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus three years ago  which is moderately managed with oral hypoglycemic medications. He has been a smoker for 35 years  although reduced in frequency in the past decade. There is no known drug allergy found in his medical records. He has a family history of coronary artery disease; his father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 71.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Flores reports to the emergency department with acute severe chest pain that began abruptly approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as 'tearing' and says it started in his chest and radiates to his back. The pain is unlike anything he has previously experienced. He also complains of profuse sweating and admits feeling a sense of impending doom. He denies any associated shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or leg pain. Upon examination  one can notice signs of anxiety and discomfort.  According to literature  the majority of aortic dissection patients are male and over 60 years old. Risk factors encompass hypertension  smoking  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of aortic disease. Symptoms typically include sudden  severe chest pain  often described as tearing or ripping  which can radiate to the back.

Case Report: Acute Aortic Dissection in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Demographics: Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old African-American male  currently retired. He has been living in an assisted living facility for the last 2 years and is widowed with three adult children.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a significant history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin  respectively. He also has a history of cigarette smoking for 40 years (one pack per day) but quit 10 years ago. Family history is notable for heart disease  with his father having died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 67. Mr. Johnson exercises irregularly  due to his hip osteoarthritis for which he takes occasional over-the-counter NSAIDs. He has no known allergies.  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest pain that radiated to his back between his shoulder blades. The pain began while the patient was performing his regular morning bathroom routine  which includes light stretching exercises. The pain was described as originating in his chest and then moved to his back over a period of a couple of minutes. Accompanying symptoms included diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and nausea  but no palpitations  headache  or loss of consciousness. The patient reported that the severity of the pain was unlike any he had ever experienced.  The demographic  past medical history  and key complaints of Mr. Johnson align with typical risk factors and symptoms observed in aortic dissection patients  including age  male sex  hypertension  history of smoking  and African American race. The penetrating chest pain  migrating to the back  is the most common clinical symptom in aortic dissection as reported in several literature reviews.

Case Study: Aortic Dissection  Patient Info Name: Mr. James Howard Gender: Male Age: 63 Race/Ethnicity: African American  Past Medical History: Mr. Howard is a retired manual laborer and has a medical background of chronic hypertension. He is a former smoker and quit approximately 15 years ago. He also drinks alcohol moderately. He has a history of occasional chest pains for which he uses over-the-counter antacids  attributing it to indigestion.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Howard visited the hospital Emergency Department complaining of sudden  high-intensity chest pain that radiated to his back. He described the pain as a sharp  tearing sensation. Accompanying these symptoms  he also reported experiencing shortness of breath  profuse sweating  dizziness  and faintness. He mentioned that the chest pain started following physical exertion  and it was unlike his usual indigestion pains.  Family History: No immediate family history of cardiac diseases. His father passed away due to lung cancer and his mother had diabetes mellitus.  Notes: - The patient's symptoms and history fit the demographic and risk factor profile of aortic dissection  with hypertension being a significant predisposing factor.  - Male sex  age above 60 years  and African-American ethnicity make the patient more susceptible to aortic dissections. - The nature of the pain (sharp  tearing)  its sudden onset  location (chest  back)  and accompanying symptoms align with the typical presentation of aortic dissection. - The symptom of chest pain following physical exertion could potentially mislead towards an angina or myocardial infarction diagnosis  re-emphasizing the importance of comprehensive differential diagnosis. - Given the seriousness and urgency of aortic dissection  immediate diagnostic action is required.  [This case is intended for educational purposes only  and should not be taken as medical advice. The patient demographics were selected in line with general trends in aortic dissection epidemiology.]

Patient Case Profile:  Name: Mr. Robert Alvarez Age: 68 years Sex: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Retired School Principal Residence: San Antonio  Texas  Presenting complaints:  Mr. Alvarez presents with a sudden onset of severe  sharp chest pain that he described as ""tearing"" in nature. The pain radiates to his back and feels worse when coughing. He also reports feelings of shortness of breath  mild syncope  and malaise.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Alvarez has a history of poorly controlled hypertension  diagnosed 12 years ago. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father dying of myocardial infarction at 72 years old. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 16 years ago  and drinks alcohol socially.   Rest Medical History: No Diabetes Mellitus  no hyperlipidaemia  and no known kidney diseases. He has not had any surgeries. His current medications include Lisinopril and Amlodipine for blood pressure control.  Allergies: None known. Family History: As mentioned above  cardiovascular diseases have been reported in his family  particularly on his father’s side. Social History: Mr. Alvarez has a history of tobacco use  but quit smoking 16 years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol occasionally but denies any illicit drug usage.  Upon physical examination  Mr. Alvarez appears anxious and in distress. His blood pressure was significantly different in the two arms. Both his lung and heart sounds are normal.  This case presentation is consistent with a patient who could potentially have an aortic dissection. Training based on this case should integrate comprehensive modules on symptom recognition  physical examination findings  diagnostic strategies  risk stratification  and management protocols for aortic dissection. It will help students to better appreciate the critical nature of the disease and equip them with a structured approach to avoid diagnostic delays for better clinical outcomes.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Information: A 69-year-old African-American male.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  managed through medication for the past 15 years. He used to smoke one pack a day for 30 years but quit 10 years back. There is also a history of hyperlipidemia  and the patient is currently on statin medication. He has no known familial history of cardiovascular disease.  Chief Complaints: Presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with acute onset severe chest pain. The pain which is tearing in nature  started suddenly about an hour ago. It's located in the anterior chest region and radiates to the back. The pain didn't relieve with rest.  Notes:  This case was chosen because it includes the most common risk factors associated with aortic dissection: hypertension  male gender  advanced age  smoking history  and hyperlipidemia. While aortic dissection is relatively rare  it is more common in men than women and has a high mortality rate. African Americans have a higher rate of hypertension  which is the most significant risk factor for aortic dissection. The complaint and history are also typical for aortic dissection  with acute severe  tearing  or ripping type chest pain radiating to the back being a 'classic' presentation.   It's important to highlight that while this represents a stereotypical case  aortic dissection can also present atypically and has been reported in younger and otherwise healthy populations. Also  it crucial to stress the importance of a thorough physical exam  diagnostic imaging  and labs to confirm aortic dissection  as well as the gravity and urgency of the situation due to its high mortality rate.

Patient Case:  Mr. Abraham Johnson  a 64-years-old African-American male presenting with sudden serious pains in his chest and back is brought to the emergency department. Abraham  a retired painter  is a resident of Montana  USA  and lives with his wife. They have three grown-up children with grandkids.   Past Medical History:  The patient has controlled hypertension for the past ten years. He has been using daily medication to control blood pressure  namely Lisinopril. He is also a chronic smoker with a history of nearly 45 years of tobacco usage. In addition to hypertension  he also has a history of high cholesterol and mild obesity. As highlighted in his medical records  he has been slightly non-compliant with the prescribed statin therapy for lipid management. Family history reveals that his father died of a heart attack at the age of 70.  Key Complaints:  The patient describes the onset of pain as 'tearing' and 'sharp'  and the pain migrated from his chest to back. He rated it as a severity of 9 on a scale of 10. Accompanying symptoms include dizziness  excessive sweating  and transient loss of consciousness. He also mentioned that he has been feeling unwell with generalized weakness for the past few days. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the chest and back.  Note: Literature suggests men are more likely to experience aortic dissection than women  and it is more common in African Americans than in Caucasians. Age and hypertension are also strong risk factors. Hence  the demographic details and medical history are reflective of these trends. Photosensitive epilepsy should also be considered among possible prognosis  as African Americans and elderly patients are high-risk groups. The presence of tobacco abuse further raises the risk of aortic dissection.

Patient Case:   Demographics:  Mr. Idris  a 62-year-old African-American male  who is married with three grown children. He is a retired truck driver living with his wife in Raleigh  North Carolina. His city living conditions are accommodating  and he enjoys light gardening.  Past Medical History: Mr. Idris is known for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His condition has been somewhat controlled with medications: hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He also has a 40-pack year smoking history  although he quit after a mild heart attack ten years ago. He has no known allergies.  Key Complaints: Mr. Idris was brought in by his wife to the ER complaining of sudden onset severe tearing chest pain that radiated to his back earlier this morning. The pain was so intense that it woke him from his sleep  and the pain was unrelieved with rest or nitroglycerin. He also reported shortness of breath and mild sweating. There were no other associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  or syncope.  Additional Context: Studies have shown that an increased proportion of African-American patients compared with white patients are diagnosed with aortic disease  including dissection  making race an important aspect of our demographic representation here. In addition  more than 75% of individuals who have aortic dissection are male  and the average age of individuals who experience aortic dissection is between 60 and 70 years. Risk factors such as smoking  hyperlipidaemia  and hypertension  as observed in our patient  are also linking factors leading to aortic dissection.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient: Mr. Samuel McKinley  Sex: Male Age: 63 years Race: African American Occupation: Retired fireman Marital Status: Married Location: Urban  Past medical history:   - Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago and poorly controlled with a calcium channel blocker - Current smoker (averaging 20 cigarettes/day) for past 40 years  - History of high cholesterol - Family history of cardiovascular diseases  Presenting Complaints:   Mr. McKinley reported to the emergency department with severe  tearing chest pain that started abruptly while engaging in moderate physical activity. He described it as the worst pain he has ever experienced  and it radiated to the back between his shoulder blades. He felt a sensation of a heavy weight on his chest. An episode of sweating and shortness of breath accompanied the chest pain. He denied any history of recent trauma.  Note: According to literature  aortic dissection is more common in males and in the 6th or 7th decade of life. Risk factors include poorly controlled hypertension  smoking  hypercholesterolemia  and family history of cardiovascular diseases. Most aortic dissections occur in patients with a history of aortic aneurysm or existing atherosclerotic disease. The ethnic disparity with African Americans having higher rates is reflected in this case. Pain  described as a tearing or ripping sensation  usually abrupt at onset is a classic symptom of aortic dissection. The depiction of the patient's occupation and lifestyle contributes to his risk factor profile and could prompt learners to consider socio-economic factors in patient care and management.

Case Study: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:  Name: Jack Steward Age: 67 years old Race: African American Sex: Male Occupation: Retired chemical engineer  Past Medical History:  Mr. Steward has a known history of hypertension  which is well-controlled with medication (Losartan). He quit smoking around 20 years ago after a 30-year habit. Has a family history of atherosclerosis  with his late father having suffered from congestive heart failure. He also has mild obesity and hyperlipidemia. He has undergone regular checkups with primary care and adheres fairly consistently to his medication regimen.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Steward came into the emergency department with sudden and severe chest pain radiating to the back  coupled with feelings of general weakness and dizziness. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and rated it as a 9 out of 10 severity. He also has a slight shortness of breath. He states that he hasn't experienced a similar episode of pain in the past.  On initial examination  blood pressure readings were found to be uneven between the left and right arm  raising the suspicion of aortic dissection. The EKG was normal  however  indicating a need for urgent diagnostic imaging to confirm the suspicion of aortic dissection.   This case report highlights important signs and symptoms for aortic dissection that medical students must be aware of. It also presents the need to correctly interpret clinical signs such as uneven blood pressure amongst other dissection markers. The complexity of the case—characterized by the acute onset of symptoms and a significant background of risk factors like hypertension  age  race  and family history of atherosclerosis—makes it a fitting example for educating medical students effectively.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Carl Thompson  a 65-year-old African American male. He is retired from the US Army and lives in Texas with his wife. Former smoking history  quit 20 years ago. Drinks alcohol occasionally.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a medical history of hypertension  for which he has been receiving treatment for the last eight years. His blood pressure has been reasonably well-controlled with amlodipine 5 mg daily. He also has diagnosed hyperlipidemia and is on atorvastatin. He has not been diagnosed with diabetes  and his BMI is 28 indicating overweight. Family history is notable for a late elder brother who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 68.  Key Complaints: Mr. Thompson presented to the ER with sudden onset severe chest pain which he describes as ""tearing"" that radiated to his back. The pain began approximately 2 hours before  while he was gardening at home. He looks distressed  his left hand was clutching his chest. He also reported shortness of breath  palpitations and mild lightheadedness. The patient denied any symptoms of nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis.   Such clinical scenario is suspected to be an aortic dissection  given the patient's age  race  gender (male)  hypertension status  and description of pain. Hypertension is a known risk factor  and sudden severe chest pain is a classic symptom of aortic dissection. More males are affected than females  and incidence increases with age. African Americans are reported to have higher risks compared to Caucasians. Case studies like this will help medical students identify and manage patients with aortic dissection effectively.

Patient Information:   Mr. Henry Davis  a 62-year-old African American male  retired plumber  who smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Davis has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He's on antihypertensive meds but is often non-compliant  attributing to poor blood pressure control.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Davis was brought to the emergency department by his worried wife due to sudden  severe pain in the chest and between the shoulder blades that started about two hours ago. The pain could be described as tearing or ripping. He's also feeling short of breath  unusually sweaty  and has a sudden onset severe headache.   Discussion:  The case presents with classical symptoms of Aortic Dissection  a relatively rare but catastrophic illness. It is most common in males and in individuals between 60-70 years. Risk factors include hypertension and smoking  both of which our case has. Symptoms generally include severe chest pain with a ripping or tearing sensation migrating to the back  shortness of breath  and sweating due to pain.  This case is useful to test students' ability to differentiate between common but less fatal conditions (like myocardial infarction) and rare but immediately life-threatening conditions. The diagnosis should be followed by emergent imaging via CT  MRI  or Transesophageal Echocardiogram for confirmation and to determine the type of dissection. Immediate treatment to control blood pressure and heart rate  and active monitoring in an intensive care setting is crucial. The course of treatment may involve endovascular surgery or open-heart surgery.   Emphasize to students the importance of communicating effectively with the patient  empathetic displaying  and maintaining calm during these critical moments. They must learn to collaborate with a multidisciplinary team  which could involve a cardiologist  cardiac surgeon  and radiologist. Communication with family members is also crucial  ensuring they are aware of the patient's condition  the prognosis  and the available interventions.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 64-year-old African American male who is a former smoker presented himself to the emergency department.  History:  The patient is known to have hypertension  which is a primary risk factor for aortic dissection. He has also suffered from coronary artery disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease due to his smoking habit of 20 years. His medications include daily doses of aspirin  lisinopril  and amlodipine.   Presenting Complaints:  The patient reported a sudden  tearing chest pain that started at rest along with shortness of breath. The chest pain radiated to his back and upper abdomen. The patient also mentioned that the pain was intense and unlike any discomfort he had previously felt. There is no nausea  vomiting  sweating  or loss of consciousness. He does not report any weakness or parasthesia in limbs  no urinary incontinence  or vision changes.  This case stands as a reminder that although the occurrence of acute aortic dissection is higher in men and individuals over 60  it can affect anyone. It highlights the importance of a thorough and prompt evaluation  especially in patients with a history of hypertension and cardiovascular disease  when patients present with sharp and tearing chest or back pain. The case also indirectly underscores the importance of preventive health measures  such as blood pressure control  in patients at risk.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 63-year-old African-American male  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension  which has been inadequately controlled over the past ten years. He also has a history of past cigarette smoking  having stopped ten years ago. He reports no surgical history. Family history is notable for hypertension in his mother and an unspecified heart condition in his father.  Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at the emergency room complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain. The pain began about an hour prior to presentation and radiates to the back. The pain is sharp  tearing in nature and the worst pain he has ever experienced. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  palpitations  and profuse sweating. He denies having any similar previous episodes.  This case focuses on the complaints and risk factors commonly associated with an aortic dissection. The age of the patient aligns with the typical age range for aortic dissections  usually occurring in individuals aged 50-70 years. The patient's race  African-American  is also represented in the literature with higher risks associated with aortic dissection. Hypertension and smoking are among the most well-established risk factors for aortic dissection. It should be noted that while his symptoms could suggest various diseases  the severe nature and specific description of the pain are highly indicative of an aortic dissection  a medical emergency often leading to sudden death if not promptly diagnosed and managed.

Patient Case:   Patient Information: Mr. Miguel Torres  a 65-year-old Hispanic male.  Past Medical History: Mr. Torres has a documented history of hypertension that has been managed with thiazide diuretics and beta-blockers for the last ten years. He also has a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking around eight years ago. He does not have diabetes mellitus or any other significant medical condition. There's no family history of aortic dissections.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Torres presents to the Emergency Department (ED) describing a sudden onset ""tearing"" chest pain radiating to his back that initiated around three hours ago. He also complained of shortness of breath. He denied fever  cough  GI symptoms  or any similar previous episodes.  Considering the demographic data and risk factors  aortic dissection is commonly seen in hypertensive males (60-70 years old)  and the majority of the patients describe the pain as sudden and ""ripping"" or ""tearing"" in character. His ethnicity also aligns with statistics that show the Hispanic population at elevated risk. Also  the patient's history of smoking is a significant risk factor even though he had quit smoking. Hence  this profile provides a suitable case for exploring aortic dissection.  Please remember  this case is designed for educational purposes and does not constitute medical advice or clinical guidance. It is important that the students consider a broad differential diagnosis and recognize how presentation may differ between patients.

Patient Information:  Full Name: John Smith Age: 60 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Chief Complaint: Sudden severe chest pain that radiates to the back.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a 20-year history of hypertension. Despite medication  he has oftentimes a poorly controlled blood pressure  mainly due to non-compliance with medication. He is also a 40 pack-year smoker  meaning he has smoked one pack a day for 40 years. Previously  he was treated for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and has a history of high cholesterol. Although his father died from a heart attack at an early age  there's no other significant family history. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.  Case Presentation:  Mr. Smith presents in the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that started about 2 hours ago while he was gardening at home. He describes the pain as 'tearing' in character  10/10 in intensity  and radiating from the front of his chest to the back. He also reports he felt dizzy and short of breath immediately after the pain started. Apart from hypertension  he denies any previous similar episodes.  Discussion:  Given the patient's demographic profile (a Caucasian male aged over 60)  risk factors (hypertension  smoking  high cholesterol)  and the nature and location of the pain  aortic dissection is a major concern. This case could aid medical students in understanding key symptoms  risk factors  and the urgency for diagnosis and treatment of aortic dissection. The course of the teaching session may include a simulated examination of the patient  interpretation of specific diagnostic tools such as chest X-ray  CT scan or MRI  and discussion on potential management and treatment strategies.

Case Report: Acute Aortic Dissection  Demographics:  Mr. Joe Gomez is a 63-year-old African-American male  with a profession in construction work. He is a chronic smoker for 40 years  averaging about a pack of cigarettes a day.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Gomez has a 15-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and had been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications due to the lack of symptoms. He is also suffering from early-stage chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to his long-standing smoking history. The patient also reported incidental findings of a thoracic aortic aneurysm in a previous health check-up but did not follow-up due to a lack of understanding of the severity.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Gomez presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden severe chest pain radiating to his back for the last three hours. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and ""worst pain of my life."" He reported feeling sweaty and dizzy and stated the pain made him so uncomfortable that he needed to move around for relief. He also reported acute shortness of breath.   This case is designed to reflect higher incidence rates of aortic dissection among males over 60 with untreated hypertension  tobacco use  and a history of cardiac conditions - factors often seen in literature. African-Americans also have been found often late to be treated for cardiovascular diseases due to lack of access to healthcare  contributing further to the patient's presentation. A profession involving heavy lifting is included  given both occupational factors and socioeconomic status often influence this condition's prevalence.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:  Mr. John Clarke  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  residing in an urban area. He is a retired military officer and currently works part-time as a security consultant.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that started suddenly about an hour ago. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and ""ripping "" rating it 10 out of 10 in severity. The pain radiates to his back between the shoulder blades and to his abdomen. He also reports shortness of breath  profuse sweating  dizziness  and feelings of anxiety.  Past Medical History: Mr. Clarke is a 20-year smoker with a 1-pack per day history. He has hypertension  diagnosed around five years ago  and he is on Lisinopril 20 mg daily for it. His blood pressure has been poorly controlled with systolic readings frequently above 160 mmHg. Known familial predisposition with his father dying at the age of 50 due to ""unknown heart condition "" for which he has never been tested but always been concerned. He also has a history of elevated cholesterol levels currently managed by Atorvastatin 10 mg. No known history of diabetes  blood thinner use  or illicit drug abuse.   Key Indicative Facts: The hallmark symptoms of excruciating chest pain radiating to the back  poorly managed hypertension  and history of smoking predispose the patient for aortic dissection.   Discussion: Aortic dissection occurs more frequently in males  particularly those aged 60-70 years old. It is associated with hypertension  smoking  dyslipidemia  and genetic conditions that affect the connective tissue. Being a hypertensive smoker with a family history of potential heart conditions  Mr. Clarke falls into the high-risk group for this condition. The nature and intensity of his chest pain  along with his systemic symptoms  push aortic dissection to the top differential diagnosis  which should be immediately evaluated in this high-risk patient.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection   Patient Information:   - Mr. Zhang  a 60-year-old Asian male presented to the emergency department. - Occupation: Retired Engineer. - Residence: Lives in a suburban neighborhood with his wife.  Past Medical History:  - Has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years  poorly controlled  often non-compliant with the medication.  - 6 months back  diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus.  - Smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history  tries to quit but relapses frequently. - No known drug allergies.   Key Complaints:  - Mr. Zhang complained of sudden  severe tearing chest pain radiating to his back that started approximately 4 hours before arriving at the hospital. - He reported no signs of relief with rest. - The ongoing pain was accompanied by dizziness and shortness of breath. - He took his home supply of nitroglycerin with no relief.   This case is representative of the typical demographic affected by aortic dissection  which is more common among hypertensive middle-aged to elderly males  and particularly higher rates have been reported in Asian populations. Smoking and uncontrolled hypertension are considered major risks. The hallmark symptom of a sudden onset severe chest or back pain  often described as tearing or ripping  is evident in this scenario.

Case Study:  Patient Information:   Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  retired construction worker.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez has been diagnosed with hypertension for over five years and is on an angiotensin II receptor blocker (Losartan). However  he admits to being non-compliant with medication in recent weeks. Furthermore  he has a 10-year history of frequent tobacco use but quit 3 years ago. He denies alcohol use. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 75. No history of connective tissue disorders in the family.   Chief Complaint:  Mr. Rodriguez was brought into the emergency department (ED) with sudden and severe chest pain that started an hour ago while he was at home. He described his pain as ""tearing"" and ""ripping""  localized in the middle of his chest  radiating to his back  particularly between the shoulder blades. He also mentioned feeling nauseous but has not vomited. He denied shortness breath  cough  fever  or any recent trauma.  Note:  Aortic dissection typically occurs in males over 60 years old with hypertension (like Mr. Rodriguez). While it's common in all ethnicities  it is relatively more prevalent in whites and slightly less common in Hispanics. Tobacco use is a known risk factor  making Mr. Rodriguez's case fit right in the demographic profile of aortic dissection patients. The symptom of ""tearing"" chest pain radiating to the back is classic for aortic dissection. As Mr. Rodriguez has many risk factors and symptoms for the disease  students will need to consider aortic dissection at the top of their differential diagnosis  with conditions like myocardial infarction and pulmonary embolism also considered.

Patient Information:  Mr. James Washington  a 67-year-old African American male.   Background:  Mr. Washington is a retired mailman  a widower living alone in urban Chicago. Mr. Washington is a father to two adult children who visit occasionally. He is active in his community church and enjoys gardening.   Past medical history:  Mr. Washington has a significant history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 15 years. Additionally  he has a smoking history of about 30 pack-years but quit smoking 5 years ago.   Key Complaints:  He presented to the emergency department with an abrupt onset of severe  tearing chest pain radiating to his back  which started a few hours ago while gardening. He also mentioned mild shortness of breath  but no other symptoms such as weakness  tingling  loss of consciousness  or fevers.  In line with demographic trends seen in medical literature  Mr. Washington's age  race  and history of hypertension place him at risk for aortic dissection. This case has been designed to highlight those risk factors  as well as the classic presentation of severe chest pain radiating to the back. These key points should be stressed when teaching medical students about potential presentations of this life-threatening condition. Students should also consider differential diagnoses in similar presentations such as myocardial infarction  pericarditis  and pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. John Brown  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  an accountant by profession  with past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset severe chest pain and shortness of breath.  History of present illness: Mr. Brown experienced sudden onset  sharp  tearing chest pain radiating to his back after lifting heavy boxes at home. He also reports difficulty breathing. He describes the pain as unlike any he has previously experienced.  Past medical history: He has been managing hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years with amlodipine and simvastatin  respectively. He has a 25-pack year smoking history but quit smoking 5 years ago. He denies any history of substance abuse.  Surgical history: Underwent appendectomy at the age of 30.  Family history: Father died due to myocardial infarction at the age of 62  and mother has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.   Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Review of systems: Denies fevers  nausea  vomiting  or sweating. He's not experiencing any neurological symptoms such as dizziness or fainting.  Social history: Lives with his wife and retired a few years ago. Enjoys gardening and occasional golf. Drinks socially  around 4-5 drinks per week. Stopped smoking 5 years ago.  This case is based on the fact that hypertensive  older Caucasian males are more susceptible to aortic dissections  as per medical literature. It's worth noting that the incidence of aortic dissection is also high amongst those who smoke or have a familial history of the condition. Aortic dissection should be suspected in older patients who present with acute onset severe chest or back pain.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 68-year-old Hispanic male with a history of hypertension and high cholesterol presented to the emergency department (ED). His weight is 75 kg and is a retired construction worker. He has lived with type II diabetes for 20 years.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed 15 years ago with hypertension and has been taking medication (Lisinopril) since. He was diagnosed with high cholesterol ten years ago and prescribed Statin therapy. A smoker for 45 years  Mr. Rodriguez quit ten years ago. He admits to moderate alcohol consumption. His father died of a myocardial infarction in his 50s.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Rodriguez reported sudden severe chest pain radiating to the back  difficulty in breathing  and a sense of impending doom. He described the pain as 'tearing ' rating it a 10 on the pain scale. Accompanying these symptoms were syncope (passing out)  nausea  and excessive sweating.  On further probing  he elucidated that he was gardening when he suddenly felt an intense pain in his chest  unlike anything he had experienced before. The severity of the pain forced him to the ground. After 10-15 minutes  he was able to get up and call an ambulance. On arrival at ED  Mr. Rodriguez appeared to be in distress.  According to available data  elderly males  especially those with hypertension  diabetes  and a history of smoking  are at a higher risk for aortic dissection. The sudden onset  location  and quality of the pain described by the patient in this case are characteristic of aortic dissection. Mr. Rodriquez's presentation fits within the commonly observed patient profile for this diagnosis.

Case Report: Acute Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:  Mr. Brown  a 65-year-old African American male  retired from his managerial job.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Brown has been diagnosed with uncontrolled hypertension for the past 15 years but has a history of medication non-compliance. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day for 20 years  and drinks alcohol occasionally. He lives a sedentary lifestyle and has a family history of cardiac disorders. He also reports having Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 5 years. No known drug allergies have been identified.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Brown came to the emergency room reporting abrupt onset of severe chest pain  which he described as 'tearing' and 'ripping'  starting from the front of his chest and radiating to his back. On further questioning  he reported that the pain started suddenly while he was watching TV and has been persistent for over an hour. Accompanying symptoms included breathlessness  mild syncope  and profuse sweating. He denied having any fever  chest trauma  cough  palpitations or lower limb swelling.  The demographic representation in this case  including race  age  sex  and risk factors such as hypertension  smoking  and a family history of cardiac diseases  is reflective of epidemiologically identifiable risk factors for aortic dissection as represented in the literature. African American men aged 60-70 with hypertension have a relatively higher incidence of this condition.  Learning Objectives: 1. Recognize the typical clinical presentation of aortic dissection. 2. Understand the importance of early detection and management of aortic dissection. 3. To appreciate the risk factors associated with aortic dissection  including lifestyle factors and non-compliance with anti-hypertensive medication.  4. Importance of immediate referral to a cardio-thoracic surgeon in suspected aortic dissection. 5. Consideration of a holistic management plan  which considers the psychosocial aspect of the patient's condition  particularly in relation to compliance with medication and smoking cessation support.  6. Highlighting the importance of early radiological investigations like CT angiogram in early diagnosis and management.

Case Subject: 60-year-old African American male  Patient Profile: The patient is a 60-year-old African American male. He lives in an urban area and works as a cab driver. He is college-educated and divorced with two kids. He has an average BMI of 25  is a non-smoker  and drinks alcohol socially.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history that includes moderate hypertension  which he manages with an ACE inhibitor. He also has a history of high cholesterol for which he takes statins. There is no record of diabetes and he has no known allergies.   Key Complaints: The patient presented at the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest and upper back pain. The pain was described as 'tearing' or 'ripping ' radiating to the back. He additionally reported feeling a general malaise and had elevated anxiety levels. The patient also mentioned experiencing shortness of breath and palpitations.  This case has been developed with the knowledge that Aortic Dissection has a heightened prevalence in males  particularly those of African American descent who are around 60 years old. The patient's reported clinical symptoms also directly align with common symptoms associated with aortic dissections. Moreover  the past medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol increases the risk of aortic dissection in this patient. Given these factors  this case allows medical students to understand the correlation between risk factors  symptoms  and high-risk populations for aortic dissection.

Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Jones Age: 66-years-old Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired Police Officer  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Jones presents to the emergency room with sudden severe chest and back pain  which he describes as tearing and radiating down to the abdomen.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jones is hypertensive  with a 15-year history. He maintains his blood pressure with a daily regimen of Lisinopril. He has a 20-year history of smoking  but quit 10 years ago. He occasionally manages his persistent stress and insomnia with Alprazolam. He also has a family history of cardiovascular pathologies  particularly his father who suffered an aortic aneurysm.  High-yield Case Notes:  Considering Mr. Jones' sudden onset of severe chest and back pain  his known history of hypertension  and his familial history of cardiovascular disease  there is a high degree of suspicion for aortic dissection. This condition tends to be more prevalent in males and in the black population  and hypertensive patients are at especially high risk. As his symptom of chest pain radiating to the back occurs in more than 90% of aortic dissection cases  his presentation warrants immediate clinical attention to rule out this diagnosis.  Further steps in his evaluation would involve advanced imaging techniques like CT angiography or transesophageal echocardiogram. Upon confirmation of diagnosis  prompt treatment strategies should be implemented  including strict blood pressure control and potentially surgical intervention.  The patient would stand as a significant learning case for trainees to recognize the symptomatology  understand the risk factors  and appreciate the urgency in diagnosing and managing aortic dissection. It also highlights the need for prophylactic cardiovascular care in hypertensive patients with a relevant family history.

Patient Demographics:  Mr. Allen Jones is a 65-year-old African-American male  employed as a bus driver.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years  smokes about a pack of cigarettes daily  and has mild obesity (BMI of 30). His father had a fatal stroke in his early 70s. He is compliant with his antihypertensive medication and has no known allergies.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Jones was driving his bus when he started feeling an abrupt  severe pain in the chest which he describes as ""tearing"" in nature and radiating to his back. He pulled over and his colleagues called an ambulance. He denied any loss of consciousness  nausea  vomiting  or any other symptoms.  NOTE: Here we cover a case of aortic dissection  which is more prevalent among males and African-Americans. Two definitive risk factors for aortic dissection are present: hypertension and smoking. Moreover  the patient's family history of cerebrovascular accident might indicate a polycystic kidney disease  which can also be associated with aortic dissection. The classic presenting symptom (""tearing"" chest pain radiating to the back) is included.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 69-year-old African American male  employed as a construction engineer  residing in an urban setting. He is a former smoker  having ceased smoking 10 years ago  and drinks socially. He is married with three grown-up children.  Past Medical History: The patient has a notable medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels for the past ten years  which have been managed with medication and lifestyle changes. As a teenager  he suffered a minor traumatic chest injury during a football game that did not result in any long-term sequelae. His father suffered from an aortic aneurysm in his late 60s.   Key Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department late in the night with a severe  tearing pain in his chest extending to his back. The pain is reported to have occurred suddenly while he was asleep and waked him. The patient also mentions episodes of lightheadedness and transient loss of consciousness. He reports shortness of breath but denies any complaint of palpitations  nausea  or vomiting.   This case primarily points towards an aortic dissection  a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention. The demographic data and medical history align with literature as African Americans and those with a history of hypertension are at a higher risk. The complaint of sudden severe chest pain  commonly described as tearing or ripping  moving to the back aligns with classic symptoms  as does faintness or dizziness. It's also worthwhile to consider the patient's history of high cholesterol and his father's aortic aneurysm in assessing the risks.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Leon Jackson  an African-American male aged 65 years  currently residing in the local urban area  comes in for a consultation. He is a retired schoolteacher and lives with his wife. His socioeconomic status is middle-class.   Past Medical History: Mr. Jackson is a known case of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes  both diagnosed ten years ago and under medication. He also has a history of tobacco use  though he quit about two years ago. There is no known allergy or family history of cardiovascular disease.   Key Complaints: Mr. Jackson reports sudden onset severe central chest pain radiating to his back  which started around an hour ago while he was doing household chores. Associated symptoms include sweating and a mild disturbance in the vision. He denies any shortness of breath  palpitations  or loss of consciousness.   Note: This case scenario represents a typical representation of the demographic distribution of individuals with aortic dissection with prevalence being highest in the 65-70-year age group; males having a higher predilection than females; high prevalence in African-American ethnicity; and associations with risk factors like hypertension  smoking  and diabetes.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Hayes  Age: 65-years-old   Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Patient's Medical History: Smoking History: 40-pack years Alcohol History: Moderate drinker  Dietary History: Regular consumption of high-fat foods and processed meats Medical History: Hypertension for 20 years  managed with medication. Family History: Father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 73 years old.   Chief Complaint: Mr. Hayes presented in the emergency department with severe and sudden onset of chest pain. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and radiating to his back. He also reported shortness of breath and feeling faint.  Rationale: The choice of presenting a 65-year-old Caucasian male is representative of the typical demographic group impacted by aortic dissection. According to literature  aortic dissection is more common among males  aged 60-70 years  with risk factors such as hypertension and smoking history  which is portrayed in this case study. The chief complaint of sudden  severe chest pain that radiates to the back is characteristic of aortic dissection. This case will give an opportunity to students to learn about recognizing and managing this potentially fatal condition.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male  who works as a construction worker.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  which has been poorly controlled over the past five years due to irregular medication intake. He also has a history of tobacco use  having smoked nearly a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. No personal history of other cardiovascular diseases  chest injury or connective tissue diseases.  Key Complaints: The patient arrives at the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden severe sharp pain in the front of his chest  which radiates to his upper back. He rates the pain as a 10 on a scale of 1-10 and states that it started about two hours ago while lifting heavy objects at work. He also mentions feeling short of breath and experiencing a loss of consciousness for a brief moment.  Notes: This case presentation represents the higher prevalence of aortic dissection in males around the 6th and 7th decade of life  with risk factors higher in African Americans  hypertensive patients  smokers  and those with physically demanding jobs.   The chief complaints reflect the classic presentation of aortic dissection which is severe  tearing anterior chest pain radiating to the back  dyspnea  and sometimes syncope  demonstrating a classic Stanford Type A dissection clinical picture.

Case Report: Acute Aortic Dissection   Patient Demographics: Mr. James Carter is a 67-year-old African American male with a weight of approximately 230 pounds and a height of 5 feet 11 inches. He is a retired civil engineer who lives with his wife. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years and drinks socially. He has a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Mr. Carter has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled adequately with prescribed antihypertensive and statin therapy. There has been a significant history of cardiovascular diseases in his paternal lineage. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his older brother suffered from an aortic aneurysm at the age of 62. He is compliant with his medications which include lisinopril and atorvastatin.  Key Complaints: Mr. Carter presented to the emergency department with acute  severe  unrelenting chest and back pain for 4 hours. The pain is described as ‘tearing’ and ‘ripping’ in nature radiating to the neck and lower back. The pain started abruptly  has persisted  and grown in intensity over the hours. He was also feeling lightheaded  had profuse sweating  and shortness of breath with moderate activity. On further inquiry  he also admitted to feeling a weak pulse in his left arm compared to the right.  Please note: The scenario was created in the context of ensuring accurate demographic representation  as aortic dissection is often seen more frequently in males over 60  particularly those of African American descent  and those with a history of hypertension.  For instructional use  this case can then proceed to diagnostic  therapeutic  and prognostic discussions.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Ethan Thomas  a 65-year-old African-American male  a retired primary school teacher  living with his wife in an urban area  non-smoker with moderate alcohol use.  Past Medical History: Highly notable for uncontrolled hypertension for the last 10 years  known with moderate left ventricular hypertrophy. No prior history of any surgeries or major illnesses. Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with his father having suffered from a myocardial infarction at age 70.  Key Complaints: Ethan presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden-onset  severe chest pain  which he described as ‘tearing’ in nature  radiating to the back. It started while he was having dinner. He also described feeling nauseous  severe sweating and shortness of breath. On examination  there was a notable difference in blood pressure between the two arms.  This case presents a classic scenario of aortic dissection  a clinical emergency requiring prompt diagnosis and management. This case was designed considering the fact that the aortic dissection is more common among males  particularly of African-American ethnicity  around sixth to seventh decade of life [1  2]. Hypertension is the single most significant risk factor  which Ethan has been dealing with for a decade now [1  2].   References: 1. Hiratzka LF  Bakris GL  Beckman JA  Bersin RM  Carr VF  Casey DE Jr  et al. 2010 ACCF/AHA/AATS/ACR/ASA/SCA/SCAI/SIR/STS/SVM guidelines for the diagnosis and management of patients with Thoracic Aortic Disease: a report of the American College of Cardiologists Foundation/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines  American Association for Thoracic Surgery  American College of Radiology  American Stroke Association  Society of Cardiovascular Anesthesiologists  Society for Cardiovascular Angiography and Interventions  Society of Interventional Radiology  Society of Thoracic Surgeons  and Society for Vascular Medicine. Circulation. 2010;121(13):e266-369.  2. Clouse WD  Hallett JW Jr  Schaff HV  Spittell PC  Rowland CM  Ilstrup DM  et al. Improved prognosis of thoracic aortic aneurysms: a population-based study. JAMA. 1998;280(22):1926-9.

Patient Profile:   Mr. Rodriguez is a 68-year-old Hispanic male who works as a semi-retired contractor. He is a widower and lives with his daughter and two grandchildren. Mr. Rodriguez has a 40-year history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes per day but quit ten years ago. He is also diagnosed with hypertension and has been managing the condition with lifestyle modifications and medication  specifically Lisinopril  for 15 years.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Rodriguez presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain that he described as sharp and tearing  radiating to the back. The pain was sudden in onset and was not relieved by rest. He also complained of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and dizziness. His daughter reported noticing her father's skin appearing paler than usual.  Past Medical History:  Apart from hypertension  Mr. Rodriguez was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia two years ago  for which he is taking Simvastatin. He also has a history of intermittent claudication. His father died of a myocardial infarction at 72  and his mother had a stroke at 80.   Social History:  Mr. Rodriguez is a former smoker who quit about ten years ago but still occasionally drinks alcohol. He admitted to having a relatively sedentary lifestyle  consuming a high-salt diet  and being under severe stress due to recent financial troubles. He denies any recreational drug use.   Discussion Point:  This case is a classic presentation of aortic dissection  wherein the key complaints of radiating chest pain align with the associated literature. Considering the patient’s age  male gender  race  and history of smoking and hypertension  he fits into the typical demographic profile for aortic dissection. It is worth noting that this condition has a higher incidence rate in males  aged 50-70  particularly in those with a history of hypertension or smoking. The ethnic component is also critical as aortic dissection is noted to have a considerable prevalence in the Hispanic population due to poorly controlled blood pressure.

Subject: Aortic Dissection - Case Study  Patient Information:  Mr. A  a 65-year-old African American male  retired  living in an urban environment.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension for the past 15 years with a documented high systolic pressure of 180 mmHg several times. Additionally  he has been a smoker for the past 40 years and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father dying of myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He has dyslipidemia  with high levels of LDL cholesterol  and has had intermittent complaints of chest discomfort over the past few years. However  he has not yet sought medical intervention for the same. He is overweight and has a sedentary lifestyle. He has not been taking his medications consistently due to financial reasons and neglect.  Key Complaints:  Mr. A presented to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the back  described as ""tearing"" in nature  and started about an hour ago. He also complained of shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and feelings of impending doom. He mentioned experiencing lightheadedness with a near syncope episode. No associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or fever were reported. He denied any recent trauma or heavy weightlifting.  Clinical Examination: On arrival  the patient seemed distressed  anxious and his skin was cold and clammy. Blood pressure reading was significantly different between the two arms with the right being 150/90 mmHg and the left 110/70 mmHg. Heart sounds were heard with a diastolic murmur noted. The remainder of the physical exam did not reveal significant findings.  Note: It is imperative to remember that aortic dissection usually occurs more commonly in men  the incidence increases with age  and is highest in individuals aged 65–75 years. Hypertension  smoking  dyslipidemia  and genetics play vital roles in the development of this condition. Several studies have also highlighted the increased risk in Black people.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old African-American male  retired from military service. His BMI is 28.2  classified as overweight.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 15-year history of hypertension  controlled with daily metoprolol and hydrochlorothiazide. He has no history of diabetes or significant heart disease but has a 20-pack-year history of smoking. He’s been treated for high serum LDL (+190 mg/dl)  borderline high triglycerides (+150 mg/dl)  and moderate chronic renal disease (Creatinine: 2.3 mg/dl). The patient stopped alcohol consumption 5 years ago and reported occasional use of recreational drugs in the past.  Key Complaints: The patient was brought in by ambulance after experiencing an abrupt  severe chest pain after carrying groceries that radiated to his back and abdomen. In addition to this pain which he described as “tearing”  he reported shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. His lower extremity seemed relatively cold and pulseless comparing to upper extremity.  Case Background: Upon review of the medical literature  aortic dissections appear most commonly among male patients in their 60s and 70s  with a particular predisposition in the African-American population. Hypertension is frequently a significant risk factor. As per the National Institute of Health  people who are male and from an African-American background are at a greater risk.   The patient's history of hypertension  smoking  hyperlipidemia and his account of sudden severe  tearing chest and back pain along with differential pulses indicate an aortic dissection until proven otherwise.

Patient Case:   Mr. Jackson  a 65-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension  presents to the emergency room with a chief complaint of sudden and severe chest pain. The pain is described as ""tearing"" and ""raging"" from the chest to his back. The pain began at rest two hours prior and has gradually grown worse. No other associated symptoms are reported except a mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jackson has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years. However  he acknowledges poor adherence to his antihypertensive medications  citing affordability issues. He also has a 20-pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit five years ago. Furthermore  he denies any history of heart disease  diabetes  or other chronic illnesses.  Demographics: Mr. Jackson is retired but previously worked as an auto mechanic. He lives alone since his wife’s death two years ago. He’s a father to three grown children who live in other states but communicate regularly. He uses VA services for his medical care  adherently attending check-ups until recently due to escalating concerns about cost.  Note: The demographic details and past medical history align with the increased predisposition of older males  specifically in the African American population with long-standing uncontrolled hypertension  toward aortic dissection. The notable risk factors here include the age (>60 years)  gender (male)  hypertension  and history of smoking.

Case Study: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information: Mr. William Byrd  a 68-year-old African American male.  Key Complaints: The patient arrived at the emergency room complaining of severe chest pain that started abruptly and radiated to the back. The chest pain was described as a ripping or tearing sensation. Mr. Byrd mentioned that the pain had reached a maximum intensity almost instantly after onset. He seemed very anxious and struggling to breathe  with mildly disoriented speech.  Past Medical History: Mr. Byrd has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 15 years  non-compliance with antihypertensive medications  and a 20-year history of smoking. He had an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) around two years ago but had not followed up for medical care since then. He also reports occasional alcohol consumption and denies any illicit drug usage.  Background: African American men are at a higher risk level for developing hypertension  and uncontrolled hypertension may increase the risk of aortic dissection. Other risk factors  including smoking  advancement in age  and male sex  align with the patient's demographics and history. The presence of a previous TIA highlights the potential of vascular disease.  Training Points: This case serves as a platform to discuss the cause and the management of aortic dissection  focusing especially on the consequences of uncontrolled hypertension. The abrupt onset of severe pain  patient's demographics (race  age  gender)  smoking history  previous TIA  and poorly managed hypertension alert us towards a potential aortic dissection  highlighting the importance of clinical history and vigilance in managing such high-risk patients.   The case can also be used to educate students on recognizing and managing hypertensive emergencies and the value of preventive care in vascular diseases. Additionally  it would be beneficial to touch on disparities in healthcare  especially considering the combination of racial and socioeconomic factors influencing this patient's access to health resources and adherence to medication.

Patient Profile:   Name: John Doe Age: 65-year-old  Sex: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired secondary school teacher Living Situation: Lives with wife in a 2-story house  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension 2. High cholesterol 3. Previous smoker (quit 10 years ago) 4. History of sporadic recreational drug use (cocaine  in the distant past)  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain described as ""sharp"" and ""tearing."" The pain began approximately 2 hours prior to admission while he was mowing the lawn. Its intensity seems to fluctuate  but it does not completely subside.  He also mentions feeling a similar pain radiating to his back between his shoulder blades. The patient also describes recent episodes of weakness and feeling of faintness.    The patient’s wife observes that his skin looks slightly hollower and paler than usual  but denies any loss of consciousness  convulsions  or bowel/bladder incontinence.   The patient does not report any cough  fever  or other systemic symptoms. He also hasn’t noticed any changes in his vision or speech. He denies any modern medication  herbal remedies  or ongoing recreational drug use.  This case highlights the key presenting features observed in patients with aortic dissection. Including a patient with these specific demographics and past medical history also importantly allows for a discussion around risk factors such as hypertension  older age  smoking history and cocaine use.

Case Report: Aortic Discombination   Patient Demographics:  Mr. Anderson is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who is a former smoker with a high stress corporate job which involves significant travel. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with both his father and grandfather dying of heart diseases. He lives in a suburban area and is generally uninterested in physical activities. His diet largely comprises of high fat  high cholesterol foods.  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a past medical history significant for hypertension which he has been managing with antihypertensive medication (losartan) for the past 10 years. His hypertension is poorly controlled  often spiking during high-stress events. He is also inflicted with hyperlipidemia and takes statins occasionally. The patient has been non-compliant in regard to medication and does not follow a regular exercise regimen. Mr. Anderson had a minor myocardial infarction 5 years ago  managed conservatively  and has no history of any other surgeries.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Anderson presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset severe interscapular pain which he describes as tearing and radiating anteriorly towards the chest. The pain started while he was in a stressful company meeting. He also reports shortness of breath  anxiety  and palpitations. His vitals showed an elevated blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. Upon arrival  he looked pale and was profusely sweating.  From recent literature  a majority of aortic dissection cases occur in men aged over 60 years with risk factors including hypertension  smoking  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases. This case discusses a patient with the risk factors and classic presenting symptoms that should alert trainees to consider aortic dissection as a potential diagnosis. Care should be taken to instruct students on the urgency of this condition and the importance of a focused history and physical examination.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 59 Race: African American Sex: Male Occupation: Truck Driver  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension - managed with antihypertensive drugs - Lisinopril (since the last 10 years) 2. Marfan Syndrome - diagnosed during his late teens 3. History of smoking - approximately 2 packs a week for the past 30 years 4. Hyperlipidemia - managed with diet modification and statin therapy  Presenting Complaints: John Doe presents to the emergency department (ED) with a sudden  excruciating tearing pain in the center of his chest  radiating to his back. He describes the pain as sharp and stabbing  the worst he ever experienced. He mentions an additional unusual pain between his shoulder blades. The pain started while he was lifting heavy objects at work approximately 3 hours ago.   The patient reports feeling dizzy and had an episode of syncope just before arriving at the ED. He also mentions experiencing shortness of breath but no other respiratory symptoms like coughing or wheezing. There is no nausea or vomiting but he does feel a little sweaty and anxious.  He denies similar past episodes  no prior history of heart problems apart from hypertension. He travels long distances in his truck but denies recent long-period immobility. His father died suddenly at the age of 62  the cause of which was never determined.  Note: African American men aged 50-70 with a history of smoking  hypertension  and Marfan Syndrome form a demographic group at an increased risk of aortic dissections. This case presentation aims at teaching medical students to recognize the typical symptoms and risk factors to reach a prompt diagnosis and select appropriate medical interventions.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African-American male  presents at the emergency department.  Past Medical History:  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been managed with medication for the past ten years. He's also a smoker with a 25-pack-year history  and he drinks alcohol socially. He had also been diagnosed and treated for hypercholesterolemia for five years. There's no family history of cardiovascular disease.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Johnson reports a sudden onset of sharp and severe chest pain that began at rest. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and says it radiates to his back  between the shoulder blades. The pain intensity has remained constant since onset and is not alleviated by positional changes. He also reports associated symptoms of light-headedness  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating.  NOTE to Educator: This case reflects the demographic trends noted in literature related to aortic dissection. According to the literature  aortic dissection is more common in males aged 60 to 80 years. Hypertension is the most important risk factor for aortic dissection  being present in up to 75% of cases. It tends to affect people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds differently  with the highest incidence rates reported in African-Americans. Other risk factors include smoking and hypercholesterolemia.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information:   Mr. J. Martinez is a 66-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 40-year pack smoking history. He is retired from a job as a factory worker and has limited physical activity due to accompanying osteoarthritis.   Chief Complaint:  Mr. Martinez presents to the ER complaining of sudden onset of severe chest pain that started an hour ago. He described the pain as 'tearing' and 'radiating' from his chest to his back.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Martinez has been treated for hypertension for over 10 years and for high cholesterol for approximately 5 years. His hypertension has been poorly controlled  with recent office readings consistently >140/90 mmHg. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  averaging one pack per day  with several failed attempts at cessation. His father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He has osteoarthritis  which has been managed by over the counter NSAIDs.  Medication History:  His current medications include Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and Atorvastatin 40 mg daily for hypercholesterolemia.  Social History:  He lives with his wife and has two adult children living nearby. He regularly consumes alcohol  averaging at two standard drinks per day.  Overview:  Patients like Mr. Martinez represent a key demographic at risk for aortic dissection  with male sex  advanced age  and uncontrolled hypertension serving as noteworthy risk factors. Upon the presentation of sudden severe chest pain  especially one described as 'tearing' and 'radiating ' aortic dissection should be highly suspected. This case allows medical students to grasp the importance of recognizing such symptoms promptly  stratifying patient risk  and initiating appropriate and timely measures.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics: The patient is Mr. Harold Smith  a Caucasian man  65 years old  retired high school teacher. He lives in suburban America  Massachusetts with his wife. Mr. Smith is a moderate smoker for the past 40 years  with a moderately unhealthy diet high in saturated fats and low in fiber. He has a BMI of 29  bordering on obesity. He doesn't exercise regularly. Immutable risk factors include him being male and his age  both of which correlate with a higher prevalence of aortic dissection.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension for 15 years which has been moderately controlled on antihypertensive medication (ACE inhibitors). He has been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  which is moderately controlled on oral hypoglycemic agents. Also  a year ago  he was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and placed on statins. He has no history of surgeries or major illnesses apart from above. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother had a stroke in her late sixties.  Key Complaint: Mr. Smith arrived in the emergency room complaining of sudden unbearable sharp chest pain that started an hour ago while he was watching television. The pain started in the middle of his chest and radiated to his back  described as ""tearing"" in character. He also reported mild shortness of breath  excessive sweating  and discomfort associated with nausea. He denied any symptoms of fever  cough  or sudden weight loss. The pain didn’t improve with rest or nitroglycerine that he had at home for angina episodes. He looked extremely anxious and was in obvious distress.  All these symptoms point towards a suspicion of aortic dissection; prompt diagnosis and management is crucial due to the disease's life-threatening nature. The aim of this case study is to further delve into the diagnostic and management pathway while managing such critical patients.  [Note for medical educators: Although these demographics and predisposing factors are typical of many aortic dissection cases  it’s important to stress to the students that the disease can occur outside this demographic too  and they should always suspect it when presented with the classic ""tearing"" type of chest pain and associated symptoms.]

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male  divorced  and a retired mechanic. He is a lifelong resident of the Northeastern United States and reports a previous smoking history of 20 pack-years  having quit about 10 years ago. He also has a history of alcohol use but really decreased his intake after retirement.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. Additionally  there is a family history of atherosclerosis and stroke in his mother.  Key Complaints: The patient presents to the Emergency department complaining of a severe  sharp pain in the lower back and abdomen. The pain started abruptly two hours ago and has been progressively worsening. The severity of the pain he describes is unlike anything he has experienced before. He also reported feeling clammy  slight nausea  and dizziness. The patient denied any recent trauma or injury and no recent strenuous activity.  Upon physical examination  the patient was observed to be hypertensive with a systolic blood pressure of 180 mmHg  pulse of 100/min  respirations of 20/min  and saturation of 92% on room air. On auscultation  there was a discrepancy in blood pressure between the right and left arms  a significant sign of aortic dissection.  This case provides an example of patients most commonly affected by aortic dissection  namely males older than 60 with a history of hypertension  as the literature indicates. Combining the classic symptoms of unexplained severe back/abdominal pain  history of smoking  and vascular diseases would allow medical students to hone in on crucial clinical components of diagnosis and management.   The case will further lead to detailed explanation and understanding of aortic dissection's clinical presentation  risk factors  diagnostic techniques  and treatment options  emphasizing the high degree of suspicion required for early diagnosis and treatment.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection   a. Patient Information  Patient: Mr. Eugene Smith Age: 65 years Race: African American Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer  b. Medical History  Mr. Smith is a known patient of hypertension and high cholesterol levels for the last ten years. He has been on regular treatment with amlodipine and atorvastatin. He has been a smoker for 30 years and quit ten years ago. His father died of a heart attack at age 60 and his elder brother had a stroke at 63.   c. Chief Complaints   Mr. Smith is presenting to the emergency department with a chief complaint of a sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to his back  specifically between his shoulder blades. The pain which started one hour ago is described as 'tearing or ripping.' He is also experiencing some shortness of breath and a fainting episode.  d. Social History  He is unmarried and lives with his younger sister. His daily activities involve light housework and gardening. He doesn't drink alcohol.   e. History of Present Illness  The patient was asymptomatic until one hour before presentation. He was doing some light gardening when he suddenly started to feel severe chest pain. The pain worsened over time  leading to a fainting episode.  Note: Aortic dissection has a male predominance  and is often seen in patients aged 60-70 years. Risk factors include hypertension (primary risk factor)  smoking  hyperlipidemia  family history of cardiovascular diseases  and African American ethnicity. This case was created maintaining these demographics and risk factors in mind for better representation.

Case Report: Acute Aortic Dissection  Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 70-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and heavy smoking  presents to the emergency department.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a history of essential hypertension  which has not been adequately managed due to medication non-compliance. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day for the last 40 years. In addition  he has brief history of high cholesterol  although he refuses to take prescribed statins. He denies any significant family history of cardiovascular disease. His only medication currently is Lisinopril  which he admits to rarely taking.  Key Complaints: The patient reports a sudden severe pain in his chest and upper back  which he describes as ""tearing"" and ""ripping""  that started approximately 2 hours ago. The intensity of the pain escalated quickly and led him to seek immediate medical attention. He also complains of mild shortness of breath  but denies nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. He denies experiencing prior episodes of similar pain.  Clinical findings and other relevant information will be explored further in the teaching session.
