Clinical context: Acute aortic dissection is a potentially life-threatening emergency that requires swift recognition and appropriate management. The patient is a representative example of demographic and risk factors that have been linked to aortic dissection: older age  male gender  African American race  uncontrolled hypertension  and tobacco use. This case aims to contrast the traditional chest pain presentations  highlight the importance of a thorough medical history  and stress urgent management of this condition.

Patient Profile:  Name: David Miller Age: 67 years Sex: Gender Occupation: Retired military officer  Ethnicity: Caucasian Residence: Rural Midwest  Past Medical History:   Mr. Miller has a history of hypertension for the past 15 years which is currently managed by medication. He has also been smoking half a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a stroke at the age of 72. His lipid profile shows moderate hyperlipidemia. Mr. Miller drinks alcohol occasionally and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to arthritis.   Key complaints:  Mr. Miller presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden  severe chest pain that started an hour ago. The pain is described as tearing  radiating to the back  and not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. He also reported shortness of breath  abnormal pulse  and a feeling of impending doom. He showed signs of sweating  pallor  and was visibly distressed.   Note:  Aortic dissection is often seen in elderly men with risk factors including uncontrolled hypertension  atherosclerosis  and tobacco use. This case is representative as it portrays a typical patient demographic  along with a typical presentation of severe chest pain and other features that would make aortic dissection a high probability in the differential diagnosis.

Patient Case:  Mr. Thomas  a 62-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department with severe  abrupt onset chest pain. He described the pain as “tearing” that radiated from the front of the chest to the back. The pain started about two hours ago and has become progressively worse.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thomas is a long-term smoker with a history of uncontrolled hypertension  high cholesterol  cardiovascular disease  with no known diabetes. He is currently taking antihypertensive medicine Amlodipine and cholesterol-lowering medication  but he admits that he doesn't take it consistently due to irregular follow-up with his primary care provider. Per his reports  he started feeling unwell last night with general malaise but dismissed it as fatigue.   Evaluation of Literature-based Demographic Representation: According to medical literature  males are more prone to developing aortic dissection  with a peak incidence at 60-80 years old. People with hypertension  particularly uncontrolled as in Mr. Thomas's case  are at an increased risk. African Americans are also believed to have higher predisposition due to increased prevalence of hypertension. Smoking can also increase the risk due to yielding changes in the aortic wall. Thus  Mr. Thomas's demographic and medical history align with the typical risk factors associated with aortic dissection.   Key Complaints: The primary complaint in cases of aortic dissection is typically acute onset severe chest pain  often described as a ""ripping"" or ""tearing"" sensation that radiates to the back. This pain is typically sudden  sharp  and may vary in intensity. Mr. Thomas's description of his pain fits this classic presentation.   In this training case  students should be able to recognize the symptoms of aortic dissection and the importance of thorough history taking  particularly focusing on cardiovascular risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. It will also provide lessons on the urgency and critical nature of aortic dissection and the importance of time-specific interventions.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old African American male from a lower-middle-class neighborhood. He is a retired mechanic  who smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for over 30 years. He admits regular alcohol consumption but denies any illicit drug use.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 15 years  for which he has been prescribed multiple medications. His blood pressure often remains above 140/90 mm Hg. He also has a history of high cholesterol levels and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Commendably  he has been compliant with his therapy but admits he does not participate in regular physical exercise. His father passed away due to a stroke while his mother has a history of coronary artery disease. He also admits avoiding regular follow-ups for monitoring his hypertension due to financial constraints.  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson arrived in the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain that started while he was doing household chores. He described it as a sharp  tearing pain radiating to the back and associated with shortness of breath. The pain was not relieved by nitroglycerin that he uses for regularly occurring chest discomfort. He also noted feeling light-headed and having a vague  undefined sense of anxiety. No similar incidents were reported in the past.  Demographic Justification: Aortic dissection is more common in males and the incidence increases with age  with peak onset in the sixth to eighth decades of life. This condition is also more prevalent among African American individuals and those with a history of hypertension. Smoking  age  race  hypertension  high cholesterol  and family history of vascular diseases play a significant role in the risk posed to the patient. It's also important to note that low socioeconomic status influences both the incidence and control of hypertension.

Patient Information: Mr. Clarence McDaniel  a 66-year-old African American retired factory worker  residing in an urban area.  Past Medical History: Mr. McDaniel has a medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  Stage 2 (moderate) chronic kidney disease  and he is a 30-pack-year tobacco smoker. He has been prescribed Lisinopril and Amlodipine for hypertension but is non-compliant with taking medications regularly. He doesn't exercise regularly and his diet consists mainly of high salt and high fat foods.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. McDaniel presented in the emergency department with acute sudden onset severe chest pain described as 'tearing' in nature that radiated to his upper back. The pain started while he was lifting a heavy bag of groceries. He reports the pain as being different from any he has experienced before  rating it 10/10 in intensity. He also mentioned a feeling of persistent coldness in his left leg and an unexplained weight loss over the past month.   Note: This case study represents a population (males  African Americans  and age group of 60-70 years) which  as per literature  is more prone to develop aortic dissection. The presence of uncontrolled hypertension  chronic kidney disease  tobacco smoking history  and weight lifting (increase in hemodynamic stress) further enforces the risk factors associated with this condition. The clinical complaints are also designed to be characteristic for aortic dissection - severe tearing pain  radiation to the back  as well as systemic and peripheral signs such as weight loss and limb coldness. This should encourage a discussion on early recognition  differential diagnoses  and management of aortic dissection.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection   Patient Information:  Name: Mr. James Williams Age: 67 years old Sex: Male  Race: African American Occupation: Retired Civil engineer  Past Medical History:  Mr. Williams has been treated for hypertension for the past 15 years and has kept it relatively controlled with medication  diet  and lifestyle changes. He also suffers from hyperlipidemia and is a former smoker  having quit twenty years ago. He has had no previous surgeries or hospitalizations. He does not have a family history of heart disease.  Present Complaint:  Mr. Williams came to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden severe chest pain that started about 2 hours ago. He describes it as a sharp  tearing sensation that radiates to his back and seems to be intensifying. He denies any recent trauma or heavy lifting prior to the onset of symptoms. Additionally  he reports symptoms of light-headedness  nausea  and sweaty palms  but negates any shortness of breath  cough  or fever. He doesn't recall any similar episodes previously.   Social History:  Mr. Williams is widowed and lives alone. He is a social drinker  consuming about 3-4 units of alcohol per week  and denies any illicit drug use. He is fairly active  engaging in regular walks and light exercises.   This case is designed to represent the typical case of aortic dissection  which more frequently affects males and is associated with ages over 60. The African American population and individuals with a history of hypertension are at an increased risk. The acute onset of severe chest pain described as 'tearing' that radiates to the back is a key symptom reflective of an aortic dissection.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Demographic Information: Patient: Mr. J.D. Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: African-American Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension controlled on meds from age 55 2. Two pack per day smoker for 50 years 3. Family history of heart disease 4. Cholesterol controlled on meds from age 60  Chief Complaint: The patient arrived complaining of sudden  severe chest pain.  History of Present Illness: Mr. J.D. is a retired engineer who presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset chest pain. Pain began two hours before presenting to the ED. Describes pain as ""tearing"" and ""ripping "" radiating to his back between his shoulder blades. Denies any recent trauma or injury. Pain is not relieved by positional changes or any other approaches. The patient looked anxious and sweated profusely.  Note: The Age  Sex  Race  and medical history are consistent with risk factors for aortic dissection  a condition markedly higher in men  those over 60  African-Americans  and prominently related to hypertension  smoking  high cholesterol and family history of heart diseases. The patient's key complaint  severe chest pain with a tearing or ripping sensation  is a classic clinical characteristic of aortic dissection.  Through this case  medical students should understand the typical symptoms and risk factors associated with aortic dissection and the immediate steps necessitated to confirm diagnosis and begin appropriate treatment. Subsequent focus on echocardiography  computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans to diagnose  and treatment involving blood pressure control and possible surgical intervention would complete the training case.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Information: Mr. Samuel Johnson  a 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for smoking  uncontrolled hypertension  and high cholesterol.  Reason for Visit:  Mr. Johnson presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset  severe chest and back pain described as tearing or ripping  that started approximately 2 hours ago. He also mentions a notable difference in blood pressure between his left and right arms.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago but has been inconsistent with his anti-hypertensive medication due to concerns about side-effects. He has been a heavy smoker (2 packs per day) for the last 30 years. He was also diagnosed with high cholesterol five years ago but has not taken any cholesterol-lowering medications due to financial constraints. He has no known drug allergies.  Family History: His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 62  and his mother had a stroke at the age of 65. He has one older brother who currently has uncontrolled hypertension.  Social History: Recently retired  Mr. Johnson previously worked as a bus driver. He continues to smoke heavily  consuming approximately 2 packs of cigarettes per day. He admits to low levels of physical activity and a diet rich in fried foods and red meat. He doesn't consume alcohol excessively and denies any illicit drug use.  Risk Factors: Several risk factors for aortic dissection should be emphasized to students. These include history of hypertension  smoking  advanced age  male sex  and high cholesterol levels. It is important to note that African-Americans have a higher incidence rate of aortic dissection  likely due to a higher prevalence of hypertension.  Presenting Complaints: Key symptoms the students should focus on are the sudden onset of severe chest or back pain  described as tearing or ripping  and discrepancies in blood pressure between the arms. Other potential symptoms include shortness of breath  fainting  heavy sweating  nausea  and signs of shock. However  these may not always be present in all patients.   Clinical guidance: A high index of suspicion is required for diagnosis as aortic dissection although not very common  may be fatal if not diagnosed promptly. Initial evaluation should include a thorough history  physical examination  and appropriate diagnostic imaging such as a CT scan. Management would often require emergent surgical repair but may vary based on the type of dissection and overall patient condition.

Patient Information: Mr. John Thompson  a 67-year-old African American male  with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and tobacco use. The patient is a retired automobile mechanic  and he lives alone. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications and has a 30-pack year smoking history.  Chief Complaint: The patient reports sudden onset of severe back pain  described as ""tearing"" in nature  since 3 hours.  Case Presentation: Mr. Thompson presented to the emergency department with acute  severe  tearing chest and back pain that radiated to his abdomen. The pain started while he was carrying groceries. He also reported feeling dizzy and faint. He is normally quite active and has not experienced symptoms like this before. The patient’s blood pressure at admission is elevated  there are differences in the pressures observed in each arm  and a faint diastolic murmur is noticed on his cardiac examination.  Past Medical History: Medical records indicate that he has been diagnosed with hypertension for over 10 years but is inconsistent with his medication. He's also been advised repeatedly to quit smoking.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Based on his severe  sharp chest pain  the acute onset of symptoms  and his demographic and medical history  aortic dissection is suspected.   Teaching Topics: This case could be used to discuss typical presenting symptoms  methods of confirming the suspected diagnosis  potential complications  and treatment plans for aortic dissection. We can discuss the importance of blood pressure control and its implications in the prevention of cases such as aortic dissection. Students should also understand how to educate patients about the adverse effects of smoking and hypertension. The moment should also be seized to discuss healthcare disparities and the importance of cultural competence in healthcare.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. A.B. is a 62-year-old African-American male  working as a construction supervisor.   Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 8 years and has been a smoker for about 40 years. He also has a mild renal deficiency along with a high cholesterol level which was noted in his last annual check-up. His father succumbed to heart disease in his early 60s.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. A.B. came to the emergency department (ED) with acute  severe chest pain that started about an hour ago. He described the pain as a tearing sensation localized in the anterior chest and radiating towards the back. The patient also reported suffering from mild shortness of breath and feeling anxious.  This case was selected considering the literature evidence where the incidence rate of aortic dissection is alleged to be higher among African-American males  older adults  smokers  and those with hypertension and high cholesterol levels. Moreover  a family history of heart disease increases the risk of cardiovascular disorders. The symptoms presented by Mr. A.B. are typical for aortic dissection  i.e.  abrupt and intense chest pain with a ripping or tearing sensation and anxiety. Yet  the physician should rule out other pathologies—such as myocardial infarction—that can present with similar symptoms.

Case Report Title: Understanding Aortic Dissection in an Older African-American Male  Subject: Mr. James  a 72-year-old African-American male  Past Medical History: Mr. James has a well-documented history of hypertension  smoking (35 pack-years)  and hyperlipidemia. He does not have diabetes  a family history of heart disease  or any history of connective tissue disorders. Mr. James is compliant with his antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily) and statin (Rosuvastatin 20mg daily).  Presenting Complaints: Mr. James presented to the emergency department (ED) with a reported sudden  intense chest pain described as tearing in character and radiating to the back. Accompanying symptoms included a shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and near-syncopal episodes.   Medical literature shows that African-American men have higher rates of hypertension and aortic dissection than others. They are often underrepresented  and addressing this specific demographic allows for a more comprehensive understanding of the diverse patient population. The case is designed to illustrate common risk factors (hypertension  smoking  hyperlipidemia) and typical presentations of aortic dissection. The aim is to increase the students' diagnostic suspicion required to combat the high morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics:  - Name: John Doe - Age: 63 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: African American - Occupation: Retired Plumber - Location: Urban Midwest  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension for 10 years  irregularly medicated with Lisinopril - Type 2 Diabetes mellitus for 7 years  managed with Metformin. - Smoker: 1 pack/day for 35 years - Occasional Alcohol consumption  - 1 prior episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 3 years ago - No known allergies   Key complaints:  Mr. Doe reported to the emergency department describing severe  sharp chest and back pain that started suddenly about 2 hours ago. The pain began while he was at rest  watching television. He describes the pain as a tearing or ripping sensation radiating from his anterior chest to his back  and progressing to his upper abdomen. Accompanying symptoms included shortness of breath  sudden onset sweating  and dizziness. No history of trauma or injury.   This fictitious case is representative of key risk factors and demographic patterns seen in aortic dissection. African American men especially have been reported to have a higher risk of this condition. Age  tobacco use  hypertension  and a history of circulatory issues like TIA are among leading causes  along with genetic factors not indicated here. This case scenario should provide a helpful training resource to illustrate a typical presentation of an aortic dissection.

Patient Case:  Patient Information: Mr. Lewis  a 65-year-old African American male  working as a retired high school principal.  Past Medical History: Confirmed chronic hypertension  with inconsistent management over the past decade. Family history reveals a father who died at the age of 70 due to a myocardial infarction. A non-smoker but drinks alcohol moderately. No previous surgeries. Body mass index (BMI) has ranged within overweight (27-30) for the past 15 years.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Lewis visited the emergency department with a sudden severe pain in his chest and back  which he described as ""tearing"" in nature. He also reported dizziness  nausea  and shortness of breath. His blood pressure reading was enormously different in each arm  and he appeared pallid and sweaty.  Clinical Reasoning: The combination of a sudden onset of severe  tearing chest and back pain  differences in blood pressure between the arms  and history of hypertension suggests a high likelihood of aortic dissection. This condition more often affects males over 60  with hypertension being the leading risk factor. There is a higher prevalence among African American males  although it is a disease process that can affect any race or ethnicity. This profile matches perfectly with our patient. However  other diseases  such as acute myocardial infarction (AMI)  should be considered.  Additional Information: Terrifying pain often is a characteristic symptom that leads patients with aortic dissection like Mr. Lewis to seek emergency care. They might arrive in shock because the dissection has caused aortic regurgitation  leading to cardiac tamponade. In Mr. Lewis’ case  his reported dizziness  sweating  and feelings of faintness might be associated with this.   Remember  this condition is a medical emergency with high morbidity and mortality rates. Teaching case like these help medical students recognize and respond promptly to such clinical emergences.   Suggest going forward with medical imaging such as Computerized Tomography (CT) or Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) to confirm the diagnosis.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. Joseph Rodriguez is a 62-year-old Hispanic male. He is a retired automobile mechanic and currently resides in Miami  Florida with his wife. He consumes alcohol socially and is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago.   Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and hypercholesterolemia  for which he has been prescribed medication. However  his blood pressure control has been inconsistent  often fluctuating in clinics. His lipid profiles reveal elevated levels despite regular statin therapy. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his older brother recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease. A year ago  he experienced a minor stroke but made a full recovery following rehabilitative therapy. Additionally  he is overweight (BMI:30.4) with no known history of diabetes or other endocrine disorders.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Rodriguez was rushed to the emergency department presenting with a sudden onset  intense chest pain radiating to his back. He described the pain as “tearing” and it started while he was lifting a heavy box. The pain is not eased by rest or nitroglycerin  and it's the worst pain he's ever felt. This was accompanied by profuse sweating and he reports a mild shortness of breath. His wife also reports that he appeared pale and was visibly shaken by the pain.  The case provides a realistic scenario of a patient at high risk of aortic dissection  given his male gender  age  and uncontrolled hypertension. Traditional risk factors for atherosclerosis such as hypercholesterolemia and a family history of cardiovascular diseases are also present. His Hispanic ethnicity takes into account the demographic representation in the literature showing a lower prevalence of aortic dissection in this group compared to non-Hispanic Whites and Blacks  thereby challenging the stereotypical patient archetype and encouraging broader critical thinking. The intriguing nature of this case mainly lies in the fact that despite his significant cardiovascular risk factors  he has never reported experiencing anginal chest pain before.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection   Patient Demographics:  64-year-old African-American male. Occupation: Retired electrician. Lives alone in a suburban environment. Smoker for 40 years  approximately 1 pack a day. Moderate alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of high blood pressure and peripheral artery disease. His M.D. has been regularly prescribing antihypertensives. There is no known familial history of aortic dissections noted but he has a deceased brother who passed away suddenly in his 60s  reason undetermined. Patient exhibits poor medication adherence due to forgetfulness and financial constraints.   Key Complaints:  The patient came to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of severe  knife-like chest pain radiating to his back  described as the worst pain he has ever felt  starting approximately 2 hours prior to presenting. He also complained of shortness of breath and profuse sweating. No reported nausea  vomiting or dizziness. The pain did not improve with rest or nitroglycerin taken at home. He denied any trauma or heavy lifting before the pain.  Note: Aortic dissection is most commonly found among middle-aged and elderly men  particularly among the African American population. It also often occurs in those with a history of high blood pressure and tobacco smoking. Based on literature  we opted to make non-adherence to medication an issue because it is a significant real-world challenge in the management of chronic conditions.   This case is simplified and abbreviated for educational purposes. In real-life  several additional clinical  lab  imaging investigations and differential diagnoses would normally be considered.  References: 1. Babatasi - Aortic dissection  acute and chronic. Ann Cardiol Angeiol (Paris). 2018;67(3):185-195.  2. Bashir M - Racial/ethnic and sex differences in the association of aortic stiffness with incident cardiovascular disease and all-cause mortality. JAMA Netw Open. 2020;3(5):e205873.  3. Benjamin EJ - Heart Disease and Stroke Statistics—2019 Update: A Report From the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2019;139(10):e56-e528.  4. Howard VJ - Racial differences in the incidence of cardiovascular risk factors in older black and white adults. J Am Geriatr Soc. 2000;48(1):23-30. 5. Kroner ES - Non-adherence to cardiovascular preventive medication: A systematic review and meta-(re)analysis. Eur J Prev Cardiol. 2020;zhaa129.  6. Clouse WD - Acute aortic dissection: population-based incidence compared with degenerative aortic aneurysm rupture. Mayo Clin Proc. 2004;79(2):176-180.

Case Report:  Patient Presentation:  Mr. Walker  a 61-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department late one evening. He is a retired construction worker who lives with his wife and they have two grown-up children. He has a 20-year history of poorly controlled hypertension and has been a smoker for over 30 years. He has no known drug allergies.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Walker complained of sudden onset severe chest pain that started an hour ago. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and ""ripping"" in nature  with the intensity as 10/10. Initially  the pain was localized to the anterior chest and later radiated to his back between the scapulae.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Walker has been diagnosed with hypertension for the last 20 years  however  due to inconsistent medication adherence  it has remained largely uncontrolled. He does not have any history of diabetes mellitus  ischemic heart disease or hypercholesterolemia. He has also undergone surgical repair of a hernia 10 years ago with no postoperative complications.   Social History:  Mr. Walker has been a heavy smoker since his early 30s  smoking 1.5 packs per day. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He admits to having a diet high in sodium and low in fruits and vegetables. He lives a sedentary lifestyle with little to no physical exercise.   NOTE:  This case is clinically relevant as it represents an important emergency pathology - aortic dissection  commonly seen in hypertensive patients with a greater prevalence amongst Black men. It emphasizes the devastating consequences of untreated hypertension and the importance of timely management. It also encourages learners to recognize the crucial differences between chest pain due to aortic dissection vs. other causes  thereby focusing on clinical reasoning  differential diagnosis  and medical decision-making.   Please customize this case as needed to fit your instructional objectives and learners' levels.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics: Patient is a 64-year-old African American male  retired logistical manager  married for 42 years  father of 2 adult children. His length is 178cm and weight 86kg  with a body mass index (BMI) of 27.1 kg/m2. He is a lifelong resident of Detroit  MI. He admits to having smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years  although he stopped 3 years ago. He is moderate alcohol drinker.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension diagnosed for about 10 years and type-2 diabetes for the past 5 years  both being managed with medication (Lisinopril and Metformin respectively). He was also diagnosed with high cholesterol levels 7 years ago and is on statin therapy. He had an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 2 years ago and since then  has been advised to take aspirin daily as a preventive measure. No history of any surgeries or any known allergies.  Key Complaints: The patient attended the emergency department reporting a sudden onset  severe chest pain which he also felt in his upper back. The pain was described as sharp  like being torn or ripped apart. The onset was sudden without any precipitating factors and it did not relieve with rest. The pain was associated with feeling of faintness and mild shortness of breath. There was no associated nausea  vomiting  or sweating. He denied any history of fever  loss of consciousness  palpitations  or weakness in any body part.  This case represents the demographic mostly affected by aortic dissection which include older males  African Americans  those with hypertension  and smokers. It aligns with accompanying diseases  such as hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and high cholesterol  as well as symptoms – severe  sharp chest  or upper back pain  described as a tearing sensation  and concurrent symptoms such as shortness of breath  faintness which may sometimes present in such cases.   Please note: Aortic dissection is relatively rare  and the above representation is based on commonly reported demographic trends in medical literature. However  it might vary and can also present in any individual irrespective of these demographics.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics: Mr. John Doe  an African-American male  aged 62  currently employed as a truck driver  resides in an urban setting. He is a non-smoker  but has a history of chronic alcohol use.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which was diagnosed 12 years ago. He is on regular medication but admits to not adhering to his medication regimen due to the erratic nature of his job. There is no known history of diabetes  cancer  or genetic diseases. His father suffered from an unspecified heart disease and passed away at the age of 68.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his back. He described the pain as ""tearing"" in nature. The pain began while he was lifting a heavy object during work. He is also reporting shortness of breath and a feeling of tightness in his chest. Furthermore  he has complained of slight dizziness and a few episodes of vomiting before coming to the hospital.   Note: As suggested by the medical literature  an aortic dissection is more prevalent in males and those above the age of 60. It also frequently occurs in chronic hypertension and a history of heart diseases. African-Americans also have a higher risk of heart disease compared to other racial/ethnic groups.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Our case involves a 65-year-old African American male who has been retired for a year and was previously working in a construction job. He's a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. He lives with his daughter and grandchildren but maintains his independence.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension which has been poorly controlled over the years. His blood pressure readings have consistently been above 150/90 despite being on antihypertensive medications. He stopped his regular follow-ups with his cardiologist due to transportation issues.   He was treated for type 2 diabetes for the past 5 years with oral hypoglycemics. His last HbA1c was about 7.0% 6 months ago. Moreover  his family history includes his father who died due to a stroke at the age of 72.  Key Complaints:  The patient presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  sharp chest pain radiating to his back. He described it as the worst pain of his life. It was associated with shortness of breath  weakness  and a sense of impending doom.   Teaching Points:  This clinical vignette provides an opportunity to delve into the presentation and management of aortic dissection. Students should recognize that risk factors in this patient presented include long-standing  poorly controlled hypertension  and male gender. They should also appreciate the life-threatening nature of this condition  and understand the urgent need for investigation via imaging and subsequent surgical intervention.   Further  this case can also be used to draw attention to the importance of effective patient communication and the challenges posed by social determinants of health  as evidenced by this patient's sporadic follow-ups due to transportation issues.

Patient Information:   Mr. James Lee  a 62-year-old African American male.  Past Medical History:  Previous history of high blood pressure and smoking  which he quit five years ago. He also has a family history of aortic disease  with his father having suffered an aortic dissection at 65.  Presenting Complaints:   Mr. Lee presented to the emergency department reporting sudden onset of severe tearing pain in his chest radiating to his back  beginning around two hours ago. He has also noted a missed or irregular pulse and general feeling of anxiety.  Literature Reference:  According to available clinical literature  the prevalence of aortic dissection is higher in males than in females and African Americans are at a higher risk than other races. Also  hypertension  smoking  and family history of aortic disease are significant risk factors for aortic dissection.  Note:  This patient represents a picture perfect case of aortic dissection given his gender  race  age  and his past and family medical history. The severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back is a characteristic symptom of aortic dissection. This brief simulation  thus  aims to help educate medical students on what to look out for in a typical presentation of an aortic dissection patient.

Case Report for Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 68-year-old African American male. He is a retired truck driver and a veteran. His height is 5'10"" and he weighs 210 lbs. He resides in rural Georgia with his wife of 45 years. The literacy level of the patient is high school education. He quit smoking 10 years ago but used 1.5 packs a day for more than 40 years. Moreover  he drinks socially - usually a couple of beers during family gatherings on weekends.  Past Medical History:  The patient's past medical history includes a clinical diagnosis of hypertension which has been controlled on medication for the last 20 years. He suffered from myocardial infarction 12 years ago and has been on regular follow up with cardiology. He has also Type 2 diabetes  controlled with metformin  for the past 10 years.  For the past 5 years  he has had a mixture of hypercholesterolemia and hyperlipidemia  which are managed by statins. Occasionally  he has episodes of chronic lower back pain caused by lumbar spondylosis  but he refused surgical intervention and wanted to control it conservatively with postural correction  exercises  and NSAIDs when necessary.  Key Complaints:  The patient came to the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to the back. He described the pain as 'tearing' in nature. This was not like the chest pain he experienced during his previous heart attack. There were no accompanying symptoms like nausea  vomiting  diaphoresis  or palpitations. His blood pressure was found to be significantly different in the two arms. His wife also mentioned that he seemed confused and his speech was slightly slurred just before they arrived at the hospital.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: - Patient X is a 66-year-old African American man from urban areas. - He's a retired mechanic  living alone since his wife passed away a couple of years back. - He has smoked a pack of cigarettes every day for the past forty years. - He is not a habitual drinker but does consume alcohol socially. - He has no known allergies.  Past Medical History: - Patient X is a known hypertensive for the past fifteen years and has been on antihypertensive medication (Amlodipine) inconsistently. - He was diagnosed with high cholesterol levels 5 years ago and is on statins. - He does not have a known history of diabetes or any cardiac disease. - There is no family history of cardiac disease. - His most recent blood pressure on a regular check-up six months back was 165/95mmHg. - He has associated obesity with a BMI of 30.  Key Complaints: - Patient X presented to the emergency department with a sudden severe sharp (like 'tearing' or 'ripping') chest pain that started about an hour ago. - The pain is primarily in the anterior chest area and radiates to the back. - He also states that the pain seemed to move downward. - Shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and symptoms of anxiety are present. - No complaints of any loss of consciousness  weakness or paralysis  palpitation  or anginal chest pain. - No associated abdominal pain  nausea  or vomiting. - He denies any previous episode of a similar kind.  Note: This case represents demographic groups at a higher risk of aortic dissection  including the older age group  males  African Americans  smokers  hypertensives  and those with high cholesterol levels. The advancing age  male gender  race  and unhealthy lifestyle (smoking) are all risk factors for aortic dissection. Moreover  poor control of blood pressure and high cholesterol levels also significantly contribute to this life-threatening condition. The key complaints are also typical of aortic dissection  which is often described as severe 'tearing' or 'ripping' pain that radiates to the back.

Case Report:  Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  35 year-long smoking habit  high total cholesterol  and obesity who presents to the emergency department (ED) complaining of a sudden onset of severe ""tearing"" chest pain. He describes the pain as radiating from the front of his chest  through to his back between his shoulder blades.  Patient History:  Mr. Johnson's hypertension has been managed with hydrochlorothiazide for the last 15 years and he reports compliance with his prescribed therapy. Despite repeated medical advice  he has been unable to quit smoking or lose weight. His cholesterol has been historically unstable despite treatment with statin therapy. He reports no known allergies and his family history includes a brother who suffered a heart attack in his early 60s.  Key Complaints:  His primary concern is sudden  severe chest pain that is different from any pain he has ever experienced. The pain started abruptly about an hour before presenting to the ED. Mr. Johnson reports a history of occasional minor chest discomfort with exertion  but he had never experienced pain this intense before and explains it feels like ""something is tearing"" inside his chest. The pain radiates to his back and is not relieved with rest or change in position. He denies symptoms of shortness of breath  cough  fever  nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or diaphoresis.   Conclusion:  Considering Mr. Johnson's background  sudden chest pain of severe 'tearing' nature  and its radiating pattern  a strong clinical suspicion for aortic dissection needs to be kept in mind. As a next step  appropriate diagnostic evaluations should be pursued promptly. Therapeutic intervention should follow in order to prevent fatal complications such as cardiac tamponade  organ ischemia or aortic rupture.  This case as illustrated ensures diverse representation as African Americans have been noted to be particularly predisposed to hypertension  a major risk factor for aortic dissection. Additionally  studies indicate elevated rates of aortic dissection occur in males over the age of 60  and smokers.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male  retired construction worker  hailing from a middle-income background. He neither smokes nor drinks alcohol. His body mass index (BMI) is 28 m/kg2  which indicates overweight. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases but no personal history of hypertension or diabetes mellitus.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J had been largely healthy with no significant previous hospitalizations. He was diagnosed with moderate hypertension about two weeks ago and was prescribed anti-hypertensives. However  compliance with medication has been poor. He also had a gallstone surgery about ten years ago.  Key Complaints:  Mr. J presented to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe pain in his chest and back. He described the pain as ""tearing"" or ""ripping"" that began about 2 hours earlier while he was gardening. It has been continuous and increasing in intensity since then. There were no other symptoms like shortness of breath  syncope  or abdominal pain.  Reasoning Numerous studies have shown that aortic dissection is more prevalent in males and older adults  usually 60s and 70s. Racially  African-Americans have been found to have a higher rate of hypertension  a risk factor for aortic dissection  compared to their Caucasian counterparts. Furthermore  patients with aortic dissection often recall significant emotional or physical stress shortly before the beginning of the symptoms  hence the inclusion of gardening. The demographic data and specificities of this case were composed bearing all these realities in mind.   Learning Objectives: 1. Recognition of aortic dissection and its presentation. 2. Understanding the importance of risk factors in aortic dissection like hypertension and age. 3. Consciousness about the challenge of diagnosing aortic dissection as the symptoms and clinical features can mimic other medical conditions. 4. Learning to prioritize aortic dissection as an immediate medical emergency that requires a quick diagnosis and treatment.   References:  Clouse WD  Hallett JW Jr  Schaff HV  et al. Acute aortic dissection: population-based incidence compared with degenerative aortic aneurysm rupture. Mayo Clin Proc 2004; 79:176. Harine L  Edwards WD  Tazelaar HD  et al. Age and Sex Distribution of Auditory Lesions in a Series of Medical Examiner Coronary Autopsies. Am J Cardiol 1988; 61:554.  Melvinsdottir IH  Lund SH  Agnarsson BA  et al. The incidence and mortality of acute thoracic aortic dissection: results from a whole nation study. Eur J Cardiothorac Surg 2016; 50:1111. Dietz HC. Marfan Syndrome. In: Adam MP  Ardinger HH  Pagon RA  et al  eds. GeneReviews  University of Washington  Seattle  WA (Accessed on April 08  2016).

Case Report:  Demographics and Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson  a 69-year-old African American male  recently retired  presents for evaluation. He has a medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  despite medication  and high cholesterol. Mr. Thompson also has a 20-pack year smoking history but quit smoking ten years ago. His father died at an early age due to sudden cardiac death.  Key Complaints: Early in the morning  Mr. Thompson woke up with an intense  tearing chest pain radiating to the back  between his shoulder blades. He described it as the worst pain he has ever experienced  reaching maximum severity almost instantly. Along with the pain  he also reports experiencing shortness of breath and a feeling of impending doom. On arrival at the emergency department  Mr. Thompson was found to be diaphoretic  anxious  and pale.   Physical Examination:  Initial vitals showed BP 160/95 mmHg on right arm and 145/90 mmHg on left arm; heart rate was 105 beats/min  respiratory rate 22 breaths/min  oxygen saturation 92% on room air  and the body temperature was normal. Physical examination revealed that the patient had unequal brachial and radial pulses.  Initial Epidemiologic considerations: Aortic dissection is most common in men  especially men of African American descent  often between 60 to 70-years of age. Hypertension is a common risk factor  present in 70-90% of cases. Also  a history of smoking substantially raises the risk of aortic dissection.  Diagnostic testing: Given the patient's concerning symptoms  physical exam findings  and relevant personal and family medical history  immediate diagnostic testing was performed to confirm suspected aortic dissection. These tests include electrocardiography (ECG)  chest X-ray and subsequently  a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest.

Case Report: Aortic Dissection  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 67-year-old African American male  named Mr. Johnson. He lives with his wife in a suburban area and he recently retired from his job as a school teacher. The patient has two adult children and 4 grandkids.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and is on regular medication. He is also a former smoker but quit 10 years ago. He has borderline diabetes that is being managed by diet and lifestyle interventions. He does not have any known drug allergies. He has no history of any surgical interventions.  Key Complaints: Today  Mr. Johnson presents himself to the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden  severe  sharp  tearing chest pain that radiates to his back between his shoulder blades. He mentions the pain started a few hours ago  and it is unlike any other pain he has ever experienced. He states he felt a sudden sharpness followed by an intense pain while he was doing yard work. The pain was not relieved by rest. He also reports feeling clammy  light-headed  and having a sporadic pounding heartbeat.  Aftermath: Potential complications such as cardiac tamponade  aortic valve insufficiency  or organ ischemia were considered  given the key complaints and medical history. Moreover  the awareness of Mr. Johnson's hypertension rendered him a potential candidate for an aortic dissection. The medical team decided to promptly investigate the condition under these suspicions.  This case report is created considering demographic representation. The prevalence of aortic dissection is relatively high among African American individuals  and data show that hypertension is an important risk factor. Additionally  the condition disproportionately affects males  especially those over the age of 60. The presentation of abrupt  severe  tearing chest pain also aligns with a typical first symptom of aortic dissection. This case scenario can be built on to include physical exam findings  diagnostic workup  and management plan to provide medical students a comprehensive understanding of aortic dissection.
